Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pdxguy1 Age: 56 4/13--PSA 101.6 (Prostatitis infection) 5/13--PSA 19.4 (after three weeks of Cipro) 7/13--PSA 9.08 (after more Cipro) 8/13--PSA 7.50 (after 6 weeks of another anti-biotic) 9/13--Biopsy 12 cores (1 poss for PCa Gleason 6 10% involvement, 1 suspicious for PCa, 1 PIN) Prostate size 100cc.. Forgot to ask you, what was your psa history prior to 4/13. That would make a difference in evaluating where you might expect to return to if it was only the prostatitis that caused the leap up.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Originally Posted by pdxguy1 Age  56 4 13  PSA 101 6

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance or Extended Preparation Time for Treatment?

Posts.Content: Until you get a biopsy you will drive yourself crazy with speculation about how much or how little prostate cancer you may or may not have. You have it or you don't. The two month delay thus far will not have made a difference. Nor will a couple more weeks. "Biopsy scheduled for this past Friday, but his blood pressure was to low and doctor was concerned about continuing. He needs pre-op clearance before continuing." What was his blood pressure? and his age? Seems odd, as a biopsy is hardly a difficult or taxing procedure. If, and its a big if... If he has prostate cancer and metastasis, then it has been going on a long time. Speed, in terms of weeks, won't be changing his eventual treatment. How quickly you get the biopsy and results are really more related to your peace of mind and knowledge of the actual present situation.
Posts.Title: Elephant in the room!

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance or Extended Preparation Time for Treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pdxguy1 1. Am I giving up on AS too soon? 2. What kind of nutrition suggestions might you have because it is not unheard for them to not show cancer on a second biopsy after cleaining up your act with better diet and excercise. It doesn't mean it's not there but it probably means it's not advancing. BB History Age: 56 4/13--PSA 101.6 (Prostatitis infection) 5/13--PSA 19.4 (after three weeks of Cipro) 7/13--PSA 9.08 (after more Cipro) 8/13--PSA 7.50 (after 6 weeks of another anti-biotic) 9/13--Biopsy 12 cores (1 poss for PCa Gleason 6 10% involvement, 1 suspicious for PCa, 1 PIN) Prostate size 100cc. Currently on Active Surveillance with a Finasteride Rx. Here is a starting point for your diet http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf You might also look at the published study conducted by Dr. Dean Ornish. http://www.ornishspectrum.com/wp-con...ate_Cancer.pdf I suppose you are aware that taking Finasteride will affect the numbers of your next PSA test. A "adjustment" will have to be made with the next results. Now, as to your questions regarding AS. Yes, I think you are giving up too soon. You went from outrageous psa levels almost entirely due to prostatitis to far more moderate levels in only 4 months. Were you aware that MOST prostatitis is NOT caused by bacteria. Making treatment by antibiotics not as effective as you may think. A antibiotic can't kill a bacteria that isn't there. Seems to me, after reading about tough cases of prostatitis that having only 4 months from the first test until the last test is not giving enough time to clearly see what your true PSA is. Thus making a judgment is in my mind very premature. 1 core out of 12 with only 10% involvement. I wouldn't even consider thinking about treatment with that result. At least not until giving the PSA a very good amount of time to calm down. Read more about tough cases of prostatitis and how difficult it can be to treat. It may take even longer than 3 more months. Take a listen to this well respected doctor in the field of prostate cancer. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 You may well have found one of the many indolent cases of prostate cancer only because of your prostatitis. The types of PCa that are better not found. Of course no one can tell for sure, but I'd be on the side of doing nothing until you see some change in course repeated more than once. Thus even if your next test came in at 8.0, I wouldn't leap for treatment. I had a 7.4 PSA not that long ago and many months later I was at 3.8 Sounds like your doctor is in no rush for you to get treatment. Your idea of holding off for a year sounds good. Gives you time to learn more and to lose the initial shock. Remember, loads of guys between the ages of 50 and 90 are walking down the street with Gleason 6 in their prostate and know nothing about it and never will. Look at this recent study http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23847245 Well that's one side of the issue. I'm sure you'll get others. Bottom line is that there is no reason to rush. You seem to know that.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> BB History Age  56 4 13  PSA 101 6
months later I was at 3 8 Sounds like your doctor

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance or Extended Preparation Time for Treatment?

Posts.Content: His decision sounds reasonable given his other health factors. Though you don't mention what leads him to believe he possibly has prostate cancer. You might include those details for us to evaluate. DRE exam? PSA test results? etc. You might also include his age.
Posts.Title: My husband does not want to be tested for Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by CarlaJean It will only be 3 weeks since his last test. I suppose I am rushing things wanting it checked sooner then later. . If I had one high test of 4.5 (or possibly 9.0 without the drug), I certainly would NOT want to get my next test in 3 weeks. That really doesn't allow time for "itis" or inflammation to calm down. Why the rush? More like 3+ months between tests to allow for a better picture. Was it you or the doctor who pushed for 3 weeks. Look at how fast my urologist wanted to re-test when I jumped up to 7.3 PSA 4.1 12/10/2010 PSA 7.3 06/30/2010 PSA 3.5 08/26/2009 (that is only a portion of all my tests. My last test a few months ago was 3.3 , a full 4.0 points below that temporary jump) You see, we waited almost 6 months. 3 weeks is crazy fast unless he was treating you with antibiotics for a infection. Even then, if it was a bacterial caused inflammation, it would still take more time to calm down. Is the doctor doing the testing his primary care doctor or a urologist? Since your husband doesn't even want a biopsy anyway, why the rush? Its not like waiting 3 months is gonna put him in greater danger then he currently is with his other health problems. Looks to me like you are risking a second high PSA test result that may lead to a unnecessary biopsy. I'd leave it alone for a while before stirring up trouble. Of course I'm not a doctor, but very very few men die because they waited a extra 3 months. PS, When I had that 7.3 jump up, I wasn't even aware of any "itis" or inflammation. You can get large jumps with what is called asymptomatic prostatitis, meaning you feel nothing unusual.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance or Extended Preparation Time for Treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by CarlaJean His PSA jumped from 1.9 a year ago to 4.5, but because of medicine he is already on for his Prostrate the doctor said it was like a 9.0 rate. He is 63. He is having his PSA checked again next week and then we meet with the doctor August 1st. . What was the date of his 4.5 (9.0) psa test? I ask to understand how much time will have taken place in between the two tests (for his test next week). PSA tests jump all over the place for reasons that are not involved with prostate cancer. Various types of inflammation can cause huge jumps. Even inflammation that gives no symptoms. Mine has jumped to over 7 and then down to 3.8 on the next test. Now the last test was 3.3. When you have too little time between testing, sometimes the inflammation is not allowed to calm down. So how many months between tests will there be when you test next week? Also, which drug are you on that makes it only 50% of the real reading.

Posts.Title: My husband does not want to be tested for Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Its mostly about money. Many companies have tied into the pink ribbon breast cancer awareness ONLY as a method to market their products to women between the ages of 25 and 65. Just Google (pink ribbon companies) and a few other terms to see how the marketing has progressed. Also, the fact that women are more open to discuss the issue combined with the fact that breast cancer is less curable than prostate cancer. Additionally, there are about 40,000 women who die while "only" 30,000 men die. More important, many of the women who die are fairly young, while most men who die are past age 60 and don't create the impact or shock. Lots of reasons for the differences. If you ask about prostate cancer, many think of it as the good cancer which causes few deaths. In other words, everyone gets it and we still see them walking around, living a long life. (except for those who don't)

AgeInfo.Phrase: women who die while  only  30 000 men die <Z> <Z>
who die are past age 60 and don't create the impact

Posts.Title: Why so little publicity for Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shinytop Dr did dre first, said all was normal. Did the ultrasound, said normal prostate is about 30 grams, mine was 140. He commented that may be the reason for the upturn in PSA. Now the wait for the biopsy, 12 cores, results. Gosh, that combined with what you said before "My PSA has been 4.0 for the last 4 years. The rise to 4.35 is why I have been referred. Urologist appointment is Tuesday." makes one almost wonder if 4.35 is below normal for a guy who has a 140 gram prostate. By the way, that "upturn" was only from 4.0 to 4.35. Given your prostate size I'd say that is just a normal deviation that one could get from month to month. Oh well, hope the results are good.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Today

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pjr ======================================= 3. What record of false-negative biopsies have you seen here in your practice? 5. We would like to have the slides sent to Dr. Epstein at Johns Hopkins for a second look, regardless of the read. Can we arrange to do this automatically? 8. Should people have a higher Gleason score suggestive of surgery or radiation, where do people typically go for treatment? Who would you recommend? If they seek treatment from a surgeon/radiologist elsewhere, does your office stop treating them? 9. Do you currently have any patients on active surveillance, and if so, how are their cases handled? I think the above questions are getting too far ahead of the game. If you get 12 negative biopsies.. you get 12 negative biopsies. Why chase down issues that are not present?
Posts.Title: Questions to ask Pre-Biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JD1969 I fully understand that a man my age with Pca is very rare, but still why don't they do PSA checks a little younger? (I know the answer to that is money). No, it is not about money. There is a huge debate as to whether any PSA testing should be done, let alone many years younger. I don't recall reading why you had your psa taken at age 38, but I don't know of anyone suggesting those under age 40 get the test. Actually its not only about the cost of testing, but more about the cost of treating so many people who probably don't need treating. Indolent cases. The entire field of testing and treating is a mess that won't be solved until they develop some method of knowing which cases need treatment and which don't. The first company to figure that out will make billions.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tamborine In the meantime I've been reading about prostate cancer and here is what I have noticed: 1) Usually you have time to diagnose it and often it takes multiple biopsy procedures to find that cancer 2) because the biopsy procedure is far from perfect, often PC metastatisizes between procedures #2, not true. The bottom line is that most men with a 5.0 PSA such as your last test, don't have prostate cancer that will result in treatment.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance or Extended Preparation Time for Treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tamborine Hey, thx for the comforting words, but what would cause a big jump in PSA? I neglected to mention that I have had my PSA read a couple of times per year for the last four years (that I've been on HRT) and my reads have always been less than 1.5. Now I suddenly jumped up to 5.0 and 6.3. I eat incredibly healthy - just trust me on that - and am a follower of Pritikin. I also exercise regularly. But the only explanation I see for the above would be "prostate leak" or possibly inflammation. But I don't think "prostate leak" is common from what I have read and I live quite healthy, so I can't imagine where inflammation would come from.. I've never heard of a "prostate leak"... no idea what you are talking about. Now, the fact that your psa is tested twice a year and always has been about 1.5, is all the more reason to believe that the 5.0 and 6.3 are just spikes caused by inflammation. Inflammation can come from many sources and need not be even noticed by the patient. There is a common "asymptomatic inflammation" that is as it says, just there, cause unknown. very very common. When a psa goes from 1.5 to 5.0 or 6.3 in a short time, that indicates it is probably from a non-prostate cancer causation. Not always the case, as there are some exceptions. BTW, you should realize that the spike in psa can take time to calm down and return to normal. Weeks, months or so. You eat healthy, Pritikin style. I eat in a similar fashion. Hope you have a good reason to be on HRT. Its becoming very popular. Too popular if you ask me, but I know that is a controversial matter. I just get concerned when all of a sudden it is seen everywhere on TV and radio... Marketing big time. What is 'normal' levels and "treatable" levels is very much open to interpretation. Many multiples of men are part of this large ongoing experiment, compared to usage in past decades. However there are some real sound usages for certain men. I know they say HRT is not connected to PCa, but I'd still be very careful about using the product. And I'd double check my psa as you are doing often.

The bottom line is that most men with a 5.0 PSA such as your last test, don't have prostate cancer that will result in treatment.
Posts.Title: Why Not a Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pdxguy1 Age: 56 4/13--PSA 101.6 (Prostatitis infection) 5/13--PSA 19.4 (after three weeks of Cipro) 7/13--PSA 9.08 (after more Cipro) 8/13--PSA 7.50 (after 6 weeks of another anti-biotic) 9/13--Biopsy 12 cores (1 poss for PCa Gleason 6 10% involvement, 1 suspicious for PCa, 1 PIN) Prostate size 100cc.. Forgot to ask you, what was your psa history prior to 4/13. That would make a difference in evaluating where you might expect to return to if it was only the prostatitis that caused the leap up.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Originally Posted by pdxguy1 Age  56 4 13  PSA 101 6

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance or Extended Preparation Time for Treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pdxguy1 1. Am I giving up on AS too soon? 2. What kind of nutrition suggestions might you have because it is not unheard for them to not show cancer on a second biopsy after cleaining up your act with better diet and excercise. It doesn't mean it's not there but it probably means it's not advancing. BB History Age: 56 4/13--PSA 101.6 (Prostatitis infection) 5/13--PSA 19.4 (after three weeks of Cipro) 7/13--PSA 9.08 (after more Cipro) 8/13--PSA 7.50 (after 6 weeks of another anti-biotic) 9/13--Biopsy 12 cores (1 poss for PCa Gleason 6 10% involvement, 1 suspicious for PCa, 1 PIN) Prostate size 100cc. Currently on Active Surveillance with a Finasteride Rx. Here is a starting point for your diet http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf You might also look at the published study conducted by Dr. Dean Ornish. http://www.ornishspectrum.com/wp-con...ate_Cancer.pdf I suppose you are aware that taking Finasteride will affect the numbers of your next PSA test. A "adjustment" will have to be made with the next results. Now, as to your questions regarding AS. Yes, I think you are giving up too soon. You went from outrageous psa levels almost entirely due to prostatitis to far more moderate levels in only 4 months. Were you aware that MOST prostatitis is NOT caused by bacteria. Making treatment by antibiotics not as effective as you may think. A antibiotic can't kill a bacteria that isn't there. Seems to me, after reading about tough cases of prostatitis that having only 4 months from the first test until the last test is not giving enough time to clearly see what your true PSA is. Thus making a judgment is in my mind very premature. 1 core out of 12 with only 10% involvement. I wouldn't even consider thinking about treatment with that result. At least not until giving the PSA a very good amount of time to calm down. Read more about tough cases of prostatitis and how difficult it can be to treat. It may take even longer than 3 more months. Take a listen to this well respected doctor in the field of prostate cancer. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 You may well have found one of the many indolent cases of prostate cancer only because of your prostatitis. The types of PCa that are better not found. Of course no one can tell for sure, but I'd be on the side of doing nothing until you see some change in course repeated more than once. Thus even if your next test came in at 8.0, I wouldn't leap for treatment. I had a 7.4 PSA not that long ago and many months later I was at 3.8 Sounds like your doctor is in no rush for you to get treatment. Your idea of holding off for a year sounds good. Gives you time to learn more and to lose the initial shock. Remember, loads of guys between the ages of 50 and 90 are walking down the street with Gleason 6 in their prostate and know nothing about it and never will. Look at this recent study http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23847245 Well that's one side of the issue. I'm sure you'll get others. Bottom line is that there is no reason to rush. You seem to know that.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> BB History Age  56 4 13  PSA 101 6
months later I was at 3 8 Sounds like your doctor

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance or Extended Preparation Time for Treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tamborine Hey, thx for the comforting words, but what would cause a big jump in PSA? I neglected to mention that I have had my PSA read a couple of times per year for the last four years (that I've been on HRT) and my reads have always been less than 1.5. Now I suddenly jumped up to 5.0 and 6.3. I eat incredibly healthy - just trust me on that - and am a follower of Pritikin. I also exercise regularly. But the only explanation I see for the above would be "prostate leak" or possibly inflammation. But I don't think "prostate leak" is common from what I have read and I live quite healthy, so I can't imagine where inflammation would come from.. I've never heard of a "prostate leak"... no idea what you are talking about. Now, the fact that your psa is tested twice a year and always has been about 1.5, is all the more reason to believe that the 5.0 and 6.3 are just spikes caused by inflammation. Inflammation can come from many sources and need not be even noticed by the patient. There is a common "asymptomatic inflammation" that is as it says, just there, cause unknown. very very common. When a psa goes from 1.5 to 5.0 or 6.3 in a short time, that indicates it is probably from a non-prostate cancer causation. Not always the case, as there are some exceptions. BTW, you should realize that the spike in psa can take time to calm down and return to normal. Weeks, months or so. You eat healthy, Pritikin style. I eat in a similar fashion. Hope you have a good reason to be on HRT. Its becoming very popular. Too popular if you ask me, but I know that is a controversial matter. I just get concerned when all of a sudden it is seen everywhere on TV and radio... Marketing big time. What is 'normal' levels and "treatable" levels is very much open to interpretation. Many multiples of men are part of this large ongoing experiment, compared to usage in past decades. However there are some real sound usages for certain men. I know they say HRT is not connected to PCa, but I'd still be very careful about using the product. And I'd double check my psa as you are doing often.
Posts.Title: Why Not a Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tamborine In the meantime I've been reading about prostate cancer and here is what I have noticed: 1) Usually you have time to diagnose it and often it takes multiple biopsy procedures to find that cancer 2) because the biopsy procedure is far from perfect, often PC metastatisizes between procedures #2, not true. Occasionally, not "often", does PCa metastasize between procedures. Actually rarely would be the best word. Originally Posted by Tamborine Why not just get a prostatectomy early in the process and avoid the risk? . Hurrying the process by a few weeks or even a year, does little to avoid the risk. The bottom line is that most men with a 5.0 PSA such as your last test, don't have prostate cancer that will result in treatment.

Posts.Title: Why Not a Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by CarlaJean It will only be 3 weeks since his last test. I suppose I am rushing things wanting it checked sooner then later. . If I had one high test of 4.5 (or possibly 9.0 without the drug), I certainly would NOT want to get my next test in 3 weeks. That really doesn't allow time for "itis" or inflammation to calm down. Why the rush? More like 3+ months between tests to allow for a better picture. Was it you or the doctor who pushed for 3 weeks. Look at how fast my urologist wanted to re-test when I jumped up to 7.3 PSA 4.1 12/10/2010 PSA 7.3 06/30/2010 PSA 3.5 08/26/2009 (that is only a portion of all my tests. My last test a few months ago was 3.3 , a full 4.0 points below that temporary jump) You see, we waited almost 6 months. 3 weeks is crazy fast unless he was treating you with antibiotics for a infection. Even then, if it was a bacterial caused inflammation, it would still take more time to calm down. Is the doctor doing the testing his primary care doctor or a urologist? Since your husband doesn't even want a biopsy anyway, why the rush? Its not like waiting 3 months is gonna put him in greater danger then he currently is with his other health problems. Looks to me like you are risking a second high PSA test result that may lead to a unnecessary biopsy. I'd leave it alone for a while before stirring up trouble. Of course I'm not a doctor, but very very few men die because they waited a extra 3 months. PS, When I had that 7.3 jump up, I wasn't even aware of any "itis" or inflammation. You can get large jumps with what is called asymptomatic prostatitis, meaning you feel nothing unusual.
Posts.Title: My husband does not want to be tested for Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by CarlaJean His PSA jumped from 1.9 a year ago to 4.5, but because of medicine he is already on for his Prostrate the doctor said it was like a 9.0 rate. He is 63. He is having his PSA checked again next week and then we meet with the doctor August 1st. . What was the date of his 4.5 (9.0) psa test? I ask to understand how much time will have taken place in between the two tests (for his test next week). PSA tests jump all over the place for reasons that are not involved with prostate cancer. Various types of inflammation can cause huge jumps. Even inflammation that gives no symptoms. Mine has jumped to over 7 and then down to 3.8 on the next test. Now the last test was 3.3. When you have too little time between testing, sometimes the inflammation is not allowed to calm down. So how many months between tests will there be when you test next week? Also, which drug are you on that makes it only 50% of the real reading.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> He is 63 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>
was the date of his 4 5  9 0  psa test

Posts.Title: My husband does not want to be tested for Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Until you get a biopsy you will drive yourself crazy with speculation about how much or how little prostate cancer you may or may not have. You have it or you don't. The two month delay thus far will not have made a difference. Nor will a couple more weeks. "Biopsy scheduled for this past Friday, but his blood pressure was to low and doctor was concerned about continuing. He needs pre-op clearance before continuing." What was his blood pressure? and his age? Seems odd, as a biopsy is hardly a difficult or taxing procedure. If, and its a big if... If he has prostate cancer and metastasis, then it has been going on a long time. Speed, in terms of weeks, won't be changing his eventual treatment. How quickly you get the biopsy and results are really more related to your peace of mind and knowledge of the actual present situation.
Posts.Title: Elephant in the room!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pjr ======================================= 3. What record of false-negative biopsies have you seen here in your practice? 5. We would like to have the slides sent to Dr. Epstein at Johns Hopkins for a second look, regardless of the read. Can we arrange to do this automatically? 8. Should people have a higher Gleason score suggestive of surgery or radiation, where do people typically go for treatment? Who would you recommend? If they seek treatment from a surgeon/radiologist elsewhere, does your office stop treating them? 9. Do you currently have any patients on active surveillance, and if so, how are their cases handled? I think the above questions are getting too far ahead of the game. If you get 12 negative biopsies.. you get 12 negative biopsies. Why chase down issues that are not present?
Posts.Title: Questions to ask Pre-Biopsy?

Posts.Content: His decision sounds reasonable given his other health factors. Though you don't mention what leads him to believe he possibly has prostate cancer. You might include those details for us to evaluate. DRE exam? PSA test results? etc. You might also include his age.

Posts.Title: My husband does not want to be tested for Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JD1969 I fully understand that a man my age with Pca is very rare, but still why don't they do PSA checks a little younger? (I know the answer to that is money). No, it is not about money. There is a huge debate as to whether any PSA testing should be done, let alone many years younger. I don't recall reading why you had your psa taken at age 38, but I don't know of anyone suggesting those under age 40 get the test. Actually its not only about the cost of testing, but more about the cost of treating so many people who probably don't need treating. Indolent cases. The entire field of testing and treating is a mess that won't be solved until they develop some method of knowing which cases need treatment and which don't. The first company to figure that out will make billions.

AgeInfo.Phrase: your psa taken at age 38  but I don't know of
anyone suggesting those under age 40 get the test <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Why so little publicity for Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Its mostly about money. Many companies have tied into the pink ribbon breast cancer awareness ONLY as a method to market their products to women between the ages of 25 and 65. Just Google (pink ribbon companies) and a few other terms to see how the marketing has progressed. Also, the fact that women are more open to discuss the issue combined with the fact that breast cancer is less curable than prostate cancer. Additionally, there are about 40,000 women who die while "only" 30,000 men die. More important, many of the women who die are fairly young, while most men who die are past age 60 and don't create the impact or shock. Lots of reasons for the differences. If you ask about prostate cancer, many think of it as the good cancer which causes few deaths. In other words, everyone gets it and we still see them walking around, living a long life. (except for those who don't)

BTW, you should realize that the spike in psa can take time to calm down and return to normal. Weeks, months or so. You eat healthy, Pritikin style. I eat in a similar fashion. Hope you have a good reason to be on HRT. Its becoming very popular. Too popular if you ask me, but I know that is a controversial matter. I just get concerned when all of a sudden it is seen everywhere on TV and radio... Marketing big time. What is 'normal' levels and "treatable" levels is very much open to interpretation. Many multiples of men are part of this large ongoing experiment, compared to usage in past decades. However there are some real sound usages for certain men. I know they say HRT is not connected to PCa, but I'd still be very careful about using the product. And I'd double check my psa as you are doing often.
Posts.Title: Why Not a Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tamborine Hey, thx for the comforting words, but what would cause a big jump in PSA? I neglected to mention that I have had my PSA read a couple of times per year for the last four years (that I've been on HRT) and my reads have always been less than 1.5. Now I suddenly jumped up to 5.0 and 6.3. I eat incredibly healthy - just trust me on that - and am a follower of Pritikin. I also exercise regularly. But the only explanation I see for the above would be "prostate leak" or possibly inflammation. But I don't think "prostate leak" is common from what I have read and I live quite healthy, so I can't imagine where inflammation would come from.. I've never heard of a "prostate leak"... no idea what you are talking about. Now, the fact that your psa is tested twice a year and always has been about 1.5, is all the more reason to believe that the 5.0 and 6.3 are just spikes caused by inflammation. Inflammation can come from many sources and need not be even noticed by the patient. There is a common "asymptomatic inflammation" that is as it says, just there, cause unknown. very very common. Posts.Title: Why Not a Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Here is one point from that study "Also, after keeping tabs on the men for 10 years, the researchers calculated that doctors would need to treat 20 men to prevent one death; 18 years out, that number had dropped to eight." http://www.latimes.com/science/scien...#ixzz2vDHkjH00 Thus even for these cases, which are cases treated decades back, one must realize that treating only changes the survival rate by a certain margin. Newer treatment methods as well as better case selection might adjust those figures a bit. Even this study using older methods of diagnosis and treatment leaves a wide open field for sensible AS...
Posts.Title: This is interesting but not unexpected.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Popi PSA came back at 2.25, so she sent me to a Urologist for a follow-up. Second test came back at 2.45, but not knowing any better, I had sex 18hrs prior to second test. (don't remember if I had sex prior to first test) DRE was normal. He would like to wait until January for a third test, which makes sense, but I will be the first to admit, I want immediate answers, and this just isn't cutting it. . Goodness, slow down. You've had essentially one single PSA test of 2.35 (the second one right away is simply a retest so average the two) Sounds like you just had it recently in November. Even getting the next test in January is almost too fast to see if anything of shorter duration impact would give you what you feel is a score that is too high. Waiting only two months is actually extremely short. Most doctors would tell you to wait 3 or 4 months to get a better picture. Of more concern is your concern. You have yourself in diapers after one PSA test that is only 2.35 average. You know, even if your next test comes back at 2.45, I doubt your urologist is going to recommend you get a biopsy right away. Rather he'll probably look at it and suggest a PSA retest in 3 more months. So then you'll be right where you are today, once again. Now if you urge him to do a biopsy now, he might relent and do so, but you should be aware that a great deal of biopsies don't find cancer even when it exists. Thus what will you be thinking after it comes back negative? More worry, more rapid PSA testing? I'm thinking your mindset is well ahead of the facts at this point. Not sure what to say to you to calm you down.

Posts.Title: Current Tools To Identify AS Candidates Not Accurate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH . When it only suggests a G6, there is no way to know with absolute certainty that there is not also a G7 lurking within. But with that mindset there is never enough reason to do AS, because there could always be a G7 lurking somewhere. Yet we know the majority of men never need treatment of their G6 "diagnosis" prostate cancer. Holding onto the "their might be a G7" thinking means all those men must be treated, even when there was no need.
Posts.Title: Current Tools To Identify AS Candidates Not Accurate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by G1enn my doctor ran a PSA test and it came back at 5.0. I was back in today to speak with a urologist and he seemed suprised and confused. He said that it was extremely rare for someone my age to have a PSA that high or Testosterone that low- let alone both. He said there was probably a 30% chance that I have prostate cancer. I am taking anti-biotics for a few weeks then going to get retested. If the numbers don't change I will be having a biopsy. I'd say that borders on malpractice. To immediately run you through a series of anti-biotics and then retest in what sounds like it may only be a few weeks is just plain nuts. A reasonable urologist would allow some significant time to elapse between testing. Not just a few weeks. The antibiotics are probably a waste of time as most prostatitis is not bacterial in origin. At any rate, if he retests you in a couple week (which is poor practice)... and your psa is still 4.0 or higher... then do NOT allow a biopsy to be taken. Instead wait at least another month or two and retest your psa. It is very very common for inflammations of the prostate to take simple plain old time to calm down. Not from antibiotics... not from early testing... just simple time. To rush ahead with a biopsy in only a few weeks is insane. I think it borders on malpractice in light of the overwhelmingly rare chance that you would have prostate cancer at age 30. Should a quick retest come in still high, and the urologist wants to do a biopsy, ask him why the rush. Ask him if its OK to wait a couple months and retest. If the says its important to biopsy right away, then find a new urologist and get a second opinion.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DonDC Doesn't negate the idea of getting a second opinion - but it seems I am on the safe side of the cancer line for now? Epstein might downgrade me or even upgrade to a gleason 6? I am just not sure if it is worth the money - but maybe it is? I think it is a absolutely bad idea to get a second reading of your slides. A waste of money as well. I also think another biopsy in 6 months is a equally poor idea. Stick with the doctor's plan. PSA in 6 months, then possibly another psa in 12 months... Then depending on results, perhaps another biopsy. Your psa is on a steady track. It isn't about to leap up and endanger you, such that you would have risked your life by not discovering something now. You may well have prostate cancer right now, but that is true of about 40% of the men your age. Most will never be diagnosed, let alone die from the disease. So they find it in 2 years or so. The odds that it will be able to be treated equally effectively then, versus now, are very very high. BTW, I also think it was crazy to test your psa in April. Gosh, you had just had it tested in March, where you got a little rise. At that point the doctor should have told you to go away for at least 3 months... 6 months even better. Don't be surprised if your next psa is back in the 3.5 to 4.0 range. Too many doctors not allowing enough time after a single test jumps up a bit. To fast on the draw and thus too fast on the biopsy. Lots of things... lots... can make your psa jump up 1, 2 or even 4 points and then take months to settle down. Certainly more than 3 or 4 weeks. Anyway.. you seem to be on the right track.
Posts.Title: Any need for second opinion on negative biopsy?

Posts.Title: Any need for second opinion on negative biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steve2015 I'm not sure what 6/10 means but that is how it is written on the report. I'm looking for a way to eradicate the cancer cells without surgery or radiation. I have no problem setting my own protocol based on my own research that is backed by documented permanent cures. I am a young 65. My father, his siblings and his parents, all lived to be about 90. That's my goal for now. Thanks for your response. 6/10 means 6 on a scale of 10. You have one 5% Gleason 6. In short, you are a completely normal 65 year old. If another 100 men your age were grabbed off the street and given several biopsies, about 50% of them would eventually be found to have prostate cancer. Yet only 1 out of 30 of them would have their lifespan shortened by prostate cancer. Many irregular DRE exams lead to biopsies. That is proper, but many times the irregular spot has nothing to do with prostate cancer. You did not mention if the one tiny Gleason 6 that was found was at the site of the irregular DRE spot. If not, then your one positive core was just found randomly and you'd probably never have been tested at this time, but for the irregular DRE. So, if that is the case, then you are just like 50 of the other 100 guys walking down the street. Except now, you are classified as a prostate cancer patient. From what you've stated, I'd do absolutely nothing for now, except to improve your diet. You do not need to "eradicate" your prostate cancer, in that it will probably not shorten your life. I am very familiar with DES as my father was on the drug for over 20 years. He was diagnosed at age 63, radiated at age 64, and lived until age 88, dying of other causes. At about age 84 he was having swollen legs, which I suspected were from the DES. Causing him lots of problems. So I read the literature in a nearby major medical school university library (pre-internet). I did not find a lot of information, but did find one interesting case report where a long term patient on DES "only", just stopped taking it for a few years, then returned to the doctor. They tested his PSA and it remained at zero... Perhaps foolishly, I took my father off the DES... and nothing happened for a few days... then one morning he walked in wearing his bathrobe and his formerly swollen legs, below the knee, had overnight become skinny and normal. It was like a miracle, and all of his related leg problems went away. Now, a few months later I went with him to his new urologist ( his 20 year urologist had just retired)... and his urologist was pissed off.. disgusted.. Very unfriendly with my ill advised experiment. Still, he sent him to the lab for his PSA... (wouldn't even give him a DRE...saying why do it) Needless to say, I did not like that new doctor. So the PSA report comes back... 0.0.... And it stayed that way for the rest of his life..about 4 more years. Now, did the DES shut down the process of producing PSA... as was the example in the case report that I read. Or was my father's prostate cancer ALL eradicated by the radiation some 20 years prior? We don't know the answer. In that case report, that patient's PSA production seems to have shut down due entirely to the DES... As you can imagine, no one was medically willing or financially motivated to take 100 long term DES users off their medication to see what the trial would produce in terms of outcome. DES is still a good drug and very very cheap if you can find it. It got a bad rap because used in higher doses, it caused heart problems in some patients. Taking on a 1 mg dose for years did not seem to cause the same problems, although it comes with several side effects that in your situation I don't imagine you'd be willing to accept, given that your current status seems fairly benign. In short, if I was you, I'd do nothing at all. Re-test your psa in 6 months or a year... and keep doing that, perhaps getting another biopsy in 12 or 18 months. If you don't have any real problem, you don't need to eradicate anything.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobertG That seems... not very useful. Wonder why the lower limit of 55? It is based on the data they collected. "The original Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial (PCPT) Prostate Cancer Risk Calculator (PCPTRC) posted in 2006 was developed based upon 5519 men in the placebo group of the Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial. " It can't be based on data they don't have. Most men facing prostate cancer decisions are 55 or older. The study and calculator are what they are. They don't claim to be all things for all men.

Posts.Title: 45 yrs old, PSA=2.45...neep a pep talk

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MikeCav (Stands up) I am really trying to find a way to justify having Brachy, but I just don't know that I can. (Any thoughts on this are welcomed) But here I am staring at a surgery date of September 28th knowing that when I wake up, things will be different. The thought of incontinence and impotence weighs heavily on this single guy (no kids). As much as I wanted that back surgery is how much I don't want this RRP. So you've seen a Radiation Oncologist... and it appears he is in the middle... One question about him, ... does he only do EBRT or does he also do brachytherapy? Might influence his opinion a bit, though you said he was fine with surgery. Certainly those who do surgery have some natural bias towards surgery. And most men on this site have a understandable tendency to think surgery is best, because that is what they chose. Since you've only recently been diagnosed, I wonder how much you have read about the other choice you've been thinking about.... brachytherapy. So much out there on the internet. Very difficult to find it all and then digest it. Along with the fact that nothing is guaranteed in this entire subject. Plus the outcomes are mostly neck and neck with each other as long as done by extremely competent experts working at excellent centers. As to the many studies on long term outcomes for brachytherapy, you might Google the following ( prostate infolink ) then do a search there for "brachytherapy," and up will pop a long list of articles which you can look at regarding long term outcomes of 5 years, 10 years, 15 years, compared to the same doing surgery. The articles tend to digest the studies, also allowing you to go to the actual studies if you need more specific information and details. I suggest you do that search because you seem to have a significant concern about surgery. Weigh the facts. If you change your mind, you can always cancel your surgery date. Regarding surgery, since you've been reading here, I assume you have all the details about your surgeon's record, number of surgeries, and how many he does each week or month. What ever you choose, have the best guy possible do the treatment. There are centers where brachytherapy is performed much more than at others. There are also different type of brachytherapy... high dose vs regular. Sorry you have to make this tough decision, but at least you aren't on the fence about needing to do something. No panic rush, but something this year seems warranted.

Might influence his opinion a bit, though you said he was fine with surgery. Certainly those who do surgery have some natural bias towards surgery. And most men on this site have a understandable tendency to think surgery is best, because that is what they chose. Since you've only recently been diagnosed, I wonder how much you have read about the other choice you've been thinking about.... brachytherapy. So much out there on the internet. Very difficult to find it all and then digest it. Along with the fact that nothing is guaranteed in this entire subject. Plus the outcomes are mostly neck and neck with each other as long as done by extremely competent experts working at excellent centers. As to the many studies on long term outcomes for brachytherapy, you might Google the following ( prostate infolink ) then do a search there for "brachytherapy," and up will pop a long list of articles which you can look at regarding long term outcomes of 5 years, 10 years, 15 years, compared to the same doing surgery. The articles tend to digest the studies, also allowing you to go to the actual studies if you need more specific information and details. I suggest you do that search because you seem to have a significant concern about surgery. Weigh the facts. If you change your mind, you can always cancel your surgery date. Regarding surgery, since you've been reading here, I assume you have all the details about your surgeon's record, number of surgeries, and how many he does each week or month. What ever you choose, have the best guy possible do the treatment. There are centers where brachytherapy is performed much more than at others. There are also different type of brachytherapy... high dose vs regular. Sorry you have to make this tough decision, but at least you aren't on the fence about needing to do something. No panic rush, but something this year seems warranted.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LetsDoThis There is a lot I don't know about our situation, and from what I've read here, I think we are in a fortunate place with our initial diagnosis, but of course you always worry about the worst. Here's some info on us: *regular physical in September 2014 (hadn't had one in a few years) *Doc called in Oct because PSA level was a little elevated (5.6) and ordered repeat test *Repeat PSA came back about a point or so higher...I can't remember the exact amount but will find out. Somewhere around 6.7 or 7.something. *Doc referred him to a Urologist Was this PSA test his first one ever? If not, what were earlier tests? Either way, he hadn't had one in years. How many days after the first psa test, was the second psa test given? You are a bit vague on the reading of the second one, but indicate it was about 6.7 or 7 What I'm getting at is, what is his true PSA? Sometimes it can be greatly raised for a period of time by things other than prostate cancer. Of course he still has prostate cancer, but we don't know how many cores are positive yet, nor the percentage of each. In my own mind, I'd like to be assured that the psa of 5.6 or 7.0 is accurate and not just raised by something not associated with prostate cancer. He'd still have the biopsy, but depending on whether the true psa is 3.0 or 7.0 might make me more or less concerned about taking any treatment sooner or later in time. PSA rises unrelated to prostate cancer can take a month or months to calm down for a true psa reading. Certainly a few days or weeks is not sufficient to calm down in many cases.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shinytop To me AS has always been about not taking action until the surveillance shows it has become more aggressive. It seems logical that the longer you go the odds increase that your Gleason can rise. I am a 6 and only 5 months into my AS. At age 66 I like my odds.. I don't believe there is much reason to believe that a typical Gleason 6 will turn into a Gleason 7. While it makes a sort of logical sense, most evidence would indicate a Gleason 6 usually remains a Gleason 6. Now, a previously undetected Gleason 7 may show up,, but the original Gleason 6 mostly stays just that. I have read of instances where that is not the case, but generally speaking I don't believe one switches into the other. If you are 66 and can delay treatment for 2 years or 5 years, there is some value in that. Every year untreated is of some value unless you spend the entire time in worry and concern. At the very least, as you indicated, you now know much more about prostate cancer. Of course I don't recall your precise details... number of positive cores, psa history, etc.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> At age 66 I like my odds <Z>

Posts.Content: Some 993 patients "At 5, 10,15, and 20 years after diagnosis, 75.7%, 63.5%, 55.0%, and 55.0% of patients, respectively, remain untreated and on active surveillance. During the follow-up period, 15 died from prostate cancer and 7 developed metastatic disease." http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/823590 So, a just over half remained on AS, though it will take many more years to get the actual percentage of those who go forever on AS. Seems like it might be about 50% as the years unfold.
Posts.Title: A new study regarding 993 AS patients after 5 to 20 years

Posts.Content: Its a little difficult to know what to ask until you get the results of the bone and CT scans. You didn't mention what his PSA test results were or if the doctor felt something when doing the DRE test (digital exam). Your mother needs to go with him and take a yellow note pad to record what the doctor says. Since you have a second opinion appointment on Wednesday, be sure that you can take with you all the details of the biopsy results, psa scores, as well as the results of the bone and CT scans. Without those details, the second opinion won't be of any value as the second doctor would have nothing to go on. You might even call the Sammons Cancer Center urologist and ask his office exactly what records you should bring with you.

Posts.Title: Family in crisis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Would you trust your gut instinct in a decision like this? or would you trust the data, the science. I suppose the issue would be regarding the "SEs less with Brachy" that you spoke about. If you are willing to accept the accurate probability of those being something you will deal with, then I guess surgery is your route. I think the problem is sometimes that we all think the SEs won't happen to us, that we'll be in the 25% or 50% that doesn't get them, or that they aren't permanent. Often this revolves around post surgery sexual function. Whether there is a high, medium, or low probability of sexual function returning to pre-surgical conditions. I don't know what your reading has done to your assessment of what is probable....or how much that matters to you vs the "get it out" comfort. The concerns about urinary continence seems of less concern because most men think that will return to normal with time. However for those that don't it is often thought to be a much larger issue than the sexual function. So anyway, do you have expectations about how those issues will likely be depending on whether you do surgery or brachy?
Posts.Title: Surgery vs Brachy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Otago, interesting perspective. Regarding the SE of ED... I was told by both the surgeon and the RO THAT I HAD ABOUT A 60-65%. Chance of maintaining full function, with surgery being after anywhere from 6 months to two years and surgery being with drugs, but Brachy being without drugs and if I fall into the 40% unlucky group, then 50% chance that would be resolved with drugs. Honestly, as much as I would like to maintain that function, it pales by comparison to my desire to come outfit this disease free. REGARDING Incontinence, I am going to admit that I believe I will be one of the lucky ones that gets it resolved, within a few months. This is based on my full continence pre treatment, my doing the Kegels now, pre treatment, and most important, having a highly skilled surgeon, Ash Tewari Now that you reminded me that Ash Tewari was going to do the surgery, yes, I think the incontinence issues are minimized. I thought I remembered reading he had developed a special technique. I looked it up and found this http://www.prostatesupport.org.au/re...4/default.aspx Seems impressive and I don't think it is yet widely done. Perhaps you have read about his technique before. As to the sexual function, my only issue would be for you to be sure what they mean by the data. Meaning what is their definition of full function and usable erection. Often times that definition differs widely from what most men are currently getting prior to surgery. Of course as we age (I'm also 64) there is a natural decline in that department anyway. I must say though, I had close friend, our age, who had earlier robotic surgery 7 years ago, and though he didn't get back full natural function, he has done quite well with drugs and injections. (as bad as that sounds, many men get quite used to the procedure). BTW, he got married a few years AFTER the procedure and all seem well. I can't think of a better surgeon than you have if you go that route. I'd probably opt for brachy, but then again, from family history, I'm not so scared about poor outcomes as my father, diagnosed at our age, lived 25 years after radiation. Didn't ever have the PCa come back. You have good choices.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Double Trouble I am 53 years old. I had a PSA reading of 1.03 last year. About 2 months ago I had another blood test done during a routine physical and I had a PSA reading of 2.97 or almost triple of my earlier one. Taking my doctor's advice I went to a Urologist who scheduled another blood test about a month later and my PSA reading came back lower than the resent one at 1.95 but still almost double my original one. My Urologist told me I had two options. He said I could wait 6 months and have another blood test done and review the scores of that one and decide on a treatment plan then or I could take the pro-active approach and have the biopsy done now. . Your PSA result dropped by a full point in only one month. Highly indicative that the prior 2 point rise had nothing to do with prostate cancer. Actually you probably should have waited he six months and then tested again. Very possible you would have been down at 1.0 or under 1.5. If prostate cancer had driven it up to 2.97 from 1.03 in only a year, then it most likely wouldn't have dropped back to 1.95 in a month. Do you understand that? Many other things can make a PSA spike. Originally Posted by Double Trouble After careful consideration with my doctor and considering the risks of doing a biopsy and waiting the 6 months in a state of mind were I would always be wondering, I decided to do the biopsy now. I had it done on Sept. 12th. My Urologist told me that visibly my prostate looked healthy but enlarged which I was already aware of (the enlarged part). He also made it perfectly clear that although he may have the biopsy results back in 7 to 10 days I could not call him or the office in order to get the results and I would have to wait until the next time that I saw him in order to get the results. My next appointment is not until Sept 27 so I have to wait another 6 days before I get any type of answer. . Absolutely no need for you to wait 15 days for the results. He could probably get the results in less than a week. Perhaps in a couple days. Now, he may give out that standard practice of not giving you the answer without seeing you in person, because if he said he only calls the negative reports, then anyone who needed to come in would infer they had a positive result of prostate cancer at which time he can then counsel the patient. So instead he tells everyone to come in, then tells 75d% of them everything is just fine. I don't like that policy and can't know if its just a way to make more quick appointments for money. My doctor gave me the results over the phone, but I don't think he would do any differently if he had found prostate cancer. In fact I think his nurse called me, but then I later talked to him. I don't think you can read anything into it either way. Originally Posted by Double Trouble Is this standard with this type of thing? I suffer from bi-polar disorder and am very easily depressed. With this, I easily find myself thinking of the worst case scenarios when I find myself waiting for different test results. Do I have a right to call him and ask for my results earlier over the phone? Is this visit to his office just another way of the doctors practice to raise the cost associated with my testing and treatment? Are my past PSA readings indicative of a positive outcome on the biopsy? . I'd say your drop from 2.97 back to 1.95 in a month is highly indicative that you will have negative finding. In fact THAT is the reason why the doctor offered you the option of waiting six months and then doing another PSA test. I give him credit for that offer. I'd say you never needed the biopsy in the first place, or perhaps should I say, it wouldn't have harmed you or placed you in danger to wait the 6 months EVEN if the eventual biopsy found something. Except for your inclination to worry. Right now, just wait 6 days, or if it will save you money for a visit, you could call and ask for the results. All he can say is NO.... You are blowing this out of proportion as to your thinking the worst. Again, the large drop back down indicates that the rise in PSA was NOT from prostate cancer. You are about as likely as the next 53 year old guy walking down the street to have prostate cancer. All those other guys won't be worrying the next 6 days. On the other hand, if you grabbed the next one hundred 53 year old guys by random and gave them all biopsies, you'd come up with a few who had low grade prostate cancer, just because its out there in many men. However in most of them you don't really want to find it because in most of them its not going to harm them. If you haven't read that much about this subject you may not understand that. Most men who die at age 80 or 90 will have prostate cancer. It just won't have anything to do with their death. Its just out there in many many men undiagnosed. Odds are high you'll be just fine. Enjoy the weekend.

AgeInfo.Phrase: by Double Trouble I am 53 years old <Z> <Z> <Z>
as likely as the next 53 year old guy walking down
grabbed the next one hundred 53 year old guys by random
men who die at age 80 or 90 will have prostate

Posts.Title: Biopsy done...Now the wait

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Didee ...well, that's what I recon. Hubby had a PSA test due to frequent urination. Age 49. Call from Doc's surgery says want to see him..urgent. Doc has never has used the word urgent before, even with my tests, diagnosis and treatment. . . There is NO need for a doctor to say "urgent" if the problem is a high PSA. Your concerns regarding that are misguided. He might very well say "urgent" for a infection. Your husband could have various PSA readings, but that would NOT be a reason for a doctor to use the term "urgent". I hope you can explain that to your husband who need not be concerned about the doctor using that term EXCEPT for the most probable explanation, a infection.
Posts.Title: Husband, probable high PSA/wasn't

Posts.Content: Well, you can do nothing for now. Take the pressure off and give it some time to think about it. There is no indication at all that if you treat it now, that you will have any better outcome than treating it 6 months from now. The chance that you would get total cure now, but not 6 months from now, is extremely small. I sense pressure or urgency on your part. If you just give it a break for a few months, your thinking might clear up. Besides, you get to use your prostate for another 4 to 8 months. BTW, which "world class" center in Boston was that?
Posts.Title: No one on same page...frustrating!

Posts.Title: Surgery vs Brachy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by heatdoctor After several yearly PSA's of around 1.5, this year mine jumped to 5.6. I am 67 years young. I was scheduled for a biopsy. So, that is what I did & the result was that my PSA went back down to 1.4. I have had 3 digital exams over the past 2 months & they are more or less unremarkable. So, the BIG question is what do I do now? There seems to be no consensus. Who in the world scheduled you for a biopsy after just one elevated PSA and a normal DRE? How insane was that. With your age and past history its hard to imagine why any doctor or urologist would do that unless they just wanted to collect another fee. Really crazy behavior if you ask me. Lucky you were smart enough to do some reading on your own. As to what you should do now.........NOTHING.... Oh I suppose you can get another psa in 6 weeks, but even if that one is 3.0 or 5.0, I would not submit to a biopsy. Rather I would wait and again repeat the psa in another 6 weeks. As the other poster said, prostate cancer does not make a steady 1.5 jump to 5.6 and then back down to 1.4.......in line with all your prior tests. Amazing that a urologist would allow a biopsy without waiting and perhaps giving you a round of antibiotics.. Please be aware you can have various forms of prostatitis that can greatly raise your psa. Also be aware that the prostatitis can be bacterial or non-bacterial and can even be asymptomatic....leaving you unaware of its presence. Under most circumstances, a man of your age need not be in a rush, nor should he be rushed into a biopsy. If the next one comes back raised, please realize the same causation for the first raised psa could have returned and that does not mean its prostate cancer. The danger for someone your age, who probably has a true 1.5 to 2.0 psa is that indeed they could do a biopsy and find some minor cancer, thus putting you on the train for treatment when had you never had that blip up in psa, you would probably have lived to 90 never having any need for treatment. Just because indolent prostate cancer is there doesn't mean you always want to find it. By age 80 or 90 most men who die of other causes, also die with undiagnosed prostate cancer. Not all, but most. Take your time. Don't be pushed into anything quickly. You may want to get a second opinion should this issue arise again. It really sounds like you did exactly the correct thing in waiting and it calls into question the advice of the person who scheduled you for a biopsy without waiting.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA followed by return to normal: what to do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blinky57 I decided to get a second opinion from a world renowned urologist at the University of Miami. After performing a very very thorough DRE and looking at the below numbers, he seemed unconcerned and recommended i do nothing at this time. He advised to come back in year. I told him i would be more comfortable with 6 months, and he said OK to that. The advice from your U. of Miami urologist seems reasonable. You PSA really isn't doing much over the past 2.7 years. It was 4.9 when you did your last biopsy in 2011. Here it is 2014 and it is up to 6.1 (however, as you can see, it very well could drop back under 5.5 on the next test. Leaving you with a true rise of about 0.6 over the past 2.7 years. Something to watch, but not a urgent indication for a biopsy. He said wait a year, then retest, and you felt 6 months was better. He was fine with that. I don't see a problem. If you're like your dad, then there is no rush. Treatment later is most often every bit as successful as early treatment. A point you don't often hear. If you get a reconfirmation of a PSA up further from 6.1, you can then get that second biopsy. Is there a little risk in waiting... sure, but very little in most cases. My numbers bounce around and thankfully my urologist always say, "lets wait".... Like you, I had one negative biopsy years ago. I'm no longer overly concerned if I get a jump up in PSA. My father had prostate cancer and was successfully treated. Lived for 25 years after that. Both you and I will probably get prostate cancer (diagnosed) at some time in the future. In fact, we both probably have a bit of it right now if we did enough biopsies. However that doesn't mean we want to treat it now, if it is very likely we can treat it equally effectively 5 to 10+ years down the road. The video I often tell people to watch is the following http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 In your case, it would not be unreasonable to choose either path, to wait 6 months, or to biopsy now. In either case I don't feel you are endangering your life. I was wondering, what if any PSA history did your father have? My father's history was before the time of PSA testing.
Posts.Title: New Member w/Rising PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dsapirste i am 62 and was diagnosed with prostate cancer gleason 6 and went to see dr brooks in Stanford and go to meet dr carol in ucsf. dr brooks said that he can save the two nurves bundles but also said that because i have experienced lately weak sexual performance he think after surgery it will get worse .is that contradict each other saving the nurves bundles but still does not improve performance?. Your Stanford doctor is being entirely honest. Saving the nerve bundles does nothing to improve sexual performance. Very good chance that even with the nerves saved that you will experience some decline in performance, possibly offset by the use is Viagra, etc. But even then, most men do not come back as well as before regarding performance. Now, on the optimistic side, in seeing Dr. Peter Carroll at UCSF, you are seeing one of the finest doctors in the nation. He will give you clear information about your best choice regarding surgery, radiation, seeds, or active surveillance. I don't know what he will say, but I'd place great trust in his best advice and the reality you can expect afterwards if you choose surgery. Come back after you see him and tell us what he said. Oh yes, and you might include all your numbers. PSA scores, biopsy scores, number of positive cores, percentage of each core that is positive, etc. The details. Makes it easier for readers to understand your current situation and diagnosis.

Posts.Title: prostate cancer feedback from patient after treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Didee ...well, that's what I recon. Hubby had a PSA test due to frequent urination. Age 49. Call from Doc's surgery says want to see him..urgent. Doc has never has used the word urgent before, even with my tests, diagnosis and treatment. . . There is NO need for a doctor to say "urgent" if the problem is a high PSA. Your concerns regarding that are misguided. He might very well say "urgent" for a infection. Your husband could have various PSA readings, but that would NOT be a reason for a doctor to use the term "urgent". I hope you can explain that to your husband who need not be concerned about the doctor using that term EXCEPT for the most probable explanation, a infection.
Posts.Title: Husband, probable high PSA/wasn't

Posts.Content: Well, you can do nothing for now. Take the pressure off and give it some time to think about it. There is no indication at all that if you treat it now, that you will have any better outcome than treating it 6 months from now. The chance that you would get total cure now, but not 6 months from now, is extremely small. I sense pressure or urgency on your part. If you just give it a break for a few months, your thinking might clear up. Besides, you get to use your prostate for another 4 to 8 months. BTW, which "world class" center in Boston was that?
Posts.Title: No one on same page...frustrating!

Posts.Content: Most cases of prostate cancer have been developing over many years. It did not just start up within 6 months. You are correct, the PSA test is not very reliable in predicting prostate cancer. But it is what indicates that a biopsy may be needed. The psa test is more useful in following patients after surgery or radiation. The jump from psa 3.6 to 7.13 may not all have been from the growth or progression of cancer. PSA results can vary widely, independent of cancer being present. Mine has jumped from about 3.8 to 7.5, only to fall back under 3.8 by the next test. I don't recall the age of your husband, but by age 55 through 70, as many as 50% of men are walking around with prostate cancer. In most it will never develop into a problem, but it is present, often undiagnosed. By the age of 80 or later, almost all men can be found to have some prostate cancer present, though it never affects most of them. In other words, late in life, it is more natural to have prostate cancer than to not have it.

Posts.Title: Very confused about PSA- can anyone help me with this?

Posts.Content: Depends on what they need the letter to say. If they are only asking the doctor to indicate that you have prostate cancer, then assuming you have a Gleason 6 or higher I don't know why they would hesitate. On the other hand if the letter needs to state that the prostate cancer is related to your work, that is completely different. Or if they are being asked to indicate that you will be disabled during or after treatment that may also cause them to hesitate. So what is the required letter or form asking for? A statement of fact or a opinion? Is it for temporary disability or for a disability retirement?
Posts.Title: Letter from doctor

Posts.Content: To go from 2.3 to 85 or 117 within 2 years is actually good news in most cases. Meaning that such a dramatic rise is most likely caused by prostatitis. Most prostatitis is non-bacterial and won't be brought down by antibiotics. Here is a Q&A quote from Dr. Catalona, a well known prostate expert. "A persistently rising PSA level can be an indication of prostate cancer, even if the absolute level is within the “normal” range. On the other hand, very dramatic rises in PSA of greater than 2ng/ml per year are more likely to be caused by prostatitis." As you can see your husband's rise if off the charts. As such it would seem much more likely that it is not being cause by prostate cancer. Throw in what the doctor said "she said that it felt "mussy" and "hot" which usually means infection" and if you were a betting person, you certainly put a big bet on some form of prostatitis. Now, anytime you start doing biopsies on men age 62, you run the chance of also finding some prostate cancer, because random men walking down the street often have some small amounts of prostate cancer in them by that age. Most are never diagnosed, but its just sitting there. Several studies have shown this. Most men who die in their 80's or 90's had prostate cancer but never knew it and were never affected by it. So like I said, its always possible to strike it when doing biopsies. But that kind of cancer is unrelated to a psa spike to 117. Do let us know the results of the biopsy.

Posts.Title: New Member w/Rising PSA

Posts.Content: "He's 48, hi's PSA was 2.5, 1 out of 12 biopsy samples came out positive, Gleason 3+4." Why did they do a biopsy with a 2.5 psa? Did you have more than one psa to confirm that result? Did the doctor feel something on the DRE? That 1 core of the 12, what percent was it? Have you gotten the second opinion reading on it yet? How soon? Surgery in February. Really moving fast though the surgeon seems top flight. Unclear from your post as to how much time passed from diagnosis to the decision to have surgery? Sounds like it may have only been a week or two. Hard to learn that much about prostate cancer and surgery in a couple weeks. Thankfully you are having John Hopkins review the slides

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA followed by return to normal: what to do?

Posts.Content: Hi, a few points that may help others answer. What is your age? What is your history of PSA tests results and dates besides the two mentioned. It appears from the T2a stage that the doctor felt something on the DRE. Was that felt by the urologist or your primary doctor or both? The one sample that was Gleason 6, 0.6 mm long. Do you know what percentage of the sample that is? If that psa of 4.7 hadn't included the doctor also feeling something on the DRE, they may well have waited a while and done another PSA test before doing a biopsy. Personally, later on, after things calm down post biopsy, I might want to re-test the PSA to see if its still 4.7 or much lower or higher. What does the doctor say. After all he is the one who felt something abnormal on the DRE. How did he describe what he felt? and where it was located. Doesn't sound like you have to rush into any treatment soon. Time to learn lots more and consider all your options. It would seem like you can easily extend that decision process into the beginning of next year, but then again we don't know all the details that your doctor has.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: So your first ever PSA was done about age 62 in 2010. I asked what the doctor felt because you listed the status as T2a which normally means he feels something other than just normal enlargement. A harder area or a nodule. Other wise it would be T1c, discovered only by needle biopsy. You might ask him about that sometime. You might also find out what percentage of that core sample the 0.6mm represents. Like, 10% or 30% or 50% etc. Not knowing to much about the length of the entire sample we don't know. Look at this from a study on such... "The mean length of 7,126 analysed cores was 14.14 ± 4.35 mm. All cores were longer than 10 mm. The mean length of needle cores sampled did not correlate with patient age, total prostate-specific antigen value, digital rectal examination, and prostate volume. The whole mean length of the six samples from the peripheral zone of the right lobe was higher than the mean corresponding value of the six samples from the left lobe peripheral zone (p < 0.001). The transperineal approach allows a greater sampling of the prostate apex than of the midgland and prostate base (p < 0.001)." If your core sample was 10 mm then 0.6 would only be 6% which would be very low (meaning good) But as I indicated, I know very little about this or how they arrive at percent of sample. Others may know more.
