Posts.Title: My Husband has triple digit PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by petermollie Length of cores where Tumour 0.6mm was found were 12/9/7mm. Urologist didnt comment on DRE after he examined me You show the 3 cores as being 12, 9, and 7 mm in length, but you indicated that only one of them was positive for the Gleason 6 with 0.6mm Again, I'm not exactly sure how they calculate this stuff, but normally they give a percentage, with lower being better. If its all simple math then 0.6 mm of even the shortest is less than 9%, while the other two possibilities would be 7% and 5%. If indeed that is how the math is done then all of those are very low, meaning good. Perhaps someone here knows more about the calculation methods. Of course your doctor would have the best and most precise answer for that, as well as the question about the DRE and why you were listed as T2a vs T1c All in all it sounds very manageable whether you do AS or some treatment. Certainly seems like you have time to explore all choices before deciding.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Double Trouble I am 53 years old. I had a PSA reading of 1.03 last year. About 2 months ago I had another blood test done during a routine physical and I had a PSA reading of 2.97 or almost triple of my earlier one. Taking my doctor's advice I went to a Urologist who scheduled another blood test about a month later and my PSA reading came back lower than the resent one at 1.95 but still almost double my original one. My Urologist told me I had two options. He said I could wait 6 months and have another blood test done and review the scores of that one and decide on a treatment plan then or I could take the pro-active approach and have the biopsy done now. . Your PSA result dropped by a full point in only one month. Highly indicative that the prior 2 point rise had nothing to do with prostate cancer. Actually you probably should have waited he six months and then tested again. Very possible you would have been down at 1.0 or under 1.5. If prostate cancer had driven it up to 2.97 from 1.03 in only a year, then it most likely wouldn't have dropped back to 1.95 in a month. Do you understand that? Many other things can make a PSA spike. Originally Posted by Double Trouble After careful consideration with my doctor and considering the risks of doing a biopsy and waiting the 6 months in a state of mind were I would always be wondering, I decided to do the biopsy now. I had it done on Sept. 12th. My Urologist told me that visibly my prostate looked healthy but enlarged which I was already aware of (the enlarged part). He also made it perfectly clear that although he may have the biopsy results back in 7 to 10 days I could not call him or the office in order to get the results and I would have to wait until the next time that I saw him in order to get the results. My next appointment is not until Sept 27 so I have to wait another 6 days before I get any type of answer. . Absolutely no need for you to wait 15 days for the results. He could probably get the results in less than a week. Perhaps in a couple days. Now, he may give out that standard practice of not giving you the answer without seeing you in person, because if he said he only calls the negative reports, then anyone who needed to come in would infer they had a positive result of prostate cancer at which time he can then counsel the patient. So instead he tells everyone to come in, then tells 75d% of them everything is just fine. I don't like that policy and can't know if its just a way to make more quick appointments for money. My doctor gave me the results over the phone, but I don't think he would do any differently if he had found prostate cancer. In fact I think his nurse called me, but then I later talked to him. I don't think you can read anything into it either way. Originally Posted by Double Trouble Is this standard with this type of thing? I suffer from bi-polar disorder and am very easily depressed. With this, I easily find myself thinking of the worst case scenarios when I find myself waiting for different test results. Do I have a right to call him and ask for my results earlier over the phone? Is this visit to his office just another way of the doctors practice to raise the cost associated with my testing and treatment? Are my past PSA readings indicative of a positive outcome on the biopsy? . I'd say your drop from 2.97 back to 1.95 in a month is highly indicative that you will have negative finding. In fact THAT is the reason why the doctor offered you the option of waiting six months and then doing another PSA test. I give him credit for that offer. I'd say you never needed the biopsy in the first place, or perhaps should I say, it wouldn't have harmed you or placed you in danger to wait the 6 months EVEN if the eventual biopsy found something. Except for your inclination to worry. Right now, just wait 6 days, or if it will save you money for a visit, you could call and ask for the results. All he can say is NO.... You are blowing this out of proportion as to your thinking the worst. Again, the large drop back down indicates that the rise in PSA was NOT from prostate cancer. You are about as likely as the next 53 year old guy walking down the street to have prostate cancer. All those other guys won't be worrying the next 6 days. On the other hand, if you grabbed the next one hundred 53 year old guys by random and gave them all biopsies, you'd come up with a few who had low grade prostate cancer, just because its out there in many men. However in most of them you don't really want to find it because in most of them its not going to harm them. If you haven't read that much about this subject you may not understand that. Most men who die at age 80 or 90 will have prostate cancer. It just won't have anything to do with their death. Its just out there in many many men undiagnosed. Odds are high you'll be just fine. Enjoy the weekend.

Posts.Title: Biopsy done...Now the wait

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kozmic He referred me to Dr Vipul Patel at Fl hospital Celebration, for an MIR guided biopsy. This all seems like a lot of waiting, weeks. The waiting is killing me. Other than the psychological aspect of waiting a few more weeks... the physical danger is very minimal. If you have prostate cancer, you've had it for years and years, slowly growing. A few more weeks is of no concern from the point of view of curing it, should it exist. Seems like you got a good referral... which alone is worth waiting a few extra weeks. Let us know the results. I'm sure there will be a good path for you whatever the results of the biopsy.

Posts.Title: My Husband has triple digit PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Cancerinoregon the tomato juice with the lycopene that I read had helped in studies. Now he's taking the SP only. I am worried though. Can the SP actually kill cancer cells in time, not just reduce the hormone? They never gave him the option of hormone therapy because his hormones were fine I guess. I had read that the following are useful in killing cancer cells. Is this true? And if so, what potency and how often should they be taken? Any help very much appreciated. Thank you! Not likely that any of the things you mention will "kill" the cancer or "cure" him.. However some of those items, along with dietary changes, may slow the cancer down, which for men age 70 can be beneficial. However you can't count on any of them being guaranteed effective on any single patient. The reality is that with or without immediate treatment, he is likely to be alive 10 years from now. If he is inclined, he should read more and more about his odds regardless of what he chooses. He may choose to do nothing for now and then begin a treatment if the cancer shows progression. Some people are willing to take more chances than others. Or willing to postpone treatment, thinking they'll do just as well treating it later if needed. I think the report you have posted says just that. Others want to take no chances with any cancer, even if found in only one of the many samples. You can't do all the research for him. He'll have to take the time and make his own call. Diet and a few supplements are at best a weak tool, but I would not entirely ignore them. BTW, the same dietary changes that are thought to be good for prostate cancer, are also good for the heart and for blood pressure. His BP is rather high. Again, none of the items you mention will kill or cure the cancer... but then again most men die with some prostate cancer in their body. They just don't die from the prostate cancer in most cases. About half of men his age have prostate cancer, though it goes undiagnosed in most of them. Just have him read the book by Patrick Walsh and also read more and more.. Then he decides which way he will place his bets.

AgeInfo.Phrase: down  which for men age 70 can be beneficial <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Dad's biopsy results, looking for alternative treatment.

Posts.Content: Hi, a few points that may help others answer. What is your age? What is your history of PSA tests results and dates besides the two mentioned. It appears from the T2a stage that the doctor felt something on the DRE. Was that felt by the urologist or your primary doctor or both? The one sample that was Gleason 6, 0.6 mm long. Do you know what percentage of the sample that is? If that psa of 4.7 hadn't included the doctor also feeling something on the DRE, they may well have waited a while and done another PSA test before doing a biopsy. Personally, later on, after things calm down post biopsy, I might want to re-test the PSA to see if its still 4.7 or much lower or higher. What does the doctor say. After all he is the one who felt something abnormal on the DRE. How did he describe what he felt? and where it was located. Doesn't sound like you have to rush into any treatment soon. Time to learn lots more and consider all your options. It would seem like you can easily extend that decision process into the beginning of next year, but then again we don't know all the details that your doctor has.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: To go from 2.3 to 85 or 117 within 2 years is actually good news in most cases. Meaning that such a dramatic rise is most likely caused by prostatitis. Most prostatitis is non-bacterial and won't be brought down by antibiotics. Here is a Q&A quote from Dr. Catalona, a well known prostate expert. "A persistently rising PSA level can be an indication of prostate cancer, even if the absolute level is within the “normal” range. On the other hand, very dramatic rises in PSA of greater than 2ng/ml per year are more likely to be caused by prostatitis." As you can see your husband's rise if off the charts. As such it would seem much more likely that it is not being cause by prostate cancer. Throw in what the doctor said "she said that it felt "mussy" and "hot" which usually means infection" and if you were a betting person, you certainly put a big bet on some form of prostatitis. Now, anytime you start doing biopsies on men age 62, you run the chance of also finding some prostate cancer, because random men walking down the street often have some small amounts of prostate cancer in them by that age. Most are never diagnosed, but its just sitting there. Several studies have shown this. Most men who die in their 80's or 90's had prostate cancer but never knew it and were never affected by it. So like I said, its always possible to strike it when doing biopsies. But that kind of cancer is unrelated to a psa spike to 117. Do let us know the results of the biopsy.

Posts.Title: My Husband has triple digit PSA

Posts.Content: "He's 48, hi's PSA was 2.5, 1 out of 12 biopsy samples came out positive, Gleason 3+4." Why did they do a biopsy with a 2.5 psa? Did you have more than one psa to confirm that result? Did the doctor feel something on the DRE? That 1 core of the 12, what percent was it? Have you gotten the second opinion reading on it yet? How soon? Surgery in February. Really moving fast though the surgeon seems top flight. Unclear from your post as to how much time passed from diagnosis to the decision to have surgery? Sounds like it may have only been a week or two. Hard to learn that much about prostate cancer and surgery in a couple weeks. Thankfully you are having John Hopkins review the slides

Posts.Title: My Husband has triple digit PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kozmic He referred me to Dr Vipul Patel at Fl hospital Celebration, for an MIR guided biopsy. This all seems like a lot of waiting, weeks. The waiting is killing me. Other than the psychological aspect of waiting a few more weeks... the physical danger is very minimal. If you have prostate cancer, you've had it for years and years, slowly growing. A few more weeks is of no concern from the point of view of curing it, should it exist. Seems like you got a good referral... which alone is worth waiting a few extra weeks. Let us know the results. I'm sure there will be a good path for you whatever the results of the biopsy.

Posts.Title: Husband diagnose with prostate cancer...

Posts.Content: So your first ever PSA was done about age 62 in 2010. I asked what the doctor felt because you listed the status as T2a which normally means he feels something other than just normal enlargement. A harder area or a nodule. Other wise it would be T1c, discovered only by needle biopsy. You might ask him about that sometime. You might also find out what percentage of that core sample the 0.6mm represents. Like, 10% or 30% or 50% etc. Not knowing to much about the length of the entire sample we don't know. Look at this from a study on such... "The mean length of 7,126 analysed cores was 14.14 ± 4.35 mm. All cores were longer than 10 mm. The mean length of needle cores sampled did not correlate with patient age, total prostate-specific antigen value, digital rectal examination, and prostate volume. The whole mean length of the six samples from the peripheral zone of the right lobe was higher than the mean corresponding value of the six samples from the left lobe peripheral zone (p < 0.001). The transperineal approach allows a greater sampling of the prostate apex than of the midgland and prostate base (p < 0.001)." If your core sample was 10 mm then 0.6 would only be 6% which would be very low (meaning good) But as I indicated, I know very little about this or how they arrive at percent of sample. Others may know more.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pink2014 one core was positive. PTI 5% Right lateral middle Why were you given a biopsy? Meaning what led to the doctor suggesting a biopsy? Did the DRE reveal something unusual? Was your psa high? How high? Was that the first high result? How long did they wait to retest the high result.. if it was a sudden jump from a prior test? Those kinds of questions might make a difference in your decision. When you say family history, what was it? Father, brothers, etc? Certainly there is no reason to arrive at a rapid decision on getting treatment or what kind to get, given your 1 core at 5%.

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by petermollie Length of cores where Tumour 0.6mm was found were 12/9/7mm. Urologist didnt comment on DRE after he examined me You show the 3 cores as being 12, 9, and 7 mm in length, but you indicated that only one of them was positive for the Gleason 6 with 0.6mm Again, I'm not exactly sure how they calculate this stuff, but normally they give a percentage, with lower being better. If its all simple math then 0.6 mm of even the shortest is less than 9%, while the other two possibilities would be 7% and 5%. If indeed that is how the math is done then all of those are very low, meaning good. Perhaps someone here knows more about the calculation methods. Of course your doctor would have the best and most precise answer for that, as well as the question about the DRE and why you were listed as T2a vs T1c All in all it sounds very manageable whether you do AS or some treatment. Certainly seems like you have time to explore all choices before deciding.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pink2014 my PSA was climbing for the last 2 years from 2.9 to 3.2 to 4.5 this year. i have a family history with my fathers side. All the males from my father, uncle grandfather died from prostate cancer. Thanks for the great answers and support. my doctor has performed 400 Da vinci procedures and is the director of robotics at my hospital. Was thinking of active monitoring, however really do not want to go thru a biopsy every 6 months-year and I'm worried of it leaving my prostate. Well, that is a fairly strong family history with them all dying of prostate cancer. You didn't mention their age at diagnosis. Any idea of their biopsy results, Gleason scores or PSA scores. (though I imagine your grandfather was before the psa testing was in practice for early diagnosis). I'm not sure about it, but it might seem that there is about a 50/50 chance you have a similar gene. Any brothers your age or older?

Posts.Title: The journey begins.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by markpw2 Please help if you can! I am scheduled to have the Davinci robotic surgery performed here in So. Cal by one of the top urology surgeons in the United States in 2 months. I am told with a 0.7 psa, Gleason at 6, and stage T2a-b1 that I am a very good candidate for this "nerve sparring" procedure and in the hands of a world class surgeon my chances for any sexual dysfunction or real incontinence issues are rather small. I sure would like to believe this as I always have been a pretty active guy and still feel and think very young-I am 67 yrs. old but look a lot younger. I'm told that my doctor uses the newest Davinci "S" robot and creates 6 ports in the lower stomach region rather than 5 ports. If anyone has a similar profile and has had this procedure within the last 1 year I would sure appreciate hearing from you re:your results. Mark You need a realistic view about robotic surgery or any type. Doctors are telling too many patients what they want to hear. Especially regarding future sexual function. Their percentages and definitions are way off from what reality seems to indicate. You want a realistic discussion. Go to the New York Times IN the search box, put in prostate and Tara Parker-Pope When you find the article, read it, then read the 75+ comments. Its the August 27 article. "I am told with a 0.7 psa, Gleason at 6, and stage T2a-b1 that I am a very good candidate for this "nerve sparring" procedure and in the hands of a world class surgeon my chances for any sexual dysfunction or real incontinence issues are rather small. " This is the point at issue. I would say your chances of one of the two of those happening is 50% or greater.. Very few men say that sex is the same after surgery. The definition many doctors use is very loose. I can assure you, it is not your definition of "normal sexual function" like you have currently been experiencing and are used to. OK......I've not had the surgery. Read the NY Times article and all of the comments. It offers a more realistic picture. You need a realistic view. Doesn't mean your choice won't be the same nor that there is a 100% chance you won't be perfect, but......well, just read it. Also, how many opinions have you gotten? I do realize that some very low PSA scored prostate cancers can still be dangerous, but normally the lower score the better. They did the biopsy because of your DRE. Did the tell you the extent of the cancer, in each core they sampled? What were the percentages? How many cores were positive? Did you get the biopisies read by a second pathologist? you should. Many men your age might choose to watch the PCa and not treat it. In many men it is a valid option, even preferred in the minds of many. The name used for this can range from Watchful Waiting to Expectant Management. Even famous medical centers have programs for this option.....such as John Hopkins. Certainly not for everyone and much of the criteria depends on the patients situation. I don't know the details of your testosterone situation. Are you currently being given testosterone? All in all, sound like you've not had much time to learn about all this. You seem to be on a "fast track" for making the decision. Gosh, you said you just learned about this 3 weeks ago and you are already set for surgery. Is there something we don't know that indicates the urgency? Seems like a very fast time frame to make all these decisions when you haven't had that much time to learn. I'd give you some other links here but I think there is some rule about that. Otago

AgeInfo.Phrase: think very young I am 67 yrs <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH If it spikes from one test to the next, a red flag is raised that suggests the prostate cancer could be there. If it spikes from one test to the next, I'd say it suggests you should wait 6 months, then test again, before poking some poor man with 30 more needles.
Posts.Title: PSA took me for a ride !

Posts.Content: Well, you can go ahead with those tests, of course. And you'll be getting back a second opinion on the slides. Probably you'll still get a Gleason 6 result, however lots of men are walking around with Gleason 6 in their prostates and are completely unaware of it. At your age, probably from 35% to 45% of men have some Gleason 6 lurking somewhere if only enough biopsies were done on random men walking down the street. However most of those men would still have a PSA under 4 or 5. You only mention that your previous PSA test was done about 5 years prior, at age 58. Back then, if you know, what was your prior history at that time and what if any previous results did you have and what were those readings. Meaning were they all under 4.0... under 2.0.... ? Any progression back then or any unusual bounces. Again, things can affect PSA readings more than many realize. In the past few years, I have had readings of 7.3 followed in six months by a 3.6 During the time the 7.3 test was taken, I felt nothing like prostatitis and I was not given any antibiotic. It just went down and I've had another bounce since then, up, then down. If my next test was 20, I'd be nearly certain it was not due to cancer but rather some inflammation related issue. However, given your 5 years of missing data, we can't know that to be the case in your situation. BUT it could be possible. Or your case could be high, but not as high as the tests indicate. It would be more comforting to know it was a 10 or 12 instead of 23. After some time goes by and before any final decision is made on treatment, I'd want to conduct another PSA test. Some have written that a anti-inflammatory is as important as a antibiotic. Ibuprofen and such for considerable time before the next test. And even then some inflammation is just plain stubborn. Though you don't give the dates, it appears the PSA tests were given in July and August. I would wait until at least October for a follow up PSA test. During that time, no DRE prior to the test, no sex in the days prior, perhaps some ibuprofen (you can look into that)... and no bike riding in the weeks leading up. Now, several of those items seldom make a high reading such as you have gotten,, but the over all inflammation along with BPH can lead to some high readings. Again you didn't mention your PSA reading at age 58 and before. BTW, back between the age of 51 and 56, I also went 5 years without testing, however my age 51 reading was only 0.8, then I got a 2.6 at age 56. A jump, but not like yours. Oh, I'm 63 now, just like you. I pay close attention to these jumps and patterns because my PSA jumps around and my one biopsy thus far came up clean. Still my interest is in this area. I might add that I have a fair degree of confidence that right now, I have lurking somewhere in my prostate, at least one sample of a Gleason 6. That reality doesn't worry me as it is the case for a good percentage of men our age. Its the progression that is important and the possible indicator of that is the PSA. Thus my focus on making sure your 20+ reading is the true reading or some blip caused by something other than prostate cancer. OK, lets see how those tests turn out. ( of course, as always, I am not a trained person and your own urologist sees this stuff every day)

Posts.Title: PSA vs Gleason vs DRE question

Posts.Content: Everything you report may very well be just as you detail it and as you were probably told by a trained professional. Now having said that, You have not included some important details. Your age Your prior PSA readings (if any) and the date of each one. 5 weeks is not all that long for a inflammation of a prostate to settle down. Something like 70% of all prostatitis is nonbacterial such that antibiotics don't have anything to treat. A good deal of prostatitis is asymptomatic. You don't even know you have it. You mention a DRE finding no lumps, then you describe the prostate as "soft and mushy". You should look up the terms "boggy" and spongy as related to prostates and prostatitis. Your description sounds more like boggy than normal. BTW, who did your DRE's? I'm sure it must have been done by a urologist. Who described it as soft and mushy? Your free PSA is not all that bad. Just wondering if your two recent PSA tests gave enough time for any possible inflammation or prostatitis to calm down. That could shoot your PSA up and make it remain there for over 5 weeks. Thus, if the true PSA was far lower it could make a great deal of difference in your treatment decisions. Again, we need your history. Did your urologist have all your history and past records? If, and its a big if..... If your true PSA was only 5 or even 8 and depending on your age, with 2 of 12 cores at Gleason 6, you might opt for no treatment at all now. Just saying, there are lots of examples where PSA scores drop big time. Of course, you can't do another one any time soon after having had a biopsy. You might also give us the date of that event. So lots of possible issues. Past history, dates, past scores, your age, etc. Or it all may be just as it appears but you don't want to get on the treatment train without knowing and considering all possibilities. That is why I ask all these questions. Sort of just on the chance. Have you had anyone else read your biopsy samples? If everything is as it appears, then I guess you'll need to be making a choice of treatment given that level of PSA. But if prior PSA tests were far lower then I'd wonder what caused the sudden jump to 20+.

AgeInfo.Phrase: depending on your age  with 2 of 12 cores at Gleason

Posts.Title: PSA vs Gleason vs DRE question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pink2014 my PSA was climbing for the last 2 years from 2.9 to 3.2 to 4.5 this year. i have a family history with my fathers side. All the males from my father, uncle grandfather died from prostate cancer. Thanks for the great answers and support. my doctor has performed 400 Da vinci procedures and is the director of robotics at my hospital. Was thinking of active monitoring, however really do not want to go thru a biopsy every 6 months-year and I'm worried of it leaving my prostate. Well, that is a fairly strong family history with them all dying of prostate cancer. You didn't mention their age at diagnosis. Any idea of their biopsy results, Gleason scores or PSA scores. (though I imagine your grandfather was before the psa testing was in practice for early diagnosis). I'm not sure about it, but it might seem that there is about a 50/50 chance you have a similar gene. Any brothers your age or older?

AgeInfo.Phrase: there is about a 50 50 chance you have a similar

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pink2014 one core was positive. PTI 5% Right lateral middle Why were you given a biopsy? Meaning what led to the doctor suggesting a biopsy? Did the DRE reveal something unusual? Was your psa high? How high? Was that the first high result? How long did they wait to retest the high result.. if it was a sudden jump from a prior test? Those kinds of questions might make a difference in your decision. When you say family history, what was it? Father, brothers, etc? Certainly there is no reason to arrive at a rapid decision on getting treatment or what kind to get, given your 1 core at 5%.

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hawk u. I was 54 with Gleason 8 and a PSA of 8.7 and higher so my decision was easier. Even in your shoes, I would need some very expert convincing before I decided on watchful waiting however. Well, if one can say anything was easy about it, at least the decision, in your particular situation, was more clear cut.. I'd certainly agree with your choice. However, in a person who was 67, with a psa of .7, unless there are other details that seriously increase risk ( and I know there can be), then I'd say "active surveillance" is a option to consider. If you look at the following study you might find it interesting for the select group to whom it applies. http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...porary-cohort/ Of course one is always making a bet. On the other hand, if you take 100 men age 67 just walking down the street.........and you grab them and perform biopsies randomly, you will find a substantial number have prostate cancer unknown to them. Repeat it 3 to 6 times and you may find 1 in 3 with previously undiagnosed PCa. Now we wouldn't want to operate on all of them EVEN if we knew they had cancer because we know most of them aren't going to die of it even if untreated. So there certainly is a place for "active surveillance" as John Hopkins calls it. I think watchful waiting......has gotten a bad name, as though its nothing more than "hopeful waiting".

Posts.Title: Side effects after Da Vinci Robotic Surgery!

Posts.Content: Everything you report may very well be just as you detail it and as you were probably told by a trained professional. Now having said that, You have not included some important details. Your age Your prior PSA readings (if any) and the date of each one. 5 weeks is not all that long for a inflammation of a prostate to settle down. Something like 70% of all prostatitis is nonbacterial such that antibiotics don't have anything to treat. A good deal of prostatitis is asymptomatic. You don't even know you have it. You mention a DRE finding no lumps, then you describe the prostate as "soft and mushy". You should look up the terms "boggy" and spongy as related to prostates and prostatitis. Your description sounds more like boggy than normal. BTW, who did your DRE's? I'm sure it must have been done by a urologist. Who described it as soft and mushy? Your free PSA is not all that bad. Just wondering if your two recent PSA tests gave enough time for any possible inflammation or prostatitis to calm down. That could shoot your PSA up and make it remain there for over 5 weeks. Thus, if the true PSA was far lower it could make a great deal of difference in your treatment decisions. Again, we need your history. Did your urologist have all your history and past records? If, and its a big if..... If your true PSA was only 5 or even 8 and depending on your age, with 2 of 12 cores at Gleason 6, you might opt for no treatment at all now. Just saying, there are lots of examples where PSA scores drop big time. Of course, you can't do another one any time soon after having had a biopsy. You might also give us the date of that event. So lots of possible issues. Past history, dates, past scores, your age, etc. Or it all may be just as it appears but you don't want to get on the treatment train without knowing and considering all possibilities. That is why I ask all these questions. Sort of just on the chance. Have you had anyone else read your biopsy samples? If everything is as it appears, then I guess you'll need to be making a choice of treatment given that level of PSA. But if prior PSA tests were far lower then I'd wonder what caused the sudden jump to 20+.

AgeInfo.Phrase: depending on your age  with 2 of 12 cores at Gleason

Posts.Title: PSA vs Gleason vs DRE question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by markpw2 Please help if you can! I am scheduled to have the Davinci robotic surgery performed here in So. Cal by one of the top urology surgeons in the United States in 2 months. I am told with a 0.7 psa, Gleason at 6, and stage T2a-b1 that I am a very good candidate for this "nerve sparring" procedure and in the hands of a world class surgeon my chances for any sexual dysfunction or real incontinence issues are rather small. I sure would like to believe this as I always have been a pretty active guy and still feel and think very young-I am 67 yrs. old but look a lot younger. I'm told that my doctor uses the newest Davinci "S" robot and creates 6 ports in the lower stomach region rather than 5 ports. If anyone has a similar profile and has had this procedure within the last 1 year I would sure appreciate hearing from you re:your results. Mark You need a realistic view about robotic surgery or any type. Doctors are telling too many patients what they want to hear. Especially regarding future sexual function. Their percentages and definitions are way off from what reality seems to indicate. You want a realistic discussion. Go to the New York Times IN the search box, put in prostate and Tara Parker-Pope When you find the article, read it, then read the 75+ comments. Its the August 27 article. "I am told with a 0.7 psa, Gleason at 6, and stage T2a-b1 that I am a very good candidate for this "nerve sparring" procedure and in the hands of a world class surgeon my chances for any sexual dysfunction or real incontinence issues are rather small. " This is the point at issue. I would say your chances of one of the two of those happening is 50% or greater.. Very few men say that sex is the same after surgery. The definition many doctors use is very loose. I can assure you, it is not your definition of "normal sexual function" like you have currently been experiencing and are used to. OK......I've not had the surgery. Read the NY Times article and all of the comments. It offers a more realistic picture. You need a realistic view. Doesn't mean your choice won't be the same nor that there is a 100% chance you won't be perfect, but......well, just read it. Also, how many opinions have you gotten? I do realize that some very low PSA scored prostate cancers can still be dangerous, but normally the lower score the better. They did the biopsy because of your DRE. Did the tell you the extent of the cancer, in each core they sampled? What were the percentages? How many cores were positive? Did you get the biopisies read by a second pathologist? you should. Many men your age might choose to watch the PCa and not treat it. In many men it is a valid option, even preferred in the minds of many. The name used for this can range from Watchful Waiting to Expectant Management. Even famous medical centers have programs for this option.....such as John Hopkins. Certainly not for everyone and much of the criteria depends on the patients situation. I don't know the details of your testosterone situation. Are you currently being given testosterone? All in all, sound like you've not had much time to learn about all this. You seem to be on a "fast track" for making the decision. Gosh, you said you just learned about this 3 weeks ago and you are already set for surgery. Is there something we don't know that indicates the urgency? Seems like a very fast time frame to make all these decisions when you haven't had that much time to learn. I'd give you some other links here but I think there is some rule about that. Otago

Posts.Content: Well Walt, while I can't comment specifically about the impact on prostate cancer, I think it is still very wise to approach the use of T replacement in much the same way that we do now with female HRT. For decades women were told that it was fine, even normal, to use HRT to avoid the "problems" associated with menopause. Only decades later they now tell all but a handful of women to NOT use HRT. That normal aging and the processes that go along with that are....indeed normal...and that you run into problems when you try to fool around with Mother Nature and the body's design. I think the current fad of T-therapy may well end up in the same place 10 or 20 years down the road. I think it wise for all those except for those with truly exceptional problems would be wise to approach the use with caution. Just listen to the ads... totally driven by money, not by what is best for men's health. Certainly not concerned about this GIANT experiment. It is so similar to the huge HRT binge women went on in past decades.

Posts.Content: PSA 29.1 07/14/2010---- I'm curious, what was your psa history prior to 7/14/2010 ? Was it really slow and gradual, or don't you have enough data points to know? I was just thinking if you had never had psa testing before the 29.1, then your type of cancer could be a very slowly growing type.... And if they got nearly every bit of it during the radiation, you could be starting over from a very low amount still existing.. Once again on a slow growing path that could take years to even get back to 10, let alone 20 or 29. Just a "out there" thought. Most prostate cancer untreated, grows very slowly. You didn't include your age wherein the prior test history would be relevant.
Posts.Title: seeking literature relevant to my case

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon After prostate cancer (3 years ago) when I had DiVinci followed a year later by 33 rounds of radiation, I may have another issue that I'm not ready for. While on vacation 6 weeks ago I noticed blood in urine. Just a note on the subject which may or not be similar to your situation. My father had about 33 rounds of radiation, as his cancer was already outside the capsule. That took place when he was about age 64 or 65. In later years, as he began to suffer from Alzheimers I was taking care of him for many years. He had repeated bouts of sporadic bleeding. Sometimes it would freak me out as his urine was bright red. Other time there were just drops or smaller amounts. The biggest problem his later stages was if any clots or sluffing off would block his urethra. I'm doing all this from memory, as he died of other causes at age 88, some 17 years ago. Anyway, my point about my father is that I was told by his urologists that this was a after effect of the radiation where it damaged the bladder and resulted from time to time in irritation and bleeding. Mostly was just cosmetically disturbing...more for me than him, because he was with his Alzheimers and such. Again, many bouts of bleeding but no real problems, unless it blocked up the bladder from some greater amount being sluffed off. Not sure if your bleeding has anything to do with what caused my father's bleeding. Your treatment is much closer in time than his was as I saw the bleeding. I don't know if he had bouts of bleeding 4 or 5 years after his radiation... My caring for him was more like 17 to 24 years after the radiation. The doctors told me the damage could progress with time.. However back then, radiation wasn't as refined or targeted as you probably received.

Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lumore51 One of the guys we are talking to is at Stanford, and the other isn't (but is the head of the Robotics department a a nearby hospital and a teaches for DaVinci). We will probably go see someone at UCSF as well as they also offer CyberKnife which I would like to know more about. I will post again when further questions arise and once a treatment course is established. The best known urologist at UCSF for prostate cancer is Peter Carroll. Though that may not make him the best robotic surgeon in that center. He would however give you a good sense of direction regarding surgery vs radiation of some sort, and perhaps guide you to a top notch surgeon. He is also one of the leaders in AS, but it now appears that is not one of your choices given the new MRI guided biopsy. What I find most interesting in your story is the huge difference between the two biopsies. I assume the initial biopsy was a TRUS (ultra-sound) guided 12 cores. Given the outcome of the MRI biopsy, it makes one wonder about the two methods. I looked a bit and found the following article. Seems clear that the MRI is superior, but the issue is still being debated by some. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/823847 I am curious, what or who prompted the followup MRI biopsy? Not that reality is all that pleasant in regard to possible side effects.... but it is good to see that either from your own efforts or from the doctors you and your wife have seen, that you have been made fully aware of the potential for significant side effects. Most men are not made aware of the true odds and as such there is a lot of displeasure with many doctors who don't spell it all out ahead of time. A couple of points for when you interview doctors.. surgeons in particular. When they tell you their rate of incontinence and erectile disfunction for surgical patients... something you can ask about.... make SURE you understand their definitions of each of those outcomes. What is their precise definition of incontinence? What is their precise definition of erectile disfunction? You'd be surprised at how different a patient's definition or expectation is compared to a given doctor's idea or definition. These differences often lead to post surgical disappointment if the patient has been mislead or was not given a definition. Since this is a issue with you and your wife, you can read up on it and make sure it is clear when you make your appointments. As you indicated, it can vary greatly depending on what the MRI and subsequent surgery encounter. BTW, you can often see youtube videos made by some of the doctors. I know their are several of Dr. Peter Carrol Here is one, but it is 5 years old, being interviewed in Australia. He comes off a bit stiff compared to some other interviews I've seen of him. there is Part 1 followed by Part 2. (the practice and science has changed in just 5 years, but those at UCSF are right on the cutting edge of research) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7kJYdK4i5xY I live in the EastBay and if I were not a Kaiser member, I'd probably head to UCSF. Keep asking around and I'm sure there are some top surgeons that some will suggest.. (if surgery is your choice)

Posts.Title: Surgeon reco for SF Bay Area

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Haliday What else? Oh, his prostate is 76 grams and has urination problems that are annoying but not severe. He is 65 and in excellent health. Kaiser Permanente is our provider--we live south of SF. Dr. Kwon is the diagnosing urologist who told us he has done hundreds of Da Vinci procedures. . It seems that several here are wondering if it pointless to do a radical prostatectomy. One good point about Kaiser is that the doctor and Kaiser have no financial motivation to do the procedure. However you might still get a second opinion from a couple other Kaiser doctors. One I've heard of in the past who is very experienced in Da Vinci and introduced it to Kaiser years ago, is the following doctor http://mydoctor.kaiserpermanente.org...=About+Me&to=1 Hardly seems he would want to proceed if it was highly likely the PCa was already out of the barn. I'm sure there is also a Kaiser urologist who is more specialized in going the radiation route. I'm also a Bay Area Kaiser member and as you know, you can go to any of the hundreds and hundreds of their doctors anywhere in Northern California. Don't hesitate to use anyone you discover as being the top guy in a certain treatment option. I switched urologists after finding the first guy not to my liking. They may well advise that you don't wait until 2014 for treatment given your higher PSA numbers. Most people that delay have PSA numbers under 10 or so.

Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jebby My current issue: started having trouble eliminating stool about a year ago, added fiber pills, occasional laxative with no relief, it literally feels like there is an egg about 3 or 4 inches up, some anal leakage. Had a colonoscopy last week, two polyps removed, no other issues observed. Even with colon cleansing still felt like I was holding stool in lower colon. Will recheck prostate and PSA in 30 days, if no change he wants to discuss surgical options. I asked him about possibility of prostate causing bowel blockage and he declined, said it was more likely for colon to "aggravate" prostate but not the reverse??? I am not having issues urinating but emptying my bowels. Wow, so many issues going on. I'd pay attention to the theme your doctor mentioned..."more likely for colon to "aggravate" prostate but not the reverse" You wrote some troubling points... " added fiber pills, occasional laxative with no relief," When I see stuff like that, all kinds of alarm bells go off. Anything could be the case, but sounds like you are trying to treat a dietary problem with pills and laxatives instead of a complete revamping of your diet.. Meaning treating it with real food instead of something squeezed into a pill. Again, there are people who can have digestive, intestinal, and colon problems even when eating properly, however for most people the problem begins with their long term diet. After that is corrected... THEN you go to the meds, pills, and such. You mention "diverticulosis lead to 12" of colon being removed 3.5 years ago" So the question is... in the past 3.5 years, after surgery, how radical of a change did you make in your eating habits? Did you completely change the foods you had been eating during the decades prior to your surgery, or did you just make minor changes, hoping you had removed the troublesome colon section? Now, as I said, sometimes even on the best diets, some folks have problems, but with experimentation many find they can greatly improve their digestive and elimination problems. And as your doctor suggested, those problems may be causing your prostate symptoms. You might cure both with a radical alteration in your eating. So... what type of diet do you follow? Typical Georgia diet, or something else? How many grams of fiber (from food, not pills) do you consume in a day? What portion of your diet is from vegetables, fruits, whole grains, in their natural form. How many grams of sugar do you consume in a day.. How much meat and dairy? Oils, fried foods.. And on and on. I'm suspicious that someone who took fiber pills is not a person who focused their dietary change on natural whole foods that contain large amounts of fiber without pills. So what is up... Any really significant dietary changes you have made over the past 3.5 years? Give us a rundown of what your daily eating is like. Seems with all your problems and worries "down there" that you would be highly motivated. I'm not one of those who says diet will cure or prevent all prostate cancer, but your doc seems to think your problems and symptoms are related to your digestive and elimination problems.
Posts.Title: Sorry for long post but.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I wish they never invented the PSA test. I know it sounds selfish of me and I'm sure it's help a lot of guys, but for me it’s been nothing but a nerve racking, anxiety ordeal. My journey started with a physical in Dec 2012 where the PSA was 5.9, up from 2.2. Now 3 years later I’ve had two biopsies and many PSA test, my last test number taken this week was 2.8. All the PSA test I’ve had have been below 5.9. If I had of just skip that physical in 2012, look at all the trouble free days and weeks I could have spent. I'm not certain your problem was caused by your PSA but rather by the doctor feeling something during your DRE that prompted him to do a biopsy. I don't see all your numbers, but aside from feeling something abnormal, I would never tell anyone to get a biopsy based on a single jump from under 3 to 5.9 or so. In such a case, you simply wait 3 or 6 months and retest. But if something significant is felt, then a biopsy may be the appropriate course. However, after that has been examined, then I'd not get another biopsy unless something unusual and constant occurs with PSA.

Posts.Title: I wish they never invented the PSA test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Newbury6 Hello We i was diagnosed with Prostate cancer in February this year which obviously was a shock with a Gleason score 3+3=6 I considered my options of treatment, and was advised that as i am only 43 years old and had a low PSA of 1.4 that the best option is to treat it as aggressively as possible by the two opinions i received from different doctor.. Paul, your subject title "Due to have Radical Prostatectomy in 2 weeks" You were only diagnosed in February... Perhaps 12 weeks later you are going in for surgery even though you have a psa of 1.4 and Gleason 6. (in a unmentioned number of cores... and unmentioned percentage of each positive core) Perhaps you'll update us on the details that might be forcing you to rush into surgery before you have learned much about this entire subject of prostate cancer. Who gave you the initial opinion? Who gave you the second opinion? What is their background? Did they both stress the need to rush this surgery? Are they both surgeons? If so, how many robotic surgeries have they done.....and how many do they do each month? There are lots of questions you need to answer for your own well being and from what I can now see, there is absolutely no reason at all to rush ahead with surgery in only 2 weeks. Give us some more information. You seem confused and making decisions under unwarranted fearful pressures. BTW, what prompted the doctor to initially take a biopsy? Did he feel something when he did the DRE, digital exam, or was it only done based on your psa test? PS... Did you have a second expert read the biopsy samples to make sure the Gleason 6 was actually a Gleason 6.. and how many cores were positive and what percent of each positive core was involved? Read this http://www.cancernews.com/data/Article/701.asp

Posts.Title: Due to have Radical Prostatectomy in 2 weeks

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I wish they never invented the PSA test. I know it sounds selfish of me and I'm sure it's help a lot of guys, but for me it’s been nothing but a nerve racking, anxiety ordeal. My journey started with a physical in Dec 2012 where the PSA was 5.9, up from 2.2. Now 3 years later I’ve had two biopsies and many PSA test, my last test number taken this week was 2.8. All the PSA test I’ve had have been below 5.9. If I had of just skip that physical in 2012, look at all the trouble free days and weeks I could have spent. I'm not certain your problem was caused by your PSA but rather by the doctor feeling something during your DRE that prompted him to do a biopsy. I don't see all your numbers, but aside from feeling something abnormal, I would never tell anyone to get a biopsy based on a single jump from under 3 to 5.9 or so. In such a case, you simply wait 3 or 6 months and retest. But if something significant is felt, then a biopsy may be the appropriate course. However, after that has been examined, then I'd not get another biopsy unless something unusual and constant occurs with PSA.

Posts.Title: I wish they never invented the PSA test

Posts.Content: Just in the last few days I've been hearing ads on the radio featuring Joe Torre (former Yankees coach) Years ago, he was in the news because of his diagnosis and surgery for prostate cancer. Now he is the spokesperson for a new genomic test and the theme of the commercial is that many men can do AS more safely with the test. I had not heard much about such a test. Has anyone here been offered that test by their doctor? Here is where the ad tells you to look http://www.myprostatecancertreatment...n#.VBhquvldWSp which leads to here http://www.myprostatecancertreatment...x#.VBhq1fldWSp Here is the company http://www.genomichealth.com/en-US/C...x#.VBhpH_ldWSp I don't know much about the accuracy of such a test, but was surprised to hear the ad played many times on local radio. Since the company stock has not shot up through the roof, I can only assume the test isn't the miracle answer we've all been waiting for to know if we'd be safe to do AS.
Posts.Title: Interesting radio ads by Joe Torre, regarding AS

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo I can see doing this if a biopsy (and a second opinion) found a small amount of G6. If a biopsy found G7 or above, then is anyone suggesting this is an option? Here is what the site says Is your prostate cancer considered low risk or intermediate risk by the following criteria? (You must be able to meet ALL of the requirements.) Gleason Score of 6 or less OR tumor involvement should be less than or equal to 33% if you have a Gleason Score of 7 (3+4) PSA score less than 20 Tumor stage of T1 or T2 So they include what they call, low to intermediate risk men as "candidates" for the test. Of course after discussing it with your doctor.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut The recumbent bike is an easy solution to this problem......as would be simply switching to other forms of aerobic exercise. Or simply doing shorter, but more vigorous rides. You can get all the cardio you need in three 35 to 45 minute rides each week. I do 3 x 45 with about 15 minutes of each ride "out of the saddle" standing up. Thus only 30 minutes each ride on a nice saddle. Or even two such rides, with jogging on two other days. No need to stop riding. Recumbents are OK, unless you live in all hills like I do. They are so slow going up hill. Besides, aren't all recumbent riders kind of strange... nerdy with beards? Often reading text books at rest stops ...
Posts.Title: Cycling and prostate cancer in men over 50

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo I assumed it meant "7 out of 10". You may be correct, but "7 out of 10" what? Slices, samples, ?? Perhaps someone else knows. I once had a girlfriend, very skilled, who worked in a lab and she would slice up the samples for later viewing under the microscope by the pathologist. Perhaps they sliced up thin samples to be place on slides and had 10 samples, 7 of which included the Gleason 4+3 sections.
Posts.Title: My Final Pathologic Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wheelar Decided to proceed with biopsy, had it done in late July. Result was 1 core positive for PC, right apex, 15% involved, Gleason 4 + 4. Doctors --- also recommended re-reading the biopsy slides at another lab. Re-read of slides came back as Gleason 3 + 4, which was encouraging for me. Also got the good news that the final pathology report was Gleason 3 + 3! Good to see you've come out the other side and are on your way healing. Apparently you're going to be around until your mid 80's or 90's given your father and grandfather. Your case is a good example of getting a second doctor or institution to look at the biopsy samples. Shows its more a art of reading them than a exact science.

Posts.Title: Interesting radio ads by Joe Torre, regarding AS

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Hi Nicnic: Welcome to the forum. Sorry any of us have to be here. After reading your post, my first reaction is to tell you to calm down. With a Gleason score of 6, nothing is going to happen overnight to you. Also, that one-month jump in your PSA from 6.3 to 9.7 seems suspect. It may simply be an inflammation or infection. Can you give us more info about your biopsy, specifically the number of cores that tested positive and the percentage of involvement? I agree, the the PSA jump from 6.3 to 9.7 in one month is more likely to be from something other than prostate cancer. It actually calls into question whether even the 6.3 is the true PSA level. Past PSA scores would be useful, along with dates. It is not impossible that the true normal PSA might be down below 5 or even 4 and that both the 6.3 and 9.7 are part of a inflammatory spell. At some point down the road, I'd probably get another PSA test, even if I had already decided on a treatment. I'd just like to know the true nature of the situation as I proceeded. Having a PSA of 5 vs 10 would be useful to know about even if you were going to do surgery. So, there still is the Gleason 6. Having another doctor read those slides might be advisable. See if they both agree.
Posts.Title: Confuzed

Posts.Content: Interesting article http://newsok.com/study-says-prolong...e/feed/733081d From age 50 to 59 I used to ride from 80 to 120 miles a week. Now I take about 3 rides a week ...each a very vigorous 45 minutes of all hills. Much of the time is spent out of the saddle (standing up on all the hills).' Total miles a week now, about 35. I think my briefer rides are ideal for my cardio and prostate health. I didn't make the change because of my prostate, but I have thought about it. I always have made it a point to lay off the cycling for about 5 days prior to getting a psa test. (btw, I still have my prostate)

Posts.Title: Different Results from Different Labs

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut If we're talking about image instead of health, I've gotten old enough that I just don't care how cool I look. Yes, growing older has some advantages. I cared much more about the first 5,000 hairs I lost than the last 5,000, even though most people probably didn't notice the first group. I did develop a hair loss rule. Do not comb-over any hair below the 45 degree tangent. (with 90 degrees being straight up and 0 degrees being horizontal) ©
Posts.Title: Cycling and prostate cancer in men over 50

Posts.Content: Rick, I thought the article was great. I know there was more, but for a local paper I thought it was extensive. I also liked the entire format with you and your wife, as well as your emphasis on having men take a second and third look at the alternatives. So often, in fact most of the time, men are all charged up on "getting it out". Study after study indicates that they don't get the full message with the full data from their doctors. Either that, or they only hear the good news data. Doctor's bright out look and their interpretation of what constitutes a excellent outcome often doesn't match up with patients expectations regarding lingering side effects of surgery. Most of the other articles you see around Prostate Cancer Awareness Month are just a few short quotes from a local urologist who gives out all the standard sanitized answers. BTW, your book seems to be getting good reviews.

Posts.Title: Confuzed

Posts.Content: Lots of questions and you have lots of issues happening at the same time. So, from what I understand, you'll be seeing the urologist soon. Perhaps he can narrow down the problem to any of the three or more issues you mention. Prostatitis, prostate, kidney, bladder, hemorrhoid, or fissure. I'm not sure a PSA done in conjunction with that appointment will offer any solid results. You have so many issues going on which could easily bump up your PSA score at this time. The main one being prostatitis, which even if due to some infection can still take weeks or more to calm down. Often still producing inflammation even when you don't feel it. Sub acute. That plus your possible sexual activity and bike riding all adding up to a PSA testing that could easily have bumped your PSA to 2.14 See what he says, but you'd probably get a more accurate reading during your January exam. While your wife may have been a oncology nurse, she may know very little about the issues that can bump up a normal PSA to where yours was, still only slightly higher than "normal". Don' lose any sleep over that prior test result. ESPECIALLY in light of what you went in for, prostatitis. That could so easily bring you up from .8 or 1.0 to a 2.14 reading, not even counting the sex. See what the urologist says. BTW, if you still have some prostatitis, he can feel it when he does the DRE. Let us know what happens. Your post is very appropriate.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GeneShue Dietary changes: Turmeric Curcumin 1000 mg 2x/day Just a note--- the bottles of Tumeric Curcumin can often be very misleading. You have to be looking for the 95% curcuminoid extract... Lot of products will have 1000 mg but 900 of the mg is just Turmeric which has a very low concentration. Also to get the advertised amount you often have to take 2 or 3 pills a day. Its fair to say that VAST majority of the products being sold as containing Turmeric Curcumin are bogus... in that they the biggest component is the non-extract type of curcumin.... tumeric curcumin. Blow up some of the labels on Amazon and you'll see what I mean. The #1 Best Seller on Amazon is such a bogus product... in the the most important ingredient only makes up 150 mg of the claimed 1,500 mg Even the product that gets the "Amazon's Choice" designation is a bogus and misleading product.. Again, made up of the non-concentrated plain root. Read the labels very very carefully or you will just be throwing your money down the drain.
Posts.Title: Throwing the "Kitchen Sink" at Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GlenBLK The PSA was done after the symptoms started and not at their worst by the colonoscopist. The urologist a week later checked my tubes and said they were slightly inflamed but did not do a DRE but I had my PSA done again. I went back a month later and after hearing the antibiotics had not cleared my symptoms the urologist suggested the TRUS. . Glen, you sound terribly confused about the situation. Your posts, if they can be understood, indicate you have not had a DRE. I find it almost impossible to believe that a urologist examined you, and indicated to you that he might do a biopsy and yet he had not yet done a simple DRE. You also failed to indicate what your second PSA is. Though I'm not sure it will be meaningful if you are still suffering from a inflamed prostate. Personally if I was you, I'd slow the entire procedure down before I'd let them do a biopsy. You need to learn more about your particular situation. Either you were not told the facts or you don't fully understand them, or you are mistaken. What was your second PSA? As others have indicated, infections or inflammations can take some time to calm down. Not all of them are bacterial based and as such do not respond to antibiotics. Figure out if you did or did not already have a DRE done by the urologist. This is no small matter. BTW, before the last PSA, was any exam preformed that same day, prior to drawing the blood? For that matter what was done, if anything, on the day they took blood for the first PSA? Also what is your complete history of PSA's. Sounds like you have had 2 done, but we've only heard the results of the first one, right? Getting a biopsy is not something you want to do, like getting a simple test, unless it is really called for. And I'm not saying that just because of the pain and possible infection.
Posts.Title: I have to have a DRE!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Baz10 Prostatitis is definately ruled out as my doc said when I questioned him on this, he said and I quote "If it was prostatitis when I pressed on your prostate you would have jumped off the couch". I absolutely disagree with that opinion. For two reasons. I've had prostatitis (a inflamation) where I not only didn't jump upon getting a DRE, but I had no symptoms whatsoever. It is called "asymptomatic prostatitis" in the medical literature. It can raise you PSA far more than a single point. In my case I've had it jump up to 7.4 and later drop back to 3.8 Your 5.1 is nothing much at all if one had a small inflammation that you were completely unaware of. Originally Posted by Baz10 He also ruled out any increases after the other 2 DRE's I've had in the last 2 weeks. I'd like to know more about the timing of the DRE relative to the blood draw. All in all I wouldn't give much thought to the 5.1 Your next test could be back under 4.0 and that drop is very very very common. Test again in perhaps 6 months. By all means, don't have a biopsy based on that one 5.1 test. My psa goes up and down that much on a regular basis.

Posts.Title: Second Opinion - Dr. Epstein

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GlenBLK My PSA the Urologist said was marginally high at 2.4 Naturally I am worried and want to ask others who have been through all this if their prostate flared up and went down with prostate cancer? My symptoms are some mild burning on the tip and I did have a very sore inflamed prostate in March and could not sit down. I have had aching testicles and tubes with some occasional pain. I had Cipro and things eased off then it flared up again but not as bad as it was in the 1st place. Then I was prescribed trimethoprim for a month in my tubes on the left testicle were aching again. I still have the burning on the tip. Feeling worried I am 41 based in the UK my ultrasound is a month should I ask for one sooner? I had a colonoscopy and that specialist said my prostate felt inflamed. . Your 2.4 PSA result. Was that PSA test taken before, during, or soon after you had all these symptoms? Because if it was during all of that, including when your prostate was probed and felt as inflamed, then its no wonder it might be a bit high for someone your age. Nothing is impossible, but none of your symptoms seem to indicate prostate cancer. More like prostatitis which can have many or unknown causes. Doesn't seem like anyone would be giving you a biopsy from what you've described. I certainly don't think you need to get the ultrasound any sooner from the point of view specifically regarding prostate cancer concerns. By the way, your subject title is "I have to have a DRE" Your post seems to indicate you've already had a DRE. When the colonoscopy was done, that specialist felt your prostate. That is a DRE and commonly done during a colonoscopy. Also seems if you saw a urologist that it would also have been one of the first things he would have done. If I was you, I'd not be too worried for the next month about prostate cancer because of what you've told us thus far.

Posts.Content: Get the PSA result. Then find out what the PSA history of your 4 brothers was including the age at which each PSA was taken. Also their PSA at the time they had their biopsy that discovered cancer. Compare everything with your current age etc. Put your own PSA result in that context and decide if a biopsy is indicated even if you have a reasonably low PSA score. A father and 4 brothers is quite a family history. You should also try to learn about their Gleason Scores and final post surgery pathology (if they chose surgery). Your father and brothers, how have they done since diagnosis?
Posts.Title: PSA or Biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Rekon Anyways, I need to find out what does that 1.7 means. Any help will be appreciated. Thank You As everyone says, depending on your age, which we don't know, you seem to be fine for now. However, you have a unusual family history. 4 of 5 brothers and a father with prostate cancer. As I indicated before, you should really ask your brothers what led to the discovery of their cancer. What put the biopsy in motion. Was it a high psa test? If so, how high were their psa results at that time. What was their age at that time. What was the final pathology after surgery? I can't imagine having a family history such as you have and not being aware of your brothers history and facts. Time for you to learn about each one. Then you can see if and when your psa pattern arrives in a similar territory. No rush, but follow up on that task, then come back here if you like and let folks see what they think. BTW, you should have that information available for your doctor. Plainly put, I'd say your odds of following in your brother's and father's footsteps is eventually fairly significant. But there are always genetic differences and you end up with the "other genes".

I find it almost impossible to believe that a urologist examined you, and indicated to you that he might do a biopsy and yet he had not yet done a simple DRE. You also failed to indicate what your second PSA is. Though I'm not sure it will be meaningful if you are still suffering from a inflamed prostate. Personally if I was you, I'd slow the entire procedure down before I'd let them do a biopsy. You need to learn more about your particular situation. Either you were not told the facts or you don't fully understand them, or you are mistaken. What was your second PSA? As others have indicated, infections or inflammations can take some time to calm down. Not all of them are bacterial based and as such do not respond to antibiotics. Figure out if you did or did not already have a DRE done by the urologist. This is no small matter. BTW, before the last PSA, was any exam preformed that same day, prior to drawing the blood? For that matter what was done, if anything, on the day they took blood for the first PSA? Also what is your complete history of PSA's. Sounds like you have had 2 done, but we've only heard the results of the first one, right? Getting a biopsy is not something you want to do, like getting a simple test, unless it is really called for. And I'm not saying that just because of the pain and possible infection.
Posts.Title: I have to have a DRE!

Posts.Title: Radical Questions

Posts.Content: I think the following study was just released. For those with Gleason 7 and PSA under 10... or Gleason 6 and PSA under 20 As it is indicated as "intermediate risk", I assume those who were included in the study were not "low-risk" Gleason 6. Not sure, but I assume all Gleason 7's (4+3 and 3+4) with PSA under 10 were included in the group. One would have to read the study to see if the sub-sets were separated. For example, dividing the 4+3 and 3+4 Gleason 7's. Or the Gleason 6 psa 10s from the psa 19's Compares brachytherapy + additional external-beam radiation to only having brachytherapy alone. Median follow-up for all patients was 6.7 years, and a total of 579 patients Progression-free survival was 85% and 86% for the two groups. Note, that is not the survival rate. From what I understand, until now, the dual therapy was the standard for such men. Lots of articles on the study if you Google it. Here are two http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/869473 http://www.healio.com/hematology-onc...rostate-cancer
Posts.Title: Intermediate-Risk Prostate Cancer, Brachy+RT vs Brachy alone. New study

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Webheadfred This past December, my PSA was 4.34 and my DRE was still considered normal. The urologist asked me to come back in March. I've just received my latest PSA, 4.32. The urologist recommended that I have a biopsy. I am scheduled for another Dr appointment in June and I thought I'd wait till then for yet another PSA. I have no adverse symptoms. So, am I being stupid to want to wait a little longer for a biopsy? Even if the next one is within normal range, should I have one anyway? Damn it there is just so much conflicting information. Fred, don't get rushed into getting a biopsy. You'll do just fine by getting another PSA test in June. It will give you a clearer picture of any trend. Very possibly it will drop down. It could drop down to 2.2 which would then take you out of the need for a biopsy. Don't get alarmed. Have you and your wife take a look and listen to this video done by two well known experts. Watch it twice and relax for a few months, then retest. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 It was good that your doctor waited 3 months for another psa. It was almost identical to the prior result. My psa was 0.8 at age 51. I didn't test again until age 56 when it was 2.6... Now I am 64 and my last test was 3.8.... but I have had test results of 5.5 and 7.4 in the interim. I'd get that third score before I'd do a biopsy. There isn't much risk in waiting 3 months. Not zero risk, but neither is driving to the grocery store in your car. I have not read anything connecting melanoma and prostate cancer risk, but you might search it.

didn't test again until age 56 when it was 2 6
2 6    Now I am 64 and my last test was

Posts.Title: Well... I suppose I need your advice.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ThatBiopsyHurt What's there to lose by not getting a biopsy except your life? Right, I suppose if you have 1,000 guys in Fred's position and they all delay their biopsy until their June appointment, then you might have 1 person in whom the delay might have caused a earlier death due to catching the prostate cancer 3 months later. Earlier treatment does not always mean better treatment or more effective treatment. Its all a matter of odds. I'd say if Fred gets another 4.3 psa then we can assume that is the true picture. Not everyone caught early is helped and not everyone caught later is harmed. His wanting to do another test in June is not unreasonable nor particularly dangerous.
Posts.Title: Well... I suppose I need your advice.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ThatBiopsyHurt Absolutely correct. Well, unless he's that one guy who has some of that agressive, low PSA cancer and it leaves the capsule in May. Yes, our actions and fears should be based on that one guy. That indeed is how much of medicine is run. On the other hand, for every guy like that guy who waited too long, there are dozens more who think nothing of delaying a change in their diet that could forestall a heart attack or stroke. For some reason we tend to treat cancer in a particularly frightful way, yet many times more men will die from heart disease and strokes. Little urgency by comparison. I think Fred will do just fine what ever decision he makes. By way of disclosure, I did have a biopsy at one point several years ago. No positive cores, but I'm sure if I did 3 more biopsies, one of them would for sure find a Gleason 6. But I'm not in any rush to find it as long as my PSA stays steady with only the occasional jump up to 6 or 7 as has been the case in the past. Matter of fact I have a standing order to take my PSA now. We shall see if its 3.7 or 7.7. In either case, should it jump up to 7, I'll wait 4 to 6 months to retest before doing another biopsy.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Alan55 . Has anyone else seen a jump of 70% in their PSA in 6 months and is it likely to be indicative or an aggressive cancer or more likely to be prostatitis or some other issue? Yes, I have had several jumps of 70%, though starting from a lower base level. (3.8 to 7.5) Since both your 14.9 and 15.0 readings were so very close together, it is very much more indicative of a inflammation of some sort. Though its hard to tell why your other readings were already at 9. You seem to have something going on, but I'm told that protatitis in some individuals can be extremely difficult to resolve even over extended periods of time.
