Posts.Content: If I was on AS I would also consider taking a statin, such as generic Lipitor known as atorvastatin. Has side effects in some men, but I don't know of any sexual side effects. You don't need to take high dose I have been given atorvastatin as a matter of my regular care, quite apart from anything to do with possible prostate cancer. I had heard it could lower your PSA and after normally being at about 3.8, after two months, it dropped to 3.3 I was still skeptical but then 12 months later, it dropped to 2.8 That new lower level is not by chance. Does not mean you won't get prostate cancer, but there are several studies suggesting it may lower the aggressiveness of that cancer and/or prevent death in many. Take a look at this article http://www.pcf.org/site/c.leJRIROrEp...ate_Cancer.htm I'm surprise the use of statins is not talked about more in men with early prostate cancer. As a normal course of taking such, you will also gain some degree of protection from future heart disease, which of course, kills more men who have prostate cancer, than the actual cancer does.
Posts.Title: Proscar for Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by goatts Met with doctor following biopsy on Thursday. Going for bone scan and MRI next Friday. My doctor is a Urogynecologist. He referred me to another doctor who is a urologist and was his university professor to read the scans when they're done. The more I think about this the more I get nervous. Is this standard practice or does he expect the worst by referring me to someone more experienced? He was also discussing debulking and we don't even know for sure that it's spread yet. . It seems you may be headed for surgery. If so, be careful who is doing it. I certainly would be skeptical of a urogynocologist doing such a procedure. Of course that may not be the case since he seems open to sending you elsewhere.
Posts.Title: Met with Doctor following Biopsy showing Gleason 7 - Question #2 - about Referral

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dmm1987 My father has been on hormone therapy for about 1 year and his PSA is now a 0. I think at one point he mentioned his PSA was an 8 when he started the hormone therapy. The doctor doing the surgery also advised my father to do radiation after he has healed from surgery because of the aggressiveness. . Oh this fact about being 1 year on hormone therapy makes this case different. I think anyone commenting here would wonder why he was placed on hormone therapy a year ago. Sounds like at that time, one year ago, he was already diagnosed with prostate cancer. Or was he on hormone therapy for some other reason. Lots of facts here we don't know about. None of that changes his ability to make it through surgery safely. If his psa was 8 then it appears that the chances of his prostate cancer being organ confined are 50% or less. According to the Partin tables. Remembering that those calculations are only probabilities for groups of similar men. http://urology.jhu.edu/prostate/partintables.php His doctor may have other information, however it sounds like he realizes there is a substantial chance of it being outside the prostate. Thus the radiation following the surgery. It could be why he is undergoing a year of hormone treatment. But we know so few of the actual facts so we are only guessing. Again, I hope he is getting the opinion of more than one doctor. Perhaps another doctor would suggest doing only the radiation without surgery. I don't know. Different doctors are very keen on doing their own type of treatment.
Posts.Title: Death rate while undergoing the robatic assisted prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: The only real concern about dying while on the operating table has to do with your fathers age and health. It has nothing to do with his Gleason score. He is just as safe as he would be with a 3+3 Gleason 6. Now, if he is older and has underlying heart problems, then as with any surgery, there is always some risk. But at this point I'd bet any chance of a dying on the table are very small. Even tiny. However, assuming he is not suffering from any substantial and dangerous conditions, your focus should be on whether surgery is the best course. I don't understand how your doctor can say "it is just in the prostate". He may think that, or hope that, but he has no way of knowing for sure. You didn't mention his PSA score, or his age, or his past PSA history. You also need to know how many of his biopsy samples were positive and what percent of each contained cancer. (something like 5 samples out of 12, with 2 being Gleason 8, involving 30% and 40% of the respective samples.) How many other opinions has he received suggesting that surgery is the best choice and what do they say the chances are that all the cancer is confined to the prostate? He really needs to get at least one opinion from someone who doesn't think surgery is the best route. However if everyone agrees surgery is best then he needs to get a surgeon who has done hundreds, or even a thousand surgeries, and who does them on a regular basis, not just 1 or 2 a month. See the following site http://urology.jhu.edu/prostate/partintables.php Then put in your dad's numbers. The point being you don't want to do surgery if its already outside the prostate.

Verified April 2013 by Johns Hopkins University http://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT01718704 Estimated Enrollment: 50 Study Start Date: March 2013 Estimated Study Completion Date: August 2013 Estimated Primary Completion Date: June 2013 (Final data collection date for primary outcome measure)
Posts.Title: Viberect

Posts.Content: What has your doctor said about it? Of course he has tested your urine for all the possible non PCa treatment related type causes. Any differences in what you drink or eat that make it better or worse?
Posts.Title: Any Medication for Urgency & Frequency?

Posts.Content: Not to complicate matters more, but I wonder if day of week, and time of day, don't factor into outcomes. I'd tend to think that the first surgery on Monday morning... perhaps beginning at 8:30 AM may not be the best. As might be the case of the last surgery on Friday afternoon, after two other surgeries that same day. Of course, I don't know what the optimal day or time would be. Not sure where you would access such information, particularly for each doctor. Just don't think I'd like to be patient #1 on Monday at 8:00 AM, following the Superbowl. Perhaps this article answers some of my questions http://medcitynews.com/2012/09/study...ome-surgeries/
Posts.Title: Potential Surgeon List

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ezzo Im just worried that my prostrate has enlarged intially in the firstplace due to cancer or is this not possible?. I had a DRE and the doctor says my prostrate is on the larger side at 41cc. Im worried that it could be cancer otherwise why would i be getting sent for a PSA. Is there another reason they want a PSA done? Im also having a cystoscopy done in 6 weeks You have a lot of things going on. You are jumping to conclusions. From what you indicated your doctor "estimated" your prostate size only from the DRE. That is not a very accurate method. I would caution you not to get too worried even if your PSA number comes in a bit high for your age. You are taking that blood draw only a few weeks after all this stuff has been going on. It would seem that some of the recent events could impact your prostate and not give it enough time to calm down any "itis" inflammation. So if the reading comes in high, you should wait some time, month or months to confirm any high number. Also your prostate is enlarged which gives a higher number. (oh and don't have any sex in the few days leading up to the PSA blood draw as it could raise your PSA score) Did they tell you why they also are going to do a cystoscopy?
Posts.Title: worried, please help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Arthro92 My urologist called me today. I DO NOT HAVE PROSTATE CANCER!!!!!!!! He says what I have is asymptomatic prostatitis. My uro believes that is the reason for the elevated PSA. I am so thankful! I am THANKFUL to all of you for your soothing, comforting, encouraging words. I am so THANKFUL to all of you, for all the things you taught me about prostate cancer. Saying thank you feels like it's not enough, but PLEASE know how grateful I am to all of you who helped me during this scary journey. . Great news. I'm sure it is a huge relief. Now, having said that, I must repost a portion of what I said in my prior post to your first thread. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- "Well, its too late for my advice, but unless there are other facts, this is absolute madness." "How about simply waiting 3 more months and retesting the PSA... Again, perhaps there is something here that is not mentioned, but reacting to every raised PSA result with a biopsy is madness. Easily, very very easily, the PSA could be over 5 due to simple infection, even a asymptomatic infection or other inflammation that isn't even caused by bacteria." ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Too many biopsies are being done for simple rises in PSA scores that are temporary. Seldom is it dangerous to wait a few months and retest.
Posts.Title: The Results of My Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tomnan24 Hi all. I will not be 65 til next May. I do not currently have any insurance. Any thoughts about waiting til next year? . Where do you live? Do you live in the USA? If so, do you realize that Obamacare kicks in January 1st, 2014. There would be no reason to wait until you turn 65 in May. Pre-existing conditions will no longer apply. Enrollment begins October 1st. Depending on your state, or "exchange" you will be able to get a insurance policy that will cover most of the costs. Your monthly premium will be fairly low considering you'll be needing immediate treatment. BTW, the examples of getting seeds for $3,500. I have considerable doubts about anything close to that when all costs are considered. More like many times that amount, but I'm open for someone who can show complete cost appointments, seeds, and followup, for less than $20,000. Perhaps you could get the shot, then wait the 6 months for Obamacare. Cutting off 5 months from May. Look, from what I understand, even if your birthday is May 31st, you get Medicare beginning May 1st. So my idea about using Obamacare, would cut off 4 full months from that Medicare timeline. Right now, you'd probably be waiting until at least August 1st for seeds or other treatment. Waiting for Obamacare would be an additional 5 months, possibly 6 months, since they couldn't treat you January 1st. Or wait until May 1st, or possibly June 1st on Medicare, to be seen and then scheduled for a procedure. Possibly you could, with a few visits and planning, set things up prior to Obamacare kicking in. Thus saving a month or more. Given your circumstances, perhaps you could shop around or bargain, plead, and get that shot down to perhaps $2,000 or less to span those 5 or 6 months. Again, what state do you live in. Do you know all about the new exchanges in your state? You must investigate that. You don't live in California, do you? One last point. Those 8 of 12 biopsy cores. Do you know what percentage of each. (like 5% or 25% or 80% of each one) You know, lots of people wait at least half that time, even when they are insured. Meaning they get diagnosed, and take about 3 months prior to any treatment. If you planned it right, on Obamacare, you'd only be about 6 months out, or 3 months extra. Odds are it would make little difference. Odds are even waiting until Medicare wouldn't change your outcome. You have several choices. You are only a few weeks into this whole process. There is less rush than you initially perceive. That prostate cancer has been growing in you for easily 10 years. Perhaps 15 or 20 years. There is a fair chance if you never treated it at all, it wouldn't kill you. BTW, what is the rest of your health like. Weight, cardiovascular, diabetes, cholesterol, heart function, high blood pressure, anything else? Above all, you don't need a full decision before the end of July, so take some time. Explore the hormone shot path as a intermediate step. Side effects, effectiveness, etc. From what I recall, many men are given such a shot, and told to wait, so that doing seeds for example is easier and more effective. Obviously that is a normal option even in those who proceed normally without any insurance considerations. Just think, only a couple months ago, you were "normal" and there was no rush for anything. Chances are, there is still no rush. But you won't get many doctors to say that, because if they do so for 50 guys, in one case they may be wrong. They always err way on the side of caution.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> I will not be 65 til next May <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Wait til next year?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mitchden I just received a second opinion Interpretation and Diagnostic report from Dr. Epstein from John Hopkins. He doesn't agree with the "local" pathologist biopsy which confirmed Gleason 7 (3+4). He said the following: "insufficient cytologic and/or architectural atypia to establish a definitive diagnosis. Follow up is warranted with serum or urine tests, imaging and, in some cases, repeat biopsy with relative increased sampling of the atypical site may be recommended." Do you think I should get a third opinion or is Dr. Epstein the best? Thanks. Wow, you didn't just drop from a Gleason 7 to a Gleason 6, you dropped from having cancer to not having cancer. A good lesson for folks to see... Especially since your original diagnosis was based on such a tiny percentage of cancer. I'll bet out there, 90% of men would have just taken the first reading as fact.. and their urologist would not have recommended a second opinion. Then most would have been scheduled for treatment...surgery. NO, I would not get a third opinion. Just do what Epstein recommended... You are back to "normal"...
Posts.Title: Pathologist Report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ezzo Could you shed any light on why I havent been given a final diagnosis? If i knew for sure that it was BPH then i would be happy to manage my lifestyle around it but all this talk of PSA cancer tests has really upset me and made the whole thing seem very serious, makes me cry with worry. If its just an enlarged prostrate due to ageing (im 43) then why test for cancer? Final diagnosis? You told us they were going to do a cystoscopy in 6 weeks. They've got everything working, but I imagine its routine to do a look inside to see if everything is fine. Goodness you were just in the hospital for 5 days. That was a EVENT. That they are waiting 6 weeks sound like its routine, to make sure. Then you'll get your "final diagnosis" as to what caused your extreme problem and hospitalization. The PSA is just a side issue. Loads of people get a routine baseline PSA test in their 40's, even when they've gone through nothing like you have. That is nothing to get concerned about. You are putting too much into getting that test. When they get you into their office and care, they check everything in that area that might have anything to do with anything. Ending that investigation by doing the cystoscopy. You seem incorrectly to be thinking the doctor felt or saw something. All he said was your prostate was enlarged. "all this talk of PSA cancer tests has really upset me and made the whole thing seem very serious" Who, other than you, is talking about prostate cancer? Did the doctor suggest he suspects prostate cancer? If you come to a prostate cancer forum and ask about prostate cancer then for sure you're going to get the entire range of possibilities, but unless your doctor said something, then all the talk here means nothing about it being probable any more than it would be in any guy with a larger prostate. Which is not very probable. But you can worry for 2 weeks. Get the test, then come back with the results.

AgeInfo.Phrase: prostrate due to ageing  im 43  then why test for cancer

Posts.Title: worried, please help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jimbo58 Hi I'm in Sacramento ca area just getting started on this. Looking for a urologist is my area next. Dre normal first ever psa 5.9. Kinda overwhelmed with info right now. Thanks Was the DRE done within the 24 hours prior to the blood draw for your PSA? That alone can affect the test. Lots of reasons a PSA can be higher than normal. I've had readings of 5.5 and 7.5 over the past years. My last one was 3.3 No prostate cancer thus far. Don't make assumptions based on one test. A wise urologist would NOT immediately schedule you for a biopsy. He would wait 3 to 6 months and retest. You can have asymptomatic inflammation and not even be aware of it. And it can't be cured in a few weeks with anti-biotics, as it is not bacterial. Don't get rushed/pushed into a early biopsy.
Posts.Title: Hello new member first test ever 5.9 at age 58.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blank 3500$ was a guess based on looking at my bills but there is little doubt it is the cheapest of all procedures I am aware of. I have no idea where your procedure and associated treatment were performed. Look at this, from 2002, over eleven years ago, from the Journal of Urology. "RESULTS: (USBT = brachytherapy) The mean total charges for USBT ($26,320) and RP ($22,660) were not significantly different. Compared with RP, USBT incurred significantly lower operating room time cost ($628 for USBT versus (2093 for RP, P <0.05). The average cost of seeds for USBT was $6184, which resulted in higher technical costs for USBT than for RP ($12,209 versus $7746, P <0.05). This was offset by lower professional fees for USBT ($7575 versus $9531). The ratio of charge to cost was lower for USBT than for RP (2.2 versus 3.0)." That is in 2002, already $26,000. Or this one, giving only 2010 Medicare reimbursement rates (Medicare pays only a fraction of normal costs)... at $12,000 Looking around the internet, it would seem more like a figure of $35,000 in 2013. I have no idea what your $3,500 figure represents. You can't walk through the front door of most hospitals for $3,500 these days. Heck, I recently did a nuclear stress test... walk on a treadmill, they shoot some radioactive stuff in your vein and then take a spect gamma ray image of your heart. A very typical procedure between a typical treadmill test and a angiogram. (BTW, my test was A-OK) Anyway, that test, non-invasive, was billed at $5,600 of which I paid $50. But still, the thought of a $3,500 brachytherapy seems impossible, even using Medicare rate reimbursements.

Posts.Title: worried, please help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tomnan24 Hi all. I will not be 65 til next May. I do not currently have any insurance. Any thoughts about waiting til next year? . Where do you live? Do you live in the USA? If so, do you realize that Obamacare kicks in January 1st, 2014. There would be no reason to wait until you turn 65 in May. Pre-existing conditions will no longer apply. Enrollment begins October 1st. Depending on your state, or "exchange" you will be able to get a insurance policy that will cover most of the costs. Your monthly premium will be fairly low considering you'll be needing immediate treatment. BTW, the examples of getting seeds for $3,500. I have considerable doubts about anything close to that when all costs are considered. More like many times that amount, but I'm open for someone who can show complete cost appointments, seeds, and followup, for less than $20,000. Perhaps you could get the shot, then wait the 6 months for Obamacare. Cutting off 5 months from May. Look, from what I understand, even if your birthday is May 31st, you get Medicare beginning May 1st. So my idea about using Obamacare, would cut off 4 full months from that Medicare timeline. Right now, you'd probably be waiting until at least August 1st for seeds or other treatment. Waiting for Obamacare would be an additional 5 months, possibly 6 months, since they couldn't treat you January 1st. Or wait until May 1st, or possibly June 1st on Medicare, to be seen and then scheduled for a procedure. Possibly you could, with a few visits and planning, set things up prior to Obamacare kicking in. Thus saving a month or more. Given your circumstances, perhaps you could shop around or bargain, plead, and get that shot down to perhaps $2,000 or less to span those 5 or 6 months. Again, what state do you live in. Do you know all about the new exchanges in your state? You must investigate that. You don't live in California, do you? One last point. Those 8 of 12 biopsy cores. Do you know what percentage of each. (like 5% or 25% or 80% of each one) You know, lots of people wait at least half that time, even when they are insured. Meaning they get diagnosed, and take about 3 months prior to any treatment. If you planned it right, on Obamacare, you'd only be about 6 months out, or 3 months extra. Odds are it would make little difference. Odds are even waiting until Medicare wouldn't change your outcome. You have several choices. You are only a few weeks into this whole process. There is less rush than you initially perceive. That prostate cancer has been growing in you for easily 10 years. Perhaps 15 or 20 years. There is a fair chance if you never treated it at all, it wouldn't kill you. BTW, what is the rest of your health like. Weight, cardiovascular, diabetes, cholesterol, heart function, high blood pressure, anything else? Above all, you don't need a full decision before the end of July, so take some time. Explore the hormone shot path as a intermediate step. Side effects, effectiveness, etc. From what I recall, many men are given such a shot, and told to wait, so that doing seeds for example is easier and more effective. Obviously that is a normal option even in those who proceed normally without any insurance considerations. Just think, only a couple months ago, you were "normal" and there was no rush for anything. Chances are, there is still no rush. But you won't get many doctors to say that, because if they do so for 50 guys, in one case they may be wrong. They always err way on the side of caution.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> I will not be 65 til next May <Z> <Z>

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Immediately following my surgery, I added as much fiber as possible to by diet.... And I believe I've recommended it to a few members of our "club". Right after surgery, stool softener, absolutely. Some fiber, absolutely. But "plenty of fiber", now I'm not so sure.. Increasing your fiber slowly... absolutely. Ideally a individual would begin slowly increasing fiber years ahead of time. It a good idea in that it directs you into eating foods that are healthy without "adding" fiber via artificial means. Best to get fiber from real food. For those who are following a rising psa, and possible negative biopsies, you might assume that in a few years you may want surgery, so start now eating right. Then for those who get a positive biopsy and are thinking about surgery, begin now to transition to higher fiber foods. Most men will have two months prior to surgery, by which time your system will be acclimated to the diet. Sudden large increases in fiber is normally not recommended for anyone, pre surgery, post surgery, or any time. BTW someone mentioned that fiber filled foods contain lots and calories and can lead weight gain. Actually the opposite is true. The fiber itself has a low amount of carbs relative to the fiber and calories involved. That "carb" idea is part of the recent trend/fad concept surrounding the "low-carb" and "paleo" diet mania. I know of no sensible or healthy diet that would avoid fiber. Though most men here are already well into diagnosis and treatment, as a general rule, they ought to be aiming for and advising friends to follow a diet more in line with that found at the UCSF Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center (San Francisco) http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf
Posts.Title: "Plenty of Fiber"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon My mother was a dietician, I was brought up on a low fat diet, we seldom had red meat and I ate copious amounts of vegetables, almonds, walnuts and fruit. Guess what?..I got prostate cancer. So if you don't mind I'll skip the rest of this post. Well the original post was specifically about fiber. However if you give me a choice of great diet or great genetics and I'll take great genetics every time. I have a much better lifestyle and diet than my older brother yet his psa remains at less than 1.0 while mine dances around 4.0. My father had prostate cancer and clearly I got some portion of that genetic package while my brother did not. The fact that you ate a great diet and got prostate cancer doesn't make me want to throw out the outlook and advice from some of those major cancer centers. More importantly, as I mentioned and always mention, that while the dietary changes may only have a weak influence on any given individual's outcome regarding prostate cancer, it has a much more proven effect on their heart health and in most men that is a much more likely problem than is prostate cancer regarding longevity. So I see it as wise choice even if it does little to alter one's specific prostate cancer course. Heart disease, and or diabetes will affect a the majority of men on this site to one degree or another. If the dietary changes influence the progression of prostate cancer that is a added bonus. Just so I'm not misunderstood. Regarding prostate cancer, diet is a tool, but a weak tool to alter outcomes. I choose to take advantage of that tool and go with the odds that it may help, alter, or slow, progression. Hardly proclaiming it as a magic bullet, especially after diagnosis.

Posts.Title: worried, please help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ezzo Im just worried that my prostrate has enlarged intially in the firstplace due to cancer or is this not possible?. I had a DRE and the doctor says my prostrate is on the larger side at 41cc. Im worried that it could be cancer otherwise why would i be getting sent for a PSA. Is there another reason they want a PSA done? Im also having a cystoscopy done in 6 weeks You have a lot of things going on. You are jumping to conclusions. From what you indicated your doctor "estimated" your prostate size only from the DRE. That is not a very accurate method. I would caution you not to get too worried even if your PSA number comes in a bit high for your age. You are taking that blood draw only a few weeks after all this stuff has been going on. It would seem that some of the recent events could impact your prostate and not give it enough time to calm down any "itis" inflammation. So if the reading comes in high, you should wait some time, month or months to confirm any high number. Also your prostate is enlarged which gives a higher number. (oh and don't have any sex in the few days leading up to the PSA blood draw as it could raise your PSA score) Did they tell you why they also are going to do a cystoscopy?
Posts.Title: worried, please help

Posts.Content: Not to complicate matters more, but I wonder if day of week, and time of day, don't factor into outcomes. I'd tend to think that the first surgery on Monday morning... perhaps beginning at 8:30 AM may not be the best. As might be the case of the last surgery on Friday afternoon, after two other surgeries that same day. Of course, I don't know what the optimal day or time would be. Not sure where you would access such information, particularly for each doctor. Just don't think I'd like to be patient #1 on Monday at 8:00 AM, following the Superbowl. Perhaps this article answers some of my questions http://medcitynews.com/2012/09/study...ome-surgeries/
Posts.Title: Potential Surgeon List

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Arthro92 My urologist called me today. I DO NOT HAVE PROSTATE CANCER!!!!!!!! He says what I have is asymptomatic prostatitis. My uro believes that is the reason for the elevated PSA. I am so thankful! I am THANKFUL to all of you for your soothing, comforting, encouraging words. I am so THANKFUL to all of you, for all the things you taught me about prostate cancer. Saying thank you feels like it's not enough, but PLEASE know how grateful I am to all of you who helped me during this scary journey. . Great news. I'm sure it is a huge relief. Now, having said that, I must repost a portion of what I said in my prior post to your first thread. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- "Well, its too late for my advice, but unless there are other facts, this is absolute madness." "How about simply waiting 3 more months and retesting the PSA... Again, perhaps there is something here that is not mentioned, but reacting to every raised PSA result with a biopsy is madness. Easily, very very easily, the PSA could be over 5 due to simple infection, even a asymptomatic infection or other inflammation that isn't even caused by bacteria." ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Too many biopsies are being done for simple rises in PSA scores that are temporary. Seldom is it dangerous to wait a few months and retest.
Posts.Title: The Results of My Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BriG Age: 46 Not in any PC risk categories. PSA 12 months ago 2.51 PSA 6 months ago 2.62 Current PSA 6.2 with a free PSA of 11% DREs by two different Urologists over the last 6 Months were normal. History of several flare ups of prostatitis in my mid 20s, early 30s with one chronic case lasting 9 months. Currently trying to get up to speed on everything. Is there anything I should be looking out for, or pushing for at this juncture? . You might be pushing for a answer as to why you are getting PSA testing every six months. Perhaps there is something in your pudendal neuralgia diagnosis that calls for such, but with your history, frequent testing for psa jumps seems to be inviting unnecessary further exploration... either MRI or even a biopsy, when simply waiting a few more months might very possibly bring your psa back to its normal level. Have you simply asked the doctor if it wouldn't just be better to wait another 6 months and retest? At least he isn't jumping directly to a biopsy.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Originally Posted by BriG Age  46 Not in any PC risk

Posts.Title: New here, recent increase in PSA.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by huntemup Thanks to all with the info and questions. Have been getting PSA for over 10 years. Only have records for past 4 years. Also had DRE at least 3 times in that period of over 10 years. 8-2012 PSA 2.4 8-2013 PSA 2.8 8-2014 PSA 3.2 8-2015 PSA 4.3 My location is WI 60 miles away from any lap scope surgery so open would be my choice. My Urologist has done many and it would be within 2 miles of home. Was planning another PSA in April. So I meant not to mean wait and see. I would continue active surveillance. You seem pretty normal to me. Such that if you grabbed the next 100 guys (in your age range) walking down the street, about 25% or 35% would end up with your results if given a few biopsies. Even without ever selecting them on the basis of a PSA test. Remember, even if you do have to undergo treatment a year or 5 years from now, the odds that it would be equally successful as doing it now, are very high. Relax, the odds are good that you'll never need treatment for other than psychological comfort of what "could" happen. Take the time over the next year to gain more understanding of the entire situation and the many AS programs ongoing, each using their own criteria and action. It would not be surprising to see your next PSA test come in lower than 4.3. I've been up over 7 and my last one was 2.8. Several times over 4 and 5 with the top at 7.5 as I recall. One negative biopsy at about your same PSA level. It was negative but I have little doubt it could have returned results similar to yours if it just hit the right spots. Then I'd be a "cancer" patient instead of a non-cancer patient. Disconcerting I'm sure. BTW, I just turned 66.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rwewpar4 I recently purchase a penile vacuum pump to try and deal with the ED. I discussed this with my wife and she wasn’t certain that she was comfortable with the idea of artificially achieving an erection. She said that she may need to talk to a councilor. I was so taken aback with her statement and the fact that she would not help me to work through these various issues. Still Frustrated Not sure if she is uncomfortable with the "machine" aspect of the device...and/or if it is done in her presence, or if just the overall concept of using something artificial is the problem. Because, after all, tens of millions of men, young and old, are using little pills to achieve somewhat artificial results. Viagra, Cialis, etc. If the machine aspect is the problem, then perhaps the better direction to go is with injections. I have a close friend who, after surgery, has used that method and now finds it routine, dependable, easy, and enjoyable. Its almost as easy as putting on a condom once you get over the unease, mostly psychological, of injecting yourself. Perhaps someone here who is using that method, can comment. BTW, you wouldn't have to do it in the presence of your wife. The entire episode of your illness and surgery is probably also difficult for her. I think it would help if she did go to a councilor that might get to the main problem, which even she may not fully be aware of.

Posts.Content: Haliday, thanks for the update. While I don't know enough to comment about anterior tumors and high PSAs, you are certainly in capable hands with Dr. Peter Carroll. I have been reading about him and what he says, writes, and studies for years. With him and the staff at UCSF you are certainly going to get excellent advice. Of course in each individual case there is always variability and the unknown. Just wanted to say that I think you and your husband are in the best place you could be for quality care. I wish you well.
Posts.Title: Update on triple-digit PSA explanation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Immediately following my surgery, I added as much fiber as possible to by diet.... And I believe I've recommended it to a few members of our "club". Right after surgery, stool softener, absolutely. Some fiber, absolutely. But "plenty of fiber", now I'm not so sure.. Increasing your fiber slowly... absolutely. Ideally a individual would begin slowly increasing fiber years ahead of time. It a good idea in that it directs you into eating foods that are healthy without "adding" fiber via artificial means. Best to get fiber from real food. For those who are following a rising psa, and possible negative biopsies, you might assume that in a few years you may want surgery, so start now eating right. Then for those who get a positive biopsy and are thinking about surgery, begin now to transition to higher fiber foods. Most men will have two months prior to surgery, by which time your system will be acclimated to the diet. Sudden large increases in fiber is normally not recommended for anyone, pre surgery, post surgery, or any time. BTW someone mentioned that fiber filled foods contain lots and calories and can lead weight gain. Actually the opposite is true. The fiber itself has a low amount of carbs relative to the fiber and calories involved. That "carb" idea is part of the recent trend/fad concept surrounding the "low-carb" and "paleo" diet mania. I know of no sensible or healthy diet that would avoid fiber. Though most men here are already well into diagnosis and treatment, as a general rule, they ought to be aiming for and advising friends to follow a diet more in line with that found at the UCSF Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center (San Francisco) http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf
Posts.Title: "Plenty of Fiber"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon OTAGO...If you reread my comment I doubt you will even see the word "calories" plus the take away for most people is that my doctor said to stick with a "well balanced diet" based on Recommended Daily Average for types of foods as I have always done. He did not want me dramatically adding fibre for any reason. He did reco. short term use of a stool softener if needed. "Fiber contains a lot of carbs which can lead to weight gain unless you are quite active and burning the calories. " You might re-read your comment. The carb--> weight gain idea has really gotten a bit out of hand recently, such that even non-processed whole foods which happen to have fiber are being thrown into the hopper as being little different than Wonder Bread or Twinkies. As to "dramatically" changing one's diet in the month(s) leading up to surgery, I agree that may be problematic and unwise. However a gradual change to higher fiber in most men who lack adequate fiber (the norm) I would think would be welcomed by most doctors. Above all, not suddenly loading up on fiber the days following surgery as was mentioned in the original post. Slowly increasing fiber intake over two or more months leading up to surgery should not cause a problem. The term "well balanced diet" means so many things to so many people. We do know that most men don't eat enough fiber, vegetables, fruit, and at the same time eat too much highly processed carbs and sugars. Almost everyone agrees with that picture of the average American male. One only need visit the local mall to see that on display with 65% of men being either overweight or obese. Extra weight itself being a risk factor for prostate cancer both before and after diagnosis. Interestingly in those few prostate cancer centers where dietary changes are recommended for preventative or during AS, they follow a fairly similar set of recommendations. Not dissimilar those put forth by UCSF which a major center for prostate cancer treatment and research. UCSF http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf From John Hopkins "The bottom line is that a diet that is low in animal and dairy fat, high in a wide variety of fruits and vegetables and healthy grains and nuts, is thought be a diet that can slow the progression of cancer." From Mayo Clinic http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-c...n/art-20045641 No magic in that advice. Probably much more valuable if followed from age 10 onward, which is impossible for 98% of us. I don't disagree with your doctors advice leading up to surgery. Even in overall dietary advice, doctors have no proof a given diet will alter the course of events in a given patient. Understandable that doctors won't suddenly have their patients alter their lifestyle. However if one was advising 20 year olds on healthy eating for their future prostate health I think many doctors might make some suggestions. Most of which would be ignored. Finally the dietary changes most often recommended for prostate health are the same ones suggested for healthy hearts which is a far more dangerous condition for 97% of men than is prostate cancer.

AgeInfo.Phrase: valuable if followed from age 10 onward  which is impossible for

Posts.Title: "Plenty of Fiber"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon My mother was a dietician, I was brought up on a low fat diet, we seldom had red meat and I ate copious amounts of vegetables, almonds, walnuts and fruit. Guess what?..I got prostate cancer. So if you don't mind I'll skip the rest of this post. Well the original post was specifically about fiber. However if you give me a choice of great diet or great genetics and I'll take great genetics every time. I have a much better lifestyle and diet than my older brother yet his psa remains at less than 1.0 while mine dances around 4.0. My father had prostate cancer and clearly I got some portion of that genetic package while my brother did not. The fact that you ate a great diet and got prostate cancer doesn't make me want to throw out the outlook and advice from some of those major cancer centers. More importantly, as I mentioned and always mention, that while the dietary changes may only have a weak influence on any given individual's outcome regarding prostate cancer, it has a much more proven effect on their heart health and in most men that is a much more likely problem than is prostate cancer regarding longevity. So I see it as wise choice even if it does little to alter one's specific prostate cancer course. Heart disease, and or diabetes will affect a the majority of men on this site to one degree or another. If the dietary changes influence the progression of prostate cancer that is a added bonus. Just so I'm not misunderstood. Regarding prostate cancer, diet is a tool, but a weak tool to alter outcomes. I choose to take advantage of that tool and go with the odds that it may help, alter, or slow, progression. Hardly proclaiming it as a magic bullet, especially after diagnosis.
Posts.Title: "Plenty of Fiber"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lilguy Hello fellow travelers. I am 63 years old and have had many bouts of chronic prostitis since my late 20s. PSA tested was always between 2.5 and 4 depending on severity. Treated with antibiotics things would calm down and life would go on. That was until last year. Mother developed lung cancer and I Was deeply involved with getting her and my dads Life set for what was coming for them. Terrible stress level for me caused a Prostitis flare up that continues to today. I knew something was up with a 4.2 PSA that climbed to a 5.9 in 3 months. I don't know all the terms or acronyms yet but I had a 14 sample biopsy a week ago And they found in 10 % of one sample cancer on the Gleason scale 3+3= 6 I go back in 10 days to discuss this health issue. . Though you didn't say so, it appears that they gave you a biopsy because your psa went from 4.2 to 5.9 over three months. That calls into question WHY they retested your psa that was 4.2, which hardly seems out of your norm of from 2.5 to 4.0 and your age advancing. So, I am guessing with the 4.2, they thought they might give you a test... then after waiting 3 months (good), they got a 5.9 and proceeded. A jump from 4.2 to 5.9 means almost nothing. My psa tests bounce around like that on a regular basis. Top one 7.5, my last one 3.3. But lets assume that 4.2 is a true value... so they gave you a 14 core biopsy which is understandable and fine. However you came back with 1 positive 3+3=6 core out of 14 and that one core was a 10% involvement. I'm about your age and with a similar PSA background, except on my biopsy, they didn't find that one positive core sample at 10%. So, what would I do in your place? Absolutely NOTHING at all. I would wait 6 months and retest your psa. Then in one year I would take another psa and do another biopsy. I would not come close to a treatment during that year. At the very least, if you do need to do something eventually, you have loads of time to think about it and arrive at some decision. Treating it now would be premature given the facts you put forth. Good chance that on your next biopsy, they find nothing. Not saying the cancer went away, only that it was just by chance they hit it this time. Make sure you watch this video of two top urologists http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 If you do so, you won't feel the need to act on anything now. Again, in your position, I wouldn't even think about doing treatment. PS, you have ZERO genetic relationship with your wife's grandfather, uncle and mother. Don't get your prostate removed because your wife is concerned. Your prostate did not "give up the fight"... Rather it sounds like you are on a fairly normal prostate progression for someone your age. Over treatment is HUGE in men your age, with your psa and biopsy results. Don't feel the need to jump on the treatment train. Wait... see what develops over the next year.

Posts.Title: Just Received Diagnosis Active Sur Route I Think

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lilguy Hello fellow travelers. I am 63 years old and have had many bouts of chronic prostitis since my late 20s. PSA tested was always between 2.5 and 4 depending on severity. Treated with antibiotics things would calm down and life would go on. That was until last year. Mother developed lung cancer and I Was deeply involved with getting her and my dads Life set for what was coming for them. Terrible stress level for me caused a Prostitis flare up that continues to today. I knew something was up with a 4.2 PSA that climbed to a 5.9 in 3 months. I don't know all the terms or acronyms yet but I had a 14 sample biopsy a week ago And they found in 10 % of one sample cancer on the Gleason scale 3+3= 6 I go back in 10 days to discuss this health issue. . Though you didn't say so, it appears that they gave you a biopsy because your psa went from 4.2 to 5.9 over three months. That calls into question WHY they retested your psa that was 4.2, which hardly seems out of your norm of from 2.5 to 4.0 and your age advancing. So, I am guessing with the 4.2, they thought they might give you a test... then after waiting 3 months (good), they got a 5.9 and proceeded. A jump from 4.2 to 5.9 means almost nothing. My psa tests bounce around like that on a regular basis. Top one 7.5, my last one 3.3. But lets assume that 4.2 is a true value... so they gave you a 14 core biopsy which is understandable and fine. However you came back with 1 positive 3+3=6 core out of 14 and that one core was a 10% involvement. I'm about your age and with a similar PSA background, except on my biopsy, they didn't find that one positive core sample at 10%. So, what would I do in your place? Absolutely NOTHING at all. I would wait 6 months and retest your psa. Then in one year I would take another psa and do another biopsy. I would not come close to a treatment during that year. At the very least, if you do need to do something eventually, you have loads of time to think about it and arrive at some decision. Treating it now would be premature given the facts you put forth. Good chance that on your next biopsy, they find nothing. Not saying the cancer went away, only that it was just by chance they hit it this time. Make sure you watch this video of two top urologists http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 If you do so, you won't feel the need to act on anything now. Again, in your position, I wouldn't even think about doing treatment. PS, you have ZERO genetic relationship with your wife's grandfather, uncle and mother. Don't get your prostate removed because your wife is concerned. Your prostate did not "give up the fight"... Rather it sounds like you are on a fairly normal prostate progression for someone your age. Over treatment is HUGE in men your age, with your psa and biopsy results. Don't feel the need to jump on the treatment train. Wait... see what develops over the next year.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon OTAGO...If you reread my comment I doubt you will even see the word "calories" plus the take away for most people is that my doctor said to stick with a "well balanced diet" based on Recommended Daily Average for types of foods as I have always done. He did not want me dramatically adding fibre for any reason. He did reco. short term use of a stool softener if needed. "Fiber contains a lot of carbs which can lead to weight gain unless you are quite active and burning the calories. " You might re-read your comment. The carb--> weight gain idea has really gotten a bit out of hand recently, such that even non-processed whole foods which happen to have fiber are being thrown into the hopper as being little different than Wonder Bread or Twinkies. As to "dramatically" changing one's diet in the month(s) leading up to surgery, I agree that may be problematic and unwise. However a gradual change to higher fiber in most men who lack adequate fiber (the norm) I would think would be welcomed by most doctors. Above all, not suddenly loading up on fiber the days following surgery as was mentioned in the original post. Slowly increasing fiber intake over two or more months leading up to surgery should not cause a problem. The term "well balanced diet" means so many things to so many people. We do know that most men don't eat enough fiber, vegetables, fruit, and at the same time eat too much highly processed carbs and sugars. Almost everyone agrees with that picture of the average American male. One only need visit the local mall to see that on display with 65% of men being either overweight or obese. Extra weight itself being a risk factor for prostate cancer both before and after diagnosis. Interestingly in those few prostate cancer centers where dietary changes are recommended for preventative or during AS, they follow a fairly similar set of recommendations. Not dissimilar those put forth by UCSF which a major center for prostate cancer treatment and research. UCSF http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf From John Hopkins "The bottom line is that a diet that is low in animal and dairy fat, high in a wide variety of fruits and vegetables and healthy grains and nuts, is thought be a diet that can slow the progression of cancer." From Mayo Clinic http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-c...n/art-20045641 No magic in that advice. Probably much more valuable if followed from age 10 onward, which is impossible for 98% of us. I don't disagree with your doctors advice leading up to surgery. Even in overall dietary advice, doctors have no proof a given diet will alter the course of events in a given patient. Understandable that doctors won't suddenly have their patients alter their lifestyle. However if one was advising 20 year olds on healthy eating for their future prostate health I think many doctors might make some suggestions. Most of which would be ignored. Finally the dietary changes most often recommended for prostate health are the same ones suggested for healthy hearts which is a far more dangerous condition for 97% of men than is prostate cancer.

AgeInfo.Phrase: valuable if followed from age 10 onward  which is impossible for

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla Hi Hogiebear.... Sorry to hear you have joined our little club. There is a wealth of info available here (recommend the stickies) and many members that can help. Can you share the details of your biopsy (number of cores, number of cores positive, % of each positive core)? That will help with the replies (you can see most of us put it in our signature). Hogiebear, also include your most recent PSA result as well as your prior PSA history going back as far as possible.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed Monday - PET Scan next Tuesday

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer, IBS, and Viagra? Help?!

Posts.Content: Welcome here. Good to see you aren't in a rush. Don't get locked into your views about the options until you gain some time from which to evaluate them. Sounds like you're only a few weeks into this process. A few questions. Your one positive Gleason 6 core. Do you know what percentage it was? Like 10% or 30% or 70%. I assume you had 12 cores taken. You indicated that you saw the new urologist and that he "sent me for another PSA test". Did he send you for that PSA test right after doing the DRE? Or was there a few days in between the exam and the blood draw? How about in the days leading up to your blood draw, did you have any sex? Just curious as to why your PSA in late January would suddenly be 5.2, when it was only 2.5 two months before in November. That kind of rise is rather unusual and not usually caused by prostate cancer. Your prior three PSA tests were not all that unusual for a guy with a enlarged prostate and frequent urination. It would not be surprising if your next PSA came in back in the 2.5 range. PSA's jump around like that and do so often. I've had one fall from about 7.4 to 3.8 from test to test. Did you get anything specific from him about what he felt in your DRE exam. You only say "I could also tell he felt something on the DRE that he didn't like"... What did he say? Or did he just grunt? Was it hard, or did he feel a nodule? I wouldn't jump right on the prostate removal train just yet. By all means, read the Walsh book. And look at the following video. As usual, all cases are different but its easy to get caught up into a narrow band of thinking I'm only giving you the link because I've found the video to be a calming one, giving a lower tone, less dramatic appraisal that many men can use in the first few weeks after diagnosis of a Gleason 6 with few cores involved. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 These are well known, well respected doctors in the field of prostate cancer.
Posts.Title: Another Newbie here

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KPINOTT FYI, mentions PCa in here http://www.nbcnews.com/health/cancer...p-says-n451396 Study published 10 years ago on the subject of diet, meat, and the progression of PCa http://ornishspectrum.com/wp-content...ate_Cancer.pdf But most folks don't want to accept it because it isn't definitive proof... and as we know, it is unlikely you'll ever gets large studies of the same diet comparison, due to enormous costs and implementation difficulties. Besides it takes a large change in lifestyle. If you look around the world at varying rates of prostate cancer, and then look at what diets those populations consume, it hard to not see some trends. As to whether it will help someone who already has PCa, and especially someone who has already undergone treatment, that is another issue for each person to decide. Not a lot in the way of significant studies from which to draw conclusions.

Not a lot in the way of significant studies from which to draw conclusions.
Posts.Title: WHO report on red meat

Posts.Content: Begin reading the following http://www.pmri.org/research.html#prostate-study There are three studies there that relate to prostates and lowering or slowing the progression of psa. Read them in depth. It isn't about turning cancer away. Prostate cancer is out there in a huge number of men. Most men after age 50. So its all about slowing it down, not eliminating it. We don't have your details about age and your current psa.

Posts.Title: Holistic approach

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hammer2016 I am leaning toward having a robotic prostatectomy. I have interviewed two surgeons and feel very good about the one I have chosen. I am scheduled to have a 3T MRI on 6/20/16 and then a robotic prostatectomy on 7/14/16. I am nervous about the surgery and possible side effects, but confident this will work out great for me. Hold on...here we go!!! I can't argue with your choice of surgery given your facts and family history. I would want to know the details about the surgeon over and above "feeling very good" about the one you choose. Don't want to get you into any kind of second guessing, but what did you base your choice on. How he talked? How many robotic surgeries has he done? How many does he do each week... or each month? The robot has been around for about 10 years now, but some doctors have done very few.... or do them so infrequently as to not stay in top form. Were you able to discern his numbers over the past 12 or 24 months? I'll let some others indicate how many per week or per month they'd think is optimal, or the minimum, for a surgeon to stay sharp with his skills. Another point... is the surgeon a general surgeon or is he a surgeon that specializes in urological surgery, or even in prostate surgery specifically? You were only diagnosed a little over 3 weeks ago. You've had this prostate cancer for years... Given your data, there isn't really a rush, so make sure you really have the surgeon you want. Just because you've set a date in July doesn't mean it has to be done that soon. Its not like you get fined if you change the date. I just think my head would be swimming with a full overload of facts after only 3 or 4 weeks.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Diagnosed on 5/13/16

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddl123161 I am 52 and was just diagnosed yesterday with prostate cancer after a biopsy I had last week returned positive results. They are as follows: 12 Core sample, 3 positive (13%, 35%, and 85%) all in the left lobe. PSA prior to the biopsy was 10.5 and the month just prior to that was 8.5. Gleason 3+4=7. One point. Don't assume that psa shift during that one month, from 8.5 to 10.5, is indicative of some rapid increase due to prostate cancer. It wouldn't go up that fast due to the prostate cancer you have. Many other things cause psa results to jump about in equally impressive ups and downs. So, don't let that make you unusually worried or rushed. Originally Posted by ddl123161 I don't like my options at this point but I am leaning towards robotic surgery. I do have a consultation for a second opinion on Sept 2. He has performed over 2000. Couple of questions I have is what should I be asking and how much time do I have to consider all my options without putting my health in further jeopardy? ! I certainly don't think you have to come to a final decision before the end of September, giving you easily 6 weeks from now. Actually you could probably make a decision by Christmas and it wouldn't affect your outcome or best choices. What I am saying is that after your September 2nd visit, assuming he recommends surgery, don't feel suddenly rushed to schedule surgery. Some might suggest you still get another person to look at those biopsy samples to confirm the 3+4 = 7 gleason. John Hopkins etc. Have you seen anyone who specializes in radiation? It would seem almost 100% certain that a doctor who has done over 2,000 surgeries will suggest you do surgery. BTW, how many of the 2,000 surgeries were robotic? That is one point you should confirm.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Posted by ddl123161 I am 52 and was just diagnosed yesterday

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bobkeenan Also the urologist and an prostate oncology expert (part of a prostate cancer seminar that I attended up here in portland that included Seattle and Vancouver BC) Said that brachytherapy was big in the 90's and early 2000's but was being done less now. So because of the added side effects and I prefer to go where most of the experience is these days.... I pulled Brachytherapy off the list. . I've been reading this forum and others almost daily for many years, in addition to reading other sites often, and this is the first time I"ve ever heard such about brachytherapy. If anything I'd heard it is more popular now than ever. Nor have I heard it described as having more "significant" side effects. Perhaps someone can give us a link to such opinions about trends in brachytherapy. Sounds very strange compared to what I always read. Just wondering, that prostate cancer seminar you attended, were any of the doctors who put it on individuals who actually performed brachytherapy? Very often, the doctors who do external radiation have a strong bias as to their method being superior. Same with surgeons. Having said that, your other options are both excellent and all offer you about the same outcome as to treating the cancer. Some might even include AS as a good choice since your 3 cores were about the same as getting 2 cores in someone doing 12 samples. Also your 3+4 is only 5%.
Posts.Title: Decisions Decisions DaVinci Prostatectomy versus External Beam Radiation????

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I would request another PSA test within the next week or two. So, after your next PSA test -- if the reading is still high -- you'll want a good urologist to quickly rule out any infection, etc. If this is ruled out, then it would be wise to have a biopsy. By rule out infection, do you mean rule out the inflammation that may be caused by such a infection? Fine, but how do you entirely rule out that inflammation which is the thing that would be causing the higher PSA reading? As I've stated before, inflammation or prostatitis is one of the major causes of spikes in PSA results. But the problem is that only a minority of such inflammations are causes by bacterial infections. Thus the doctor can't rule out the majority of the inflammation that is caused from non-bacterial sources even if he puts you on antibiotics. Time is more often the only thing that can resolve such inflammations. That is why doctors don't rush to re-test while patients often clamor for more urgent retesting. A retest in a week or two will not likely answer the questions regarding higher PSA caused by prostatitis. But then you say it would be wise to do a biopsy right away. Your logic on this matter seems at odds with the science. Urologists wait for reasons. They see PSA scores jumping up and down all the time. Why.... why do you imagine excellent urologists tell their patients to wait 4 months to retest? Why? Are they just trying to take undue risks?
Posts.Title: PSA results question

Posts.Content: If it was recent, then you may not know what his post orchiectomy PSA is for a few months. Take a look at this study. However it would seem his doctors, with all the details, would know more specifics. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7544202 Here is a older thread from 2008 and 2009 along similar lines. You may find some link in that. http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...-bonesecondary I know very little about that particular situation. I wish him well.
Posts.Title: post-castration treatment and life expectancy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by kent4610 I am a 53 y/o wm who's psa went from 1.5 to 4.7 in a year, had a biopsy with 12 samples and 1 came back pos. everything else looked normal. I believe my Gleason score was 6,, I remember seeing that number on the paper but that is a blur, I will find out this week for sure though. I am also very okay with AS and again,, THANK YOU, I think I will be able to take a nap now as the stress just left my body... have a great day When you see the doctor, in addition to finding out the Gleason score (probably 6), also ask what the percentage of that one sample was involved. For example it may be Gleason 6, with 10% involved........or it could be Gleason 6 with 50% or even 80% involved. Also, if you have it, give us your complete history of PSA tests prior to the last two, which you said were 1.5 and 4.7. I find it some what odd that your doctor would have even given you a biopsy without first waiting a few months to see if the 4.7 dropped back down under 2.0. The psa scores jump all over the place for reasons that have nothing to do with cancer. Very possible you didn't even need a biopsy which only sets up the current confusion about what to do. Under any circumstances, do NOT do any treatment now. There is no need to rush anything. Re-test your psa in 3 or 6 months and see what it does. If it drops back down, then almost certainly you don't want to do any treatment. Millions of men have low percentage Gleason 6 samples just sitting there, and in most men nothing bad will happen.. Most won't ever know it is there and will never have a problem. Anyway, get those extra questions answered and then by all means, wait and retest your psa in a few months.... (not in a few weeks). Lastly be sure the next time you get your psa tested that no one does the "finger" exam (DRE) on you prior to the blood draw. Also, no sex of any type in the 3 to 4 days leading up to the test. And even stay off a bike for a few days prior. You want your next psa test to be "clean"...without other possible items that might boost your result. However.... even if your recent 4.7 test was "clean".... you can still get wildly jumping test outcomes from all manner of inflammations that are completely without symptoms. Watch this video where prostate cancer experts are interviewed about findings and psa's like yours. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Watch the whole thing.. about 11 minutes... pay special attention to from 7:40 to about 8:40

Posts.Title: just found out

Posts.Content: Just to clear up the AS criteria... it is important to see that it varies from top institution to top institution. For example both the University of San Francisco (UCSF) and Sloan Kettering (MSKCC) use less than or equal to 33% of cores... or less than or equal to 3.... for the number of positive cores. In each case, the maximum percentage for a single core is 50%. Thus a individual who, upon a second reading of the slides, might be re-diagnosed as all 3+3, could qualify with 3 positive cores. In this case, 33% of 16 cores would actually be 5 positive cores. In light of the fact that the percentage of each core is 10% or less... IF... and its a big IF.... one were to get a designation of 3+3 on that 3+4, then the option would still be available... with active follow-up See Table 1 in the following journal article http://www.europeanurology.com/artic...pg-alt-eulogo1 I'd get a second reading of the slides. Then proceed knowing you covered all your bases.
Posts.Title: Value of Second Opinions and Newly Diagnosed Questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KPINOTT I had my PSA checked again and it was 2.54 in December. Then had it re-checked in January and it was 2.56. Hence the panic. My family Dr. said it was elevated for my age and referred me to a Urologist. The urologist was impressed with my knowledge of the disease as I had done my research and agreed with my suggestion to monitor it every year and do nothing else at that point. I have no risk factors such as race, obesity (in top physical condition), under 50, no family history etc Fast forward to this week; to my delight, my PSA was down to 2.16. I don't have an explanation but I think it might be related to the regimen of dietary and increased physical exercise. Have read a ton on nutrition and diet relating to PC and some of the common foods that come up are; tree nuts pomegranate green tea extract soy Lycopne cruciferous vegetables,to name a few I added all of these foods to my diet and started doing intense exercise 5-6 times per week First of all, you learn to not panic when your psa changes. Going from 2.54 to 2.16 or from 2.16 to 2.56 ... means almost nothing. In many men the "ups and downs" are far greater between tests. I have gone from 3.8 to 7.5.. then down to 3.8 then 2.8 and my last was 3.3 or 3.4. All reasonably normal variations depending on what is going on in your prostate. You can have mild or even greater prostatitis and it can be completely asymptomatic... You'd never be aware of it and yet it can make your psa jump all over the place. Just wait a while... 3 to 6 months... or in your case perhaps a year, and see where it goes. I've had two blood draws at one sitting, and due to a clerical error in the order, they did two psa tests, less than 30 seconds apart. Sent to the same lab. One was 2.5 and the other 2.7 The foods you mention are just fine. May help the prostate and even if they don't they are good for you in other respects. If you want to go all in on the diet thing, you could read the following study https://www.ornish.com/wp-content/up...ate_Cancer.pdf Exercise is good, though there is no need in terms of prostate health or prostate cancer avoidance, to do "intense" exercise 5 to 6 days a week. Moderate to moderate/intense 3 to 4 times a week will give you all the benefits in health without having it become a overly important component in your life. You gain very little going from 3 days to 6 days and from doing intense compared to moderate. I actually wish I had done less exercise during certain periods of my life. Example, running 3 miles, 3 or 4 times a week will give you all the cardio you need. Adding in more days and more miles will give you nothing extra in prostate or heart health. I doubt there is any study suggesting such a added benefit. Regarding "tree nuts".. watch out how many and which types you consume. They can be loaded with fat. And you don't want to eat too many Brazil nuts... getting too much selenium.

Posts.Title: PSA reduction curiosity

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bobkeenan After talking with the Urologist/ Surgeon and reading the Walsh book and all of the online info I was convinced that surgery was the answer. My rationale was when you pull the prostate PSA goes to 0 and should stay there. A biopsy of the lymph nodes and the prostate will tell me if they got the cancer out. And I was accepting of the fact that i will have some pain, discomfort of the catheter and bag, and potential for some continence issues in the future. Even thought those may be small. So now I am being seduced by the promise of the same cure with no painful surgery, no catheter, no bag, and minimal continence issues. . You mention the continence issue twice, but no mention of erectile function differences between the two (or three) choices. Is that issue not a big part of your consideration?

Posts.Title: just found out

Posts.Content: Let me completely disagree with all the other posts. You should follow your doctors advice and re-test in 4 months. Do not rush to retest. Retesting in 2 months is not only not needed, but is very likely to give you the wrong impression. The major causes of temporarily high psa often do not resolve themselves quickly. The most common, inflammation from prostatitis, often takes months to resolve. Even prostatitis caused by bacterial infection are often not resolved quickly after treatment. Most prostatitis is not caused by bacteria and even in those cases where it is, the time needed for the prostate to calm down can be several months. Given the circumstances your doctor has given you sound advice. Do not be led into thinking that retesting in 2 months is a better idea. Your doctor knows full well that he could retest you in two months, but with good reason and experience he chose 4 months. He doesn't want a interim false reading to further confuse the matters. There is no rush. Anything that may be needed to be done can be done in 4 months. Only in the most unusual cases would you benefit by speeding up the process by two months. Worst of all if you take a test in 2 months and it is still 3.3 to 3.7, he will still want to retest you at 4 months. It would be premature to test you at 2 months, get a similar result, and the go ahead with a biopsy. Simply jumping the gun. No, wait the 4 months as instructed. Prostates take "time" to calm down from many of the situations that produce higher results. In fact they often take more than 4 months. A further note. You may think you'd know it if you had prostatitis, or inflammation. Very often there are no symptoms at all. It is a very very common reason why prostates give out a false reading on a PSA test. Asymptomatic prostatitis. Google it. Regarding ---- "I am already miserably ill from a variety of maladies - Chron's disease, ulcerative colitis, irritable bowel syndrome, Hiatal Hernia, Barretts Esophagus, Severe Sleep apnea, been a smoker most of my life." Wow, what a witches brew of conditions. Sleep apnea, would that indicate you are also overweight? Just curious but all those conditions are connected with the food pathway from top to bottom. Given that you are a smoker, I'll assume you aren't a health nut. Have you ever totally altered your diet and lifestyle for extended periods of time... meaning fully changed for very long periods of time. I know those conditions are very difficult. I think I'd try many alternative eating plans for extended periods of time in searching for the one that would resolve many of those or at least greatly modify them. Sound like you are in a prolonged difficult physical condition. Sorry to hear that. Anyway, I'd wait the 4 months as the doctor suggests. One other thought.... only crossing my mind. You have a variety of conditions, each of which involve inflammation of your eating channel. Would it be too much to expect or think that many parts of your body are also rather prone to inflammation? Too possibly include your prostate. All that and smoking. I sure hope you are getting equally good testing of your cholesterol levels and blood pressure, with the focus on avoiding future heart disease. Remember, most men who get relatively higher (for their age) psa test, do not have prostate cancer. Don't talk yourself into that over the next 4 months.
