Wow, what a witches brew of conditions. Sleep apnea, would that indicate you are also overweight? Just curious but all those conditions are connected with the food pathway from top to bottom. Given that you are a smoker, I'll assume you aren't a health nut. Have you ever totally altered your diet and lifestyle for extended periods of time... meaning fully changed for very long periods of time. I know those conditions are very difficult. I think I'd try many alternative eating plans for extended periods of time in searching for the one that would resolve many of those or at least greatly modify them. Sound like you are in a prolonged difficult physical condition. Sorry to hear that. Anyway, I'd wait the 4 months as the doctor suggests. One other thought.... only crossing my mind. You have a variety of conditions, each of which involve inflammation of your eating channel. Would it be too much to expect or think that many parts of your body are also rather prone to inflammation? Too possibly include your prostate. All that and smoking. I sure hope you are getting equally good testing of your cholesterol levels and blood pressure, with the focus on avoiding future heart disease. Remember, most men who get relatively higher (for their age) psa test, do not have prostate cancer. Don't talk yourself into that over the next 4 months.
Posts.Title: PSA results question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hammer2016 I am leaning toward having a robotic prostatectomy. I have interviewed two surgeons and feel very good about the one I have chosen. I am scheduled to have a 3T MRI on 6/20/16 and then a robotic prostatectomy on 7/14/16. I am nervous about the surgery and possible side effects, but confident this will work out great for me. Hold on...here we go!!! I can't argue with your choice of surgery given your facts and family history. I would want to know the details about the surgeon over and above "feeling very good" about the one you choose. Don't want to get you into any kind of second guessing, but what did you base your choice on. How he talked? How many robotic surgeries has he done? How many does he do each week... or each month? The robot has been around for about 10 years now, but some doctors have done very few.... or do them so infrequently as to not stay in top form. Were you able to discern his numbers over the past 12 or 24 months? I'll let some others indicate how many per week or per month they'd think is optimal, or the minimum, for a surgeon to stay sharp with his skills. Another point... is the surgeon a general surgeon or is he a surgeon that specializes in urological surgery, or even in prostate surgery specifically? You were only diagnosed a little over 3 weeks ago. You've had this prostate cancer for years... Given your data, there isn't really a rush, so make sure you really have the surgeon you want. Just because you've set a date in July doesn't mean it has to be done that soon. Its not like you get fined if you change the date. I just think my head would be swimming with a full overload of facts after only 3 or 4 weeks.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Diagnosed on 5/13/16

Posts.Content: Let me completely disagree with all the other posts. You should follow your doctors advice and re-test in 4 months. Do not rush to retest. Retesting in 2 months is not only not needed, but is very likely to give you the wrong impression. The major causes of temporarily high psa often do not resolve themselves quickly. The most common, inflammation from prostatitis, often takes months to resolve. Even prostatitis caused by bacterial infection are often not resolved quickly after treatment. Most prostatitis is not caused by bacteria and even in those cases where it is, the time needed for the prostate to calm down can be several months. Given the circumstances your doctor has given you sound advice. Do not be led into thinking that retesting in 2 months is a better idea. Your doctor knows full well that he could retest you in two months, but with good reason and experience he chose 4 months. He doesn't want a interim false reading to further confuse the matters. There is no rush. Anything that may be needed to be done can be done in 4 months. Only in the most unusual cases would you benefit by speeding up the process by two months. Worst of all if you take a test in 2 months and it is still 3.3 to 3.7, he will still want to retest you at 4 months. It would be premature to test you at 2 months, get a similar result, and the go ahead with a biopsy. Simply jumping the gun. No, wait the 4 months as instructed. Prostates take "time" to calm down from many of the situations that produce higher results. In fact they often take more than 4 months. A further note. You may think you'd know it if you had prostatitis, or inflammation. Very often there are no symptoms at all. It is a very very common reason why prostates give out a false reading on a PSA test. Asymptomatic prostatitis. Google it. Regarding ---- "I am already miserably ill from a variety of maladies - Chron's disease, ulcerative colitis, irritable bowel syndrome, Hiatal Hernia, Barretts Esophagus, Severe Sleep apnea, been a smoker most of my life." Wow, what a witches brew of conditions. Sleep apnea, would that indicate you are also overweight? Just curious but all those conditions are connected with the food pathway from top to bottom. Given that you are a smoker, I'll assume you aren't a health nut. Have you ever totally altered your diet and lifestyle for extended periods of time... meaning fully changed for very long periods of time. I know those conditions are very difficult. I think I'd try many alternative eating plans for extended periods of time in searching for the one that would resolve many of those or at least greatly modify them. Sound like you are in a prolonged difficult physical condition. Sorry to hear that. Anyway, I'd wait the 4 months as the doctor suggests. One other thought.... only crossing my mind. You have a variety of conditions, each of which involve inflammation of your eating channel. Would it be too much to expect or think that many parts of your body are also rather prone to inflammation? Too possibly include your prostate. All that and smoking. I sure hope you are getting equally good testing of your cholesterol levels and blood pressure, with the focus on avoiding future heart disease. Remember, most men who get relatively higher (for their age) psa test, do not have prostate cancer. Don't talk yourself into that over the next 4 months.
Posts.Title: PSA results question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bobkeenan After talking with the Urologist/ Surgeon and reading the Walsh book and all of the online info I was convinced that surgery was the answer. My rationale was when you pull the prostate PSA goes to 0 and should stay there. A biopsy of the lymph nodes and the prostate will tell me if they got the cancer out. And I was accepting of the fact that i will have some pain, discomfort of the catheter and bag, and potential for some continence issues in the future. Even thought those may be small. So now I am being seduced by the promise of the same cure with no painful surgery, no catheter, no bag, and minimal continence issues. . You mention the continence issue twice, but no mention of erectile function differences between the two (or three) choices. Is that issue not a big part of your consideration?
Posts.Title: Decisions Decisions DaVinci Prostatectomy versus External Beam Radiation????

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bobkeenan Also the urologist and an prostate oncology expert (part of a prostate cancer seminar that I attended up here in portland that included Seattle and Vancouver BC) Said that brachytherapy was big in the 90's and early 2000's but was being done less now. So because of the added side effects and I prefer to go where most of the experience is these days.... I pulled Brachytherapy off the list. . I've been reading this forum and others almost daily for many years, in addition to reading other sites often, and this is the first time I"ve ever heard such about brachytherapy. If anything I'd heard it is more popular now than ever. Nor have I heard it described as having more "significant" side effects. Perhaps someone can give us a link to such opinions about trends in brachytherapy. Sounds very strange compared to what I always read. Just wondering, that prostate cancer seminar you attended, were any of the doctors who put it on individuals who actually performed brachytherapy? Very often, the doctors who do external radiation have a strong bias as to their method being superior. Same with surgeons. Having said that, your other options are both excellent and all offer you about the same outcome as to treating the cancer. Some might even include AS as a good choice since your 3 cores were about the same as getting 2 cores in someone doing 12 samples. Also your 3+4 is only 5%.

Posts.Title: Decisions Decisions DaVinci Prostatectomy versus External Beam Radiation????

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tghag11 Both surgeons see surgery is inevitable. I haven't seen an oncologist or radiologist. Does it matter much if my 3+4 gets interpreted in second opinion as 3+3? I've also considered getting a genomic test, hopefully showing slow progression. What do you think of these genomic tests? What do you guys think of delaying? I don't think you need to be any rush. I'd look at it that way rather than calling it "delaying". Its only been one 6 weeks since your biopsy. I'd certainly get your slides looked at again by a second expert.. John Hopkins etc. There are several AS programs that allow more than 2 Gleason 6 results. Example UCSF (University of California San Francisco.) "in no more than one third of the total needle samples; and cancer in no more than 50 percent of any single needle sample." Given that you have 5% + 5% + 10% in your three samples....OUT OF 16, not 12, you'd seem to fit their criteria if the 3+4 became a 3+3 Give yourself considerable time to get a second opinion and at the same time start reading as much as you can about AS I assume you've only been dwelling on this for the past 6 weeks. As is often the case, surgeons recommend surgery and may not suggest a second reading of your biopsy samples. Strange things have happened and been reported here from those who obtain a second reading of samples. Explore all your options and if you need surgery, get it done by a overly experienced doctor who does robotic surgery frequently...
Posts.Title: Value of Second Opinions and Newly Diagnosed Questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Popi Why would getting the test sooner than what the Doctor ordered make it unreliable? My guess, waiting 3-4 months between tests simply allows time for a significant enough change to take place. Three tests in one year, or 10 tests in one year...you're still going to arrive at the same numbers by the end. A test result is nothing more than a data point, and really, what's so bad about having more test results than what's normally obtained. . Popi, you fail to understand the issue. Sure, go ahead and get your test. Apparently you don't grasp the reasons why they wait a given amount of time prior to re-testing. Why not test every week? Do you know anything about why psa tests jump around? You have had ONE psa test. The two, close together are really only one test. If your actual PSA is 1.2 and you got your two 2.4 tests then you won't know the real psa score until you allow the conditions to calm down adequately such that the next score will have a greater likely hood of being accurate. A psa test raised by inflammation, unnoticed by you, does not calm down in a week. I won't go on. You seem intent on thinking that all data points are equal and revealing of the true picture. That is entirely wrong. I have had on several occasions a psa of as high as 7.4, turn out 6 months later to be only 3.7. Now, do you think if i had tested again in a few weeks, the inflammation that caused the 7.4 would have gone all the way down to 3.7? Of course not. So I'd get a 6.2 or 5.9 and say OMG.... disaster awaits. Early and premature followup psa testing is of little value. That is why your trained urologist tells you to wait months. He has seen your situation a thousand times.
Posts.Title: Ordering your own PSA test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I would request another PSA test within the next week or two. So, after your next PSA test -- if the reading is still high -- you'll want a good urologist to quickly rule out any infection, etc. If this is ruled out, then it would be wise to have a biopsy. By rule out infection, do you mean rule out the inflammation that may be caused by such a infection? Fine, but how do you entirely rule out that inflammation which is the thing that would be causing the higher PSA reading? As I've stated before, inflammation or prostatitis is one of the major causes of spikes in PSA results. But the problem is that only a minority of such inflammations are causes by bacterial infections. Thus the doctor can't rule out the majority of the inflammation that is caused from non-bacterial sources even if he puts you on antibiotics. Time is more often the only thing that can resolve such inflammations. That is why doctors don't rush to re-test while patients often clamor for more urgent retesting. A retest in a week or two will not likely answer the questions regarding higher PSA caused by prostatitis. But then you say it would be wise to do a biopsy right away. Your logic on this matter seems at odds with the science. Urologists wait for reasons. They see PSA scores jumping up and down all the time. Why.... why do you imagine excellent urologists tell their patients to wait 4 months to retest? Why? Are they just trying to take undue risks?

Posts.Title: 10-Year Outcomes after Monitoring, Surgery, or Radiotherapy for Localized PCa

Posts.Content: Just to clear up the AS criteria... it is important to see that it varies from top institution to top institution. For example both the University of San Francisco (UCSF) and Sloan Kettering (MSKCC) use less than or equal to 33% of cores... or less than or equal to 3.... for the number of positive cores. In each case, the maximum percentage for a single core is 50%. Thus a individual who, upon a second reading of the slides, might be re-diagnosed as all 3+3, could qualify with 3 positive cores. In this case, 33% of 16 cores would actually be 5 positive cores. In light of the fact that the percentage of each core is 10% or less... IF... and its a big IF.... one were to get a designation of 3+3 on that 3+4, then the option would still be available... with active follow-up See Table 1 in the following journal article http://www.europeanurology.com/artic...pg-alt-eulogo1 I'd get a second reading of the slides. Then proceed knowing you covered all your bases.

Posts.Title: Value of Second Opinions and Newly Diagnosed Questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Uncle Bill This is my first post since 2013. I'm hoping someone can help me understand what's going on with me. My PSA count in July 2015 was 4.9, a big jump from January 2015 at 3.0. I'm very worried Date PSA age 7/15 4.9 49 1/15 3.0 49 9/9 3.2 43 Ignore the 4.9 jump. Your psa has been remarkably stable over the last 6 years. Going from 3.2 to 3.0 ..... Getting a jump up to 4.9 means nothing. Simply retest in 6 months. I have had several jumps in my psa... up to 7.5. My last two were 3.3 and 2.8 Some men have psa results that jump and some do not. The only concern is that your psa has been somewhat higher than normal for your age. Inflammation in the pelvic area, or even asymptomatic inflammation, could easily create and abnormal jump in psa. BTW, the vast majority of prostatitis and inflammation is non-bacterial, and thus not cured by antibiotics. Even retesting in September is really not giving a inflammation enough time to calm down. A 3 to 6 month wait between tests would be better.
Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: I was looking up the "news" on Google for prostate cancer when clicking on a article I saw one of those links to other unrelated articles. Anyway, seems in the back of my mind I remember reading about aspirin and prostate cancer, but with so many articles available, I had forgotten about this one. Its about aspirin use before and after surgery or radiation. Unsure of the precise dosage involved. Whether the typical 81 mg for heart prevention or the typical pill which is 325 mg. http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...0828170725.htm Seems like at least the 81 mg might be worthwhile taking since it is also often mentioned for the prevention of heart related disease and stroke prevention. A note of caution. Anyone who is on any other meds should proceed with caution. Especially dangerous would be any anticoagulants.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Popi Just found out that I can order my own PSA test through my hospital's lab. ($30) I will not use the results to self-diagnose, but I fret, and waiting until the end of February for my next test is killing me. . The testing concept is nice although the Sentara Laboratory Services Drawsite Locations are limited. Regarding your urgent "need to know"--- Rather than just thinking about what to type, I'll simply repost what I told you on November 26th. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Goodness, slow down. You've had essentially one single PSA test of 2.35 (the second one right away is simply a retest so average the two) Sounds like you just had it recently in November. Even getting the next test in January is almost too fast to see if anything of shorter duration impact would give you what you feel is a score that is too high. Waiting only two months is actually extremely short. Most doctors would tell you to wait 3 or 4 months to get a better picture. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Simply put, you don't seem to understand why doctors don't want to order repeat PSA testing sooner than you think would be good. All you get by testing too soon is another test result that isn't reliable.
Posts.Title: Ordering your own PSA test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nick P How remarkable that the survival rates for untreated aren't that much lower at 10 years compared to the other options. At 68 with my PSA of 38 and my Gleason score of 8 I thought the Surgeon was crazy when he offered me the option of just monitoring it. I chose removal and I'm glad I did and I don't think I'd do it any differently had I read this study before making my decision, but still it does give one pause... Oh, I don't think there was anything wrong with your decision. The following was the description of the men in the study " The median age of the participants was 62 years (range, 50 to 69), the median PSA level at the prostate-check clinic was 4.6 ng per milliliter (range, 3.0 to 19.9), 77% had tumors with a Gleason score of 6 (on a scale from 6 to 10, with higher scores indicating a worse prognosis), and 76% had stage T1c disease;" None of the participants had a psa of anywhere near 38 Median PSA2 --- in ng/ml (IQR3) 4.7 (3.7, 6.7) 4.9 (3.7, 6.7) 4.8 (3.7, 6.7) PSA2 --- 10+ ng/ml (%) 57 (10) 57 (10) 58 (11) That indicates the median psa for the participants was less than 5 ng/ml and that only 10% of the men had a psa over 10.0 The highest PSA out of over 1,600 men was 19.9, or only half of yours. Not sure of what to make of the surgeon suggesting you had the choice to monitor it... unless he thought the 38 was just a blip up.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman 5. you should probably ask that the slides be sent to a lab that focuses on PC for a second opinion. Either dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, orDavid Boatwick at Bostwick Labs. Others may want to chime in here, as I'm not sure if it would change treatment options.. Ordinarily I'd also suggest that slides be sent for a second opinion, but in this case the initial report is so extensive that the we're not talking about small variations that might impact treatment choice. I'm not sure how much additional accuracy, if any, there is in telling if it has escaped the prostate thus far. As the doctor said, he was going to proceed assuming that some cancer had already escaped. Sounds reasonable given the psa results.
Posts.Title: Some advice

Posts.Content: Kargok9, Welcome to the forum. You seem to have things well in hand regarding your options and the time to consider them all without feeling rushed. I was curious as to whether after diagnosis you are still on testosterone shots or gels? I looked up the gist of the Men's Eating and Living Study (MEAL) for Prostate Cancer Patients and though you were disapproved, of course you can do everything they were going to do on your own regarding diet, which is really all the study was about. Actually you can do better because half of those in the study were just going to be the control group, eating a standard diet for the next two years. On your own, you can do everything the intervention group was going to do and even more, as it didn't sound like their dietary changes were over large. Have you already changed your diet or looked into the prior studies about that? Dr. Dean Ornish conducted one smallish study regarding diet and PSA increases as a probable marker for cancer advancing. http://www.ornishspectrum.com/wp-con...ate_Cancer.pdf Also another one on gene expression. http://www.ornishspectrum.com/wp-con...8369.full_.pdf Then there is the general suggested diet at such centers as UCSF (University California Medical Center/School San Francisco) http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf Those it would seem more than cover or exceed anything that was going to be suggested in the MEAL study if you were one of the intervention participants. Can it help? Some evidence it can, but every individual's case is unique. At the very least it is a heart healthy diet as well. Anyway, you'll get loads of advice for surgery here, and less for Brachytherapy, but that has far more to do with the choices people have already made, much like the surgeon you mentioned being all set to take out your prostate as fast as possible. I'd favor the Brachytherapy or even doing the AS for a while longer. I tend to think everyone who gets surgery believes they won't be one of the ones with a problematic outcome. Yet someone is on the other side of the outcome data. Here is a article I just happened to see yesterday, though it isn't new http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...0808115405.htm Just think everyone in the process of making a choice needs to understand the full reality of outcomes. Brachytherapy has its own set of problems. Neither has guarantees of cures, but your case sounds very straightforward. You'll probably be "cured" regardless of what you do. You may even be "cured" if you do nothing at all and just roll the dice. Well, I'm sure you'll hear more. I do think there is too much emphasis on suggesting that your two Gleason 6 5% cores ,may in fact turn out to be Gleason 7 after the fact, because something like 30% get upgraded in the final post surgery pathology. But allowing that type of thinking to dominate your decision process makes everyone approach their Gleason rating as being worse than it is graded. NO end to that kind of thinking. Makes it as though all choices should be based on no one really having a Gleason 6, which as we know is actually the most common grade. So some thoughts. You get lots more. The dietary changes you can do while you make up your mind.

The dietary changes you can do while you make up your mind.
Posts.Title: New player on the block

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Popi Just found out that I can order my own PSA test through my hospital's lab. ($30) I will not use the results to self-diagnose, but I fret, and waiting until the end of February for my next test is killing me. . The testing concept is nice although the Sentara Laboratory Services Drawsite Locations are limited. Regarding your urgent "need to know"--- Rather than just thinking about what to type, I'll simply repost what I told you on November 26th. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Goodness, slow down. You've had essentially one single PSA test of 2.35 (the second one right away is simply a retest so average the two) Sounds like you just had it recently in November. Even getting the next test in January is almost too fast to see if anything of shorter duration impact would give you what you feel is a score that is too high. Waiting only two months is actually extremely short. Most doctors would tell you to wait 3 or 4 months to get a better picture. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Simply put, you don't seem to understand why doctors don't want to order repeat PSA testing sooner than you think would be good. All you get by testing too soon is another test result that isn't reliable.
Posts.Title: Ordering your own PSA test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Popi Why would getting the test sooner than what the Doctor ordered make it unreliable? My guess, waiting 3-4 months between tests simply allows time for a significant enough change to take place. Three tests in one year, or 10 tests in one year...you're still going to arrive at the same numbers by the end. A test result is nothing more than a data point, and really, what's so bad about having more test results than what's normally obtained. . Popi, you fail to understand the issue. Sure, go ahead and get your test. Apparently you don't grasp the reasons why they wait a given amount of time prior to re-testing. Why not test every week? Do you know anything about why psa tests jump around? You have had ONE psa test. The two, close together are really only one test. If your actual PSA is 1.2 and you got your two 2.4 tests then you won't know the real psa score until you allow the conditions to calm down adequately such that the next score will have a greater likely hood of being accurate. A psa test raised by inflammation, unnoticed by you, does not calm down in a week. I won't go on. You seem intent on thinking that all data points are equal and revealing of the true picture. That is entirely wrong. I have had on several occasions a psa of as high as 7.4, turn out 6 months later to be only 3.7. Now, do you think if i had tested again in a few weeks, the inflammation that caused the 7.4 would have gone all the way down to 3.7? Of course not. So I'd get a 6.2 or 5.9 and say OMG.... disaster awaits. Early and premature followup psa testing is of little value. That is why your trained urologist tells you to wait months. He has seen your situation a thousand times.
Posts.Title: Ordering your own PSA test

Posts.Content: I can understand the disappointment your husband is having from the trail being dropped. I did find the below statement regarding your question about Radium-223 causing a PSA to climb. " The prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test is not used to measure response because this level typically continues to rise during treatment with radium-223." I Googled (radium 223 psa response) and saw a article with that quote. Not sure if it pertains to your husbands particular situation. Wishing you and your husband the best during this difficult time.
Posts.Title: Dropped Trial

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman 5. you should probably ask that the slides be sent to a lab that focuses on PC for a second opinion. Either dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, orDavid Boatwick at Bostwick Labs. Others may want to chime in here, as I'm not sure if it would change treatment options.. Ordinarily I'd also suggest that slides be sent for a second opinion, but in this case the initial report is so extensive that the we're not talking about small variations that might impact treatment choice. I'm not sure how much additional accuracy, if any, there is in telling if it has escaped the prostate thus far. As the doctor said, he was going to proceed assuming that some cancer had already escaped. Sounds reasonable given the psa results.
Posts.Title: Some advice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Uncle Bill This is my first post since 2013. I'm hoping someone can help me understand what's going on with me. My PSA count in July 2015 was 4.9, a big jump from January 2015 at 3.0. I'm very worried Date PSA age 7/15 4.9 49 1/15 3.0 49 9/9 3.2 43 Ignore the 4.9 jump. Your psa has been remarkably stable over the last 6 years. Going from 3.2 to 3.0 ..... Getting a jump up to 4.9 means nothing. Simply retest in 6 months. I have had several jumps in my psa... up to 7.5. My last two were 3.3 and 2.8 Some men have psa results that jump and some do not. The only concern is that your psa has been somewhat higher than normal for your age. Inflammation in the pelvic area, or even asymptomatic inflammation, could easily create and abnormal jump in psa. BTW, the vast majority of prostatitis and inflammation is non-bacterial, and thus not cured by antibiotics. Even retesting in September is really not giving a inflammation enough time to calm down. A 3 to 6 month wait between tests would be better.
Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by boeinguy I'm 52. I have no symptoms other than a PSA bouncing around the 4 to 5 area (always been high). So, is this all it takes to be considered as having prostate cancer? Doctor is talking about options; remove prostate, radioactive seeds, etc. My feeling is, do nothing and keep an eye on it. Thanks! If your doctor gave any indication that he thought any of those options were reasonable in your case, I'd be looking for a new doctor. Less than .05 mm is like nothing. Here is some mention of criteria regarding 0.5 ml to 1.3 ml http://www.active-surveillance.com/laurence-klotz-md/ After you do the conversion you can see how tiny .05 mm is http://www.unitjuggler.com/convert-v...ml-to-mm3.html Sure, there may be more somewhere in your prostate, but if you looked hard enough, you'd find .05 mm in almost every guy, age 52, walking down the street. By all means, just keep a eye on it and see what happens. Here is a nice video with two experts in the field. I think you'll be comforted with the opinion expressed. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Mean while it wouldn't be bad to follow a diet that gives you a possible edge on slowing down any progression of cancer that may exist. http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf That very same diet will help all other aspects of your health, especially heart related matters.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Originally Posted by boeinguy I'm 52 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>
in almost every guy  age 52  walking down the street <Z>

Posts.Title: What criteria define's prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Kargok9, Welcome to the forum. You seem to have things well in hand regarding your options and the time to consider them all without feeling rushed. I was curious as to whether after diagnosis you are still on testosterone shots or gels? I looked up the gist of the Men's Eating and Living Study (MEAL) for Prostate Cancer Patients and though you were disapproved, of course you can do everything they were going to do on your own regarding diet, which is really all the study was about. Actually you can do better because half of those in the study were just going to be the control group, eating a standard diet for the next two years. On your own, you can do everything the intervention group was going to do and even more, as it didn't sound like their dietary changes were over large. Have you already changed your diet or looked into the prior studies about that? Dr. Dean Ornish conducted one smallish study regarding diet and PSA increases as a probable marker for cancer advancing. http://www.ornishspectrum.com/wp-con...ate_Cancer.pdf Also another one on gene expression. http://www.ornishspectrum.com/wp-con...8369.full_.pdf Then there is the general suggested diet at such centers as UCSF (University California Medical Center/School San Francisco) http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf Those it would seem more than cover or exceed anything that was going to be suggested in the MEAL study if you were one of the intervention participants. Can it help? Some evidence it can, but every individual's case is unique. At the very least it is a heart healthy diet as well. Anyway, you'll get loads of advice for surgery here, and less for Brachytherapy, but that has far more to do with the choices people have already made, much like the surgeon you mentioned being all set to take out your prostate as fast as possible. I'd favor the Brachytherapy or even doing the AS for a while longer. I tend to think everyone who gets surgery believes they won't be one of the ones with a problematic outcome. Yet someone is on the other side of the outcome data. Here is a article I just happened to see yesterday, though it isn't new http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...0808115405.htm Just think everyone in the process of making a choice needs to understand the full reality of outcomes. Brachytherapy has its own set of problems. Neither has guarantees of cures, but your case sounds very straightforward. You'll probably be "cured" regardless of what you do. You may even be "cured" if you do nothing at all and just roll the dice. Well, I'm sure you'll hear more. I do think there is too much emphasis on suggesting that your two Gleason 6 5% cores ,may in fact turn out to be Gleason 7 after the fact, because something like 30% get upgraded in the final post surgery pathology. But allowing that type of thinking to dominate your decision process makes everyone approach their Gleason rating as being worse than it is graded. NO end to that kind of thinking. Makes it as though all choices should be based on no one really having a Gleason 6, which as we know is actually the most common grade. So some thoughts. You get lots more. The dietary changes you can do while you make up your mind.
Posts.Title: New player on the block

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigbrad2008 ED, a significant issue, finally broke down and Viagra is on the way. Should arrive today as I have a date 2night with a new woman. Maybe if it does not arrive I can act like, I want to wait so I get to know you better. That sounds better than saying, the friggin post office has not got my Viagra to me yet. Brad, I know that is a serious issue, but the way you said it is just too funny lol. BTW, my close friend had surgery in 2007, while dating a woman , a beautiful woman at that, about 20 years younger than himself. Afterwards, he had some difficulty, used meds and finally injections as far as I know, but the bottom line is they got married about 3 years after his surgery and are doing fine. Still, I do understand the initial dating situation.

Posts.Title: New player on the block

Posts.Content: Diagnosed in the last week or two and radiation starting on Monday. That sounds most unusual. I can't imagine any doctor doing such. How long since his biopsy? What treatment options was he given? Is his doctor a urologist? Who is doing the radiation. External radiation or seeds placed internally. Unless you haven't given a entirely clear picture on the timeline, this rapid treatment is most strange indeed. Find out if your father understands what is going on and what his true diagnosis was. Why is it called aggressive. How often does the radiation team do this procedure and what is their record over the years? Is this some small town hospital or a major medical center? I hope your father has received more than one doctors opinion. Lastly, don't feel duty bound to go ahead so quickly if you don't know the answers. Seldom is there a case that needs such a rapid decision or treatment.
Posts.Title: Dad is joining the club

Posts.Content: Interesting study. Cialis doesn't seem to help more than placebo, however most men on the placebo did OK. http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...rapy-patients/ Lots of drugs for all sorts of conditions are like that. They are given, but only do a little better than nothing. Often just enough to get FDA approval.
Posts.Title: Study -Cialis doesnt help to maintain erectile function among radiotherapy patients

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 The surgeon said this is considered a “clinically insignificant” amount of cancer and it his recommendation that we repeat biopsy in 6 months. Therefore he is recommending active surveillance. He was very clear that in his opinion this is not an aggressive situation. I’m curious what any of you would do based upon these results?? Well, at the very least, I wouldn't make any quick decisions. You've only been into this current situation for 2 months and it may take 2 to 4 months before you might get comfortable with all the facts and realities. Slowly learn more while you await a second biopsy. Enjoy the holidays knowing there is no need for speed. You might get another PSA in 3 or 4 months to make sure your current PSA range is accurate. In short, I'd not do any treatment during the following 6 months. BTW, if you get several "2nd opinions", you are sure to find a urologist who tells you to get surgery now. Then again, to do something active for now, you could send your biopsy slides to John Hopkins for a second reading. A confirmation of the first reading or perhaps a different outcome.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Positive

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 My name is Steve. I am 58 and had an abnormal DRE, along with an elevated PSA of 3.3. So I told him I would do one more PSA and I wanted to see the free psa vs. bound psa numbers - he said ok but it was not part of what he originally ordered for blood work. I am thinking about proceeding to the biopsy sooner rather than later. Any thoughts or advice based on the information I have shared? Why do you say your PSA is elevated? What and when was your prior PSA? This recent 3.3 PSA... What was the date? If you are thinking about doing the next PSA much before the end of the year, you are really rushing it. That last thing you want is to get another PSA soon after the recent one. That will tell you nothing if the result is still around 3.3. I'd say a minimum of 3 months between the 3.3 and your next test. We don't know what "abnormal" means. Abnormal can just mean spongy "boggy" sometimes. Indicative of a possible infection rather than a hardness or nodule. Did the doctor say what he felt? It would be nice to see what your normal psa is before getting a quick biopsy. Perhaps you have more details. Under the circumstances the skilled urologist doesn't seem to feel the urgency you have.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> I am 58 and had an abnormal DRE

Posts.Title: Prostate Questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Robert: With the vast amount of medical info available to you, I am somewhat surprised that you would even mention the possibility of a Kevorkian-like solution. With proper treatment, patients with Stage IV prostate cancer can frequently live to a normal life expectancy and even beyond that age. I know we're trying to be positive here, but men diagnosed with a PSA of 3200 (assuming there was a retest for error) do not live to a normal life expectancy. However some can live many years in relative comfort and enjoy a worthwhile quality of life.

Posts.Title: New player on the block

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KJWin I would love to find out that this is all caused by some inflammatory situation. I've been reading articles all over the place looking for another cause which fits my symptoms, or lack thereof. In the meantime, I went in for the urinalysis earlier today and the results came back amazingly quickly. Everything looks to be within normal ranges. WBC was 0/HPF which seems to rule out asympomatic prostatitis (though that's based on my poor use of Google rather than a discussion with the urologist since their office is closed). I am currently swinging wildly between "it must be something else, just need to figure out what" and "it must be cancer". Waiting and not knowing is terrible. Just because the urinalysis comes back in normal range, does not mean that the psa rise can't be caused by prostatitis. In fact, the majority of asymptomatic prostatitis is non-bacterial. As such it would not show up on the urinalysis as being abnormal. --Acute bacterial prostatitis affects 2-5% of patients with prostatitis. Chronic bacterial prostatitis affects 2-5% of prostatitis patients. Chronic Nonbacterial Prostatitis/Chronic Pelvic Pain Syndrome affects 90-95% of patients with prostatitis. --Asymptomatic inflammatory prostatitis is present in up to 32.2% of men with elevated PSA levels. So, you see, just because you don't feel it, or it doesn't show up in a urinalysis, doesn't by any means suggest it must be prostate cancer. Indeed, the odds are far greater that the cause of your jump in PSA has nothing to do with cancer. Especially given your age, and despite your family history. It will be checked out, though you very likely may get another high psa reading after only two weeks. Prostatitis can be very tough and hang around for some time.
Posts.Title: High PSA at 40 years old - could use some advice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KJWin I have a couple questions if anyone has advice. First, how important is time right now? Is waiting two weeks for a retest a big deal? Objectively it doesn't seem like that long but emotionally it seems like an eternity during which things could go from bad to even worse. Two weeks is really too short of a time... If the jump up is temporarily caused by some version of prostatitis... even asymptomatic prostatitis, then two weeks is not enough time to allow it to calm down. A jump from under 2, to over 8, is much more likely caused by such a inflammatory situation than by cancer. However, given your father's experience, I doubt you or your doctor are willing to wait 3 months. So go ahead and get the test... two weeks is NOT waiting too long by any means. Good that at age 40 you got a benchmark measurement of your normal psa, which assuming this latest one is due to a "itis" of some sort, will leave you with a mark from which to judge future psa results. Let us know the results.

Posts.Title: Radiation vs Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Powderfinger Interestingly, my doc told me today that brachy was something that is not being done so much anymore? I forgot the reason but I got the feeling it was like becoming obsolete? More interestingly, I've read online and perhaps here in this forum that Cryosurgery hasn't been proven so much yet so many don't even consider it a viable option. But my Doc said today he does it regularly and I should consider it as an option....So I do think I have much to investigate. You definitely need to get a opinion from a doctor that is not so negative about brachy. It is very mainstream. That your doctor would say that it is something that is not being done so much anymore is absurd. Then for him to suggest Cryosurgery is what he does regularly suggests he might have more than a mild bias in the matter. This is not uncommon for doctors to tell their patients that the procedure they do is the best. Cryo may be great, but you won't find many people on forums who have had cryosurgery. Sounds like you haven't had much more than a week to really be reading about all this, your biopsy being only a week ago. So much information and so little of it gives a clear picture making a choice simple. Lots of people go for surgery with the idea that it provides a greater chance of total cure. I do not think there is much data to back that up comparing it to other options. It may be just as good, but to suggest it is better is another matter. BTW, there is surgery and there is radiation and there is brachy.... In the case of brachy some do both that and regular external radiation at the same time. You will hear lots of things about sexual performance outcomes after surgery and brachy. First of all, you need the doctor to be very clear about his definition of sex after surgery and what he defines as a erection and his percentage outcomes. This because some doctors give out inflated numbers regarding outcomes of sexual ability and urinary continence. Over all one of the biggest problems with surgery is that the patients often complain they weren't given the true picture of outcomes. This can happen with any treatment but is a more common complaint with surgery. Expressed for years, as seen in a article such as this http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/0...-surgery/?_r=0 Lots of people opt for surgery because they "want it out"... You've been through a lot over the years, so you may have a more realistic picture of what odds and data mean. There are no guarantees with any treatment or any surgery. Sexual ability and recovery is not guaranteed with any treatment, but surgical procedures leave many with less than expected outcomes. Here is a NPR radio discussion on that matter http://www.npr.org/2011/10/03/141014...cancer-surgery Now I don't want to give you a overly negative picture. One of my closest friends had his prostate surgery in 2007 and was married in 2010 to his much younger wife, and before and after marriage things worked out, as he used injections when needed. Not the terrible thing most imagine. They were together for years before and now years after surgery. He was 57 at the time of surgery. He has no regrets. I know another individual who was about the same age and he never had a problem or so I was told by his cousin. But as in that radio show, lots of people are disappointed in that the doctors never fully informed then about the real data of outcomes regarding sexual performance and ability. If you have not already done so you can read many more first person examples on http://www.healingwell.com/community/?f=35 and hundreds of men on http://www.yananow.org/Links.shtml Don't want to flood you with information as it can be overwhelming when you first dive in but those are some excellent sites. Also http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/treatment/ showing you a list of potential treatment options. Take your time and you'll end up with a suitable treatment and great chances for a long future. My father thought he was going to die soon, as his prostate cancer was out of the capsule and inoperable. He had radiation and died of other causes 25 years later at age 88. Yes, he did have side effects as time went on. No treatment is without the chance of those. Wish you well. Give yourself adequate time to investigate your options and to seek second opinions. Perhaps even see someone who specializes in brachy for his take.

Posts.Title: New member, just diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Powderfinger Interestingly, my doc told me today that brachy was something that is not being done so much anymore? I forgot the reason but I got the feeling it was like becoming obsolete? More interestingly, I've read online and perhaps here in this forum that Cryosurgery hasn't been proven so much yet so many don't even consider it a viable option. But my Doc said today he does it regularly and I should consider it as an option....So I do think I have much to investigate. You definitely need to get a opinion from a doctor that is not so negative about brachy. It is very mainstream. That your doctor would say that it is something that is not being done so much anymore is absurd. Then for him to suggest Cryosurgery is what he does regularly suggests he might have more than a mild bias in the matter. This is not uncommon for doctors to tell their patients that the procedure they do is the best. Cryo may be great, but you won't find many people on forums who have had cryosurgery. Sounds like you haven't had much more than a week to really be reading about all this, your biopsy being only a week ago. So much information and so little of it gives a clear picture making a choice simple. Lots of people go for surgery with the idea that it provides a greater chance of total cure. I do not think there is much data to back that up comparing it to other options. It may be just as good, but to suggest it is better is another matter. BTW, there is surgery and there is radiation and there is brachy.... In the case of brachy some do both that and regular external radiation at the same time. You will hear lots of things about sexual performance outcomes after surgery and brachy. First of all, you need the doctor to be very clear about his definition of sex after surgery and what he defines as a erection and his percentage outcomes. This because some doctors give out inflated numbers regarding outcomes of sexual ability and urinary continence. Over all one of the biggest problems with surgery is that the patients often complain they weren't given the true picture of outcomes. This can happen with any treatment but is a more common complaint with surgery. Expressed for years, as seen in a article such as this http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/0...-surgery/?_r=0 Lots of people opt for surgery because they "want it out"... You've been through a lot over the years, so you may have a more realistic picture of what odds and data mean. There are no guarantees with any treatment or any surgery. Sexual ability and recovery is not guaranteed with any treatment, but surgical procedures leave many with less than expected outcomes. Here is a NPR radio discussion on that matter http://www.npr.org/2011/10/03/141014...cancer-surgery Now I don't want to give you a overly negative picture. One of my closest friends had his prostate surgery in 2007 and was married in 2010 to his much younger wife, and before and after marriage things worked out, as he used injections when needed. Not the terrible thing most imagine. They were together for years before and now years after surgery. He was 57 at the time of surgery. He has no regrets. I know another individual who was about the same age and he never had a problem or so I was told by his cousin. But as in that radio show, lots of people are disappointed in that the doctors never fully informed then about the real data of outcomes regarding sexual performance and ability. If you have not already done so you can read many more first person examples on http://www.healingwell.com/community/?f=35 and hundreds of men on http://www.yananow.org/Links.shtml Don't want to flood you with information as it can be overwhelming when you first dive in but those are some excellent sites. Also http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/treatment/ showing you a list of potential treatment options. Take your time and you'll end up with a suitable treatment and great chances for a long future. My father thought he was going to die soon, as his prostate cancer was out of the capsule and inoperable. He had radiation and died of other causes 25 years later at age 88. Yes, he did have side effects as time went on. No treatment is without the chance of those. Wish you well. Give yourself adequate time to investigate your options and to seek second opinions. Perhaps even see someone who specializes in brachy for his take.

Posts.Title: New member, just diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 The surgeon said this is considered a “clinically insignificant” amount of cancer and it his recommendation that we repeat biopsy in 6 months. Therefore he is recommending active surveillance. He was very clear that in his opinion this is not an aggressive situation. I’m curious what any of you would do based upon these results?? Well, at the very least, I wouldn't make any quick decisions. You've only been into this current situation for 2 months and it may take 2 to 4 months before you might get comfortable with all the facts and realities. Slowly learn more while you await a second biopsy. Enjoy the holidays knowing there is no need for speed. You might get another PSA in 3 or 4 months to make sure your current PSA range is accurate. In short, I'd not do any treatment during the following 6 months. BTW, if you get several "2nd opinions", you are sure to find a urologist who tells you to get surgery now. Then again, to do something active for now, you could send your biopsy slides to John Hopkins for a second reading. A confirmation of the first reading or perhaps a different outcome.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Positive

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Imp 1st MRI was good 6 months ago but last week had 2nd MRI and was informed that one of the lesions seems to have changed shape. It's still small but if it's changed its probably not 3+3. In the NY I'll have another template guided biopsy to see if it's changed to a more aggressive level than previous 3+3. I'm guessing it has. From what I've ever read, there is no reason to think that the 3+3 lesion... if it changes shape or grows, then turns into a higher grade such as 4+3 . Now, they might find a new lesion that is higher grade, but the old one would be possibly larger but of the same grade. Did your doctor suggest otherwise, or have you just assumed that as a lesion grows, it changes to a higher grade?

Posts.Content: Sounds like you are doing fine in your choice of approach. I do have one question about the following. "5/1/15: Diagnosed adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 6 (pattern 3+3), involving approximately 10%" How many samples were taken... 10, 12, or more? Out of, say 12 cores, how many were Gleason 6 at approximately 10%? One, or two, or ?
Posts.Title: Saying "Hello"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe . So without talking to the doctor I’m not sure when he will want to do a PSA or another biopsy. All that worry (for now anyway) for nothing. Good outcome. Seems like you'd want to wait at least 6 months for your next psa test. Then, and only then, if you get a higher result, you might consider doing a biopsy. However, if you retest and its up to 6.5 or more, you might still want to wait 3 more months to confirm that jump. You don't want to be doing multiple biopsies without good reason.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Jack1954! In your case, even with pristine surgical results, most MDs will recommend Adjuvant or Salvage Radiation for G9 PC. So you are suggesting that almost anyone with G9 will have radiation recommended regardless of the post surgical findings. In this case, Jack1954 has said that two of his biopsy samples were as follows "And 2 cores shows 100% cancer entire tissue.(these core were taken from the left peripheral zone which was highlighted in the MRI as heterogeneous signal and also during the TRUS biopsy) " Given what you say about most MDs recommending radiation...just in case..., then why even do the surgery if you are going to do the radiation regardless. Does that suggest that radiation is "iffy" as to its ability to destroy the cancer inside the prostate? Such that it is better to remove it? Seems if radiation is almost certain, then why do the surgery? I don't know the answer to this, as this is not a topic I have looked into.

Posts.Content: "In more than 14,000 radical prostatectomies, there was not a single case of a Gleason score 6 tumor ever spreading to lymph nodes." Though there is always the chance of finding a 3+4 or 4+3 in the post surgical pathology report, the information above may well allow many more men to be willing to go ahead with AS for several years. Zero in 14,000 is pretty impressive.

Posts.Title: Surgery success for Gleason 9

Posts.Content: Thought you might find this interesting. My father was diagnosed back in January 1974. I just came across his "Anatomical Pathology Consultation Report" ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --Clinical Data (what his Dr gave with the specimen) Benign prostatic hypertrophy. ?? neoplasm of prostate. Report: Gross: Specimen consists of 3 cylindrical portions of friable grey-white tissue averaging 1 cm. in length and 1 mm in width. All are embedded. Microscopic: The prostate tissue is diffusely infiltrated by somewhat pleomorphic small tumor glands. These are lined by cuboidal cells with prominent dark nuclei. Diagnosis: PROSTATE BIOPSY WITH INFILTRATING ADENOCARCINOMA. Signed, Dr. xxxx xxxxx ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So, this was in the pre PSA era and pre-Gleason era. You don't get all the 3 + 3 or 4 +3 stuff. You didn't get the 10 to 14 cores, nor the percentage of each core. No ultrasound to guide the biopsy. It appears that only 3 cores were taken. It is difficult to read the report and see what the nature of his cancer was. I've looked up the terms but can' t get a fix. I heard from him that it was "inoperable" but don't know how his doctor might have established that to be the case. Meaning it seems his doctor felt it was already outside the capsule. Might have been very lucky for him because surgery back then was not nearly so precise or gentle. Anyway he got external beam Cobalt radiation, followed up by a form of hormone treatment. 1.0 mg of DES. Still in use and very cheap in some cases. Rarely used now. Not sure why. I've heard a few guys have still used it. It is amazingly inexpensive as it is generic. Anyway, he was diagnosed at age 63 and treated at age 64 and lived to age 88. At the end, with the PSA test now in place, his results were always 0.0 I even took him off the hormone pills in the last few years and his psa stayed at 0.0 I removed him from the pills because they were causing so much water retention and quality of life issues. I wonder if he even needed to be on the pills for all those years. However since it was apparently working, no one wanted to rock the boat,, and risk cancer returning. In his 25 years after diagnosis he did have quality of life issues from the radiation treatments. Including bleeding in the bladder and an occasional blockage of the urethra from a blood clot. Then the rush to a emergency room before he exploded. Radiation was less precise back then and there were more tissues affected. Bladder, Anal sphincter muscle, etc. Also the hormone treatments caused the usual problems and body changes. Plus, nice people didn't discuss these issues back then. Just you and the occasional visit to your doctor. No forums. All very scary and embarrassing. No support groups. Perhaps the radiation killed everything and he could have gone without the hormone treatment after the first few months. Who knows. So, that is the limited information they got in the past from a biopsy. That and no PSA number. Flying blind. Anyway, I hadn't seen this pathology report before now and thought it was interesting. Interestingly I am the exact same age as he was when diagnosed. Thus my continued interest. PS, this is about DES as a substitute drug http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22578092 http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...ement-of-crpc/

AgeInfo.Phrase: he was diagnosed at age 63 and treated at age 64
63 and treated at age 64 and lived to age 88

Posts.Title: Surgery success for Gleason 9

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Cathy792 My partner was diagnosed today with prostate cancer. The doctor told him that he is a 6 on a scale of 1 to 10.. Cathy, Well, of course we weren't in the room to hear the doctors exact words, but if that is what he said... then that is a terrible way to describe it to a naive patient. Left out of the "6 on a scale of 1 to 10" is the fact that Gleason 5 is not even considered cancer. Thus 6 is the absolute lowest that even qualifies. (BTW, the profession is in the process of replacing that troubling way to describe what is and isn't cancer). We don't know your partners age and that is important. It may surprise you, but by the time men reach 80, the majority of them have some prostate cancer. Mostly undiscovered and undiagnosed. In addition to his age, you might tell us why they did a biopsy. Was his PSA test result high, relative to his past PSA history? Also, you will almost certainly want to get a second reading of his biopsy samples. Some men get downgraded from cancer to no cancer. As you can see the diagnosis and grading of prostate cancer can vary from doctor to doctor that looks at the biopsy samples. You should get your partner to come to this site and give the details. Seems like right now, all that you and he have in your mind is C-A-N-C-E-R... (which most people equate with death) You should be aware that the long time statistics show that only 1 man in 6 diagnosed with prostate cancer, dies from the disease. A fair percentage require no treatment at all. Let us know more details and encourage your partner to come here and gain a view of his condition with a bit more perspective than he might get in a single visit to the doctor. Often times the patient leaves the office in a daze, only remembering the word CANCER and thinking the worst. Cheer up, he is most likely going to be around for a very long time.
Posts.Title: Newbie with a question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon For what it's worth I would suggest you meet with the best surgeon and best oncologist you can find for their recommendations. Your 3+3 is better than my 3+4 but were it me, given your age and diabetes, I would be pro-active and not consider active surveillance. Allen Well, of course we would want to know how many of the cores were Gleason 6, and what percent of each of those was involved. That would make a difference. I don't exactly understand why being 67 and having Type 2 diabetes would make anyone "be pro-active and not consider active surveillance" ? However here is a study suggesting that danger may be somewhat greater. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24384808 I would say this, the danger of heart attack and stroke due to the Type 2 diabetes still far outweighs the risk of mortality from prostate cancer. We don't know the details, but I'd be paying as much or more attention to my heart risk factors... diet and exercise... than to my choice of treatment or surveillance of prostate cancer. To include a huge emphasis on getting any possible excess weight off via the diet and exercise even though the type 2 may be controlled with meds in some.

Posts.Title: Surgery success for Gleason 9

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Knowing that something like 20% (25%?) of biopsies results are upgraded, one can only hope that PC detection (biopsy, MRI etc) and the reliability of biopsy scoring increases Actually the reliability of biopsy scoring is excellent. The problem is hitting the target with 10 to 14 samples. However, those that choose AS with a Gleason 6 will almost all be doing follow-up biopsies. Say two more over the next 2 to 4 years. With each subsequent follow-up the odds of having missed a higher Gleason grade core will drop. Obviously at the same time, the PSA will be observed. And then, perhaps as many as 50% will decide to do a treatment down the line. Even those will almost all end up with a result every bit as effective as if they had done treatment initially. Of course, a few will have made a poor choice, but I'd guess that percentage to be very low.

Posts.Title: Newbie with a question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman there is a lot of good support here for PC patients, especially newbies. But while I've found multiple forums on the subject, none of them are active. That's crazy to me, considering how widespread Heart disease is in the developed world. Like you, I've come across no heart forum comparable to this prostate cancer forum. I also think it is crazy, given the huge number of people with typical heart disease. I see you found the HW forum, but as I visit it every few months, I find it fairly useless for the typical traditional heart disease subject. So many other forums are dead or have infrequent and old replies. I'll keep looking and perhaps someone here will tell us about something We have missed.
Posts.Title: Need a Resource

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I read that 80% of heart attacks do not come from blockages but from an artery rupturing or a piece of plaque breaking off and clotting. So I worry about a sudden event. You can, to some degree, regularize and alter the most dangerous areas via diet and statins, in a fairly short time frame. The softer lipid pool is what you are worried about, breaking through, and releasing substances that set up a thrombosis (clot). Take a look at the changes over a very short term that begin to take shape in a artery in this example. Notice the lessening of the blue lipid pool(s) as you blow up Figure 2 http://www.journalofcardiologycases....2811%2900025-9 There are lots of reasons to think you can greatly stabilize those regions that are most prone to rupture and thrombosis, over a period of a few months. Not reversal, but stabilization in the shorter term.
Posts.Title: Need a Resource

Posts.Content: Of course we all await the much needed better tests that will surely come in the next 10 years, but until then, there are still some interesting statistics and research about AS The overview of the journal article Link removed because similar site URLs are prohibited by forum rules. However, if anyone wishes to know the URL, it would be okay to send Otago a PM to obtain it. In any case, the other link below is to a very similar article. --Chuck The actual article http://journals.lww.com/co-urology/F...rative.15.aspx
Posts.Title: Interesting new journal article on AS following Gleason 6 diagnosis

Posts.Content: Men who are diagnosed with prostate cancer face two realities. Five out of six will not die of the disease. They are much more likely to die of heart disease and related vascular diseases as well as precipitating diseases such as diabetes. Each of those threats are very treatable and often preventable by the very same diet that is thought to be the best for preventing and slowing prostate cancer. Additionally, obesity is more and more being linked to the chance of more aggressive prostate cancer. So if you eat in manner that is best for the most likely causes of a premature death, then you will also be eating in a manner thought to be best for prostate cancer. Seems like a no brainer for your overall health. Yet for some reason, men get really motivated and scared when the word "cancer" comes up, but shirk off the much higher probability of a early death due to all those other causes. We don't always think or act logically. For a over all diet that can help with all of the above, look at the extensive information included from UCSF prostate center. A highly repected medical center and training center. http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf That includes most of the ideas. If you are really motivated you might read the following http://www.ornishspectrum.com/wp-con...ate_Cancer.pdf So, in short, for most men, start worrying about that heart attack causing your death, instead of your prostate cancer. Better yet, do the diet that is probably best for both.

Posts.Title: Need a Resource

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sarg This isn't really about prostate cancer. This is American Heart Month. Just a reminder if you have any sort of chest pain, go get checked out! I had the pain for awhile and didn't get it checked until a couple of weeks ago. I just got out of the hospital yesterday after a quadruple bypass. So pay attention to your body. It is scary as hell going in for a bypass surgery. Sarg, good to hear you are on the mend. Its been a eventful 3 years in your health. Prostate cancer surgery (with a great doctor) and now quadruple bypass...(that seems to have been done well also). I just want to add a bit of what Pratoman has come around to understand. Your combination of genes and lifestyle brought the heart condition to a danger point, and despite your new plumbing, the same process will continue unless you radically alter your lifestyle. They bypassed the 4 dangerous areas, but the process is system wide and will come back again, either in other areas or in the new plumbing unless you make some fairly drastic changes. Just taking the meds... including a statin... will not do the job by itself. I would agree with Pratoman that you, from this point forward, look into altering your diet in a manner similar to that which Dr. Dean Ornish advises. There are several similar doctors, but he is one of the best known ones. Former president Bill Clinton underwent a multiple bypass and then only moderately changed his diet. A few years later his bypasses were closing up. They had to put stents in his bypassed arteries. From that point forward Clinton went the whole 9 yards and did the nearly complete alteration of his diet with the help of Dr. Ornish and Dr. Esselstyn. Thus far he has been doing well and now considers his new diet...along with the meds... part of normal every day living. I would only advise that you not follow his original path of waiting until the bypass needed new procedures. Often times cardiologists will not lead you in this direction. Not because they don't believe it is healthy, but rather because they believe (with good reason), that very few patients will follow through. Up to you.... but if you have not already done so, begin studying these alternative ways of eating. Books, videos,, the information is out there on a largely plant based way of eating. Some will insist it isn't proven for everyone.... the general population. But you are not everyone. You are a person with a proven susceptibility to coronary artery disease. OK... I realize you are in your very first days... Just past a HUGE major hurdle. I normally wouldn't lay all this on someone right away, but in a few weeks, this thread will be old and history. Too late for me to give my advice. I now eat this way, and also take my meds, including statin. You and I are the same age. You have been through so much, I wish that your future is filled with far less drama and many good healthy years.
Posts.Title: Health

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ray61 Well this was a surprise. Newly diagnosed Jan 9th. 3+3=6 gleason with PNI. 24 cores done, only one confirmed PC, the others showed atypical cells. My urologist recommended prostatectomy or radiation. I want it out. Have an appointment at Shands with Dr Su who is supposed to be pretty good with the robot. Look forward to getting info from this site. Goodness, SLOW DOWN.. What is your most recent psa and psa history? What is your age? How many biopsies have you had prior to this one? Why in the world did they do a 24 core biopsy? Are you really sure that you had 1 core at 3+3=6 and ALL of the other 23 were found with atypical cells? I've never heard of such a report. Not saying it isn't possible, only very unusual. That one positive core, what percentage was involved? (like 10% or 40%... etc.) Have you had a second opinion reading of those 24 samples? Any family history of prostate cancer? If so, what outcome? Its a natural reaction to say "I want it out"... but remind yourself, its been sitting there for years, not just a few months. In most cases its growing very slowly. You'd do well, depending on those other questions I raised, to take a good deal of time to understand the situation and to consider your options. Unless there is important information you left out, you could take 6 months or a year to make a decision and not likely affect the outcome of your case.

These statements have not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration. None of these products or services are intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease." Important sentence " None of these products or services are intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease"

Posts.Title: Health

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wolfgang After my prostatectomy I got severe Urinary Tract Infection (via the catheter I guess). I told the nurse I had severe pain (the doc was never accessible) and she said it is normal to have pain after the surgery up to 6 weeks so I suffered the pain until the follow-up. When I told my surgeon I still have severe pain and can't even walk normally he was surprised. You cannot listen to the "gatekeepers". If you are in real pain you need to plant yourself in the doctors office and refuse to leave. Nurses hear about pain on every call. They lump all pain into one box. If needed exaggerate... or at the very least be very precise. Remember, when that nurse gets off the phone, she is not feeling any of your pain.... and the doctor never hears about it at all. Physical presence in the doctors office... right at the desk or window.... Harder for them to ignore a body right in front of them who refuses to leave.
Posts.Title: Still Fighting Infection after Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dmcook695 Hello all! My head is in a tailspin as I was just told late last night that my father was going in for a biopsy this morning and has ended up with a dx of probable prostate cancer. Basically the surgeon told my mother that we need to wait until Wed. for the biopsy results but the tissue did not look good. He said he did a very slight TURP to give him a little relief but wanted to handle the tissue as little as possible. My brother who is an MD and mother who is a nurse said they will both be shocked if biopsy comes back negative. My dad is 79 and generally healthy but has a history of BPH and has had ongoing symptoms of this, just worsening over the last 6 weeks. Any thoughts? Wednesday seems like an eternity away at this point! Thanks! As indicated, you will know very little until the biopsy results come back. Wednesday would be a very rapid turnaround. If he gets diagnosed with prostate cancer, unless it is very aggressive, he is unlikely to die from the disease. At his age he will most likely outlast the disease and die from other "natural" causes. And you should know the following. If you were to closely examine 100 men his age, half of them would have some prostate cancer, undiscovered in most cases. It is almost normal to have some prostate cancer by age 79. For most, it will go undiagnosed and untreated, never threatening their life. You can just wait and see... Report back and let us know what the biopsy reveals.

some prostate cancer by age 79 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Newbie with question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ray61 Sorry I wasn't more clear. I had 2 biopsys of 12 cores each over a two month period. Both had 4-6 cores of atypical cells, the last one had one core of PC at 5%. Because there was PNI (perineural invasion) I was told by 2 Docs that active surveillance should be avoided as the cancer is a little more aggressive than the gleason score suggests. Dr Su at Shands will give me the third and final opinion in two weeks. He is the head of the Urology robotics program and one of the best in Florida. If not for the PNI, They all agree that the active surveillance would be the best course. Johns Hopkins agrees with this standard. Oh, and my PSA is 6.7. Spiked from 4.2 in 3 months. Yes, that makes a bit more sense. I wasn't aware of John Hopkins standard relating to PNI and doing AS. I would say one thing though regarding "Oh, and my PSA is 6.7. Spiked from 4.2 in 3 months.", I doubt that the "spike" from 4.2 to 6.7 over only 3 months was mostly caused by a growing prostate cancer. Far more probable that it was due to other causes. If only over 3 months that would suggest a rate or rise of over 10 points in a single year. Not likely given your biopsy results. So I wouldn't use that to suggest a particular urgency.

Posts.Title: DaVinci 6/25/2013

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman In the spirit of looking for something new to worry about when it doesn't yet exist, I went to the various nomogram tools on the MSKCC, Johns Hopkins, and Cleveland Clinic websites, and input my pathology stats. What I found was all three showing a 99% 15 year PC specific survival rate. However when it came to 2, 5, 7, and 10 year Biochemical recurrence free rate, the numbers for 10 year where in the low 90% range, on the CC and JH Nomograms, but 81% on the MSKCC website. Anybody have any thoughts on this? . How would the biochemical recurrence free rate for you.... of from 81% to 90%.... stack up with the average 64 year old man's "occurrence rate" walking down the street, never having been diagnosed in the first place. Given that 1 out of 6 such men will be diagnosed, it would seem like that man chances are about the same as yours at about 16%. You at from 10% to 19%.

AgeInfo.Phrase: stack up with the average 64 year old man's  occurrence rate

Posts.Title: Surprise

Posts.Content: That course of treatment sounds reasonable, however I still think it would be wise to get at least one second opinion. There are different types and courses of radiation. Not sure which type of doctor gave you that first choice. There may be in your area, doctors who specialize in prostate radiation treatment as opposed to general radiation treatment. I don't know, but in any case, you'd be wise to get a second opinion on the case. Also find out how many treatments the treating radiologist has performed on prostate cancers. As with surgery, the experience of the doctor and the treatment center team, are very important. I'm not well versed on radiation, except to know there are different types and courses in various treatments. I'd want to know why one type is being chosen vs another type. Thus the need for a second opinion. Which may only confirm the first choice. BTW, my father had radiation for prostate cancer at age 63 and lived until age 88, dying of other causes. So have a positive outlook.

AgeInfo.Phrase: for prostate cancer at age 63 and lived until age 88
