Any family history of prostate cancer? If so, what outcome? Its a natural reaction to say "I want it out"... but remind yourself, its been sitting there for years, not just a few months. In most cases its growing very slowly. You'd do well, depending on those other questions I raised, to take a good deal of time to understand the situation and to consider your options. Unless there is important information you left out, you could take 6 months or a year to make a decision and not likely affect the outcome of your case.
Posts.Title: Surprise

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Drbbt Hello everyone. I'd like to say that I am happy to be here, but I will say that I am happy that this forum is here. This is my first post, but I've been helped immensely by what I have found here already. I found out that I have PCa on July 22nd, just 4 days before my 48th birthday. I was not new to urology as I began having occasional bouts of prostatitis back in my early 30s. My PSA had fluctuated a bit over the past 5 years, but had never gone above 2.5 and had always settled back down. Couple of years ago it climbed to 2.6 and created some anxiety for me. We retested and it dropped to 1.7. For the next year, I forgot that I even had a prostate. Then it shot up to 4.2 (!!!) a year later. Based my history of chronic prostatitis and years of fluctuations, my doctor recommended a round of antibiotics and a retest. 2 months later it was down to 3.2. He told me to come back in four months, but it was basically the same at 3.1. He recommended the biopsy (which was slightly uncomfortably in one lobe, but hurt like a mug in the other!). Results revealed 3/12 cores positive (all Gleason 6) with up to 30% of volume in the three cores. No evidence of PIN. I took the news like a champ, but slowly unraveled over the next few days. My uro has done hundreds of open prostatectomies and recommended surgery, although he took a couple of hours to explain all of my options to me and did not push anything. He said that I had some time and that I should carefully weigh my options. I have done my research and talked to other doctors, but believe surgery is my best course of action. I have been fortunate to have never had surgery in my life and I have some apprehension, but I also have a young family and I want the best shot that I can get. I am leaning on God and my always supportive wife and I am very grateful to have found this forum. Your psa seems in both the measurement and gyration seems almost normal for someone with such a history of chronic prostatitis. Really hard to tell what it would be without that condition. Still, now that you've had the biopsy you were faced with a decision. I'll tell you one thing, I would not proceed with surgery before having another expert read the same slides. Like Dr. Epstein at John Hopkins. You are moving as rapidly as possible having surgery only 2 months after the biopsy. I don't see the need to rush before exploring the entire situation. Your doctor has done hundreds. How many has he done in the last 6 months? I mean, "hundreds" could mean 250 spread over 20 years, or about 1 per month. I don't know, he could be doing several each week, keeping his skills sharp. You get only one shot at surgery. Take your time to make sure it goes well. Be very clear about the reality of the side effects of surgery. The definitions that the doctor uses and definitions that you use when discussing those issues. Often times people can be using the same words but not meaning the same thing as to the degree of the side effects.

Posts.Title: Another Newbie: 48 years old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Vick Anyway, it seems like mine is minimal, but I have an appointment with a Radiologist Oncologist this Friday, and an appointment with a surgeon on February 2nd. The more I research, the more confused I get. by the way, I am 61, will be 62 in February, and still work full time (45 - 50 hours a week - my company). Any suggestions? Yes, keep in mind that your results are minimal in terms of needing to do anything quickly. So allow yourself plenty of time to remove some of that confusion you've been getting from all your reading. Not saying anything will clear it up completely, but you will begin to view it from different perspective. Don't let either the radiologist or surgeon talk you into any quick decision. You may want get your biopsy samples read by another doctor, such as one at John Hopkins. For a sound confirmation. Not difficult and it doesn't take long. The results might be different. I know the word cancer scares some people, but right now, the larger danger to your health and longevity is from heart disease and stroke due to you being a Type 2 diabetic. So put the prostate cancer risk in perspective. People often think little of diabetes compared to cancer. As far as working, keep in mind all the men who have or have had prostate cancer who a are still working.... well past age 62. Secretary of State John Kerry, age 71, keeps up a schedule that would kill most men. Not forgetting that he had his prostate cancer treated the year before running for president in 2004. What could be more difficult than running for president? Hundreds of other well known men have gone through everything, hardly missing a beat in their work. Keep reading and keep all your options open. And don't overlook that Type 2. That is the real danger over the next 15 years.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Yes, it comes up from time to time, but I have never read anything indicating it has any value... No valid studies indicate it works for anyone. I'd say it is a waste of time regardless of what some internet sites would have you believe. What are the details of your loved one's prostate cancer? Why search for unproven protocols?
Posts.Title: Anyone used or heard of the Budwig protocol

Posts.Content: We must all be aware that doctors are human. As such their advice can be influenced by motivations that may not always be in the best interests of the patient. Look at this recent article where doctors that have a financial interest in radiation treatment may increase their usage of such equipment by a large percentage. "The rate of IMRT use by self-referring urologists in private practice increased from 13.1 to 32.3%, an increase of 19.2 percentage points" http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1201141 This type of bias could extend to other forms of treatment. Even to some types of surgery. Thus the need for second opinions and a full understanding of how a doctor is compensated. Doctors may even have this bias and be unaware of how it is influencing them. They would honestly deny it but it may still be present. This article about the same NEJM entry http://www.businessweek.com/news/201...ts-reap-profit
Posts.Title: Doctors treatment choices influenced by monetary factors

Posts.Content: There is no rush. Don't even think about coming to a final decision on what to do, for at least a month or more. A decision you make in two months will not impact your success. What ever cancer you have has been growing for years and won't be much different in October than it is today. That will be more clear after your provide all the details... positive cores, percent of each, gleason of each. Then realize each doctor you consult will claim his solution is best. Right now you are overloaded with information. Take weeks, even months to digest it. Very little evidence that rushing will improve your outcome.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 7Seas i am litteraly in tears right now. I can't stop reaserching the life expectacy of this desease and have scared myself to an extensive degree. your reasurance that I am not going to die in five years come not a moment to soon. Thank you. Good to hear you are finding some relief from your worries. We don't know your age or your psa history... all your past psa tests including the most recent. You might include that in a future post. Generally speaking, without knowing your other details, even if you did no treatment, you'd live more than 5 years. Now, to be clear, I am NOT advising doing nothing, only telling you that your concerns about 5 years are way off. As the others have indicated, there is every probability that you will never die due to your prostate cancer. Only about 1 in 6 men with prostate cancer die from it. And almost all of them have Gleason scores higher than yours. My father was concerned he would die from his inoperable prostate cancer. Made some last minute trips to see Europe one more time. Ran himself ragged and worried greatly. Well, he lived 25 more years, dying at age 88 of other causes. The prostate cancer never did return. Modern day treatments are much better than what my father had to choose from. So, go to your appointment, take a yellow pad with all your questions, and realize that you have many weeks to decide on your choice of treatment.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mitchden 7) The thought of having surgery and then having a negative biopsy is frightening. Do you know how frequent this happens? Hopefully, very very rarely. When my urologist did the DRE, he said that 1 side of the prostrate felt "rubbery". Has anyone had this reported? He was surprised that the cancerous core came from the other side of the prostate. Two weeks ago, I saw a radiation oncologist who also did a DRE. He told me he didn't feel anything. #8-- from another excellent site The DRE is used to detect possible signs of prostate illness: A DRE that finds a smooth, soft prostate but that causes intense pain is commonly a sign of prostate infection, also known as prostatitis. ---(I've also been told in those cases where there many be a asymptomatic prostate infection and no feeling of pain, described as feeling "boggy" upon exam...kind of spongy soft.) A DRE that finds a smooth, rubbery, and enlarged prostate is commonly a sign of prostate enlargement, also known as benign prostate hyperplasia. A DRE that finds hard nodules, generalized firmness, or an unusual shape to the prostate is commonly a sign of prostate cancer. #7--- I'm thinking that many patients are not fully informed about the final pathology when such negative cases come about. Unless the patient inquires further, everyone just walks away whistling while they look skyward. Perhaps thats just my imagination... or perhaps not.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman , 2.7, 2.9,2.7, then 3.1 six months ago. Went to uro doc today, got results - 4.3. Seems like a bigger jump than in the past. I am scheduled for biopsy next week. UGH. Am i wrong to think the odds of a negative biopsy are very much stacked against me here? Looks like until this recent psa of 4.3, that your psa has made only a tiny advance. From 2.7 to 3.1 over what appears to be a few years. Fair chance that if you repeated the psa in 3 months, you might easily go back down to a 3.2 or so. I'd retest your psa before undergoing another biopsy. Certainly don't see the need for a rush. I'm very conservative in these matters. Of course I don't know your fathers history. What was his psa and what was his Gleason score and how did his prostate cancer proceed. Was he treated and did it shorten his life, or did he die of other causes? ( given your age, I do realize he may have had his diagnosis prior to the introduction of the psa test and even prior to the use of the Gleason scoring) BTW, I am also 64 and my father had prostate cancer diagnosed at age 63. My psa jumps around. I've had 7.5 and 5.5 results, but just waited for another test rather than getting another biopsy. I did have one negative biopsy several years ago. I'm trying to avoid further biopsies as I don't want to find a insignificant cancer that doesn't need treatment. For your biopsy, assume it will be just like the last one... essentially negative. If its not, you'll be catching early, with good treatments to choose from.

Posts.Title: Da Vinci - What I didn't know

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by vingal My DR called with my biopsy results and indicated that 11 of twelve cores were clear; the one positive core had a small, microscopic indication of cancer cells. He said it was a good result and we will discuss how to adress it when we meet this coming week. I had the biopsy as a result of DRE; my psa is low. This sounds like a good, but not perfect, result. Any thoughts on what he might suggest and any questions I should ask? It really doesn't sound like you have even Gleason 6, at 10% or less....from the wording you describe the doctor using. He said the "result is good"... Though it could mean Gleason 6 at 10%. Nothing to think about doing surgery over before doing a follow up biopsy much later. "the one positive core had a small, microscopic 'indication' of cancer cells." Sounds more like high grade PIN or something. ---High-grade PIN is characterized by cells that share many genetic and molecular similarities with cancer cells.--- BTW, there are many times when something is noticed on a DRE, that often turns out to be nothing. AND....the one questionable core may come from a different area than where the DRE felt something unusual. You didn't give the specifics of your PSA history, but indicate it was low. You also didn't give your age. Bottom line, he said it was a "good result"... Don't get ahead of yourself on this before you get the precise details. I can tell you this (not knowing your age)... that I wouldn't even be thinking about treating what you appear to have. Not even a close call in my book.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by annie62 is this normal for this type of cancer or has it got nothing to do with it? sorry for the daft question but i am really worried. annie There is a 99.9% chance his weight loss has nothing to do with it, except that his worry about a biopsy, and your concern, has probably led to a loss of appetite, or excess agitation. Actually make that 99.99%. Your husband is going to be around for a very long time. Make something nice for him to eat. While I don't know his psa or the reason for doing a biopsy, most biopsy results are negative.

Posts.Content: I didn't realize how popular primary androgen deprivation therapy was in men 65+ "Use of primary androgen deprivation therapy for early stage prostate cancer is widespread. Despite the lack of randomized clinical trials to test its effectiveness, recent studies have reported it as the second most common treatment, after radiotherapy, for clinically localized prostate cancer among older men age 65 and older." http://www.sciencecodex.com/primary_..._cancer-129768 Seems it is not any more effective than AS in most men.

Posts.Title: Primary androgen deprivation therapy study released

Posts.Content: ddayglo, as a thread develops, it is the natural nature for it to take a life of its own. Various points and discussions follow, just as would be the case in any normal conversation. It is up to the original poster to bring it back to his specific case if it has wandered into unrelated minor disagreements. Most people here are "post decision" and "post treatment" as they contribute. Only natural they bring in their viewpoints. Just something that comes with the territory. The seeds-vs-surgery debate is healthy, but perhaps confusing and unsettling to a person making a difficult decision. That stems from the fact that no one, not even the experts, know which treatment is best for a given patient. There is a excellent case to be made for each treatment choice. If people bash the choices about, it isn't meant to sway your decision. Often times they are reinforcing their own reasons for choosing x or y. Like owners of a Honda and Toyota telling each other why their car was the best choice. Both choices get them to the supermarket and back. Also helps other readers who have yet to decide on their option. Even is informative to someone like me, who hasn't even been diagnosed, but has a family history and borderline PSAs. Lastly I don't think there is any way to limit the scope of a thread once it starts.

Posts.Title: Posts about Pre-Treatment Options

Posts.Content: You did not give us your PSA history/results prior to the 4.2 test in March. Simply put, far too often, doctors get one jump up in psa and rush to the biopsy. Then far too often, they find harmless amounts of Gleason 6, such as in your case where there are two cores at 5%. That is a insignificant finding. In all probability your doctor should simply have waited after the single 4.2 test and allowed 3 to 6 months to pass, then testing again, he would have gotten the 3.1 result and you would have not needed the biopsy and the insignificant finding of two 5% cores would have never been found. ---And you'd be just fine, just like the millions of other men over age 60, walking around every day with insignificant, "indolent", cases of prostate cancer. But now, due to a premature and very possibly unnecessary biopsy, you are now declared to have cancer which might be unsettling to you and put you in line for endless testing and frequent biopsies. You should realize that about half the men you know between the ages of 65 and 95, have exactly the same "cancer" that you have. Except they don't know it and yet they will be just fine. PSA scores jump all over the place on a regular basis. You don't need to have a infection or any other cause. They just jump around naturally. I've had scores of 7.5 and 5.5... My most recent test was 2.8 If I got a biopsy every time it jumped up, I'd be full of holes. The only thing of note, was your brothers case, however we don't know the details of that. Do you know his psa history or biopsy result, age compared to yours. You should watch the following video to set your mind at ease. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 BTW, I also like my doctor, but he is often mistaken.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and dropping PSA?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by vingal Sorry I haven't reported back until now. I had back surgery a couple of weeks ago, so I've been dealing with that. (Sucks to get old but I guess I don't have to tell you guys.) I'm 59 yo. My PSA was reported to me as .9 on a 4.0 scale, which confuses me because I haven't seen PSA reported like that anywhere else. At any rate, my doctor says it is low. The Gleason score is 7 (4+3); stage 1, bordering on 2. The core with cancer was not taken from the area of the nodule or the area identified on the MRI. My doctor is Badar Mian MD. He is trained in robotic surgery. Everything I can find on him seems to be very positive. When I see him on 2/27, I'll ask him questions like how many robotic surgeries has he performed, success rate re incontinence, ED, etc. He discussed all options, radiation, seeds, AS, but was definitely recommending surgery. I'd like to get a second opinion. Any suggestions on how to find an expert in the Albany, NY area? You need to get a second opinion on those biopsy cores. You can easily send them to a highly respected center like John Hopkins and have a top person take another look at them. I would ABSOLUTELY do that before acting on the basis on one interpretation by one doctor. BTW, you did not tell us the percent of involvement of that one positive core (4+3)... Meaning was it 10% or 50% or 90%....? In addition to asking the urologist how many specific prostate surgeries he has done using a robot, ask him how long he has been doing them and how many he does each week.. (not all robotic surgeries, but specifically the removal of the prostate) Of course you should also get second opinions because though he talked about other options, doctors who do robotic surgery have a strong bias for that form of treatment. If you ask him about incontinence.. and ED.... you MUST get from him, his precise definition of each of those terms. Far too many doctors declare that a semi-soft erection qualifies as usable and such designations can lead to misleading statistics. Take your time, it doesn't sound like you need to rush this.
Posts.Title: biopsy result, small indication

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by matthewb So for my 50th birthday I had my first PSA test which has led me to discover I have prostate cancer. Not sure how long it's been going on. I'm hopeful that I'm not already dead. b) I am less concerned about side-effects than my kids (9, 13, and 15) growing up without a father. c) I don't have multiple PSA tests to see how fast the cancer is growing, but the fact that it is already palpable (big enough to feel), d) So eventual treatment seems highly likely. So what's the idea? You wait for it to get worse? The data I've seen suggests that as PSA levels rise, and/or clinical staging levels increase, the cure rates fall off rather quickly. Do I really want to wait for my PSA to hit 10? Or my staging to go to T2B or T2C? Some alternative thoughts to keep in mind. First from your reported status 5/31/16 PSA 6.1 7/15/16 DRE ridge left side T2A 7/21/16 Biopsy 3+3 on 2/12 cores involving 10% and 20% of tissue You've only ever had one psa test. Don't assume that is your true psa score. You could have a psa of 2.0 that just happened to be elevated that day or that week. Not at all unusual to have a bout of prostatitis that you might not even be aware of, that makes your psa jump up... even to 6+ The fact that they later felt something on the DRE doesn't make that idea null and void. You mention status as T2A... but wouldn't that mean the core(s) came from the ridge? Did the positive cores actually come from the "ridge"... Not at all impossible for a "ridge" or nodule to have nothing to do with the prostate cancer cores found to be positive. You mention that the biopsy was 3+3 on two cores involving 10% and 20%.. Have those two cores, or all the core samples been read by a second expert? Each of these three items, the psa, the DRE ridge, and the 2 positive cores, are not set in stone as being absolute. Anyone one or two of them, if not representative of the actual facts, could change your outlook and choice of going ahead with one treatment, or even any treatment. You seem to have read a lot, but you are still only 30 days post diagnosis. Nothing in your case suggests you need to be in a rush to get treated rapidly. Almost certainly some of your initial ideas will change over the next month or two. Regarding this one point from Walsh's book Potent 18 months: 86% Beware of definitions of "potent"... Doctors definition may not be at all like the patients definition. Or it may be that Walsh is the Jack Nicklaus of prostate surgery with all others scoring below him. "I saw one other surgeon on line with 7000+ surgeries that has similarly positive claims of 83% regaining sexual function" You should ask him for a written definition of "regaining sexual function"... I have a friend who regained sexual function... with injections. Mind you, he is still satisfied with his surgery, and married several years after the surgery to a much younger woman. Still he initially went through a couple years of frustration before going with injections. His surgeon was very positive prior to surgery. He was about 56 at the time of surgery. "b) I am less concerned about side-effects than my kids (9, 13, and 15) growing up without a father" A understandable concern, but I'd say the probability of them all being out of college before anything happens to you is extremely high... unless they decide to hang out in college for over 25 years. Just a few ideas to think about as you sort out which path is best for you... Always knowing that nothing is guaranteed for any one individual case.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> He was about 56 at the time of surgery

Posts.Title: biopsy result, small indication

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lumore51 Hello everyone: I had my first of 2 HD Brachytherapy treatments yesterday at Stanford with Dr. Mark Buyyounouski. Brilliant guy. First off, some background and a few reasons why I chose this procedure over surgery. Apologies for the long post, but I think many guys who are still deciding will appreciate my perspective: I live 10 miles from a then Oakland based, medical group (now at UCLA) that reported the following outcomes using HD Brachytherapy. I wonder if Kaiser in Oakland or elsewhere in Northern California offers this treatment. I know they do most of their regular brachytherapy in Roseville outside of Sacramento. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Hauswald et al. reported the 10-year results on 448 favorable risk patients treated by the California Endocurietherapy Cancer Center (now at UCLA) from 1996 to 2009. The patient characteristics were as follows: 288 low risk; 160 intermediate risk 76 percent Gleason score ≤ 6; 20 percent Gleason 3 + 4 = 7 Median age: 64 years Only 9 percent received neoadjuvant androgen deprivaton therapy (ADT) Median prostate volume: 33 cm3 (range, 9 to 134 cm3) Median follow up: 6.5 years The ten-year results were as follows: Biochemical progression-free survival: 98 percent Low risk: 99 percent Intermediate risk: 95 percent Local control: 100 percent Distant metastasis-free survival: 99 percent Prostate cancer-specific survival: 99 percent Overall survival: 77 percent None of the outcomes were statistically different for low-risk or intermediate-risk groups. Late grade 2 genitourinary (GU) toxicity: 10 percent; grade 3: 5 percent; 1 patient had grade 4. Late grade 2 gastrointestinal (GI) toxicity: 1 percent; no grade 3 or 4 60 percent of previously potent patients were able to have erections suitable for intercourse, with or without medication (at median age of 69) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Unsure how much they have perfected the procedure in the 6 to 7 years since 2009 when the above results were obtained.

AgeInfo.Phrase: medication  at median age of 69                                                                                                                 Unsure how much they have

Posts.Title: Just Dx w/ gleason 4+3=7.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Webheadfred My surgery will be scheduled next week. The Doc wanted to wait 6 weeks for the prostate to calm down after the biopsy. I did bleed for about 8 days. I should be having my surgery in the second or third week in July. Any thoughts? You had a biopsy on May 23rd and here we are 11 days later and you've already made your decision? What the heck is the rush? First of all, it is unclear whether you had 4 positive biopsies or 8 positive, since it appears that 2 were taken from each site. So, do you know if 4 or 8 were positive? Given that you had some 27 samples or about twice the normal number, then if you indeed only have 4 positive, that is equal to about 2 in the normal 12 core biopsy. All of yours are from 2% to 10%. If indeed there are only 4, which some might say, equals 2, then you should realize you may be a borderline case. I'm just giving you the other side of the coin. If I were you, I'd certainly give the decision process another month or so. I'm sure some others may disagree, but you should know, there is no rush to do surgery. Exactly what do you know about surgery and the side effects that most men have? Given the time frame within which you have made your decision, it would seem you've have little time to understand the whole picture. On the other hand, the surgery may be a fine choice. I'd certainly want to know all the details if I were in your shoes. Again, there is no rush at all

Posts.Title: HD Brachy Monotherapy: My choice & my experience

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ajm63 Hello all. This is my first post. I am 51 and have recently been diagnosed with PCa. Vital stats are as follows: 3/09 PSA 2.2 4/10 PSA 3.1 no PSA in 2011 to 2013 tests as testing age changed. 5/1/14 PSA 4.7 6//26/14 PSA 6/free PSA 7% (Different assay method than previous PSA tests) Biopsy 10/14 5 of 12 cores positive, both sides (<5% on 2, 5% on 2, 10 % on 1), 2 cores ASAP, G 3+3= 6 on all cores I have been doing quite a bit of research since the 7% free PSA test in June and have come down to surgery (open or robotic) or AS. From what I can tell I fit most of the AS criteria except for the fact that 5 cores were positive. Therefore, I have come to the conclusion that given that I am 51, the cancer will likely become a problem down the road, so I might as well deal with it now while the long term prognosis is best. Therefore, I am leaning heavily towards surgery in the near future. Am I missing something? . Though you have been researching this since your June free-psa test, you have had less than 3 week since the diagnosis. Now that it is a official reality in your mind, I'd not be creating any kind of rush on the decision...as indicated by "surgery in the near future". Minds and thinking can change from week to week. With 2 cores at <5%...2 cores at 5% and 1 core at 10%, there is certainly no need to rush on a decision. In fact whether you had possible surgery now or a year from now is unlikely to make much difference in the outcome. Just saying that learning more, then taking a few weeks off, then looking into it again a few times, often results in a different outlook. At the very least I would be exploring a wide rage of possible surgeons, even if it requires travel to the one you decide upon. Of course that may depend on your insurance. There are guys with big numbers and then there are artists with large numbers. They all sound overly confident. You didn't mention your location or what your insurance allows regarding choices. But the bottom line is that you need to avoid any rushing. Slow down, many would advise getting a second reading of the biopsy samples by someone like John Hopkins before proceeding. http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...s/urologic.cfm You only get one shot at surgery. Best to be as sure as possible as to what you are dealing with.

Posts.Title: Recent PCa diagnosis - Looking for some opinions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I'm 69, so I've been going over my options just in case of PC showing up. I have a question; why would someone choose Active Surveillance. . You may not realize it, but there is a very good chance that you already have prostate cancer. At your age, its about 50/50 regardless of the results you just got from your biopsy. I don't think I am exaggerating that one bit. In effect anyone with a 5.9 psa and about age 69 and above is already on Active Surveillance... Your's is just a bit less "active" then a official designation. The other way to ask the question is why would anyone want to treat prostate cancer if it wouldn't harm them before they die? Take a listen to this 11 minute video. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe Got back from the doc with blood results. My PSA now is 3.3. Went up .02. He did not seem to concerned about it since he thinks it is due to my enlarged prostate. He did a DRE and found nothing where as last JAN he said he felt a rough place. Said will do another PSA test 6 months. . Everything about your details seems completely normal. Your PSA and the jumps up and down are completely normal for many men. At your age and with a enlarged prostate, you shouldn't be concerned about the results. I would even suggest that doing another PSA in 6 months, instead of waiting 12 months, is a waste of medical dollars regardless of who is paying. Doing a free PSA when uncalled for is another unneeded medical expense. Had you not brought it up to the doctor, he never would have ordered it. Even if there is some tiny prostate cancer hidden somewhere, there is no need to find it sooner than 12 months from now. On the other hand, "even though I piss like a race horse every hour and at night" Do you really get up 6 to 7 times each night? How long has that been going on at such a hourly rate. How long ago were you only getting up once or twice a night?
Posts.Title: Blood results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shinytop Uro told me my prostate was 137 grams. 11/13 PSA of 4.7, Am currently on Proscar to hopefully reduce size of prostate. . Just wondering, how long have you been on Proscar? Proscar reduces your PSA by about 50%. So were you on Proscar for some time prior to getting that 4.7 psa result, or were you put on Proscar after that 4.7 test?
Posts.Title: Choices Limited by Size of Prostate?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wjw My thought, which I also will be discussing with my urologist/surgeon, is that waiting for treatment after positive diagnosis of cancer gives you a higher probability of increasing Gleason score thus a higher probability of cancer returning. This seems to contradict the validity of AS altogether. . I think you are talking about two different things. (1) A Gleason 6 evolving into a Gleason 7 (2) a Gleason 7 being found after the prior biopsies had only located a Gleason 6. I don't think those Gleason 6 cancers turned into Gleason 7. The prostate is like a loaf of bread with some olives hidden in it. Some may be Gleason 6 and some may also be Gleason 7. Into that loaf of bread you insert some straws hitting some cancer and often missing many others. In your case it would seem they missed the Gleason 7 olives rather than the Gleason 6 olives turning into Gleason 7 olives. The study you read indicated a 45% return after 18.6 years. I am unclear if those aged 65 or older were treated at that age or are being followed up at that age. You don't indicate the median age of that group or their age when initially treated. All those details are important. Until you know those figures the picture is unclear. Of course we could entirely eliminate AS and treat everyone with Gleason 6 and even that would not change the status of those who were actually Gleason 7. In your case there doesn't seem to be any indication you would have been treated better even if you acted sooner. I suppose there are lots of studies with varying results as to the eventual outcome of large groups of Gleason 7.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 And that something other than prostate cancer will likely kill you first. What they never mention is that if something else doesn't kill you first, then prostate cancer will indeed kill you. I think I'd like to take exception to that statement. Many men with prostate cancer simply die of old age. Sure eventually the heart stops, but often not due to any particular abnormal disease. I realize they always put some cause of death on the death certificate, but often its just a general overview of a old mans' condition that can't be avoided by the late 80's or 90's.. As we know, most men past age 85 have prostate cancer. though often undiagnosed.

Posts.Title: Possible good Information regarding Cancer and general health

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wjw My thought, which I also will be discussing with my urologist/surgeon, is that waiting for treatment after positive diagnosis of cancer gives you a higher probability of increasing Gleason score thus a higher probability of cancer returning. This seems to contradict the validity of AS altogether. . I think you are talking about two different things. (1) A Gleason 6 evolving into a Gleason 7 (2) a Gleason 7 being found after the prior biopsies had only located a Gleason 6. I don't think those Gleason 6 cancers turned into Gleason 7. The prostate is like a loaf of bread with some olives hidden in it. Some may be Gleason 6 and some may also be Gleason 7. Into that loaf of bread you insert some straws hitting some cancer and often missing many others. In your case it would seem they missed the Gleason 7 olives rather than the Gleason 6 olives turning into Gleason 7 olives. The study you read indicated a 45% return after 18.6 years. I am unclear if those aged 65 or older were treated at that age or are being followed up at that age. You don't indicate the median age of that group or their age when initially treated. All those details are important. Until you know those figures the picture is unclear. Of course we could entirely eliminate AS and treat everyone with Gleason 6 and even that would not change the status of those who were actually Gleason 7. In your case there doesn't seem to be any indication you would have been treated better even if you acted sooner. I suppose there are lots of studies with varying results as to the eventual outcome of large groups of Gleason 7.

AgeInfo.Phrase: am unclear if those aged 65 or older were treated at

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance (AS)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I've also read that the Gleason score, after surgery, is found to be HIGHER than predicted by the biopsy somewhere between 20 and 28% of the time. I don't know the number, but there is a smaller percentage where the score turns out to be LOWER than predicted by the biopsy. I would always be nervous about going with AS -- until they are able to find a way to determine, without any doubt, the true nature of the cancer within the prostate. Only then will AS be a sure thing, risk-wise. Well then, you are going to have to treat millions and millions more men because prostate cancer is sitting there in a huge percentage of men walking down the street. Most of whom will never know it and few of whom will die from it. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23847245 Just one of many studies indicating that prostate cancer is wide spread in the general (unbiopsied) population. AS to the other issue about 20% - 28% of patients being upgraded after surgery and a smaller percentage being downgraded, that only makes sense if the great majority of patients treated begin as Gleason 6. Meaning that very seldom is a Gleason 6 downgraded. I can only recall a few times I've ever heard that. I suspect there are some instances when it is true, but the patient is not told, for obvious reasons. The trend of the field is to do more AS rather than less. That is clear. Up to the patient to weigh the risks and importantly access whether treatment down the road will be any less effective than treatment now. The problem is that most doctors are in a position where they only stand to get blamed if they don't treat. One has to realize that built in bias in their evaluation because they'll always hear about the case where waiting was wrong, but won't ever know if many other patients could have waited for 3 or 5 or 15 years and still be effectively treated or never treated. Up to fully informed patients to make the call and take the risk.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by cvictim Colon health and the long road to a healthy life because of proper colon cleansing and nutrition. I guess we will wrap this one up. Just one more note. There is no need for "colon cleansing".... Your colon will clean itself if you simply eat good foods with a fair amount of fiber. The entire business of "colon cleansing" is 99.9% bogus. I don't care what they write, or what photographic evidence they produce, it is all 99.9% bogus. A word to the wise.
Posts.Title: Possible good Information regarding Cancer and general health

Posts.Content: Highly unlikely ... very very unlikely that your psa would go from under 4 to 108 in 6 months due to prostate cancer. Your doctor seems to be doing the right thing. However, even after you complete your antibiotics, it could take some considerable time for your prostate to get back to normal and give you a accurate PSA test. Even after the infection is gone you could still have residual inflammation. Don't be in a rush to get that PSA test. Although they may give you one sooner just to make sure they are following the right path. You didn't mention what your PSA result was in December. You only said it was normal. Do you know the actual number?
Posts.Title: Question about PSA Level

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Alpez Thank you all for your replies. I do have a slightly enlarged prostate. My first psa test was done 9 years ago and was 5.8. I have had 4 biopsies since then with the last one being positive. My psa has been checked every six months for the past 9 yrs and has been as low as 2 and as high as my last test of 7.2. I have been on proscar which my doctor says keeps your Psa down. Well 9 years ago puts you at age 44. Appears you have a unusual case with psa tests and nothing until now found in biopsies. I was trying to get at the possibility that your psa fluctuates greatly for unknown reasons unrelated to prostate cancer and that the one core found was only incidental. In some men it does this. However you didn't include examples of your past couple years, three or four prior psa tests. As your doctor indicated, the Proscar can reduce the psa score from 30% to 70%, with 50% being the average reduction. That would put your true current psa at about 14. I have read of example here of high psa scores, but with little or no positive cores, and then they find the real source in the "transition zone" which seldom gets sampled in biopsies. Here is a example from someone who has posted here and elsewhere in the past. I present it only as a small possibility that it could be similar to your situation. http://www.yananow.org/display_story.php?id=557 All in all after 4 biopsies.. with the last one being 24 cores, finding a tiny amount of Gleason six would almost be expected in anyone. I'd guess that many doctors would assume that what was found (5%) is not what is responsible for your psa being 7.2 (times 2... 14.4) Have you gotten a second opinion from another urologist? I think I would want a fresh set of eyes to view my case before I'd proceed with any treatment.

AgeInfo.Phrase: ago puts you at age 44 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Alpez 53 yrs old. Psa7.2 Gleason 6. Cancer in 1 of 24 samples less than 5%. I was told it was low grade and low volume but have gotten 3 different opinion...active surveillance, radiation and surgery. Waiting for MRI. Very confusing Very important for you to know and give us your PSA history. What was the prior PSA test result before you got the 7.2 result? What was the date of the 7.2 psa test and what was the date and score of the prior psa test. Give us your history of psa scores and dates going back a few years. We don't know if this was your only psa test. We don't know if you were given several tests recently. It is very common for one single test to come in high, then the patient being given a biospy before further testing. Or given a follow up test only a few days or a few weeks later. This may not be the case with you, but we see it all the time. So give us a little history of your dates and results of your psa testing. Try to be precise with the dates. I would assume you were re-tested if the 7.2 was your only high result. It makes all the difference in how to interpret your 1 in 24.... 5% sample (which is a very good result given the number of cores.)

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed prostate cancer

Posts.Content: From time to time new individuals post here and include in their description that they were or are on Low -T Therapy. At that time there is normally a few questions about how it does or doesn't relate to prostate cancer growth. Added fuel to the fire or completely safe. So the debate or discussion goes. Anyway here is another article about Low-T Therapy and how fast is has grown in the past decade, six fold. I've always been skeptical about Low-T Therapy in all but the most clear cut cases. I remember when they put most women on HRT (hormone replacement therapy) 20 to 30 years later the science began to emerge and now most women no longer take HRT, deeming it too risky. Men and women age. Their hormones change. That is natural. I'd be very hesitant to begin adding or adjusting testosterone levels unless I had classic and well defined Low-T. The article http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/24/bu...ewanted=1&_r=0

Posts.Title: Here is one for you to digest

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 Hi Everyone, I just got my lastest psa results. Just to remind you, I did have an abnormal DRE which has led to some further testing. My psa results are as follows, 2011 1.9; 2013 3.7; 8/2014 3.3; 9/2014 2.9. This last result also for first time measured free psa - which was 13%. The doctor still seems to think I am headed towards a biopsy just based on all the above considerations. He said the 13% free psa is abnormal as he would be looking for 15% or higher. So he wants to wait 3 months and have me do the psa again. I think he recognizes that I am hessitant about a biopsy but I am wondering based on what I have shared, is there any reason to hope that something will change to lead me away from a biopsy and am I being foolish to not demand one sooner? While the doc cannot be certain, there is nothing in the numbers that make him suspect we are dealing with anything aggresive. Steve What was it about the DRE that was abnormal. Did he give you any description of why it was "abnormal". Other wise, at age 58, I don't quite understand why your doctor places a limit of 2.5 on how high your psa should be. What is the size of your prostate? small, medium, large... I'd have to guess your doctor's take on this hinges on the "abnormal" DRE. Other wise I'd guess he wouldn't have given you the Free PSA test. There are mixed opinions about using the free-psa test when your psa is lower than the 4 to 10 range. You might read up on that. Your doctor seems reasonable. You are NOT being foolish to not demand a biopsy sooner. Test again in 3 months and see what you get.

Posts.Title: PSA Update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by L Eugene I'm scheduled to have the Di Vinci surgery in the area where I live I'll read the threads today. The last few weeks have been a bit of a whirlwind . You have been overwhelmed with information. There seems to be no question but that you will have some form of treatment. Have you gotten a second opinion from the other two doctors, including one who deals mostly with radiation as a treatment? You might look into that. Now, if you decide to go with surgery, you need to know a great deal about who would be doing the surgery and how much experience they have. Flat out, you should ask how many Di Vinci surgeries they have done and for how many years they have been doing it. You want to know if they have done 50 or 250 or 500 or 1000+. That is critical information. Also you want to know how often they do the surgery. Twice a month or 4 times each week. Where they got their training in using the robotic machine. Don't be shy about asking those questions and watch for robotic only surgeries vs some who throw in all their prior non-robotic surgeries as well. I don't know if you are in a smaller town or large city. 9 of 12 biopsies positive both sides of prostate You did not mention the percentage involvement of each positive core. Like 10% or 35% or 65% or 90%. That might make a difference in choosing radiation vs surgery though I'm sure each of the 3 doctors had that information available. Your doctor can tell you that if he hasn't already.
Posts.Title: prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by silver trooper Anyone else out there have or had a PSA that high with no detected cancer (yet)? Here is one man's story regarding diagnosis that you might find interesting I hope special links for specific stories are allowed. Can't remember the rules here regarding that. MODERATOR'S EDIT: Yes, this link was to another forum, so I had to delete it. HOWEVER, I did copy-paste the post down below for you. Chuck ************************************************** ************************************************** ********************** John Thompson and Jean live in California, USA. He was 63 when he was diagnosed in October, 2008. His initial PSA was 40.00 ng/ml, his Gleason Score was 7, and he was staged T1c. His choice of treatment was Brachytherapy (Seed Implant with EB and ADT). Here is his story. In 1999 I had a PSA of 4.4 and had a negative biopsy. Over the years my PSA has continued to rise and over the last 10 years I have had 12 biopsies from 4 different doctors and an endorectal MRI that were all negative. My PSA by this time had risen to 40. All doctors said that I probably didn't have cancer, but to continue to get a biopsy every year just to make sure. The 13th biopsy at UCI showed 2 cores out of 25 positive, Gleason 6 less than 5%. The urologist recommended surgery and was certain that the cancer was contained. I was making appointments for surgery and fortunately my wife told her oncologist about my diagnosis and he insisted I get a 2nd opinion from a prostate oncologist that he recommended before making any treatment decisions. It was the best move I ever made. The oncologist said the cancer that was found was statistically insignificant, and didn't warrant treatment, and most certainly wasn't the cause of my high PSA. He suspected something much more serious and ran a PSA3 and color Doppler ultrasound. Based on this he send me to an interventional radiologist who did a color Doppler ultra sound targeted biopsy. 3 out of 6 samples positive Gleason 7 were found. He had discovered a large tumour 16mm X 18mm in the transition zone that 13 previous biopsies and MRI had missed. I learned that most doctors don't biopsy the transition zone and when they do they go in at an angle that is not able to pick up most transition zone tumors. 25% of all prostate cancers are in the transition zone and are rarely biopsied. My oncologist still feels that this still doesn't account for all of my PSA. Bone and CT scans were clear but he wants to make sure there isn't small cancers in the lymph nodes. He is scheduling me for a Combidex MRI, a lymph node imaging protocol, in Holland that is supposed to be 90%+ effective in picking up small lymph node involvement. I'm trying to get scheduled for late Feb. There is only one doctor in the world that does this MRI and he's in Holland. The recommend treatment is Hormone therapy, followed by radiation, followed by more hormone therapy. The radiation will depend of if and where they find any lymph node involvement. I'll keep you updated on my progress. UPDATED April 2009 I went to Holland to have a Combidex MRI to confirm lymph node involvement. The MRI came up clear and I chose seeds and IMRT as a treatment choice. I would highly recommend the Combidex MRI to anyone suspected of lymph node involvement. I'm on Casodex and Proscar to reduce my 60mm prostate and PSA went to 15 after 7 days. I'm having a volume study done on April 7 and will start with seed implants in about 4-5 weeks. UPDATED June 2009 I had seeds implanted on May 19, 2009. It was a 3 hour procedure from the time I left my house to the time I got back; played golf 2 days later. The only side effects are frequent and slight burning urination getting better this last week. I start 5 weeks of IMRT at the end of June. I took Casodex and Proscar to reduce my prostate size, in 6 weeks PSA went from 30 to 0.6 and prostate from 60mm to 32 mm. UPDATED August 2009 Six weeks after I had seeds implanted on May 19th 2009, I had 25 treatments of IMRT which ended the 1st week in August. I had no side effects, energy level high, no fatigue. Only issue was urinary frequency for about 4 weeks after seeds. Now I just have to wait for my PSA tests to see if the treatment worked. My last PSA was undectable, but I had been taking Casodex. I'll stop Casodex in two weeks. John Thompson UPDATED July 2010 Just had my 1 year PSA test at 0.10; I have had no side effects from my treatments. JohnT UPDATED November 2010 I'm 19 months out now from treatment with Brachy and IMRT for a G4+3 and a PSA of 40. Last two PSA readings have been 0.1 and I have no side effects from the treatments. UPDATED November 2011 Last 3 PSAs were 0.10. I'm nearing the three year mark and still have no side effects from treatments. UPDATED December 2012 As of Dec 2012 psa checks every 6 months have shown psa steady at 0.1 since treatments. I have experienced no long term side effects at all and all symptoms of pretreatment BPH have disappeared. UPDATED January 2014 It's been nearly 5 years now and I'm happy to report all psas at 0.1 and no side effects at all. John's e-mail address is: [email protected]

Posts.Title: I need some support...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by sandy09 Hello to all. I'm 62 and regular viewer of the forum, albeit Prostate cancer free so far. I just visited my Uro doc yesterday to review my latest PSA readings. My PSA was 3.8, 6 months ago and now it's jumped to 4.7. He did a Free PSA test this time and it came back at 33%. He's told me this is good and I should be comforted by it. When he told me 4.7, however, I immediately thought that we should do a biopsy right away with the change since last time. He advised me not to jump into it so fast and that with my history of Prostatitis and BPH, the number could be related to that. He wants me to do a 4kscore test to see what the likelihood of me developing cancer is and then we'll sit and talk about what to do next, in about 3 weeks. I've been going to this doc for over 8 years and I do trust him and find his conservative approx makes sense in my sensible mind. He says he does lots of biopsies and assures me that if the 4kscore test comes back poorly, we'll arrange for me to have one. Otherwise he could suggest Active Surveillance. My gut tells me that if they find even the littlest bit of cancer I want it out! Am I overreacting to all this? Yes... you are indeed overreacting. Just as you were back in 2009... some 7 years ago. ( I went back and re-read your posts) Your path and increases closely mirror mine. (By the way, why don't you make a list of the last 8 years or more of psa tests and post them here. ) Anyway from the few items I see, you, like myself, got a jump up to 2.9 at age 54, from 1.4 the year earlier. Since then I suppose you've mostly had a gradual rise.. or perhaps not? Now you "jump" from 3.8 six months ago... to 4.7 now. First of all, why did you test after only 6 months? That itself is a important question. Let me tell you, my first "jump" up was to 2.6 at age 56 after 5 years of no testing, my only prior being 0.8 at age 51. Since then I have been all over the place.... "Jumps" of far more than you just got no longer concern me at all. Over the past 10 years since my 2.6, I have had lots of scores in the 3.5+ area to the 4.5+ area but I have also had results of 5.5 and 7.5 during that time. My most recent 4 annual tests were 3.8, 3.3, 2.8 and just last week, 3.4. Gosh... a "jump" from 2.8 to 3.4 in the last 12 months... OMG.. As you can see, PSA scores can and do "jump" all over the place. I will wait one year and re-test. If I get another 5+ or 7+, I will simply wait many months and retest. I will not lose any sleep over it. Simple and unnoticed "asymptomatic" prostititis inflammation can and does cause major "jumps" in PSA scores. 3.8 to 4.7 is nothing... Even a tiny bit of unnoticed prostititis can cause such a jump. I'd say you are even going overboard to take that special test. I'd bet if you weren't so hyped up, your doctor would be fine with you just waiting 6 months or a year to retest with a simple psa... no special testing. After all, your free psa is fantastic. DON'T be in a rush to biopsy...to find a inconsequential prostate cancer.... which then puts you in line for treatment of a cancer that most likely won't ever cause you problems. Your concern dial is cranked way up. Your statement " if they find even the littlest bit of cancer I want it out" is completely wrong... completely wrong. If they find the "littlest bit of cancer".... You DON'T want it out. Get used to the fact that before you turn 85, you will have prostate cancer, just as most 85 year old men have prostate cancer, most of it thankfully undiagnosed... You are very lucky to have sensible doctor. Don't push him into finding a prostate cancer that you don't want to find. Now, the usual video I tell men like yourself to watch.. A must see http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Calm down, you're going to be just fine. If you are ever eventually diagnosed, you'll have tons of time to treat it successfully. Mean time, be happy to have your prostate. And stick with your current doctor. PS... in fairness, during my own series of psa results...some time after a result of around 4.0 to 4.5... I can't recall exactly... I did have a biopsy which turned up nothing. But if I got a similar psa score today, I'd not biopsy, but I might do as you did and get a free-psa... As I recall, my one psa was about 18% or 20%.. not nearly as good as yours at 33%.

A must see http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Calm down, you're going to be just fine. If you are ever eventually diagnosed, you'll have tons of time to treat it successfully. Mean time, be happy to have your prostate. And stick with your current doctor. PS... in fairness, during my own series of psa results...some time after a result of around 4.0 to 4.5... I can't recall exactly... I did have a biopsy which turned up nothing. But if I got a similar psa score today, I'd not biopsy, but I might do as you did and get a free-psa... As I recall, my one psa was about 18% or 20%.. not nearly as good as yours at 33%.

Posts.Title: To biopsy or not

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dshinnick ... Any thoughts? Thanks- Dave Welcome... My thoughts.... Don't even entertain the idea of having any treatment any time soon. Retest your PSA in 3 to 6 months and again in 12 months. See how its going. In the interim you can slowly learn all about prostate cancer. Perhaps after 12 months, if your PSA is rising more than a bit, you could do another biopsy. Meanwhile you could do some healthy adjustments to your diet. http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf Watch this video. It will give some well measured advice from a well known expert. It may set your mind at ease. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Enjoy your weekend
Posts.Title: Welcome me to the club!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MZ13 My first two PSA were a little over 8 but then a subsequent PSA was a little over 7. My new urologist recommends to wait til May with another PSA. If this new urologist then recommends a biopsy, I will get it. . You didn't mention the dates or time frame in which you got the first two psa tests or the most recent one. By waiting until May, it gives a chance for any other issues affecting the prostate to calm down for a true PSA reading. Makes me wonder which of the two doctors gave you that 60% chance of cancer estimate? Your new uro sounds like a reasonable guy. Not in a rush to do a biopsy which may not be needed if your psa drops back down.

Posts.Title: Uro says I have 60% chance of having PC

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by montrob I am a 59 year old, had DaVinci surgery for prostate cancer a year and a half ago. Always in pretty good shape before, no problems with erections. Had my surgery and came out achieved continence within 2 to 3 weeks. Now a year and a half later I have begun to have leakage problems to the point where I am wearing pads to absorb the leakage. Never have recovered the ability to have an erection despite using the blue pill for over a year. Now I feel like I was lied to. Would have traded 10 years of life for the ability to have an erection and control my leakage. Any suggestions I can't speak to the continence issues, but I would be optimistic that you can return to the state you were in only months after surgery in that regard. Don't limit yourself to one or even two doctors when getting opinions. That you had good control suggests there is a path back to that same position. Some doctors who are very busy, employ trained assistants that specialize in helping patients with incontinence. I'd guess that some of them are more skilled in that regard than the urologists. Certainly they have more time to address individual problems. Don't give up on finding a solution, before you resort to some surgical answer....which come with a whole other set of problems. Regarding the ED, a close friend of mine with some reluctance finally began using injections and has become quite satisfied with that approach after the initial getting familiar with the process. But what I really wanted to comment on was the following statement you made "Now I feel I was lied to".... I don't disagree with you in the following sense. As has been written in many articles, many doctors fail to inform their patients who are undergoing surgery about the true rate of ED and incontinence. They don't tell them what they consider to be ED and what they consider to be a usable erection. They raise false hopes by not being up front about their definitions of what constitutes a erection and continence. Even in this forum, the numbers of those who end up with ED and incontinence are under played. Most men... Most men, who undergo surgery will not return to having normal erections as they understand that definition. Too many doctors do not tell their patients about this expected outcome. Only if a man takes considerable time on his own to investigate the subject will he find out the true numbers and true definitions of ED and incontinence. Given the huge number of men who end up with outcomes they didn't expect, one has to be aware that such problems are not adequately discussed in many forums. Too much emphasis is placed on optimistic outcomes. Also, there seems a bias for not risking any danger to life expectancy. Meaning that if someone said you'd have a 10% chance of dying 10 years earlier, that many wouldn't even want to risk that. I think lots of men would accept a 10% chance of losing 10 years of life, if they decided to take some path other than surgery with all of its risks. The point is that patients need all the true facts and then they can decide on the risk they are willing to take. Generally speaking, doctors will advise the path that entails the lowest risk to patient life vs patient quality of life. Doctors seldom get blamed for too much treatment whereas they can be blamed for not doing adequate treatment. Thus, most doctors have a built in bias for treatment. That would be OK if they had adequately informed their patients of true outcomes. I know you are discouraged, but there is great reason to believe that you can overcome your incontinence problems with the right help. Also, as was the case of my friend, he has gotten to a place where he has a enjoyable sex life with the use of injections. BTW, he married his wife about two years AFTER his surgery and now 7 years later, they are doing fine.

AgeInfo.Phrase: by montrob I am a 59 year old  had DaVinci surgery

Posts.Title: Suggestions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla Otago: "I think lots of men would accept a 10% chance of losing 10 years of life, if they decided to take some path other than surgery with all of its risks." Really?!! Based on what (in 50 words or less)? You give me 100 men with a low grade prostate cancer. Inform those men that they face a 10% chance that they may lose 10 years of their life if they don't do surgery. Then tell that same group that if they don't choose surgery, they have a 90% chance they won't shorten their life. I say, you get lots and lots of men who decide to take their chances when appraised of the real outcomes of surgery. Meaning fully informed about the data and definitions of incontinence and ED. Now, I'm not saying that every man who fails to choose surgery only faces a 10% chance of his life being shortened by 10 or more years, but there are many men who, if they had the choice to do over, would not go ahead with surgery. That is why there is a growing trend towards AS, as well as other forms of treatment. The data says take the risk, but it really depends on the individual and their own set of details. Gleason score, PSA, age, family, wife, and ability to live with uncertainty. All I'd want is to give each man full information. I'm guessing more than half of men go forward with surgery, without being fully informed of the true outcomes that can be expected. BTW, the average person on this forum is more informed than the average guy who is diagnosed. Going way back, there have been numerous articles about men who would make other choices if they had all the facts. Here is just one http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/0...ype=blogs&_r=0 We don't know montrob's particular details. It could be possible he was a Gleason 8 or 9 and would not change anything if he was fully informed. All we know is that right now, there is massive over treatment because we can't predict who will lose years of life if they don't do surgery. I believe that many of those who undergo surgery would choose to take their chances if fully informed about the true data. Others want no risk, even if its under 10%. As I've often said, if the level of risk aversion that is placed on prostate "cancer"..... were done for the average guy's reaction to heart disease, knowing the true risk data, then more than half of all prostate patients would overnight become vegans because the risk of losing 10 or more years of life from heart disease if far greater than 10%... In most prostate cancer patients, treated or untreated, their risk of dying from heart disease is far greater than dying of prostate cancer. Yet very few of them do total lifestyle changes, like becoming vegans or similar. I don't believe fully informed men would act like they do, for either prostate cancer or heart disease, if they were fully informed of the actual data and outcomes. (sorry if that went over 50 words)

Posts.Content: Brian, what is your prior history of PSA test results? Was the 8.77 out of line with the prior pattern? Meaning did you get a series of 3's and 4's and then a jump up to 8.77 prompting the biopsy? If so, was there a period of time and then a retest? Dates, years, levels etc. for your PSA history. Nice that your doctor isn't urging you to quick action. Other than IMRT did he also discuss brachytherapy (seeds)?

Posts.Title: Just recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: You are 64. In which month is your 65th birthday? You'll be covered by Medicare on the first of that month even if your birthday is on the 30th. You do know you need to sign up early so you'll be ready to go on that first day of that birthday month. Do I understand that you know which type of treatment you will choose? Often times if you are doing seeds, and your prostate is large, then they use hormones to shrink the size of the prostate prior to doing the seeds. Not sure if your prostate is large. One example of a study talking about this dual procedure. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20869105 I'm sure there are many many other studies you could look up. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/580995 Or you could just do nothing for 5 months. Probably wouldn't make a difference, but I suppose in a small percent, it could make some problem. In the prostate business, nothing is for sure. Where do you live? BTW, do you know the percentage of each of those 8 cores, that is involved? Like in each one being from 5% to perhaps 80%. I don't recall if you gave us that information. You and each doctor you see should know that information. If you acted sooner, you'd probably still be a month or so out anyway. In September at the earliest. Perhaps October. You need to know which type of treatment you will do and how fast you'd be doing it even if you had insurance. The time between that and waiting for Medicare may be small, if you did some preliminary planning prior to actually getting Medicare. Need to know which type of Medicare you'll have. Independent or through someone like Kaiser Senior Advantage,, or whatever they call it now? Where the HMO does all your care and you pay a supplemental fee each month. I take it you've explored all those aspects. Again, where do you live? Has anyone given you a "total cost" estimate of doing any of the treatments prior to getting insurance. How much for the total treatment?
Posts.Title: More confused than ever.

Posts.Content: "My research so far has pretty well convinced me that I do not want the surgery due to the possible complications and quality of life issues afterward" You got that right. I realize we aren't doctors, but in your case, I'd sure want to know there was some value in doing surgery. I'm sure the doctor isn't suggesting there isn't a large risk that surgery won't actually help at all. How can he know exactly where the cancer is and especially where it isn't . I'd get a second and even third opinion before I'd undergo surgery in this type of case. I'm betting one or both of those opinions would steer you away from that path. Very different than doing surgery in the first place. Be sure to ask your doctor how certain he is that surgery would "get it". Ask him to put a percentage on it. 50% or 95%. Also, what is his surgical experience in such cases, after radiation? Has he done a handful or over a hundred? Or hundreds. What is the 5 year outcome for those cases? Recurrence rate? Last thing you seem to want is to go through all that and then perhaps for nothing. But again, I'm not the doctor who has all the specific facts..... nor the training.

Posts.Title: Just recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Alpez 53 yrs old. Psa7.2 Gleason 6. Cancer in 1 of 24 samples less than 5%. I was told it was low grade and low volume but have gotten 3 different opinion...active surveillance, radiation and surgery. Waiting for MRI. Very confusing Very important for you to know and give us your PSA history. What was the prior PSA test result before you got the 7.2 result? What was the date of the 7.2 psa test and what was the date and score of the prior psa test. Give us your history of psa scores and dates going back a few years. We don't know if this was your only psa test. We don't know if you were given several tests recently. It is very common for one single test to come in high, then the patient being given a biospy before further testing. Or given a follow up test only a few days or a few weeks later. This may not be the case with you, but we see it all the time. So give us a little history of your dates and results of your psa testing. Try to be precise with the dates. I would assume you were re-tested if the 7.2 was your only high result. It makes all the difference in how to interpret your 1 in 24.... 5% sample (which is a very good result given the number of cores.)

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tattlebaum Initial test was on the 23rd, follow up on the 29th. I was given nothing between the dates additional to the statin and Omperazole I always take. Of note, one test is "immunoassay Roche COBAS" with a 4.0 as the high normal limit and the other unnamed with 4.5 as the high upper limit. What's with that? OK, according to some, if you are over 60, then 4.0 is the upper "normal" limit, and for some past age 60, they call 4.5 the "normal" limit. They are both talking about the same group of men. Don't pay too much attention to those differences. I could give you respectable doctors who suggest everyone over 2.5 should be given a biopsy. Much of the science about prostate cancer is all over the map. NOW, after a year or so, you getting your normal physical, etc, with a PSA....which came in at 6.... followed by ANOTHER... PSA test only SIX days later. Then referred to a urologist... who then gave you a biopsy. Well, in my book, that is sheer insanity. Waiting all of 6 days to do a followup test is madness.. Uninformed madness. If... IF a inflammation of any origin is boosting your PSA from 2 or 3 up to 6, there is little chance that inflammation will have subsided in only 6 days. You may not even be aware of the inflammation. Called asymptomatic prostatitis. Very common and can easily boost a PSA from 2.0 to 6.0 or 7.0. I have gotten a 7.5... only to have my current PSA at 3.3 Then after that silly confirmation test, you are put aboard the biopsy express train. Yes, they did come up with a Gleason 6, something that you may have been better off never having been discovered. Now you are officially a "cancer patient" whereas if they had waited 3 to 6 months to retest your PSA, there is a good chance it would have been back in the 2.0 to 2.9 range. Which of course would not have entitled you to a biopsy. Then you may well have lived the rest of your life officially without prostate cancer. You see, the majority of men have prostate cancer before they die. Except most of them are undiagnosed and are never affected by the prostate cancer. But now you are on board the train. Called upon to make decisions and to worry. First off all... do nothing for now. Wait 6 months and retest your PSA. At the very least, if you can't stand it, wait 3 months and retest. Nothing bad is going to happen by waiting 6 months. Good chance your PSA will be back under 3.0. Now, listen to this interview. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Listen to all of it, especially focus on minute 8:00 onward. Speaks about those who get spikes in PSA, only to return to normal range if they only wait. But too often, by then, they were forced to under go a biopsy and now they are officially a "cancer" patient....faced with the mess of treatment options, for a "cancer" that in most men, would never have caused them a problem. We can't know for sure what you'll find in 6 months, but for now, you have been prematurely put through a unnecessary biopsy procedure. That they found some "official" prostate cancer, in Gleason 6.... small amounts, only makes you a normal man of age 62. Be assured of this' you will die with prostate cancer, as will most men. Only a good portion of men are never aware of it and are unaffected by their cancer. Too bad you had a biopsy after two psa's only 6 days apart. Now wait.. Retest in 6 months... and don't spend much time worrying. Very good chance you are just fine. A fair chance.. you'll never need treatment. A very small chance you'll ever die of prostate cancer. Remember now, my PSA was 7.5 and now it is 3.3

AgeInfo.Phrase: and for some past age 60  they call 4 5 the
a normal man of age 62  Be assured of this' you

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with some questions.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kens I was just diagnosed following a biopsy on July 14th, with results on July 30th. The pathology shows 1 of 10 specimens having 10% adenocarcinoma with a Gleason 3+3. My last PSA was on April 3, 2014 and showed 3.76. I am very interested in knowing what the common treatment modality is in this situation? Personally I am looking most seriously at the DaVinci nerve-sparing prostectomy right now, if I can convince my insurance company to do it... Please share any thoughts and recommendations, or insight...? ! You might include your past PSA history. Why were you given a biopsy? Include your past psa history. Was there something felt on a DRE? Unless there are other missing factors, if I was in your shoes, I'd do absolutely nothing. From what you have given us, you are the prime example of someone who could do no treatment. Instead, just do AS... sit back and see what happens in a year or two or five. Most men in your situation could do nothing and end up living to age 85 or 90 without ever treating their prostate cancer. They'd be just like the other 80 year old men, over half of whom die with prostate cancer, but from other causes. Seriously, move very very very very slowly on this. Take 6 months or a year before making a decision about treating this low grade prostate cancer. Listen to the following discussion/interview between two highly respected experts in the field http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 11 minutes long. I don't see how you can listen to that and still feel the need to take action right away. Apparently you are new to all of this, only having your results for a few days. I can assure you, at this point you know almost nothing about the subject. If you did, you be amazingly more hesitant to do anything quickly. Certainly in ZERO rush to come to any decisions. You could sit back, read up and study for the next year, and be in no more danger than you are now. If after a year, you decided to make a treatment choice, it would almost certainly be just as effective a year from now, or even two years from now, as it would be today. You also need to learn far more about the side effects. Far too many men underestimate the side effect from surgery. Only a minority of men return to full sexual function (like it was before), after having surgery of any type. You need to be very precise on the definition of what constitutes a usable erection. Many doctors will give out glowing numbers of the percentage of their patients who have full function. It can be very different than the patient's definition. That difference lead to much disappointment after surgery as expectations are not met. The same hold true for the definition of continence. What you consider continence may not be the same as the doctors definition. If you take a good deal of time, you will begin to understand the actual reality of what to expect after surgery or other treatments.

AgeInfo.Phrase: end up living to age 85 or 90 without ever treating
be just like the other 80 year old men  over half

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by matthewb I called my urologist's office today, but he doesn't work mondays. I talked to a nurse instead. She was annoyed with me, said I was low risk, and I should stop reading the internet. Anyway, I can't sleep. I can't eat. I'm convinced I'm a dead man walking. I'm terrified my kids are going to grow up without their father. Perhaps it's nothing, but I'm totally stressed out. Nurse has some good advice... though after perhaps a couple days off you can do some low intensity internet reading. However, the situation you describe, "Anyway, I can't sleep. I can't eat. I'm convinced I'm a dead man walking. I'm terrified my kids are going to grow up without their father." ... Is exactly why I told you that you need a couple months minimum to be able to make sense of all the information you are drinking from a fire hose. And, that you do not need to rush any decisions. You stated "As an engineer, I'd like to make this decision based on the best statistics available," If you were currently thinking as you stated... as a engineer, and basing your thinking on the best statistics available, you wouldn't be thinking that you might have advanced cancer. And yes, you will see all your children graduate from college, even the 9 year old, unless she/he runs away and joins the circus...
