Posts.Title: Have I got advanced prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: You are lucky to have a wise urologist. All this talk of your PSA rising 0.6 in that last year and the suggestion that you get another PSA in 2 or 3 months is just plain overkill. If people pick out the PSA tests they choose to count, they can often come up with all manner of rises.... Why not pick the 2011 test which was 1.59 and couple it with your latest 2015, 1.94...? Because then instead of a 0.6 rise in ONLY 12 months, you get a 0.35 rise in FOUR years!... No one is going to rush you back into a unnecessarily rapid retesting for a average rise of less than 0.1 per year. Again, it appears your doctor is the only one looking at the greater picture. Why do you insist on second guessing him and rushing off to see a second urologist for entirely normal numbers? I can assure you that if you continue "looking for" something, you'll soon find some doctor more than willing to take a 12 core biospsy, "just to be sure" You seem to be hunting for something that is not advisable to find. Re-testing in a year is entirely proper.

AgeInfo.Phrase: 2011 test which was 1 59 and couple it with your

Posts.Title: PSA that increased

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steven72 Now, I've been referred to a urologist for a DRE, and I have a PSA re-test. The Dr. hesitated, but prescribed a two week course of Cipro to address the diarrhea and potential prostatitis. I'm on day 5 of the Cipro, and the diarrhea is improving. Do not rush to have your next PSA test any time soon after finishing your Cipro. If...and its a big if....If your prostatitis was caused by a bacterial infection, then even after treatment with antibiotics, it can take some time for the inflammation to calm down, such that you get a true PSA score. I'd wait many weeks, a month or more. Also please be aware that the majority of prostatitis is not caused by a bacterial infection and thus the antibiotic can't cure it. Sometimes the only cure is more "time"... Originally Posted by Steven72 Anyway, it all seems very weird to me... and of course, the a bad scenario here is that the previous Doctors should have investigated the discharge further, and because they didn't, it may well be Prostrate Cancer that has spread into my bowel - causing the diarrhea. Of course, the best case scenario is that the two are unrelated, the Cipro kills the bugs causing the diarrhea and the prostate infection. . Extremely....very extremely unlikely...that a prostate cancer has spread to your bowel and is causing diarrhea.. I wouldn't even be thinking about that. Far more likely you just had a bad meal at Chipolte...
Posts.Title: 43 y/o, PSA=6. Retest and urologist app't in New Year

Posts.Content: tgow, Originally Posted by tgow At first I was really strict on myself and didn't eat any fat. Just couldn't grasp the concept of high fat. Ketosis induced itself at that time. I use a lot of olive oil and like the natural fats in the foods. Probably eat 20 eggs per week, beef, pork, salmon and tuna, veggies. Not as strict now with bread as I've discovered low carb tortillas, but still limit those. Can enjoy a ham and cheese sandwich using lettuce leaves as bread slices. . That recent study had more to it than just lowering some refined carbs and replacing them with some vegetable oils. In that same study they gave out numbers, death rates per thousand years of study (or however they define such things) Anyway, regarding your link to the Diet Doctor and his favored way of eating. The study looked at death rates for the highest quintile vs the lowest quintile For prostate cancer specifically, the highest users of vegetable oils was 4.7 vs 8.7 for the lowest users For Prostate cancer specifically, the highest users of animal fats was 8.3 vs 5.7 for the lowest users For All Cause motality specifically, the highest users of animal fats was 32.0 vs 17.2 for the lowest users. http://archinte.jamanetwork.com/arti...icleid=1696179 http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releas...-eou060613.php http://www.bioportfolio.com/news/art...w-Studies.html You might keep those numbers in mind when you visit the Diet Doctor's site again. The picture is not completely clear, however if there is one thing most people in the field of prostate cancer agree upon, its that animal fats are the least beneficial type of food for that condition. Who knows, that concensus might change, but for now I'd be thinking the Diet Doctor's ideas are not entirely compatible with the science around prostate cancer. You might read the results of this recent study diffently but I thought you would like to see more of the details.
Posts.Title: UCSF Study: Diets Do Reduce Prostate Cancer Death

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gunrun Can you send his info to me? I am at my urologists office now waiting for the consult thanks. I suppose the original doctor who did the biopsy was a urologist, right? Who is the "consult" with? Type of doctor, and the reason for the "consult". Advised by the other doctor or just your own choice? Look, you apparently only found out your status yesterday. You have not yet heard from the second reading of the biopsy samples. Given your data...you really need to slow down. You can always be "aggressive" with any treatment you may choose, but right now all of this is happening too fast for a person who is new to all of this. Should the new reading hold the same, this cancer has been in you for years, not weeks or even months. No need to come to any quick decisions. Certainly no need to book a surgical date. A decision you make in a month will be more well thought out than some urgent decision you come to in the first week. Again, this cancer is years old... not just something that popped up in the last couple months.

Posts.Title: Just got the bad news

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by shu246 Well, I've never asked the Doc.s about it, but I'd assumed it'd be like flying. You might have a pilot, co-pilot, instructor pilot, and flight examiner - all doing their assigned duties and logging time on the same flight. You might have a daVinci trainee getting 'stick time' on the rough cutting, and the team chief/master surgeon/instructor doing the more critical parts. Both get to chalk up one mission. B'lieve I saw somewhere there are three 'hands' and two operator consoles on the machine. Could be mistaken, tho. They exist http://www.intuitivesurgical.com/pro...alconsole.html However in local settings I think they are very rare. I think most surgeons just go to training classes for a few days or so. I'd guess they are very raw in their first 20 surgeries. Imagine a kid on a video game. How many hundreds of hours does it take to be skilled?
Posts.Title: Curious about experience

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kens I was just diagnosed following a biopsy on July 14th, with results on July 30th. The pathology shows 1 of 10 specimens having 10% adenocarcinoma with a Gleason 3+3. My last PSA was on April 3, 2014 and showed 3.76. I am very interested in knowing what the common treatment modality is in this situation? Personally I am looking most seriously at the DaVinci nerve-sparing prostectomy right now, if I can convince my insurance company to do it... Please share any thoughts and recommendations, or insight...? ! You might include your past PSA history. Why were you given a biopsy? Include your past psa history. Was there something felt on a DRE? Unless there are other missing factors, if I was in your shoes, I'd do absolutely nothing. From what you have given us, you are the prime example of someone who could do no treatment. Instead, just do AS... sit back and see what happens in a year or two or five. Most men in your situation could do nothing and end up living to age 85 or 90 without ever treating their prostate cancer. They'd be just like the other 80 year old men, over half of whom die with prostate cancer, but from other causes. Seriously, move very very very very slowly on this. Take 6 months or a year before making a decision about treating this low grade prostate cancer. Listen to the following discussion/interview between two highly respected experts in the field http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 11 minutes long. I don't see how you can listen to that and still feel the need to take action right away. Apparently you are new to all of this, only having your results for a few days. I can assure you, at this point you know almost nothing about the subject. If you did, you be amazingly more hesitant to do anything quickly. Certainly in ZERO rush to come to any decisions. You could sit back, read up and study for the next year, and be in no more danger than you are now. If after a year, you decided to make a treatment choice, it would almost certainly be just as effective a year from now, or even two years from now, as it would be today. You also need to learn far more about the side effects. Far too many men underestimate the side effect from surgery. Only a minority of men return to full sexual function (like it was before), after having surgery of any type. You need to be very precise on the definition of what constitutes a usable erection. Many doctors will give out glowing numbers of the percentage of their patients who have full function. It can be very different than the patient's definition. That difference lead to much disappointment after surgery as expectations are not met. The same hold true for the definition of continence. What you consider continence may not be the same as the doctors definition. If you take a good deal of time, you will begin to understand the actual reality of what to expect after surgery or other treatments.

AgeInfo.Phrase: end up living to age 85 or 90 without ever treating
be just like the other 80 year old men  over half

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mitchden With regard to AS, does anyone know how many people eventually have treatments and over what period of time? If there's a high probability that I will need treatment in 5 years, I would be concerned that my body may not be as strong to handle treatment than it is today. Additionally because I struggle with depression and anxiety, I'm not sure I can handle AS. For much of my adult life, I've been on medication for depression and anxiety. This emotional roller coaster is very stressful. When someone tells me that I won't die of prostate cancer, it's based on statistics. As Ben Franlin said, "In this world nothing can be said to be certain, except death and taxes." Well, clearly the exact picture of your biopsy samples.....is unclear. Great example of how one has to take the "thought to be" precision with a grain of salt. You have some concern about how a "older" you might be able to handle treatment later on. It would seem you are mostly referring to surgical treatment. I don't think you should have the same concerns if you choose focused external beam radiation, or seeds (brachytherapy), which are equally good treatments for someone like yourself. I am the same age as you. I also have some heart issues though I have not yet had a suggested stent placed. I'm holding out and have completely changed my lifestyle. Though you are concerned about what to do regarding treating or watching your prostate cancer, having closely followed both prostate cancer and coronary artery disease (CAD) for years, I can tell you that I'd be far less concerned about this early prostate cancer than I would be about your existing CAD. Meaning I'd be taking every step available to curtail advancement of CAD before I'd be focusing on the prostate cancer. But the good thing about that emphasis is that the very lifestyle steps that are beneficial for CAD are the same ones for slowing prostate cancer progression. I do realize that not everyone is up for doing all those changes, but I thought I'd bring it up just in case you might be motivated for such. A study of individuals on AS ...some doing the lifestyle changes and some doing their normal routine, ended up with many more on their old ways, needing subsequent treatment compared to those making the significant lifestyle changes. BTW, are you on a statin? Which one, how much... There is a fair amount of data on how that impacts any potentially aggressive prostate cancer. So lots of ideas out there which could impact your choices of whether to proceed with treatment or not. One thing for sure..... and it cannot be emphasized enough..... with your borderline call, there is zero need for you to come to a quick decision. Take your time... slowly evaluate all the choices and paths. You've already witnessed the imprecision of the testing and science. This prostate cancer condition is going very slowly.. and has been inside of you for many many years. It didn't just pop up in the last 12 months. Unlikely to change much over the next 6 months.
Posts.Title: Roller Coaster Ride Continues

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hopefull4TheFuture Hi, my boyfriend was just recently diagnosed. He's going for his first surgery consultation on friday. I'm getting the impression that your boyfriend isn't the kind of guy who had done a lot of investigation into all of this. Part of that investigation is knowing completely about the doctor who is going to be doing the surgery. Your boyfriend needs to know a great deal about the doctors past experience with robotic surgery. How many times has he done this surgery with a robot. 20 times.... 200 times.... 2000 times? At a minimum he needs to know those details. Sounds like he has made his mind up very very quickly. Not a wise thing to do. Hopefully he had gotten second opinions. Both about the type of treatment and if he actually needs treatment. Lastly, he (and you) may be in for a big surprise after surgery. Side effect are frequent and can last a very long time. Very often much more severe than many doctors will tell the unquestioning patient. Your boyfriend should know the statistics before undergoing surgery. There is a lot more to this surgery than simply curing the cancer. Usually there is no reason to rush into surgery. He has had this "cancer" for many years. It didn't just pop up suddenly. If he goes ahead without being knowledgeable about all aspects of this, he does so at risk of being disappointed or regretful. Perhaps he has done all his homework, but it doesn't sound like it.

Posts.Content: Thanks for filling in the facts. Well, either way, it appears you have 7 positive cores out of 24 total. That alone would seem to exclude AS (active surveillance) However your actual psa might still be in question. You will be getting follow up psa test results for a blood draw on Dec. 13. That will be interesting, however a note of caution. You only had your "24 core" biopsy 17 days prior to that blood draw. Not only are you possibly waiting for any prior inflammation from prostatitis to calm down, but now you've thrown in another potential inflammatory issue, the 24 core biopsy. --"Recent prostate biopsy can cause a significant increase in PSA values." --"After biopsy, it may take a month or more before the PSA returns to baseline." source http://www.lexmed.com/docs/understanding_psa_test.pdf So lets see the result of the psa , but keep in mind those two potential influencing factors. 1. the fairly recent inflammation, and 2. the very recent biopsy. Might be you'll want to do another psa test in about mid January. It is still possible your true "prostate cancer related" psa is actually under 10. Can make some difference in your choice of treatment and level of concern, or even your feeling of urgency to treat. That you got all Gleason 6 is good. Might turn out lucky that you got that urinary infection that seems to have brought about the further testing of your psa.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shittingbricks To start, how do I put info of my condition at bottom of page. I am 47, firefighter from the uk. PSA score 17.4. Gleason score 6, right lobe 1 core 2% positive out of 12, left lobe 4 out of 12, 8% As Mikla suggested, perhaps you can clear up your actual number of positive cores. We can understand the right lobe, 1 core at 2%, but out of 12? on the right side? or 12 total? Then you indicate 4 positive on the left side at 8%. I can't imagine that all 4 are each at 8%. Perhaps you can clear up what each of the 4 left cores are regarding their percentage (for example #1 @ 8%, #2 @15%, #[email protected] 18%, #[email protected] 22%) Originally Posted by Shittingbricks Urine infection triggered investigation, never had psa reading prior to this and had second psa after infection clear 17.2. Could you give us a timeline on that psa testing. Date of the first psa test, then how soon and how long you were treated with antibiotics. Then importantly the following questions-- #1. how long after finishing the antibiotics were you tested for the second time? #2. How long between the first psa test and the second psa test? Were you ever actually tested for a urine infection and was a actual bacteria found in that test? Or was it just assumed that your symptoms indicated a urinary bacterial infection so you were given antibiotics either for that or for both that and a potential bacterial caused prostatitis? You should understand that most prostatitis is caused by non-bacterial inflammation. Thus the antibiotic will not kill a bacteria that does not exist. And your inflammation that can be the cause of the spiked PSA will persist, often for a good deal of time afterwards. Months.... So you could have a low risk Gleason 6 prostate cancer along with a seemingly higher risk PSA score that is mostly not caused by your prostate cancer, but rather by your prostatitis. It can take considerable time for prostatitis to calm down and for the PSA to reveal its true level. IF your PSA were only 4 or 7 in stead of 17, then you might feel a bit less anxious. Though you still would have prostate cancer. But it may be fairly low risk that could influence your treatment choices or at least the feeling of being rushed to act quickly. Those doctors indicating you should wait, may be counting on your true PSA reading to be much lower than in the last tests. " Biopsy showed prostatitis and chronic inflammation"... Both can greatly raise your PSA results.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman So i got home an hour ago, very uneventful. They found nothing. He told me that the stents were in place and working just the way we want them to, and they found nothing significant that needed to be stented. I asked, in that case, how should we approach the fact that i did have a positive echo stress test. He told me that the positive aspect of the stress test were not that significant, so just dont worry about it. I know that about 30% of stress tests are false positives. Also it was only the EKG that was abnormal, the images looked very good. So hopefully thats the end of it and i can move on. I'll talk with my cardiologist later today or tomorrow. Otago, you've given me some great questions to ask the cardiologist, expecially about whether to exercess through what appears to be stable angina (or my defective brain, not sure which. . Sounds like all went well. Nothing new discovered. Regarding exercising through angina, I want to emphasize I am not talking about gritting it out or pushing through the pain. I'm only talking about getting a minor feeling in arms, neck, jaw, chest.... where it just lets you know its there, but not causing you any significant discomfort. I refer it as "notification angina" (my name for it)... letting me know its there, but not causing what I would label as real pain or discomfort. By the way, if that same level of angina were to occur after the initial 15 or 20 minute warm up, then I would either slow to a cruise or stop. I get mine at the precise same points in my bike ride every day. Just like clock-work. On better days, it can be very subtle, but I am aware of the early symptoms. Of course I might drop over any day... but I don't think it likely. By the way, "walk-through" angina, as the name implies, means you just keep on going at a pace that doesn't increase the discomfort and then as dilation occurs and collateral circulation comes on, the discomfort goes away. However, it is also called "warm up angina"... where one exercises until feeling some angina... then stops for about 15 minutes... then resumes the exercise with the angina often resolved. Those names, "walk through" and "warm up" are the actual names used in the medical journals. The practice may or may not be advisable in your situation, however I do find that doctors are likely to want to reduce even the tiny chances of problems and thus can be very conservative in their advice. Even to the point of always saying "STOP" whenever you feel anything. The correspondence I have had with doctors who study this in Canada and in the UK, all tell me that exercise is a essential element in treating coronary artery disease. That and your diet, of course. Plus the statin you are already on. It will be interesting to hear what your doctor says.

Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shittingbricks To start, how do I put info of my condition at bottom of page. I am 47, firefighter from the uk. PSA score 17.4. Gleason score 6, right lobe 1 core 2% positive out of 12, left lobe 4 out of 12, 8% As Mikla suggested, perhaps you can clear up your actual number of positive cores. We can understand the right lobe, 1 core at 2%, but out of 12? on the right side? or 12 total? Then you indicate 4 positive on the left side at 8%. I can't imagine that all 4 are each at 8%. Perhaps you can clear up what each of the 4 left cores are regarding their percentage (for example #1 @ 8%, #2 @15%, #[email protected] 18%, #[email protected] 22%) Originally Posted by Shittingbricks Urine infection triggered investigation, never had psa reading prior to this and had second psa after infection clear 17.2. Could you give us a timeline on that psa testing. Date of the first psa test, then how soon and how long you were treated with antibiotics. Then importantly the following questions-- #1. how long after finishing the antibiotics were you tested for the second time? #2. How long between the first psa test and the second psa test? Were you ever actually tested for a urine infection and was a actual bacteria found in that test? Or was it just assumed that your symptoms indicated a urinary bacterial infection so you were given antibiotics either for that or for both that and a potential bacterial caused prostatitis? You should understand that most prostatitis is caused by non-bacterial inflammation. Thus the antibiotic will not kill a bacteria that does not exist. And your inflammation that can be the cause of the spiked PSA will persist, often for a good deal of time afterwards. Months.... So you could have a low risk Gleason 6 prostate cancer along with a seemingly higher risk PSA score that is mostly not caused by your prostate cancer, but rather by your prostatitis. It can take considerable time for prostatitis to calm down and for the PSA to reveal its true level. IF your PSA were only 4 or 7 in stead of 17, then you might feel a bit less anxious. Though you still would have prostate cancer. But it may be fairly low risk that could influence your treatment choices or at least the feeling of being rushed to act quickly. Those doctors indicating you should wait, may be counting on your true PSA reading to be much lower than in the last tests. " Biopsy showed prostatitis and chronic inflammation"... Both can greatly raise your PSA results.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: They get experience in teaching hospitals and from the 75% to 90% of patients who don't bother to ask about how much experience they have. Only a small subset of men come to sites like this where all the issues are discussed. Think about it, there are 238,000 new cases in the USA alone. If you go to the 2 to 4 major discussion sites you might find at most perhaps 1000 individual posters, many of whom are long timers. Then if you assume that 20 times that number read the site, that is still less than 20,000. Thus less than 1 in 10 diagnosed patients read these forums. Probably far less because they draw world wide readers. Most probably read articles on the internet, but those tend to not discuss details about how effective doctors are who have less than 200 or 300 surgeries.
Posts.Title: Curious about experience

Posts.Content: From time to time new individuals post here and include in their description that they were or are on Low -T Therapy. At that time there is normally a few questions about how it does or doesn't relate to prostate cancer growth. Added fuel to the fire or completely safe. So the debate or discussion goes. Anyway here is another article about Low-T Therapy and how fast is has grown in the past decade, six fold. I've always been skeptical about Low-T Therapy in all but the most clear cut cases. I remember when they put most women on HRT (hormone replacement therapy) 20 to 30 years later the science began to emerge and now most women no longer take HRT, deeming it too risky. Men and women age. Their hormones change. That is natural. I'd be very hesitant to begin adding or adjusting testosterone levels unless I had classic and well defined Low-T. The article http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/24/bu...ewanted=1&_r=0
Posts.Title: New IYork Times article on Low-T therapy.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Thanks for filling in the facts. Well, either way, it appears you have 7 positive cores out of 24 total. That alone would seem to exclude AS (active surveillance) However your actual psa might still be in question. You will be getting follow up psa test results for a blood draw on Dec. 13. That will be interesting, however a note of caution. You only had your "24 core" biopsy 17 days prior to that blood draw. Not only are you possibly waiting for any prior inflammation from prostatitis to calm down, but now you've thrown in another potential inflammatory issue, the 24 core biopsy. --"Recent prostate biopsy can cause a significant increase in PSA values." --"After biopsy, it may take a month or more before the PSA returns to baseline." source http://www.lexmed.com/docs/understanding_psa_test.pdf So lets see the result of the psa , but keep in mind those two potential influencing factors. 1. the fairly recent inflammation, and 2. the very recent biopsy. Might be you'll want to do another psa test in about mid January. It is still possible your true "prostate cancer related" psa is actually under 10. Can make some difference in your choice of treatment and level of concern, or even your feeling of urgency to treat. That you got all Gleason 6 is good. Might turn out lucky that you got that urinary infection that seems to have brought about the further testing of your psa.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by webster Hi all, Recently OH had his PSA checked which came back as 7.8, up from 2.2 4 years ago. He is only 57. This set in motion some tests, MRI and a TRUS biopsy that is scheduled in the next 90 to 120 days. Public hospital system wait list here. We did the MRI a couple of days ago. . Obviously this is a very stressful time and the wait for answers is very difficult to cope with for all of us. So how do I best support him through this process? It's so hard to see your partner going through this As is often the case, doing a biopsy after ONE jump in PSA is crazy, unless there are other factors. You report nothing that would indicate prostate cancer other than the ONE jump in PSA. I have had large jumps twice. The last one was to 7.5. I did not do a biopsy after that 7.5. Instead we waited either 3 or 6 months and then my last PSA was 3.3. Lucky for you the TRUS biopsy is scheduled 3 or 4 months from now. Two weeks before that appointment you need to get another PSA done. If it is around 3.0 or less you should cancel that biopsy. The notion that every jump in PSA should lead to a biopsy is madness. Retesting the PSA a 3 or more months later is the right way to approach this. You and your partner have allowed your lack of knowledge of this to cause you grief. When I was 57 my psa was about 2.7... Seven years later it is 3.3 But as stated, it has jumped twice, with one jump being 7.5. I no longer worry about jumps. We calmly wait and retest. Look at this thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...-My-PSA-Is-5.5 Then look at this thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...iopsy-Is-Today Then look at the same guy starting this new thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...s-of-My-Biopsy All that worry over nothing. Should have waited to retest his PSA in the first place, rather than jumping to a biopsy.

Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe If you had a doctor that you knew and trusted with your life who only does open surgery ( several thousand), would you go with him for your surgery or find one that has done many Robotic procedures. Besides the down time is there any great advantage to the robotic. Dec 6, 2011 PSA 2.3 Dec, 11, 2012 PSA 5.9 Jan 2012. saw the uroligist who did a DRE and found nothing except enlarged prostate, set up time for biopsy Jan. 22, 2013 had biopsy, results 11 cores negative and one core a few atypical cells April 25, 2013 PSA 3.1 Oct. 29, 2013 3.3 Dec 11, 2013 had a physical from different doctor and PSA was 3.9 Jan 29, 2014 full body CT scan, found Prostatic Hypertrophy April 2, 2014 PSA 4.8, Free PSA 23% Why are you even thinking about surgery? Thus far you have benign enlargement of the prostate. What are we missing? What is your age?
Posts.Title: Open or Robotic, which to choose

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I guess what you are missing is my PSA steadily going up. Why, I hope it is a benign reason but if it's not I will just be that further ahead on info. I go for another PSA Friday and I'm just finding out what I can in advance should I have another biopsy and it is cancer. You guys are always saying make sure you get plenty of info before making a decision so that's what I'm during. What's it hurt to get as much info up front so that I will have a better knowledge of what I will want to do and what surgeon I will choose.. I'm 69 Well I do understand some of it as I've done the same, though you seem to be getting real specific. You may be like me, with a psa that just jumps around. Looking back, you had a 5.9 which dropped back to 3.1 Mine jumps all over the place. I no longer worry. I've had one 7.3 and one 5.5. My last one was 3.3. I've gotten use to the game and no longer think about getting a second biopsy. Anyway, let us know after your next one what the result is. Looks like its been 3 months since your last, which was up a bit, but with a freePSA that was OK. If you get another 4.8, I'd probably wait another 3 months and test again, before I'd do another biospy. You have to be careful, if you biopsy enough on almost any man age 69, they'll find a cancer. Mostly ones you don't want to find. Like a 3+3 in one or two cores, with a low percentage of each core. Then what do you do? BTW, I'm 64 and my father had PCa... lived 25 years afterwards, died of other causes.

Posts.Title: Open or Robotic, which to choose

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by njs I believe the best (but definitely not perfect) way to compare surgeons apples-to-apples is to look at their positive surgical margin (PSM) rates stratified by pathological stage. For the handful of best surgeons in the world this is 2% or less for true organ-confined (pT2) disease and around 25-30% for non-organ-confined (pT3+) disease. As far as I have know, Samadi has not published his PSM rates. The best PSM rates I have seen are from Tewari (Cornell, but soon to moving be Mt Sinai) and Ahlering (UC Irvine) who have both published studies showing specific refinements in technique that have significantly reduced their PSMs. Although I don't believe he has published them, Dr. Allaf who is chief of robotic surgery at Johns Hopkins, told me his pT2 PSM rates were also sub 2% when I consulted with him. From his website "The SMART Technique It should be emphasized that the SMART technique is an advanced technique that should not be performed early in a novice robotic surgeon’s learning curve. Since 2003, Dr Samadi has performed over 2,000 RALPs, approximately half by this technique. In the 12 months since the final modifications were made to this technique in early 2008, he has performed more than 2,224 RALPs. We are able to achieve continence rates of 97% and potency rates of 81% at 1 year (in 193 and 169 patients, respectively) while maintaining a 4% rate of positive surgical margins. " Now, one must be very careful when seeing data on both continence and especially potency rates. The definition of each is important. What constitutes a full erection widely varies. I seriously doubt he has 81% of his patients reporting that sex is just like before surgery. You need to ask for a very detailed and precise definition of these terms before accepting them as valid. Still he may be among the best surgeons around. Hard to tell.
Posts.Title: Question about Robotic Prostatectomy Techniques

Posts.Content: Here is a recently released study/article about one potential downside of biopsies. http://www.renalandurologynews.com/e...rticle/429030/ Here is the scoring method explained. http://www.hiv.va.gov/provider/manua...logy-tool2.asp Part of the reason why I often suggest giving the psa some "time" to go down before doing a quick biopsy following a recent spike up. Obviously biopsies are important and needed, but some times doctors can be a bit quick on the draw.
Posts.Title: Potential ED problems with repeated biopsies

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dom555 Hi all just new on here n really worried my husband is 48 and has had an enlarged prostate for a while now so he gets his levels checked regularly. Before Xmas his psa was 4 and has now jumped to 33. Can anyone tell me whether he's more likely to have this as we r waiting for an appointment with the urologist but the wait is killing us You should feel good that his psa jumped from 4 to 33 since Xmas. Prostate cancer would not cause such a rapid jump. This doesn't mean he couldn't still have some prostate cancer, only that the rapid jump up is almost certainly NOT caused by prostate cancer. The huge jump, plus his clear symptoms, indicate your fears about having a rapidly growing prostate cancer are highly unlikely to be the cause of the test result.

AgeInfo.Phrase: really worried my husband is 48 and has had an enlarged

Posts.Title: Could My Husband Have Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Just in case you missed the link to this recent journal article http://journals.lww.com/co-urology/F...rative.15.aspx I would say that most here are more conservative regarding doing AS. Much more inclination to do treatment, just to be safer. Some of that may be tilted by a reinforcement of a choice they've already made. I would say this, a high percentage of those who do AS and then eventually do a treatment, come out just as positively as though they had done initial treatment. If I was in your shoes, I'd probably postpone treatment a bit, just because I tend to do that with lots of things. From your first post "Went to world-class cancer center in Boston for second opinion. " "They recommended active surveillance, PSAs retested every 4-6 months, biopsy every year unless PSAs rising. First PSA test (that started this whole matter in first place) was 5.1 Boston center retested and was at 5.3, 3 months later." Your choice... seems like you'd be OK doing either path for a few months while you get comfortable with a final decision.
Posts.Title: "inactive Surveillance"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde And even if your total diagnosis is not the worst in the world you will sooner or later need treatment. It might not be a big hurry but at 62 a 3+4 cancer will certainly have the time needed to kill you. Simply not true that a 3+4 will absolutely need treatment or with time will kill you. "There is an increasing recognition that patients with Gleason 3 + 4 = 7, in which the component of pattern 4 is small (<10%), have a very similar natural history to those with Gleason 3 + 3, perhaps reflecting the stage migration phenomenon associated with grade reclassification [44]. These patients are surveillance candidates. MRI to confirm the absence of large volume, high-grade cancer is particularly important in these patients." http://journals.lww.com/co-urology/F...rative.15.aspx

AgeInfo.Phrase: a big hurry but at 62 a 3 4 cancer will

Posts.Title: "inactive Surveillance"

Posts.Content: You are lucky to have a wise urologist. All this talk of your PSA rising 0.6 in that last year and the suggestion that you get another PSA in 2 or 3 months is just plain overkill. If people pick out the PSA tests they choose to count, they can often come up with all manner of rises.... Why not pick the 2011 test which was 1.59 and couple it with your latest 2015, 1.94...? Because then instead of a 0.6 rise in ONLY 12 months, you get a 0.35 rise in FOUR years!... No one is going to rush you back into a unnecessarily rapid retesting for a average rise of less than 0.1 per year. Again, it appears your doctor is the only one looking at the greater picture. Why do you insist on second guessing him and rushing off to see a second urologist for entirely normal numbers? I can assure you that if you continue "looking for" something, you'll soon find some doctor more than willing to take a 12 core biospsy, "just to be sure" You seem to be hunting for something that is not advisable to find. Re-testing in a year is entirely proper.

AgeInfo.Phrase: 2011 test which was 1 59 and couple it with your

Posts.Title: PSA that increased

Posts.Content: Very unusual that they begin doing a PSA test at age 33. You can have inflammation or "itis" that you don't feel, but that causes a rise in PSA. It can also be non-bacterial and thus not treated by antibiotics. It appears you did have a biopsy, right? (US Transrktali ) Perhaps they'll have to do another one, though prostate cancer at age 33 is most unusual. Perhaps you should get a second opinion about the entire matter.

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Pratoman;201397]Age 62 (in 2013), Father had PCa PSA Feb 2006 - .7 PSA Feb 2009 - 1.1 PSA Mar 2012 - 1.6 PSA OCT 2012 - 2.2, two weeks later 2.7 (after DRE & diff lab) Nov 2012 - Biopsy - 14 cores all negative for PCa, 1 showed Hi Grade PIN PSA April 2013 - 2.8, FPSA 11, PCa3 - 13 [QUOTE] Who is the one behind all this testing and the biopsy? Seemed awfully jumpy giving you a 14 core biopsy after that Oct. 2012 2.2 psa. Your psa didn't jump from 2.2 to 2.7 in two weeks. Why the second psa test at all? Did he detect something on the DRE? Also, who was it who did the DRE then gave you a blood draw? Then 6 months later, another psa and a free psa. Perhaps we're missing something here that you didn't include. Seems your treatment is very aggressive unless he felt something on the DRE. BTW, how did your father's PCa evolve. I'm your age and my father also had PCa but lived 25 years after being diagnose at age 63, so I have a somewhat more relaxed view of the subject. He died of other causes. However your father may have had a more difficult case. What was his age at diagnosis? You may be on track for something, but first I'd probably question that second 2.7 psa. The free psa issue wouldn't even qualify if your psa was less than 2.5. At 2.8 its more borderline as to giving you a good picture. Above all, you had 14 negative cores. I'm sure if he felt something, he would have told you so and directed the samples at that location. Perhaps you have more info. (Note,) I just looked at some of your older posts and they answer some of my questions. I won't rewrite the above as it indicates my wonderment at the rather fast trip you took to a biopsy. I think you need to take a more relaxed attitude about your entire situation. Heck, I'm 63 and have had psa readings of over 7 and over 5 on two tests. I'm now at around a steady 3.8. Had one negative biopsy about two or three years ago and don't really worry about it. I still come here because I just like the subject and am interested, but I don't think much about it in terms of worry. Put it this way, I'm almost certain there is some Gleason 6 some where in my prostate if I was only given enough biopsies over time. But that doesn't bother me knowing that is probably the case. I just want to delay it for 5 or 10 or 20 years and if needed treat it later, or never. Gave up worrying about it a few years ago.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mario361 Do these tests vary often, and are the results occasionally inaccurate depending on the lab? I guess these are questions the urologist will answer, but I'm just concerned. Thanks again. Yes... test vary and even when the lab is accurate, the psa can jump all over the place. I have had tests that jump from 3.5 to 7.5 and then back to 3.8 six months later. I've had several jumps like that. I do not run for a biopsy every time that happens or I'd be getting stuck with needles every year. My last PSA was 3.3. I've had tests of 7.5 and over 5.5. You simply don't understand the many causes of jumps in PSA. You don't even need to see a urologist now. Just wait a minimum of 3 months (6 months better)... and retest. Far better than getting 12 giant needles punched into your rear end.
Posts.Title: Concerned 41 yr old PSA 2

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mario361 Increased urgency to urinate, dribbling, increased frequency at times. I was wondering if anyone could help shed light on this for me as I'm a wreck. Made an appt to see urologist next week. There are a hundred reasons your PSA could go from 0.8 to 2.0 Any "itis".... any inflammation (even asyptomatic and unfelt) could easily... VERY EASILY cause a psa to make that little jump. It means nothing. Nothing more than suddenly seeing you have a bruise and not remembering bumping anything. How many times have you discovered a bruise or scratch and can't recall what caused it. So, what to do. Wait 6 months and retest. Simple as that. Any talk of doing a biopsy now is crazy, unless and until you have given some months between now and your next test. If the psa is still over 2.0 in six months, then you could see a urologist. You are letting your imagination get out of control. You don't need a biopsy. However if you keep insisting, you'll find a urologist who will give you one and make a nice fee. He will justify it only by doing it for your mental health.
Posts.Title: Concerned 41 yr old PSA 2

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JD1969 Scheduled a biopsy, which was done last Wednesday (7/3/13), still waiting on the results form that. I have pretty much accepted that with THAT high of a PSA, along with firmness of the prostate, that I have very high chance of PC. Well, you should be getting the results any day now. That will clear up most of your ideas. We can't guess what "firmness" means as only your doctor felt that. However, just based on the PSA test, the second confirmation, after only 3 weeks, would have hardly given enough time for any infection or non-bacterial "itis" to have calmed down. There are lots of reasons you could have had a temporarily high PSA. So don't start thinking surgery just yet. You may have gotten yourself into all this worry over nothing more than inflammation or "itis" caused by something minor. In fact the odds favor just that. See what you get, then think about getting a new doctor IF it is even necessary at all. BTW, who did the biopsy?

Posts.Title: Concerned 41 yr old PSA 2

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JD1969 I just figured that with a PSA that high, it would most likely not be caused by an "itis". I hope that is all it is, . Actually a "itis" is the thing that makes a PSA go "that high" and much more, far more likely than prostate cancer in a person your age. Here is a Q&A from a famous urologist who is well known in prostate cancer fields -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- OUTSIDE THINGS THAT AFFECT PSA LEVELS: Q.--In a normal, healthy man, would sexual intercourse the morning of the PSA test is performed raise the levels and possibly by how much if at all. Could a prostate exam prior to the PSA test elevate levels and by how much? Could an infection in a healthy man elevate PSA to 21? A.--The answer to all three questions is yes. Usually, ejaculation or a prostate exam has only a slight effect on the PSA level that lasts for 24 to48 hours only. The PSA might increase a point or two. With infection, very high PSA levels can occur (even up to 21 or higher) and in some cases it takes a long time for the PSA levels to return to baseline. In about 25% of cases, antibiotic therapy is effective; however, some men have to wait for their body’s defense mechanisms to clear the infection. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- BTW, not all infections or inflammation would give you a burning sensation. They can be there and be asymptomatic in terms of sensation, but might still cause some difficulty with urinating brought about by a possibly enlarged prostate. Of course I am no doctor and you'll get your results soon. We hope those are good. Odds are still on your side.
Posts.Title: 38 years old, high PSA

Posts.Content: Take a look at this interview. Also read the varying comments at the end. Several from doctors. You might also listen to the entire interview ( I did not listen to the entire interview as it is 28 minutes long) http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/...l&uac=208857FG Clearly the interviewed doctor has a bias on the subject. Still it can be interesting to read and listen.
Posts.Title: Interesting article/interview on the history of the PSA test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 And that something other than prostate cancer will likely kill you first. What they never mention is that if something else doesn't kill you first, then prostate cancer will indeed kill you. I think I'd like to take exception to that statement. Many men with prostate cancer simply die of old age. Sure eventually the heart stops, but often not due to any particular abnormal disease. I realize they always put some cause of death on the death certificate, but often its just a general overview of a old mans' condition that can't be avoided by the late 80's or 90's.. As we know, most men past age 85 have prostate cancer. though often undiagnosed.

Posts.Title: Well Crap!

Posts.Content: Two recently released items. One, the abstract of a Swedish study and the other a commentary on that study as it relates to men in the USA. Uptake of Active Surveillance for Very-Low-Risk Prostate Cancer in Sweden http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama...stract/2570080 Active Surveillance for Low-Risk Prostate Cancer—An Evolving International Standard of Care http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama...stract/2570082 Interesting definitions they use for very-low risk and low risk "men with very-low-risk (subset of the low-risk group) (clinical stage, T1c; Gleason score, ≤6; prostate-specific antigen [PSA], <10 ng/mL; PSA density <0.15 ng/mL/cm3; and <8-mm total cancer length in ≤4 positive biopsy cores), low-risk (including all men in the very-low-risk group) (T1-T2; Gleason score, ≤6; and PSA, <10 ng/mL), and intermediate-risk disease (T1-T2 with Gleason score, 7 and/or PSA, 10-20 ng/mL)." Interesting that they used 4 or fewer positive biopsy cores as included in very-low risk.
Posts.Title: Evolving treatment choices for very low and low risk PCa in Sweden and the USA

Posts.Content: Yes, read that particular section of the book I linked you to. Also, you said you and your wife were trying to have kids. This from Medscape on asymptomatic prostatitis "Asymptomatic inflammatory prostatitis is characterized by the incidental discovery of prostatic inflammation without genitourinary complaints.[3] This condition is diagnosed during a workup for infertility or elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level. This disease entity can produce elevated white blood cells in the ejaculate (leukocytospermia) and can cause male infertility but is usually otherwise left untreated. See the following for more information: " Also, look at this study http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20414405 RESULTS: The median age of the 75 men was 33 years (range, 26-40 years) and the mean PSA level was 6.57 ng/ml (range, 4.32-13.45 ng/ml). The results of the primary biopsy was 1 (1.3%) case of prostate cancer, 70 cases (93%) with benign tissue, 2 cases (2.6%) with inflammation, and 1 case each (1.3%) with high grade intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN) and atypical small acinar proliferation (ASAP).

Posts.Title: Scared and Confused 32 Year Old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter RTS, Using the last three PSA reading, your PSA doubling time is ~10 months. IF I use the last two values, doubling is about 7.5 months. So it is accelerating meaning there is cause for concern especially since recent MRI indicated cancer in both sides of your prostate now. Then again, throwing out the last one, as possibly induced by inflammation, the prior 3 PSA tests would indicate a deceleration. "psa 5.2 at biopsy 02/2012 psa 3.8 02/2013 psa 4.4 06/2013 "especially since recent MRI indicated cancer in both sides of your prostate now." There is reason to believe that a MRI back at the time of the biopsy may well have shown the same thing since 6 cores on that side could easily miss the cancer seen on the current MRI. Just to play the other side of the picture, it may well be that nothing has changed since the biopsy. The data is too limited.

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tomseeley My reason for asking is: right now, we're planning a 2-week RV trip March 5-18. If the PSA is done Feb 17, is it practical to plan on fitting in the biopsy between then and going on the RV vacation March 5? Or is more likely that the biopsy would be put off till after mid-March? I'd get the PSA test done about March 3rd or 4th... allowing even more time for any inflammation to have calmed down since December and your round of antibiotics. Then I'd not get the PSA results until you return from your nice RV trip. If the results are still high, you can then do a quick biopsy. There is little to be lost in delaying a few weeks and depending on the results of either the psa or the biopsy, you could really ruin your trip. Right now, I'd assume the best and not get any results before you return. Imagine how your RV trip will be if you get a high psa or especially a positive core in a biopsy. After all, regardless of the results of those tests, you won't be taking any immediate action. Why possible ruin a good trip. Get the PSA test just before you leave... even the day before... or the day you return. Don't feel the need to call in quick and get the PSA result before you leave. Don't have it emailed to you or call to get it. Yes, sometimes a "head in the sand" approach is the best, especially with a potential very slow growing prostate cancer.
Posts.Title: What comes after I have my first biopsy--scheduling question not a medical one

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Flkjr Howdy. You seem to have a history of yo-yoing PSA. Your 7.3 in 2006 was followed by a 5.0 in the same year and a 4.5 the following. Why not wait 6 months (or even 3) and see if it indeed comes down again. If not then get that biopsy. Good luck and stay positive. I'd second this opinion. Even if it does drop back to around 5.0, then depending on how "enormous" your prostate is, you may or may not go ahead with a biopsy. At least you will have confirmed the PSA at 5.0 or perhaps 8.0, which might make a difference in how you approach treatment if you decide to do anything. Of course, the fact that you had a negative biopsy back in 2006 doesn't mean there wasn't some cancer back then. So if you are comfortable, give it 6 months or 3 months, just in case some "itis" or inflammation is driving the PSA up to 8.0. My psa jumps around more than yours. Have had 7.5 and 5.4 followed by going back under 4.0 and now down under 3.5 I no longer jump to biopsies after a jump up... but if I had the 7.3, followed by your 8.0... and that 8.0 was confirmed, then I'd do another biopsy just to see what is going on. BTW, at age 67, getting up once a night seems more normal than abnormal.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> BTW  at age 67  getting up once a night

Posts.Title: Time for another biopsy?

Posts.Content: If that same urologist did the biopsy and is the one giving you the results, I'd question the entire process and analysis. Take your slides, if the doctor will even give them to you, and have them read by another quality person, such as at John Hopkins. Others on this board do that on a regular basis, even when they are seeing good doctors who aren't like the crazy doctor you seem to have found. I don't know the whole process to send them to John Hopkins, but it isn't that complicated. I wouldn't trust anything your current doctor says. Someone here may post and tell you how to send those slides for that second opinion of what type of cancer you actually have. The guy you are seeing sounds like he may be a quack out for fast buck.
Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wifey It was the same urologist who did the biopsy. He's had an MRI and then an Atermis biopsy. I'm getting a copy of the MRI sent to me. Whilst we're not discounting HIFU or indeed any other treatment, the doc we saw who is apparently well known didn't exactly had a good bedside manner. I was probably a bit overboard in suggesting he might be a quack, but anytime I hear suggestions of going to Mexico you have to question the practice. If you send the core samples elsewhere you have to send the actual samples. I don't know what good the MRI will do. At the very least you need to deal with a doctor with whom you get along and can communicate.

Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Guys what do you think I should do about that other doctor that my father went to about 4.5 psa. He didn't recommend any test. Should I seek legal advice ? I am angry that he didn't tell him to repeat psa sooner nor he did any other test to figure out why psa is above normal. . You need to slow down. Prostate cancer is very slow in almost all cases. You are way off base in your assessment of the original doctor. You have not included your father's entire PSA history, but for the doctor to not act on a initial 4.5 psa test is rather normal. In fact under some criteria 4.5 is still considered normal at age 64. http://www.medicinenet.com/prostate_...igen/page3.htm Not doing a biopsy after ONE 4.5 reading is good medicine. Doing a biopsy at the drop of the hat, the first time someone gets a 4.5 would be unwise. There is ZERO reason to contact legal help. His doctor acted well within the standard of care. In fact he probably did a good job by NOT rushing to a biopsy based on one 4.5 psa test. As others have indicated, we have no idea what his real data is. the "7" could be 7 positive cores, or it could be 3+4= 7 Either way there is no rush for immediate appointments or decisions. Calm down, this is all going to take a very long time. There is every reason to believe your father has overwhelming odds to live well into his 80's, and die of something unrelated to prostate cancer. My father, diagnosed "late" at age 63, lived until age 88, dying of other causes.

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: Your boss may be as unfamiliar with prostate cancer as the average public. I would tailor the message to not make it sound like it is CANCER!!!.... For some all cancers fit into one box and precede death. Consider ways to introduce it via the many other well known men who have it and have fully resumed their activities in high profile busy jobs.. There are dozens and dozens of good examples. Who is busier than Sec. of State John Kerry? I'll tell you who, John Kerry when he was running for president in 2004. Right in the middle of running for president, he has prostate cancer surgery. Then after a period of time he is back on a grueling campaign schedule that would kill most men. General and Sec. of State, Colin Powel., Robert De Niro at age 59 had surgery. Arnold Palmer, Warren Buffett, the list goes on and on. There are hundreds of well known men you can use as example to make it clear it is not much more disabling than many other operations or accidents. My point being that for much of the uneducated public you need to introduce the "cancer" as not typically being something like they think of most cancers. I don't know your job, but I can't imagine if you were in a car crash that they would fire you for taking some time off. I think the bigger issue is for them to not think of you dying down the road, or being unable to do your job in the future.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Robert De Niro at age 59 had surgery <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter One issue with AS is while on it, most likely your doctor won't prescribe TRT and your "energy level" will continue to remain low during this time. With treatment, after your PSA becomes undetectable, your doctor might restart TRT to improve your "energy level". . I just wanted to interject something about this issue of being able to get back onto TRT after one chooses to get treatment for prostate cancer. Your statement follows from Mikla's statement in his original post as follows "The minor complication is that I have low testosterone and have been getting 100mg testosterone/wk IM and it had significantly improved my energy level, mood and libido. Since I am no longer taking it, the symptoms have returned. Doc said it is possible that given successful radiation I could look at going back on testosterone six months after completing radiation" I think there is a real danger here in the possibility that one may think their libido or sexual function may actually be improved after treatment for prostate cancer, with the addition of TRT, compared to someone who goes on AS during which time he may be precluded from taking TRT for improved libido. If you take 100 men who go on AS during which they give up TRT and compare them to 100 men who take some form of treatment for prostate cancer, I am betting that those who go on AS have a far greater chance of having a superior sexual experience relative to those who undergo treatment. After all, even if one goes on AS, and drops their TRT, they still have the ability to use all the enhancements available to those who undergo treatment, with the possible exception being the TRT. Nothing is more likely to affect one's sexual performance than the various forms of prostate cancer treatment. So, I'd just not want Mikla to think that undergoing treatment, then getting back on TRT, is the best idea for improving libido or improving sexual performance. Quite the opposite is more likely given all the data and stats. Of course individual cases are unique, but the overall numbers are clear in regard to this issue. Definitely not a reason to choose treatment over AS. I do realize that you only specifically mentioned "energy level", but Mikla mixed that in with libido and mood.
Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla My wife is awesome and very understanding, but having low energy and libido is taxing on her and me. So I am a bit stuck... I am currently thinking that this would be the best plan: 1. Stop smoking 2. Lose some weight and improve diet 3. Exercise more (I certainly have the time) 4. AS for six months and re-access Age 55, DOB 11/1957, 6'2", 240# 08/29/2013 Biopsy: 2/12 positive (RLM,RLA), <5%/core, Gleason 3+3 ! I wouldn't even consider being treated now if I had your numbers. I'd wait and keep tracking your PSA, which according to you was probably about 3.8 in earlier tests and now in the mid 4 range. If it keeps advancing then do another biopsy in a year. I don't think I'd bother fishing around with a additional biopsy. I mean, the sampling is such a small portion of one's prostate that to have any certainty you'd have to do about 100 cores. Simply getting another 10 or 12 is fractional confirmation at best. You could randomly grab 55 year old guys walking down the street and come up with a portion who have Gleason 6 in one or two cores at 5% or greater. Take a look at this excellent measured discussion of the subject by two well known urologists. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Delay is not always bad, even if you later seek treatment. Now, in the mean time, regarding your potential danger from PCa as well as your libido and your overall health. (btw, you didn't include your cholesterol panel, blood pressure and the other stuff such as your blood sugar readings which can be very important in pre-diabetes, Impaired Glucose Tolerance or Impaired Fasting Glucose etc). In your current state, you are probably 10 times more likely to die of heart disease than from prostate cancer, even if you never treat your prostate cancer. Lucky for you the changes in lifestyle needed are similar for all your problems, prostate cancer, heart disease, and even libido improvement without the injections. When is the last time you were fit? Smoking, obesity (over 30 BMI), and lack of exercise all affect your libido. Seriously, smoking is the most dangerous thing in your current health profile. You do know how bad it is for heart disease, right? You do know that all those blood vessels in your heart are not dissimilar to the blood vessels that bring blood to your penis, right? Unless you have fantastic genes you probably have a fair degree of typical heart disease in process. Greatly compounded by your long time smoking. All the damage your diet, lack of exercise, and smoking do to your heart are being done everywhere else your blood flows. The more radical dietary changes many prostate cancer subjects make are identical to those which studies have shown are best for your heart. BTW, they also bring about considerable weight loss in most subjects. A Trifecta of benefits. Dr. Dean Ornish has done published studies on this diet and how it affects PSA progression in those with diagnosed prostate cancer. How it slows the advance of your psa. UCSF (University of California, San Francisco) has a good overall nutrition guideline (64 pages) here... http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf Good for your prostate cancer advancement, excellent for your probable heart disease, and a near guarantee on weight reduction. A fairly good chance that following such a diet, along with a real exercise program, will do wonders for your libido even if you never take any more TRT injections.. You are 55, this may be a blessing in disguise for your overall health regardless of whether you treat or don't treat your prostate cancer. I'll tell you this, if you and your wife are concerned as you indicate about your libido, then you may face problems soon anyway, with all your other factors. Age, obesity, smoking, lack of exercise, etc. That combo leads to a good percentage of men losing it by age 55 or 60. OK, more than you asked for, but from your original post, you seem to have already come to many of the same conclusions. Time for action now, regarding all those lifestyle changes that will absolutely be beneficial to your future health. Your wife will be supportive and no doubt she could use some of the same lifestyle changes. If you like, I could suggest a few books to look into.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I've also read that the Gleason score, after surgery, is found to be HIGHER than predicted by the biopsy somewhere between 20 and 28% of the time. I don't know the number, but there is a smaller percentage where the score turns out to be LOWER than predicted by the biopsy. I would always be nervous about going with AS -- until they are able to find a way to determine, without any doubt, the true nature of the cancer within the prostate. Only then will AS be a sure thing, risk-wise. Well then, you are going to have to treat millions and millions more men because prostate cancer is sitting there in a huge percentage of men walking down the street. Most of whom will never know it and few of whom will die from it. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23847245 Just one of many studies indicating that prostate cancer is wide spread in the general (unbiopsied) population. AS to the other issue about 20% - 28% of patients being upgraded after surgery and a smaller percentage being downgraded, that only makes sense if the great majority of patients treated begin as Gleason 6. Meaning that very seldom is a Gleason 6 downgraded. I can only recall a few times I've ever heard that. I suspect there are some instances when it is true, but the patient is not told, for obvious reasons. The trend of the field is to do more AS rather than less. That is clear. Up to the patient to weigh the risks and importantly access whether treatment down the road will be any less effective than treatment now. The problem is that most doctors are in a position where they only stand to get blamed if they don't treat. One has to realize that built in bias in their evaluation because they'll always hear about the case where waiting was wrong, but won't ever know if many other patients could have waited for 3 or 5 or 15 years and still be effectively treated or never treated. Up to fully informed patients to make the call and take the risk.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance (AS)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wjw My thought, which I also will be discussing with my urologist/surgeon, is that waiting for treatment after positive diagnosis of cancer gives you a higher probability of increasing Gleason score thus a higher probability of cancer returning. This seems to contradict the validity of AS altogether. . I think you are talking about two different things. (1) A Gleason 6 evolving into a Gleason 7 (2) a Gleason 7 being found after the prior biopsies had only located a Gleason 6. I don't think those Gleason 6 cancers turned into Gleason 7. The prostate is like a loaf of bread with some olives hidden in it. Some may be Gleason 6 and some may also be Gleason 7. Into that loaf of bread you insert some straws hitting some cancer and often missing many others. In your case it would seem they missed the Gleason 7 olives rather than the Gleason 6 olives turning into Gleason 7 olives. The study you read indicated a 45% return after 18.6 years. I am unclear if those aged 65 or older were treated at that age or are being followed up at that age. You don't indicate the median age of that group or their age when initially treated. All those details are important. Until you know those figures the picture is unclear. Of course we could entirely eliminate AS and treat everyone with Gleason 6 and even that would not change the status of those who were actually Gleason 7. In your case there doesn't seem to be any indication you would have been treated better even if you acted sooner. I suppose there are lots of studies with varying results as to the eventual outcome of large groups of Gleason 7.

AgeInfo.Phrase: am unclear if those aged 65 or older were treated at

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance (AS)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Flkjr Howdy. You seem to have a history of yo-yoing PSA. Your 7.3 in 2006 was followed by a 5.0 in the same year and a 4.5 the following. Why not wait 6 months (or even 3) and see if it indeed comes down again. If not then get that biopsy. Good luck and stay positive. I'd second this opinion. Even if it does drop back to around 5.0, then depending on how "enormous" your prostate is, you may or may not go ahead with a biopsy. At least you will have confirmed the PSA at 5.0 or perhaps 8.0, which might make a difference in how you approach treatment if you decide to do anything. Of course, the fact that you had a negative biopsy back in 2006 doesn't mean there wasn't some cancer back then. So if you are comfortable, give it 6 months or 3 months, just in case some "itis" or inflammation is driving the PSA up to 8.0. My psa jumps around more than yours. Have had 7.5 and 5.4 followed by going back under 4.0 and now down under 3.5 I no longer jump to biopsies after a jump up... but if I had the 7.3, followed by your 8.0... and that 8.0 was confirmed, then I'd do another biopsy just to see what is going on. BTW, at age 67, getting up once a night seems more normal than abnormal.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> BTW  at age 67  getting up once a night

Posts.Title: Time for another biopsy?

Posts.Content: Highly unlikely ... very very unlikely that your psa would go from under 4 to 108 in 6 months due to prostate cancer. Your doctor seems to be doing the right thing. However, even after you complete your antibiotics, it could take some considerable time for your prostate to get back to normal and give you a accurate PSA test. Even after the infection is gone you could still have residual inflammation. Don't be in a rush to get that PSA test. Although they may give you one sooner just to make sure they are following the right path. You didn't mention what your PSA result was in December. You only said it was normal. Do you know the actual number?
Posts.Title: Question about PSA Level

Posts.Content: You seem off base on so many issues. Where does one begin? That second PSA test was foolish to take. From what I can read, it was taken only a few days after the first test. You seem to think that a inflammation could calm down after a few days. The self administered Cipro would have done nothing in a few days, EVEN if there was a bacterial infection. You may not know this, but only about 30% of inflammations are caused by a bacterial infection. The vast majority are of unknown cause and antibiotics make no difference. Besides, even if there was bacteria a inflammation would take much longer to resolve in order to give a lowered PSA. Most probably you have a inflammation of unknown origin causing a spike in PSA. Actually even waiting 4 weeks is no guarantee that possible inflammation will calm down enough. These things can go on and on even with anti-inflammatory medication. It might take several months. This scare might give you pause regarding future use of Testosterone Therapy for the long term. Read this (Dr. Peter Scardino is a well known prostate cancer specialist---) http://books.google.com/books?id=gGy...%20psa&f=false You are going nuts for no good reason. You could very well have prostatitis. Often--- Often one can have asymptomatic prostatitis and not even be aware of it. It could easily raise your PSA to 5 or 10 or 20 and more. That is why your urologist told you not to worry. He has seen this a hundred times. Up to you, freak out for the next 4 weeks and even then face the prospect your PSA could still be raised, the anti-inflammatory meds not having made much difference. Then more weeks of fear as you wait longer, or get rushed into getting a biopsy. I warn you, 4 weeks is a very short time for things to settle down. Read that book section again. Remember prostatitis need not be made evident by symptoms you would be aware of. Sometimes the little knowledge you have can be a dangerous thing when it gets into a hypochondriac's mind. You might have cancer, and you might win the Powerball this weekend. I hear its $300,000,000 for the Saturday draw. Perhaps you should buy a ticket. It would be awful if your lucky numbers were drawn and you didn't play. Of course I'm being a bit over the top, but so are you. Have a nice weekend and wear your seat belt.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by clarksurvey Has anyone worked with the above book by Roger Mason? Can you get PC (1% is next to nothing) to subside and lower your psa thru diet and supplement and the 7-10 things Roger Mason clains will fix PC? Roger Mason writes new book every other year claiming to have the cure for x, y, or z... He is not a doctor and has no science training. Though he may say some things that are true, you can find better advice elsewhere. Look at all his "cure" books http://www.amazon.com/Roger-Mason/e/..._athr_dp_pel_1
Posts.Title: The Natural Prostate Cure

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by weballoon Otago, thanks for your reply. I am 62. Diagnosed 12/5/2014. So I am just getting into the research. My time frame for action is the next 3-6 months. (I don’t want any chance of it spreading so I am being aggressive). I have not gotten a second opinion on the Biopsy results. 12/5: Biopsy results (1 core positive; 5% cancer; Gleason 3 + 3) Well, you are 3 days into being diagnosed. My first bit of advice is to make NO decisions about treatment for at least 6 months. The chance of it spreading during that time is negligible. Allow yourself some months, not weeks, to get a 1st, 2nd, and 3rd take on all the information you will be digesting. Of those diagnosed, you are in the very very safest end of the spectrum. Quite frankly, in your position, I'd do nothing for at least a year except to get a second opinion on your 12 cores, and to follow your psa every three or four months. You might look at the following video interview between two well known prostate cancer specialists... done at the 2013 American Urological Association (AUA) Annual Scientific Meeting. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 I simply can't imagine either of those two doctors suggesting you do any treatment in the coming 12 months. You can allow yourself time... and it does take time... to gain a balanced view of the whole subject of prostate cancer. In short, slow way down. Don't even begin to think about finding the right surgeon any time soon.

Posts.Title: I need some support...

Posts.Content: Joe, you are really only a month into this since your biopsy and diagnosis. Given that one of the doctors was thinking about active surveillance, that should given you enough confidence to allow for you to take a couple more months before making a decision. Even six more months, depending on what your next psa score is. That most recent 12.4 may be a fluke, caused by other than cancer. Over a few more months you will get more comfortable with the material and have a better perspective on your situation rather than having your decision being based on confusion and fear. Allow some time.

Posts.Title: How do you process all the information?

Posts.Content: Several news items today about a study that looked at diet for those already diagnosed. I'm sure it would be equally important for those not yet diagnosed. http://www.theguardian.com/society/2...e-from-disease http://www.upi.com/Health_News/2015/...4221433183291/ "Based on the data, men who ate a Western diet were 2.53 times more likely to die a prostate-cancer related death and 1.67 times more likely to die from another cause in comparison to the fourth quartile of participants, whose diet was the least Western." The abstract http://cancerpreventionresearch.aacr...6/545.abstract I've long since changed my diet to a plan similar to what they indicate will point toward better outcomes. Can't imagine why most others would not do the same given that at the very least, it helps with the other, more probable, causes of illness and death.
Posts.Title: Multiple news items about a study regarding diet and PCa outcomes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FedCav Hello from Kansas City. My wife (together since 1984 and still going strong) and I are having our first "treatment options" meeting with my urologist tomorrow. Gary, nice that your wife can accompany you to the appointment. Let her be the one taking most of the notes as you may be overwhelmed with the information during the appointment. It appears you will be having some type of treatment. Many urologists do one or the other treatment and tend to have somewhat of a bias for the one they specialize in. But of course you can see others who specialize in the other options. And even if you decide on the option your urologist specializes in, there is no requirement that you have him do it. If during your visit he indicates the treatment he may do... then at that point, even though you are far from a decision, you might ask him how many of those procedures he has done... and how many he does each week or month. Where he got his training. (some doctors get their training only from short courses over a few days, while some have done year long fellowships involving the new robotic machine) You don't have to grill him, but those questions are ones you would need to know the answer to eventually. Easier to ask while you are there. I just mention it because it might crop up in your mind AFTER you've left the appointment.... then you have to call the office...and its just easier while you are there. Of course some urologists don't do one or even any of the treatments you might choose. Make a check list for the initial questions you may have. A year from now you can go back to worrying about your hair like everyone else

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Webheadfred My surgery will be scheduled next week. The Doc wanted to wait 6 weeks for the prostate to calm down after the biopsy. I did bleed for about 8 days. I should be having my surgery in the second or third week in July. Any thoughts? You had a biopsy on May 23rd and here we are 11 days later and you've already made your decision? What the heck is the rush? First of all, it is unclear whether you had 4 positive biopsies or 8 positive, since it appears that 2 were taken from each site. So, do you know if 4 or 8 were positive? Given that you had some 27 samples or about twice the normal number, then if you indeed only have 4 positive, that is equal to about 2 in the normal 12 core biopsy. All of yours are from 2% to 10%. If indeed there are only 4, which some might say, equals 2, then you should realize you may be a borderline case. I'm just giving you the other side of the coin. If I were you, I'd certainly give the decision process another month or so. I'm sure some others may disagree, but you should know, there is no rush to do surgery. Exactly what do you know about surgery and the side effects that most men have? Given the time frame within which you have made your decision, it would seem you've have little time to understand the whole picture. On the other hand, the surgery may be a fine choice. I'd certainly want to know all the details if I were in your shoes. Again, there is no rush at all
