Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Deech But I'm wondering what is accomplished if he lowers his PSA at this point? I suspect it's a measure of denial at work but I surely do not know. (I hesitate to ask him directly because 1) he IS a medical professional and 2) I don't want to sound like I'm challenging his professional opinion. ) He, (the urologist/surgeon) is also opining that a second opinion for his stats is not warranted. If anyone has thoughts on that, I would appreciate any comments. PSA May/2012 2.97 PSA Aug 2013 3.91 PSA May 2014 3.1 PSA May 6, 2015 8.5 PSA May 20, 2015 12.9 Prostate Needle Core Biopsy Highlights June 2015: Right mid: low grade adenocarcinoma, Gleason 3+3 = 6, present in 1 of 2 core biopsies, occupying 1% of 1 core left apex: low grade adenocarcinoma, Gleason 3+3 = 6, present in 1 of several cores, occupying 10% of 1 core Stage T1C Weight of prostate 55g . Seems to me like the only one using sound thinking in this case is your husband. Everyone else, including many of those making the other comments, are saddling up the horse, ready to gallop off and attack the invasion.... before they are even certain there is a enemy to fight. It is very possible that the cancer found in your husband is simply a normal age related finding of indolent prostate cancer, that is present in about half the men his age. The ONLY thing suggesting other wise is ONE single snapshot of his PSA. Why do I say ONE single snapshot? Because taking a second psa test, only 2 weeks after the first, allows no time for a inflammation, bacterial or non-bacterial, to calm down. Indeed it could get worse, and produce exactly the results you have seen in his two tests. Even if it is bacterial and the course of antibiotics can help, it may still take some time to get a accurate psa reading that is not affected by a bout of prostatitis. Take the antibiotics... but realize that some prostatitis is not only non-bacterial, unaffected by the antibiotic, but may also be asymptomatic, yet produce a large jump in psa results. By all means get a second opinion from another well respected urologist who is known for not jumping the gun and who is also known for encouraging active surveillance when appropriate. But for the sudden and possibly brief jump in PSA, your husband could be a prime candidate for AS. I'm troubled by the surgeons leap to quick surgery and his dismissive attitude about getting a second opinion. Very troubled by such a view. There is at least a 50/50 chance he needs no treatment at all. Your husband seems to be the only one not in a panic mode. Aside from a course of antibiotics, he may just need some time for this inflammation to pass. Prostatitis bouts can be very stubborn even with antibiotics. Read up about that before jumping to the knife. Thank goodness the doctor is on vacation, and that your husband is not being railroaded into rapid surgery. You and your husband need to stand back, take a deep breath and proceed with caution. His doctor might be right, but there is no solid indication that he is right. Don't be at all surprised if his psa over the next 3 or 6 months is right back at 2.9 to 3.9. If so, he is more than appropriate for AS. I hope he gets to read these posts. We can't link some sites here, but here is one section from a well known and respected site ============================================= Apart from these variances, PSA levels can be elevated by a number of causes, from infection to physical activities. For this reason it is very important to try to establish the cause of any elevated PSA level reported. If the PSA is below 20 ng/ml this should be done before having a biopsy. The most common causes of an elevated PSA are: prostatitis (an infection of the prostate); a bladder infection; or BPH (benign prostatic hyperplasia). This last condition affects most men over 50 years of age and is not deadly. Any infection should be treated before a second PSA test is carried out. Acute prostatitis can cause the PSA levels to rise five to seven times the normal level for up to six weeks or even longer. Both prostatitis and bladder infections are notoriously difficult to treat. There are various natural and pharmaceutical products that may reduce the size of a gland and these may reduce the effect of BPH on the PSA level =================================================

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by weballoon I was recently diagnosed with Prostate Cancer (Gleason 6, PSA 5.8, 1 of 12 cores had cancer and that core show only 5%) so I am somewhat fortunate for that. My urologists indicated that I would be a candidate for Active Surveillance (AS) but also outlined the various radiation and surgery options. After doing some general research I am not comfortable with the AS or radiation options and will likely pursue surgery. How recent is "recently diagnosed"... ? Meaning how much time have you had to evaluate your situation? What is your age and what is your complete PSA history... especially the dates and results of your past few years of PSA tests? Was your PSA tested again after your 5.8 ? How long after that 5.8 was taken? Were your 12 biopsy cores read for a second opinion by some place like John Hopkins? What is your time frame for action?

Posts.Title: I need some support...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by montrob I am a 59 year old, had DaVinci surgery for prostate cancer a year and a half ago. Always in pretty good shape before, no problems with erections. Had my surgery and came out achieved continence within 2 to 3 weeks. Now a year and a half later I have begun to have leakage problems to the point where I am wearing pads to absorb the leakage. Never have recovered the ability to have an erection despite using the blue pill for over a year. Now I feel like I was lied to. Would have traded 10 years of life for the ability to have an erection and control my leakage. Any suggestions I can't speak to the continence issues, but I would be optimistic that you can return to the state you were in only months after surgery in that regard. Don't limit yourself to one or even two doctors when getting opinions. That you had good control suggests there is a path back to that same position. Some doctors who are very busy, employ trained assistants that specialize in helping patients with incontinence. I'd guess that some of them are more skilled in that regard than the urologists. Certainly they have more time to address individual problems. Don't give up on finding a solution, before you resort to some surgical answer....which come with a whole other set of problems. Regarding the ED, a close friend of mine with some reluctance finally began using injections and has become quite satisfied with that approach after the initial getting familiar with the process. But what I really wanted to comment on was the following statement you made "Now I feel I was lied to".... I don't disagree with you in the following sense. As has been written in many articles, many doctors fail to inform their patients who are undergoing surgery about the true rate of ED and incontinence. They don't tell them what they consider to be ED and what they consider to be a usable erection. They raise false hopes by not being up front about their definitions of what constitutes a erection and continence. Even in this forum, the numbers of those who end up with ED and incontinence are under played. Most men... Most men, who undergo surgery will not return to having normal erections as they understand that definition. Too many doctors do not tell their patients about this expected outcome. Only if a man takes considerable time on his own to investigate the subject will he find out the true numbers and true definitions of ED and incontinence. Given the huge number of men who end up with outcomes they didn't expect, one has to be aware that such problems are not adequately discussed in many forums. Too much emphasis is placed on optimistic outcomes. Also, there seems a bias for not risking any danger to life expectancy. Meaning that if someone said you'd have a 10% chance of dying 10 years earlier, that many wouldn't even want to risk that. I think lots of men would accept a 10% chance of losing 10 years of life, if they decided to take some path other than surgery with all of its risks. The point is that patients need all the true facts and then they can decide on the risk they are willing to take. Generally speaking, doctors will advise the path that entails the lowest risk to patient life vs patient quality of life. Doctors seldom get blamed for too much treatment whereas they can be blamed for not doing adequate treatment. Thus, most doctors have a built in bias for treatment. That would be OK if they had adequately informed their patients of true outcomes. I know you are discouraged, but there is great reason to believe that you can overcome your incontinence problems with the right help. Also, as was the case of my friend, he has gotten to a place where he has a enjoyable sex life with the use of injections. BTW, he married his wife about two years AFTER his surgery and now 7 years later, they are doing fine.

AgeInfo.Phrase: by montrob I am a 59 year old  had DaVinci surgery

Posts.Title: Suggestions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tattlebaum Initial test was on the 23rd, follow up on the 29th. I was given nothing between the dates additional to the statin and Omperazole I always take. Of note, one test is "immunoassay Roche COBAS" with a 4.0 as the high normal limit and the other unnamed with 4.5 as the high upper limit. What's with that? OK, according to some, if you are over 60, then 4.0 is the upper "normal" limit, and for some past age 60, they call 4.5 the "normal" limit. They are both talking about the same group of men. Don't pay too much attention to those differences. I could give you respectable doctors who suggest everyone over 2.5 should be given a biopsy. Much of the science about prostate cancer is all over the map. NOW, after a year or so, you getting your normal physical, etc, with a PSA....which came in at 6.... followed by ANOTHER... PSA test only SIX days later. Then referred to a urologist... who then gave you a biopsy. Well, in my book, that is sheer insanity. Waiting all of 6 days to do a followup test is madness.. Uninformed madness. If... IF a inflammation of any origin is boosting your PSA from 2 or 3 up to 6, there is little chance that inflammation will have subsided in only 6 days. You may not even be aware of the inflammation. Called asymptomatic prostatitis. Very common and can easily boost a PSA from 2.0 to 6.0 or 7.0. I have gotten a 7.5... only to have my current PSA at 3.3 Then after that silly confirmation test, you are put aboard the biopsy express train. Yes, they did come up with a Gleason 6, something that you may have been better off never having been discovered. Now you are officially a "cancer patient" whereas if they had waited 3 to 6 months to retest your PSA, there is a good chance it would have been back in the 2.0 to 2.9 range. Which of course would not have entitled you to a biopsy. Then you may well have lived the rest of your life officially without prostate cancer. You see, the majority of men have prostate cancer before they die. Except most of them are undiagnosed and are never affected by the prostate cancer. But now you are on board the train. Called upon to make decisions and to worry. First off all... do nothing for now. Wait 6 months and retest your PSA. At the very least, if you can't stand it, wait 3 months and retest. Nothing bad is going to happen by waiting 6 months. Good chance your PSA will be back under 3.0. Now, listen to this interview. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Listen to all of it, especially focus on minute 8:00 onward. Speaks about those who get spikes in PSA, only to return to normal range if they only wait. But too often, by then, they were forced to under go a biopsy and now they are officially a "cancer" patient....faced with the mess of treatment options, for a "cancer" that in most men, would never have caused them a problem. We can't know for sure what you'll find in 6 months, but for now, you have been prematurely put through a unnecessary biopsy procedure. That they found some "official" prostate cancer, in Gleason 6.... small amounts, only makes you a normal man of age 62. Be assured of this' you will die with prostate cancer, as will most men. Only a good portion of men are never aware of it and are unaffected by their cancer. Too bad you had a biopsy after two psa's only 6 days apart. Now wait.. Retest in 6 months... and don't spend much time worrying. Very good chance you are just fine. A fair chance.. you'll never need treatment. A very small chance you'll ever die of prostate cancer. Remember now, my PSA was 7.5 and now it is 3.3

AgeInfo.Phrase: and for some past age 60  they call 4 5 the
a normal man of age 62  Be assured of this' you

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with some questions.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Omar1968 This is my first post to this forum. I am 46 years old, and I was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. Histologic Type: Adenocarcinoma (acinar, not otherwise specified) Gleason Pattern: Primary 3, Secondary 3, Total 6 PSA 4.82 This was my first and only PSA Number of cores positive: 2 Total number of cores: 22 Proportion of prostatic tissue involved by tumor: 5% I have seen three surgeons, Any information you can share with me will be greatly appreciated as I attempt to make a decision. #1. Slow down. You say you have been "recently diagnosed"... What was the date of your diagnosis and what was the date of your psa test. Did no one suggest that you do a follow up psa test instead of just proceeding to the biopsy? Either way, I'd want a follow up psa test to confirm what your true psa result is. Frankly they should have done a second psa test before doing the biopsy... unless they also felt something on your DRE exam. Now, I'd still like a 2nd psa test.. because your true psa could be 1 or 2 instead of 4.82. #2, Anyway they did a biopsy. Did they give you any reason why they did 22 cores? That seems excessive for a 1st biopsy. Makes it all the more likely to find something... even a insignificant prostate cancer. Which brings up the 2 cores at only 5%... Actually had they done the more normal 12, it is probable they would have had 1 positive core at 5%... A Gleason 6 in one core at 5% would seem to be a very good case for AS... Especially if your true psa turned out to be only 1 or 2. #3... Certainly before I'd be making any decisions, I'd be sending in my slides to another institution for second analysis. We had recent person here, given a Gleason 8 score (3+5) who turned out to be a Gleason 6 (3+3)... (he sent his to John Hopkins and they couldn't imagine how he got a 5 reading) #4. . Slow down ( I know I said that twice) You only get one shot at this. If they take out your prostate, there is no going back. Again, why didn't they retest your psa, and what reason did they give for doing 22 cores? I'm trying to take the conservative angle on this because often men get into the "get it out quick" mode. You could do as each surgeon suggested... do watchful waiting... perhaps for 6 months or one year, while you gain a better feel for the whole subject matter and then make a decision after that time period. It appears that if all the surgeons think that AS is reasonable option, that they don't sense a need to rush. I don't either.

Posts.Title: Looking for information

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tattlebaum Because of a rising PSA (it was 2 for eons and a routine annual test and retest was 6 and 7) my PCP sent me to a urologist. DRE was unremarkable. A biopsy was done. 12 cores, 2 positive, one at 5% and the other at 10%. Gleason 3+3=6. No other information. Only another PSA in 6 months is planned. The urologist suggested I see an oncologist, my PCP didn't think that was necessary. Is there anything else I should be doing at this time, except waiting 6 months for another PSA and DRE? Been reading as much as I can about it and there's so much conflicting information... . You should include the date you had the recent test and retest. Specifically, how long was the time between those two tests? That is important. Also what if anything were you given between the two tests? In other words... if the time between the two recent tests was insufficient for a inflammation to have calmed down, then your psa of 6 and 7 might be abnormal for you and your true psa may still only be 2 or 3. So let us know the time between the two tests. Often doctors recheck only a month or less after getting one higher psa.... then if its still high they whisk you off to the uro who finds a low risk Gleason 6 that would have been better if it were not discovered... Or perhaps your doctor waited 3 to 6 months for the next psa test. Let us know.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with some questions.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by azsunshine I made a mistake with his age. He's 60. He has his prostate. His urologist did his PSA several years ago before pellets and it was zero. . I don't think that is possible. Might be zero-point something (0.5) but not zero unless his prostate has been killed. Perhaps I am wrong???
Posts.Title: Stupid ignorant doctors!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I've also read that the Gleason score, after surgery, is found to be HIGHER than predicted by the biopsy somewhere between 20 and 28% of the time. I don't know the number, but there is a smaller percentage where the score turns out to be LOWER than predicted by the biopsy. I would always be nervous about going with AS -- until they are able to find a way to determine, without any doubt, the true nature of the cancer within the prostate. Only then will AS be a sure thing, risk-wise. Well then, you are going to have to treat millions and millions more men because prostate cancer is sitting there in a huge percentage of men walking down the street. Most of whom will never know it and few of whom will die from it. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23847245 Just one of many studies indicating that prostate cancer is wide spread in the general (unbiopsied) population. AS to the other issue about 20% - 28% of patients being upgraded after surgery and a smaller percentage being downgraded, that only makes sense if the great majority of patients treated begin as Gleason 6. Meaning that very seldom is a Gleason 6 downgraded. I can only recall a few times I've ever heard that. I suspect there are some instances when it is true, but the patient is not told, for obvious reasons. The trend of the field is to do more AS rather than less. That is clear. Up to the patient to weigh the risks and importantly access whether treatment down the road will be any less effective than treatment now. The problem is that most doctors are in a position where they only stand to get blamed if they don't treat. One has to realize that built in bias in their evaluation because they'll always hear about the case where waiting was wrong, but won't ever know if many other patients could have waited for 3 or 5 or 15 years and still be effectively treated or never treated. Up to fully informed patients to make the call and take the risk.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance (AS)

Posts.Content: Thanks for filling in the facts. Well, either way, it appears you have 7 positive cores out of 24 total. That alone would seem to exclude AS (active surveillance) However your actual psa might still be in question. You will be getting follow up psa test results for a blood draw on Dec. 13. That will be interesting, however a note of caution. You only had your "24 core" biopsy 17 days prior to that blood draw. Not only are you possibly waiting for any prior inflammation from prostatitis to calm down, but now you've thrown in another potential inflammatory issue, the 24 core biopsy. --"Recent prostate biopsy can cause a significant increase in PSA values." --"After biopsy, it may take a month or more before the PSA returns to baseline." source http://www.lexmed.com/docs/understanding_psa_test.pdf So lets see the result of the psa , but keep in mind those two potential influencing factors. 1. the fairly recent inflammation, and 2. the very recent biopsy. Might be you'll want to do another psa test in about mid January. It is still possible your true "prostate cancer related" psa is actually under 10. Can make some difference in your choice of treatment and level of concern, or even your feeling of urgency to treat. That you got all Gleason 6 is good. Might turn out lucky that you got that urinary infection that seems to have brought about the further testing of your psa.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman So after having a cardiac catheterization 2 months ago with 2 stents inserted, to clear blockage sq, I'm having another one this morning. Had a very slight tightness in my throat when I run, after about a minute, that goes away when I slow to a walk. Honestly I'm not sure if it's real, or in my head, because I am so hyper aware of every little sensation since the stents were inserted in June. In fact, it's so slight, that I told the Dr if I wasn't looking for it, I wouldn't even notice it. Each case is different. I exercise 6 days a week for the last 3.5 years. That is over 1,000 episodes of exercise. I have felt angina on about 998 of those days. Again your situation may have other details, but simply feeling a bit of angina in your arms, neck, jaw, or chest is not unusual for someone with some blockages. It normally falls under the category of "stable angina". If it happens when you are not exercising, well that is another matter. My angina comes on about 3 to 4 minutes into my exercise routine, however if I were to start off faster or jog/run up hill, I could bring it on within 1 to 2 minutes. I am used to it by now and while I'd rather it were gone, the small temporary discomfort between minutes 3 and 16...(after which it goes away as I bike), are not enough for me to go in for a stent on my one blockage. By the time you read this, you probably will have already undergone the angiogram with the possible insertion of another stent. Get all the precise details about what the blockage was (%) and exactly where it was. In some people, some stents are essential. In others, it is purely a matter of choice. For most people with stable angina it is a matter of preference since the stent does not prevent a heart attack or death. Meaning treatment by meds, lifestyle, and diet give about the same result. HOWEVER, each case is different, but the patient should be asking the doctor those questions as to whether the stent will prevent anything, or is only to provide comfort from angina during exercise. You should also ask him if you always need to stop when feeling slight discomfort. There is a term... the actual name... called walk-through angina... or warm up angina. Where you feel the slight discomfort, but continue. Not everyone has to stop exercise at the first sign of stable angina. So, even if you'v already had a stent inserted by the time you read this, you need to ask the doctor on your next visit, why he is putting in the last stent or the next one.. Is it only for discomfort, or is there another medical reason? Remembering that as we have discussed before, you have a calcium score over 900 while mine is under 100. So I don't want to suggest that everything that applies to me would be the same for you, in terms of the value and advisability of getting a stent today or in the future. Let us know how it all came out and the details of what was found and what was done. Did you ever get that second opinion from that additional cardiologist? You had mentioned your intent to do that a couple months back.
Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steven72 Now, I've been referred to a urologist for a DRE, and I have a PSA re-test. The Dr. hesitated, but prescribed a two week course of Cipro to address the diarrhea and potential prostatitis. I'm on day 5 of the Cipro, and the diarrhea is improving. Do not rush to have your next PSA test any time soon after finishing your Cipro. If...and its a big if....If your prostatitis was caused by a bacterial infection, then even after treatment with antibiotics, it can take some time for the inflammation to calm down, such that you get a true PSA score. I'd wait many weeks, a month or more. Also please be aware that the majority of prostatitis is not caused by a bacterial infection and thus the antibiotic can't cure it. Sometimes the only cure is more "time"... Originally Posted by Steven72 Anyway, it all seems very weird to me... and of course, the a bad scenario here is that the previous Doctors should have investigated the discharge further, and because they didn't, it may well be Prostrate Cancer that has spread into my bowel - causing the diarrhea. Of course, the best case scenario is that the two are unrelated, the Cipro kills the bugs causing the diarrhea and the prostate infection. . Extremely....very extremely unlikely...that a prostate cancer has spread to your bowel and is causing diarrhea.. I wouldn't even be thinking about that. Far more likely you just had a bad meal at Chipolte...
Posts.Title: 43 y/o, PSA=6. Retest and urologist app't in New Year

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kens I was just diagnosed following a biopsy on July 14th, with results on July 30th. The pathology shows 1 of 10 specimens having 10% adenocarcinoma with a Gleason 3+3. My last PSA was on April 3, 2014 and showed 3.76. I am very interested in knowing what the common treatment modality is in this situation? Personally I am looking most seriously at the DaVinci nerve-sparing prostectomy right now, if I can convince my insurance company to do it... Please share any thoughts and recommendations, or insight...? ! You might include your past PSA history. Why were you given a biopsy? Include your past psa history. Was there something felt on a DRE? Unless there are other missing factors, if I was in your shoes, I'd do absolutely nothing. From what you have given us, you are the prime example of someone who could do no treatment. Instead, just do AS... sit back and see what happens in a year or two or five. Most men in your situation could do nothing and end up living to age 85 or 90 without ever treating their prostate cancer. They'd be just like the other 80 year old men, over half of whom die with prostate cancer, but from other causes. Seriously, move very very very very slowly on this. Take 6 months or a year before making a decision about treating this low grade prostate cancer. Listen to the following discussion/interview between two highly respected experts in the field http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 11 minutes long. I don't see how you can listen to that and still feel the need to take action right away. Apparently you are new to all of this, only having your results for a few days. I can assure you, at this point you know almost nothing about the subject. If you did, you be amazingly more hesitant to do anything quickly. Certainly in ZERO rush to come to any decisions. You could sit back, read up and study for the next year, and be in no more danger than you are now. If after a year, you decided to make a treatment choice, it would almost certainly be just as effective a year from now, or even two years from now, as it would be today. You also need to learn far more about the side effects. Far too many men underestimate the side effect from surgery. Only a minority of men return to full sexual function (like it was before), after having surgery of any type. You need to be very precise on the definition of what constitutes a usable erection. Many doctors will give out glowing numbers of the percentage of their patients who have full function. It can be very different than the patient's definition. That difference lead to much disappointment after surgery as expectations are not met. The same hold true for the definition of continence. What you consider continence may not be the same as the doctors definition. If you take a good deal of time, you will begin to understand the actual reality of what to expect after surgery or other treatments.

AgeInfo.Phrase: end up living to age 85 or 90 without ever treating
be just like the other 80 year old men  over half

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with some questions.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by vaportrail I'm a little bit hesitant about getting a biopsy. I don't like the idea of bacteria from my colon getting introduced into my prostate and blood stream. . If you wait 4 months and you're still up near 5.6 then you will be doing a biopsy. I don't think anyone questions that. Done properly, with some antibiotic ahead of time, your risk of a bacterial infection is quite low. About 1% or so. No need to worry about spreading cancer during a biopsy. Originally Posted by vaportrail I was doing good losing weight on testosterone. I shed 15 pounds without much problem. But now I'm gaining it back... I have a lot of other old injuries, that prevent me from exercising. Makes it really hard to for me to get back into shape. In your mid 40's its about time to be considering a significant change in your diet anyway, or you'll face a future of weight gain. With some real change, you could lose that 10 pounds you've regained, though not as fast as you put it back on. Do your old injuries prevent you from doing a low-impact sport such as cycling? I find cycling to leaves me without pains, yet burns a lot of calories and does great things for one's heart. BTW, the very same dietary changes that are best for your prostate are also the best for your heart (and weight loss), and you are much more likely to die from heart disease than prostate cancer (even if you get prostate cancer). All in all, chances are very good you don't have prostate cancer. Good to wait 4 months before a retest. Anything less and you may not give time for a inflammation to calm down.

We can't know for sure what you'll find in 6 months, but for now, you have been prematurely put through a unnecessary biopsy procedure. That they found some "official" prostate cancer, in Gleason 6.... small amounts, only makes you a normal man of age 62. Be assured of this' you will die with prostate cancer, as will most men. Only a good portion of men are never aware of it and are unaffected by their cancer. Too bad you had a biopsy after two psa's only 6 days apart. Now wait.. Retest in 6 months... and don't spend much time worrying. Very good chance you are just fine. A fair chance.. you'll never need treatment. A very small chance you'll ever die of prostate cancer. Remember now, my PSA was 7.5 and now it is 3.3

a normal man of age 62  Be assured of this' you

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with some questions.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tattlebaum Because of a rising PSA (it was 2 for eons and a routine annual test and retest was 6 and 7) my PCP sent me to a urologist. DRE was unremarkable. A biopsy was done. 12 cores, 2 positive, one at 5% and the other at 10%. Gleason 3+3=6. No other information. Only another PSA in 6 months is planned. The urologist suggested I see an oncologist, my PCP didn't think that was necessary. Is there anything else I should be doing at this time, except waiting 6 months for another PSA and DRE? Been reading as much as I can about it and there's so much conflicting information... . You should include the date you had the recent test and retest. Specifically, how long was the time between those two tests? That is important. Also what if anything were you given between the two tests? In other words... if the time between the two recent tests was insufficient for a inflammation to have calmed down, then your psa of 6 and 7 might be abnormal for you and your true psa may still only be 2 or 3. So let us know the time between the two tests. Often doctors recheck only a month or less after getting one higher psa.... then if its still high they whisk you off to the uro who finds a low risk Gleason 6 that would have been better if it were not discovered... Or perhaps your doctor waited 3 to 6 months for the next psa test. Let us know.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with some questions.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by azsunshine He said his was 0 and his doctor told him there was no chance of him ever getting pc and didn't see the need for PSA test. . Can we assume this man has had his prostate removed some time prior to this party?
Posts.Title: Stupid ignorant doctors!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman So after having a cardiac catheterization 2 months ago with 2 stents inserted, to clear blockage sq, I'm having another one this morning. Had a very slight tightness in my throat when I run, after about a minute, that goes away when I slow to a walk. Honestly I'm not sure if it's real, or in my head, because I am so hyper aware of every little sensation since the stents were inserted in June. In fact, it's so slight, that I told the Dr if I wasn't looking for it, I wouldn't even notice it. Each case is different. I exercise 6 days a week for the last 3.5 years. That is over 1,000 episodes of exercise. I have felt angina on about 998 of those days. Again your situation may have other details, but simply feeling a bit of angina in your arms, neck, jaw, or chest is not unusual for someone with some blockages. It normally falls under the category of "stable angina". If it happens when you are not exercising, well that is another matter. My angina comes on about 3 to 4 minutes into my exercise routine, however if I were to start off faster or jog/run up hill, I could bring it on within 1 to 2 minutes. I am used to it by now and while I'd rather it were gone, the small temporary discomfort between minutes 3 and 16...(after which it goes away as I bike), are not enough for me to go in for a stent on my one blockage. By the time you read this, you probably will have already undergone the angiogram with the possible insertion of another stent. Get all the precise details about what the blockage was (%) and exactly where it was. In some people, some stents are essential. In others, it is purely a matter of choice. For most people with stable angina it is a matter of preference since the stent does not prevent a heart attack or death. Meaning treatment by meds, lifestyle, and diet give about the same result. HOWEVER, each case is different, but the patient should be asking the doctor those questions as to whether the stent will prevent anything, or is only to provide comfort from angina during exercise. You should also ask him if you always need to stop when feeling slight discomfort. There is a term... the actual name... called walk-through angina... or warm up angina. Where you feel the slight discomfort, but continue. Not everyone has to stop exercise at the first sign of stable angina. So, even if you'v already had a stent inserted by the time you read this, you need to ask the doctor on your next visit, why he is putting in the last stent or the next one.. Is it only for discomfort, or is there another medical reason? Remembering that as we have discussed before, you have a calcium score over 900 while mine is under 100. So I don't want to suggest that everything that applies to me would be the same for you, in terms of the value and advisability of getting a stent today or in the future. Let us know how it all came out and the details of what was found and what was done. Did you ever get that second opinion from that additional cardiologist? You had mentioned your intent to do that a couple months back.
Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gunrun Can you send his info to me? I am at my urologists office now waiting for the consult thanks. I suppose the original doctor who did the biopsy was a urologist, right? Who is the "consult" with? Type of doctor, and the reason for the "consult". Advised by the other doctor or just your own choice? Look, you apparently only found out your status yesterday. You have not yet heard from the second reading of the biopsy samples. Given your data...you really need to slow down. You can always be "aggressive" with any treatment you may choose, but right now all of this is happening too fast for a person who is new to all of this. Should the new reading hold the same, this cancer has been in you for years, not weeks or even months. No need to come to any quick decisions. Certainly no need to book a surgical date. A decision you make in a month will be more well thought out than some urgent decision you come to in the first week. Again, this cancer is years old... not just something that popped up in the last couple months.

Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman So i got home an hour ago, very uneventful. They found nothing. He told me that the stents were in place and working just the way we want them to, and they found nothing significant that needed to be stented. I asked, in that case, how should we approach the fact that i did have a positive echo stress test. He told me that the positive aspect of the stress test were not that significant, so just dont worry about it. I know that about 30% of stress tests are false positives. Also it was only the EKG that was abnormal, the images looked very good. So hopefully thats the end of it and i can move on. I'll talk with my cardiologist later today or tomorrow. Otago, you've given me some great questions to ask the cardiologist, expecially about whether to exercess through what appears to be stable angina (or my defective brain, not sure which. . Sounds like all went well. Nothing new discovered. Regarding exercising through angina, I want to emphasize I am not talking about gritting it out or pushing through the pain. I'm only talking about getting a minor feeling in arms, neck, jaw, chest.... where it just lets you know its there, but not causing you any significant discomfort. I refer it as "notification angina" (my name for it)... letting me know its there, but not causing what I would label as real pain or discomfort. By the way, if that same level of angina were to occur after the initial 15 or 20 minute warm up, then I would either slow to a cruise or stop. I get mine at the precise same points in my bike ride every day. Just like clock-work. On better days, it can be very subtle, but I am aware of the early symptoms. Of course I might drop over any day... but I don't think it likely. By the way, "walk-through" angina, as the name implies, means you just keep on going at a pace that doesn't increase the discomfort and then as dilation occurs and collateral circulation comes on, the discomfort goes away. However, it is also called "warm up angina"... where one exercises until feeling some angina... then stops for about 15 minutes... then resumes the exercise with the angina often resolved. Those names, "walk through" and "warm up" are the actual names used in the medical journals. The practice may or may not be advisable in your situation, however I do find that doctors are likely to want to reduce even the tiny chances of problems and thus can be very conservative in their advice. Even to the point of always saying "STOP" whenever you feel anything. The correspondence I have had with doctors who study this in Canada and in the UK, all tell me that exercise is a essential element in treating coronary artery disease. That and your diet, of course. Plus the statin you are already on. It will be interesting to hear what your doctor says.
Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by webster Hi all, Recently OH had his PSA checked which came back as 7.8, up from 2.2 4 years ago. He is only 57. This set in motion some tests, MRI and a TRUS biopsy that is scheduled in the next 90 to 120 days. Public hospital system wait list here. We did the MRI a couple of days ago. . Obviously this is a very stressful time and the wait for answers is very difficult to cope with for all of us. So how do I best support him through this process? It's so hard to see your partner going through this As is often the case, doing a biopsy after ONE jump in PSA is crazy, unless there are other factors. You report nothing that would indicate prostate cancer other than the ONE jump in PSA. I have had large jumps twice. The last one was to 7.5. I did not do a biopsy after that 7.5. Instead we waited either 3 or 6 months and then my last PSA was 3.3. Lucky for you the TRUS biopsy is scheduled 3 or 4 months from now. Two weeks before that appointment you need to get another PSA done. If it is around 3.0 or less you should cancel that biopsy. The notion that every jump in PSA should lead to a biopsy is madness. Retesting the PSA a 3 or more months later is the right way to approach this. You and your partner have allowed your lack of knowledge of this to cause you grief. When I was 57 my psa was about 2.7... Seven years later it is 3.3 But as stated, it has jumped twice, with one jump being 7.5. I no longer worry about jumps. We calmly wait and retest. Look at this thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...-My-PSA-Is-5.5 Then look at this thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...iopsy-Is-Today Then look at the same guy starting this new thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...s-of-My-Biopsy All that worry over nothing. Should have waited to retest his PSA in the first place, rather than jumping to a biopsy.

<Z> <Z> When I was 57 my psa was about 2

Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde And even if your total diagnosis is not the worst in the world you will sooner or later need treatment. It might not be a big hurry but at 62 a 3+4 cancer will certainly have the time needed to kill you. Simply not true that a 3+4 will absolutely need treatment or with time will kill you. "There is an increasing recognition that patients with Gleason 3 + 4 = 7, in which the component of pattern 4 is small (<10%), have a very similar natural history to those with Gleason 3 + 3, perhaps reflecting the stage migration phenomenon associated with grade reclassification [44]. These patients are surveillance candidates. MRI to confirm the absence of large volume, high-grade cancer is particularly important in these patients." http://journals.lww.com/co-urology/F...rative.15.aspx

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobertG How can you be scheduled for surgery and not be aware that incontinence is one of the side-effects of that surgery? You'd be amazed at how little of what the doctor passes onto the patient is retained. 20%... 30% ...? How many men bring a yellow legal pad into the appointment with them? Catching every 3rd point. Additionally, only a tiny fraction of men read this forum and the other 3 or 4 active sites where information is passed along. Amazing but true. Can you imagine if 250,000 new men were reading and posting here every year? Or even if only 10% of them came her. 25,000 new men every year. This site would be a zoo. Perhaps 1 patient in 10 reads Walsh's book or something similar. Lastly, those side effects... "they probably won't happen to me"...

Posts.Title: Johns Hopkins on Kegel Exercises

Posts.Content: Thanks for filling in the facts. Well, either way, it appears you have 7 positive cores out of 24 total. That alone would seem to exclude AS (active surveillance) However your actual psa might still be in question. You will be getting follow up psa test results for a blood draw on Dec. 13. That will be interesting, however a note of caution. You only had your "24 core" biopsy 17 days prior to that blood draw. Not only are you possibly waiting for any prior inflammation from prostatitis to calm down, but now you've thrown in another potential inflammatory issue, the 24 core biopsy. --"Recent prostate biopsy can cause a significant increase in PSA values." --"After biopsy, it may take a month or more before the PSA returns to baseline." source http://www.lexmed.com/docs/understanding_psa_test.pdf So lets see the result of the psa , but keep in mind those two potential influencing factors. 1. the fairly recent inflammation, and 2. the very recent biopsy. Might be you'll want to do another psa test in about mid January. It is still possible your true "prostate cancer related" psa is actually under 10. Can make some difference in your choice of treatment and level of concern, or even your feeling of urgency to treat. That you got all Gleason 6 is good. Might turn out lucky that you got that urinary infection that seems to have brought about the further testing of your psa.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I guess what you are missing is my PSA steadily going up. Why, I hope it is a benign reason but if it's not I will just be that further ahead on info. I go for another PSA Friday and I'm just finding out what I can in advance should I have another biopsy and it is cancer. You guys are always saying make sure you get plenty of info before making a decision so that's what I'm during. What's it hurt to get as much info up front so that I will have a better knowledge of what I will want to do and what surgeon I will choose.. I'm 69 Well I do understand some of it as I've done the same, though you seem to be getting real specific. You may be like me, with a psa that just jumps around. Looking back, you had a 5.9 which dropped back to 3.1 Mine jumps all over the place. I no longer worry. I've had one 7.3 and one 5.5. My last one was 3.3. I've gotten use to the game and no longer think about getting a second biopsy. Anyway, let us know after your next one what the result is. Looks like its been 3 months since your last, which was up a bit, but with a freePSA that was OK. If you get another 4.8, I'd probably wait another 3 months and test again, before I'd do another biospy. You have to be careful, if you biopsy enough on almost any man age 69, they'll find a cancer. Mostly ones you don't want to find. Like a 3+3 in one or two cores, with a low percentage of each core. Then what do you do? BTW, I'm 64 and my father had PCa... lived 25 years afterwards, died of other causes.

Posts.Title: Open or Robotic, which to choose

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shittingbricks To start, how do I put info of my condition at bottom of page. I am 47, firefighter from the uk. PSA score 17.4. Gleason score 6, right lobe 1 core 2% positive out of 12, left lobe 4 out of 12, 8% As Mikla suggested, perhaps you can clear up your actual number of positive cores. We can understand the right lobe, 1 core at 2%, but out of 12? on the right side? or 12 total? Then you indicate 4 positive on the left side at 8%. I can't imagine that all 4 are each at 8%. Perhaps you can clear up what each of the 4 left cores are regarding their percentage (for example #1 @ 8%, #2 @15%, #[email protected] 18%, #[email protected] 22%) Originally Posted by Shittingbricks Urine infection triggered investigation, never had psa reading prior to this and had second psa after infection clear 17.2. Could you give us a timeline on that psa testing. Date of the first psa test, then how soon and how long you were treated with antibiotics. Then importantly the following questions-- #1. how long after finishing the antibiotics were you tested for the second time? #2. How long between the first psa test and the second psa test? Were you ever actually tested for a urine infection and was a actual bacteria found in that test? Or was it just assumed that your symptoms indicated a urinary bacterial infection so you were given antibiotics either for that or for both that and a potential bacterial caused prostatitis? You should understand that most prostatitis is caused by non-bacterial inflammation. Thus the antibiotic will not kill a bacteria that does not exist. And your inflammation that can be the cause of the spiked PSA will persist, often for a good deal of time afterwards. Months.... So you could have a low risk Gleason 6 prostate cancer along with a seemingly higher risk PSA score that is mostly not caused by your prostate cancer, but rather by your prostatitis. It can take considerable time for prostatitis to calm down and for the PSA to reveal its true level. IF your PSA were only 4 or 7 in stead of 17, then you might feel a bit less anxious. Though you still would have prostate cancer. But it may be fairly low risk that could influence your treatment choices or at least the feeling of being rushed to act quickly. Those doctors indicating you should wait, may be counting on your true PSA reading to be much lower than in the last tests. " Biopsy showed prostatitis and chronic inflammation"... Both can greatly raise your PSA results.

Posts.Title: Just got the bad news

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dom555 Hi all just new on here n really worried my husband is 48 and has had an enlarged prostate for a while now so he gets his levels checked regularly. Before Xmas his psa was 4 and has now jumped to 33. Can anyone tell me whether he's more likely to have this as we r waiting for an appointment with the urologist but the wait is killing us You should feel good that his psa jumped from 4 to 33 since Xmas. Prostate cancer would not cause such a rapid jump. This doesn't mean he couldn't still have some prostate cancer, only that the rapid jump up is almost certainly NOT caused by prostate cancer. The huge jump, plus his clear symptoms, indicate your fears about having a rapidly growing prostate cancer are highly unlikely to be the cause of the test result.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mario361 Do these tests vary often, and are the results occasionally inaccurate depending on the lab? I guess these are questions the urologist will answer, but I'm just concerned. Thanks again. Yes... test vary and even when the lab is accurate, the psa can jump all over the place. I have had tests that jump from 3.5 to 7.5 and then back to 3.8 six months later. I've had several jumps like that. I do not run for a biopsy every time that happens or I'd be getting stuck with needles every year. My last PSA was 3.3. I've had tests of 7.5 and over 5.5. You simply don't understand the many causes of jumps in PSA. You don't even need to see a urologist now. Just wait a minimum of 3 months (6 months better)... and retest. Far better than getting 12 giant needles punched into your rear end.
Posts.Title: Concerned 41 yr old PSA 2

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear the news. Difficult that you have to wait 3 more days for the details. Take a pad and paper to write down everything. You'll be getting a lot of information in 20 or 30 minutes. The good thing about having to wait until Monday is that you can prepare a list of questions so that you get precise details I'm sure some where there is a good list online, of questions you should ask Perhaps someone here can find it and post it. Stuff that, after the appointment, will pop up in your mind, and then its too difficult to re-contact the doctor for those one or two additional questions. Clearly you had 10 to 14 cores taken. You need to know how many are positive What percent of each is positive The Gleason score of each I guess. I suppose you can ask for and obtain a copy of the entire report so you can discuss it and look up details as you gain understanding. I'm sure others here will give you more questions to prepare. Yes, the more I think about it, your doctor not being available today is a good thing for your eventual meeting such that you gain a full understanding by being more prepared with questions. Wishing you well.
Posts.Title: 38 years old, high PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kens I was just diagnosed following a biopsy on July 14th, with results on July 30th. The pathology shows 1 of 10 specimens having 10% adenocarcinoma with a Gleason 3+3. My last PSA was on April 3, 2014 and showed 3.76. I am very interested in knowing what the common treatment modality is in this situation? Personally I am looking most seriously at the DaVinci nerve-sparing prostectomy right now, if I can convince my insurance company to do it... Please share any thoughts and recommendations, or insight...? ! You might include your past PSA history. Why were you given a biopsy? Include your past psa history. Was there something felt on a DRE? Unless there are other missing factors, if I was in your shoes, I'd do absolutely nothing. From what you have given us, you are the prime example of someone who could do no treatment. Instead, just do AS... sit back and see what happens in a year or two or five. Most men in your situation could do nothing and end up living to age 85 or 90 without ever treating their prostate cancer. They'd be just like the other 80 year old men, over half of whom die with prostate cancer, but from other causes. Seriously, move very very very very slowly on this. Take 6 months or a year before making a decision about treating this low grade prostate cancer. Listen to the following discussion/interview between two highly respected experts in the field http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 11 minutes long. I don't see how you can listen to that and still feel the need to take action right away. Apparently you are new to all of this, only having your results for a few days. I can assure you, at this point you know almost nothing about the subject. If you did, you be amazingly more hesitant to do anything quickly. Certainly in ZERO rush to come to any decisions. You could sit back, read up and study for the next year, and be in no more danger than you are now. If after a year, you decided to make a treatment choice, it would almost certainly be just as effective a year from now, or even two years from now, as it would be today. You also need to learn far more about the side effects. Far too many men underestimate the side effect from surgery. Only a minority of men return to full sexual function (like it was before), after having surgery of any type. You need to be very precise on the definition of what constitutes a usable erection. Many doctors will give out glowing numbers of the percentage of their patients who have full function. It can be very different than the patient's definition. That difference lead to much disappointment after surgery as expectations are not met. The same hold true for the definition of continence. What you consider continence may not be the same as the doctors definition. If you take a good deal of time, you will begin to understand the actual reality of what to expect after surgery or other treatments.

AgeInfo.Phrase: end up living to age 85 or 90 without ever treating
be just like the other 80 year old men  over half

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gunrun Can you send his info to me? I am at my urologists office now waiting for the consult thanks. I suppose the original doctor who did the biopsy was a urologist, right? Who is the "consult" with? Type of doctor, and the reason for the "consult". Advised by the other doctor or just your own choice? Look, you apparently only found out your status yesterday. You have not yet heard from the second reading of the biopsy samples. Given your data...you really need to slow down. You can always be "aggressive" with any treatment you may choose, but right now all of this is happening too fast for a person who is new to all of this. Should the new reading hold the same, this cancer has been in you for years, not weeks or even months. No need to come to any quick decisions. Certainly no need to book a surgical date. A decision you make in a month will be more well thought out than some urgent decision you come to in the first week. Again, this cancer is years old... not just something that popped up in the last couple months.
Posts.Title: Just got the bad news

Posts.Content: Well if you do discuss it with others, realize that at least half of them won't understand anything about it other than the word "cancer". They are as ill informed as most 50 year old men, prior to diagnosis, not knowing even what a prostate does. You might make up a list of 20 well known men who have been diagnosed over the past 10 years. Explain you have the same thing as those 20 men who are still alive and active in their lives and career. From politics, to military, to sports, to billionaires, the list is endless and famous. Puts the scary word "cancer" in context of specifically "prostate cancer". Explain that by age 80, about 3 of every 4 men have prostate cancer, often undiagnosed. Explain that 5 out of 6 men who get prostate cancer, don't die of it. The news if full of men who have been diagnosed and treated. Colin Powell, Rudy Giuliani, Warren Buffett, Sec. of State John Kerry, California Governor Jerry Brown, Yankees coach Joe Torre, Lakers coach Phil Jackson. One could go on and on with dozens more. Lots more Hollywood types who just don't make it public. Notice so many of those men are still in very demanding jobs, active, alive and planning on staying that way for a very long time. My own father, 25 years after diagnosis, died of old age at 88. Two of those above examples, in the news, John Kerry, no one even thinks about prostate cancer when he is seen. Same with Governor Jerry Brown. Only health issue in the news about Kerry is his wife and her own problem.

AgeInfo.Phrase: as ill informed as most 50 year old men  prior to
<Z> Explain that by age 80  about 3 of every 4
died of old age at 88  Two of those above examples

Posts.Title: Another nodule with low PSA

Posts.Content: Well, its too late for my advice, but unless there are other facts, this is absolute madness. (Though it may prove to produce a positive finding by mere chance) ----------------------------------------------------- December 18, 2013 | Turned 40 yrs. old July 9, 2014 | Had my yearly physical July 11, 2014 | PSA was 5.5 referred to a urologist July 29, 2014 | Urologist performed a DRE and found nothing August 19, 2014 | Biopsy recommended {not diagnosed with anything} ------------------------------------------------- How about simply waiting 3 more months and retesting the PSA... Again, perhaps there is something here that is not mentioned, but reacting to every raised PSA result with a biopsy is madness. Easily, very very easily, the PSA could be over 5 due to simple infection, even a asymptomatic infection or other inflammation that isn't even caused by bacteria. Biopsies are not NOTHING.. they are a real invasive operation to the prostate, with their own set of dangers as well as lingering effects. To simply get a high psa with no other symptoms or abnormalities, and quickly do a biopsy is inappropriate. But, too late now. Of course something could show up. That is always possible, but it is unlikely to be something that could not have waited 3 more months to be discovered... AFTER a second confirmation PSA was found to still be raised up to unusual levels. I would like to hear some alternative views to my stance.

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hopefull4TheFuture Hi, my boyfriend was just recently diagnosed. He's going for his first surgery consultation on friday. I'm getting the impression that your boyfriend isn't the kind of guy who had done a lot of investigation into all of this. Part of that investigation is knowing completely about the doctor who is going to be doing the surgery. Your boyfriend needs to know a great deal about the doctors past experience with robotic surgery. How many times has he done this surgery with a robot. 20 times.... 200 times.... 2000 times? At a minimum he needs to know those details. Sounds like he has made his mind up very very quickly. Not a wise thing to do. Hopefully he had gotten second opinions. Both about the type of treatment and if he actually needs treatment. Lastly, he (and you) may be in for a big surprise after surgery. Side effect are frequent and can last a very long time. Very often much more severe than many doctors will tell the unquestioning patient. Your boyfriend should know the statistics before undergoing surgery. There is a lot more to this surgery than simply curing the cancer. Usually there is no reason to rush into surgery. He has had this "cancer" for many years. It didn't just pop up suddenly. If he goes ahead without being knowledgeable about all aspects of this, he does so at risk of being disappointed or regretful. Perhaps he has done all his homework, but it doesn't sound like it.
Posts.Title: hi, question from the g/f of a newly diagnosed prostate cancer man

Posts.Content: Just in case you missed the link to this recent journal article http://journals.lww.com/co-urology/F...rative.15.aspx I would say that most here are more conservative regarding doing AS. Much more inclination to do treatment, just to be safer. Some of that may be tilted by a reinforcement of a choice they've already made. I would say this, a high percentage of those who do AS and then eventually do a treatment, come out just as positively as though they had done initial treatment. If I was in your shoes, I'd probably postpone treatment a bit, just because I tend to do that with lots of things. From your first post "Went to world-class cancer center in Boston for second opinion. " "They recommended active surveillance, PSAs retested every 4-6 months, biopsy every year unless PSAs rising. First PSA test (that started this whole matter in first place) was 5.1 Boston center retested and was at 5.3, 3 months later." Your choice... seems like you'd be OK doing either path for a few months while you get comfortable with a final decision.
Posts.Title: "inactive Surveillance"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by azsunshine The pellets are tiny compressed pellets that are inserted under the skin of the rear. His PSA was 197 before he started and it was raised to about 1000 after insert. He got them about every 4-5 months. Uh, I think you mean testosterone was 197 and then 1000.
Posts.Title: Testosterone After PC Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe If you had a doctor that you knew and trusted with your life who only does open surgery ( several thousand), would you go with him for your surgery or find one that has done many Robotic procedures. Besides the down time is there any great advantage to the robotic. Dec 6, 2011 PSA 2.3 Dec, 11, 2012 PSA 5.9 Jan 2012. saw the uroligist who did a DRE and found nothing except enlarged prostate, set up time for biopsy Jan. 22, 2013 had biopsy, results 11 cores negative and one core a few atypical cells April 25, 2013 PSA 3.1 Oct. 29, 2013 3.3 Dec 11, 2013 had a physical from different doctor and PSA was 3.9 Jan 29, 2014 full body CT scan, found Prostatic Hypertrophy April 2, 2014 PSA 4.8, Free PSA 23% Why are you even thinking about surgery? Thus far you have benign enlargement of the prostate. What are we missing? What is your age?
Posts.Title: Open or Robotic, which to choose

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by njs I believe the best (but definitely not perfect) way to compare surgeons apples-to-apples is to look at their positive surgical margin (PSM) rates stratified by pathological stage. For the handful of best surgeons in the world this is 2% or less for true organ-confined (pT2) disease and around 25-30% for non-organ-confined (pT3+) disease. As far as I have know, Samadi has not published his PSM rates. The best PSM rates I have seen are from Tewari (Cornell, but soon to moving be Mt Sinai) and Ahlering (UC Irvine) who have both published studies showing specific refinements in technique that have significantly reduced their PSMs. Although I don't believe he has published them, Dr. Allaf who is chief of robotic surgery at Johns Hopkins, told me his pT2 PSM rates were also sub 2% when I consulted with him. From his website "The SMART Technique It should be emphasized that the SMART technique is an advanced technique that should not be performed early in a novice robotic surgeon’s learning curve. Since 2003, Dr Samadi has performed over 2,000 RALPs, approximately half by this technique. In the 12 months since the final modifications were made to this technique in early 2008, he has performed more than 2,224 RALPs. We are able to achieve continence rates of 97% and potency rates of 81% at 1 year (in 193 and 169 patients, respectively) while maintaining a 4% rate of positive surgical margins. " Now, one must be very careful when seeing data on both continence and especially potency rates. The definition of each is important. What constitutes a full erection widely varies. I seriously doubt he has 81% of his patients reporting that sex is just like before surgery. You need to ask for a very detailed and precise definition of these terms before accepting them as valid. Still he may be among the best surgeons around. Hard to tell.
Posts.Title: Question about Robotic Prostatectomy Techniques

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by washsci 4. Wait and see. He highly recommends #4 option of wait and see, . For sure, I'd agree, given the other medical issues. Take a listen to these two experts discuss the topic http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Not sure if you have to register to hear that discussion, but to me, it is worth it. Gives you a good appraisal of the choice of waiting and seeing. You risk very little by delaying. Treatment now, or possibly treatment later. Very little difference in outcome and the potential is significant that he may never need treatment.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddl123161 I am the owner of a small business here in this small town that I live in. I was wondering if anyone has any insight or experience with in repercussions from letting their staff/employees know about their cancer diagnosis. What I am trying to make sure doesn't happen is that people get nervous about the long term viability of their jobs and they decide to leave. All I know I can do is explain the situation as clearly as I can and reassure them that this is a manageable condition. Thoughts? Well its a small town. Seems like word will get around regardless. If you go the route of full disclosure, you have to overcome the word "cancer", which to the uninformed means ALL cancers. You'd be surprised at how uninformed the general public is about prostate cancer. Aside from telling them that only 1 in 6 prostate cancer patients ever dies from the condition, you would do well to supply current day examples of men who are in the news... after surgery for prostate cancer and living a completely normal life. A few you might include 1. Secretary of State, John Kerry, who has to be the most busy man on the planet. He had surgery 11.5 years ago. (heck, he ran for President ... shortly AFTER... he had surgery.... what could be more demanding than running for president?) 2. Rudy Giuliani, check the dates, but it was years ago, and he is traveling all over the country. 3. Arnold Palmer, had surgery 18 years ago. 4. Former Sec. of State, Colin Powell, 11 years ago in 2003. The man is very active and busy today and was shortly after surgery. There are hundreds of examples you could pick from... sports stars, politicians, seems you can't pick up the paper without seeing someone new. You need to give these ongoing examples to impress upon the staff, that this surgery will less disruptive than something like hip replacement surgery. That the chances you'll still be alive in 10 years is about 95%. There may be local town examples. Frankly I don't personally know of anyone who has actually died from the disease in my circle of acquaintances. This surgery will be far less disruptive than heart surgery. Anyway... I'd let them know via other examples.
Posts.Title: Telling employees at work

Posts.Content: Just in case you missed the link to this recent journal article http://journals.lww.com/co-urology/F...rative.15.aspx I would say that most here are more conservative regarding doing AS. Much more inclination to do treatment, just to be safer. Some of that may be tilted by a reinforcement of a choice they've already made. I would say this, a high percentage of those who do AS and then eventually do a treatment, come out just as positively as though they had done initial treatment. If I was in your shoes, I'd probably postpone treatment a bit, just because I tend to do that with lots of things. From your first post "Went to world-class cancer center in Boston for second opinion. " "They recommended active surveillance, PSAs retested every 4-6 months, biopsy every year unless PSAs rising. First PSA test (that started this whole matter in first place) was 5.1 Boston center retested and was at 5.3, 3 months later." Your choice... seems like you'd be OK doing either path for a few months while you get comfortable with a final decision.
Posts.Title: "inactive Surveillance"

Posts.Content: "psa 5.2 at biopsy 02/2012 psa 3.8 02/2013 psa 4.4 06/2013 MRI done 11/01/2013 showed cancer in both right and left lobes. Oncologist suggest MRI in 6 months for comparison psa 7.2 11/11/2013 Urologist suggest removing prostate" Why not wait 6 months, see the MRI and see the PSA. If both are higher, then you could proceed. I don't see the need to rush to remove the prostate. Who would be removing the prostate?
Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter RTS, Using the last three PSA reading, your PSA doubling time is ~10 months. IF I use the last two values, doubling is about 7.5 months. So it is accelerating meaning there is cause for concern especially since recent MRI indicated cancer in both sides of your prostate now. Then again, throwing out the last one, as possibly induced by inflammation, the prior 3 PSA tests would indicate a deceleration. "psa 5.2 at biopsy 02/2012 psa 3.8 02/2013 psa 4.4 06/2013 "especially since recent MRI indicated cancer in both sides of your prostate now." There is reason to believe that a MRI back at the time of the biopsy may well have shown the same thing since 6 cores on that side could easily miss the cancer seen on the current MRI. Just to play the other side of the picture, it may well be that nothing has changed since the biopsy. The data is too limited.
Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla My wife is awesome and very understanding, but having low energy and libido is taxing on her and me. So I am a bit stuck... I am currently thinking that this would be the best plan: 1. Stop smoking 2. Lose some weight and improve diet 3. Exercise more (I certainly have the time) 4. AS for six months and re-access Age 55, DOB 11/1957, 6'2", 240# 08/29/2013 Biopsy: 2/12 positive (RLM,RLA), <5%/core, Gleason 3+3 ! I wouldn't even consider being treated now if I had your numbers. I'd wait and keep tracking your PSA, which according to you was probably about 3.8 in earlier tests and now in the mid 4 range. If it keeps advancing then do another biopsy in a year. I don't think I'd bother fishing around with a additional biopsy. I mean, the sampling is such a small portion of one's prostate that to have any certainty you'd have to do about 100 cores. Simply getting another 10 or 12 is fractional confirmation at best. You could randomly grab 55 year old guys walking down the street and come up with a portion who have Gleason 6 in one or two cores at 5% or greater. Take a look at this excellent measured discussion of the subject by two well known urologists. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Delay is not always bad, even if you later seek treatment. Now, in the mean time, regarding your potential danger from PCa as well as your libido and your overall health. (btw, you didn't include your cholesterol panel, blood pressure and the other stuff such as your blood sugar readings which can be very important in pre-diabetes, Impaired Glucose Tolerance or Impaired Fasting Glucose etc). In your current state, you are probably 10 times more likely to die of heart disease than from prostate cancer, even if you never treat your prostate cancer. Lucky for you the changes in lifestyle needed are similar for all your problems, prostate cancer, heart disease, and even libido improvement without the injections. When is the last time you were fit? Smoking, obesity (over 30 BMI), and lack of exercise all affect your libido. Seriously, smoking is the most dangerous thing in your current health profile. You do know how bad it is for heart disease, right? You do know that all those blood vessels in your heart are not dissimilar to the blood vessels that bring blood to your penis, right? Unless you have fantastic genes you probably have a fair degree of typical heart disease in process. Greatly compounded by your long time smoking. All the damage your diet, lack of exercise, and smoking do to your heart are being done everywhere else your blood flows. The more radical dietary changes many prostate cancer subjects make are identical to those which studies have shown are best for your heart. BTW, they also bring about considerable weight loss in most subjects. A Trifecta of benefits. Dr. Dean Ornish has done published studies on this diet and how it affects PSA progression in those with diagnosed prostate cancer. How it slows the advance of your psa. UCSF (University of California, San Francisco) has a good overall nutrition guideline (64 pages) here... http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf Good for your prostate cancer advancement, excellent for your probable heart disease, and a near guarantee on weight reduction. A fairly good chance that following such a diet, along with a real exercise program, will do wonders for your libido even if you never take any more TRT injections.. You are 55, this may be a blessing in disguise for your overall health regardless of whether you treat or don't treat your prostate cancer. I'll tell you this, if you and your wife are concerned as you indicate about your libido, then you may face problems soon anyway, with all your other factors. Age, obesity, smoking, lack of exercise, etc. That combo leads to a good percentage of men losing it by age 55 or 60. OK, more than you asked for, but from your original post, you seem to have already come to many of the same conclusions. Time for action now, regarding all those lifestyle changes that will absolutely be beneficial to your future health. Your wife will be supportive and no doubt she could use some of the same lifestyle changes. If you like, I could suggest a few books to look into.

Posts.Title: Interesting article/interview on the history of the PSA test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wifey It was the same urologist who did the biopsy. He's had an MRI and then an Atermis biopsy. I'm getting a copy of the MRI sent to me. Whilst we're not discounting HIFU or indeed any other treatment, the doc we saw who is apparently well known didn't exactly had a good bedside manner. I was probably a bit overboard in suggesting he might be a quack, but anytime I hear suggestions of going to Mexico you have to question the practice. If you send the core samples elsewhere you have to send the actual samples. I don't know what good the MRI will do. At the very least you need to deal with a doctor with whom you get along and can communicate.
Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shelson To answer you questions, I am 63 years old and I heard about the product from the manager of a health store. He has been using it for some time now with reported success. There is a lot of commercial garbage in health food stores. In fact half the stuff in health food stores is unproven garbage. The educational requirement to be a manager of a health food stores is to have finished 8th grade. A health food store is in the business of selling products, the more the better. Even well meaning health food stores carry about 50% unproven garbage products. Then beyond products that are worthless, there are products that can be harmful. In the past, certain versions of Prostasol were laced with DES. Do you know what DES is? Again, there is zero reliable information to suggest that Prostasol is of any value to a individual either before or after diagnosis of prostate cancer. Why in the world would you listen to the "manager" of a "health food" store? I tell you what. You know how to use a search engine. Google Prostasol and come back with any reliable information that suggests or proves it works. I"ll be amazed if you find any science based proof.

AgeInfo.Phrase: answer you questions  I am 63 years old and I heard

Posts.Title: Prostasol

Posts.Content: Well, its too late for my advice, but unless there are other facts, this is absolute madness. (Though it may prove to produce a positive finding by mere chance) ----------------------------------------------------- December 18, 2013 | Turned 40 yrs. old July 9, 2014 | Had my yearly physical July 11, 2014 | PSA was 5.5 referred to a urologist July 29, 2014 | Urologist performed a DRE and found nothing August 19, 2014 | Biopsy recommended {not diagnosed with anything} ------------------------------------------------- How about simply waiting 3 more months and retesting the PSA... Again, perhaps there is something here that is not mentioned, but reacting to every raised PSA result with a biopsy is madness. Easily, very very easily, the PSA could be over 5 due to simple infection, even a asymptomatic infection or other inflammation that isn't even caused by bacteria. Biopsies are not NOTHING.. they are a real invasive operation to the prostate, with their own set of dangers as well as lingering effects. To simply get a high psa with no other symptoms or abnormalities, and quickly do a biopsy is inappropriate. But, too late now. Of course something could show up. That is always possible, but it is unlikely to be something that could not have waited 3 more months to be discovered... AFTER a second confirmation PSA was found to still be raised up to unusual levels. I would like to hear some alternative views to my stance.
