Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter One issue with AS is while on it, most likely your doctor won't prescribe TRT and your "energy level" will continue to remain low during this time. With treatment, after your PSA becomes undetectable, your doctor might restart TRT to improve your "energy level". . I just wanted to interject something about this issue of being able to get back onto TRT after one chooses to get treatment for prostate cancer. Your statement follows from Mikla's statement in his original post as follows "The minor complication is that I have low testosterone and have been getting 100mg testosterone/wk IM and it had significantly improved my energy level, mood and libido. Since I am no longer taking it, the symptoms have returned. Doc said it is possible that given successful radiation I could look at going back on testosterone six months after completing radiation" I think there is a real danger here in the possibility that one may think their libido or sexual function may actually be improved after treatment for prostate cancer, with the addition of TRT, compared to someone who goes on AS during which time he may be precluded from taking TRT for improved libido. If you take 100 men who go on AS during which they give up TRT and compare them to 100 men who take some form of treatment for prostate cancer, I am betting that those who go on AS have a far greater chance of having a superior sexual experience relative to those who undergo treatment. After all, even if one goes on AS, and drops their TRT, they still have the ability to use all the enhancements available to those who undergo treatment, with the possible exception being the TRT. Nothing is more likely to affect one's sexual performance than the various forms of prostate cancer treatment. So, I'd just not want Mikla to think that undergoing treatment, then getting back on TRT, is the best idea for improving libido or improving sexual performance. Quite the opposite is more likely given all the data and stats. Of course individual cases are unique, but the overall numbers are clear in regard to this issue. Definitely not a reason to choose treatment over AS. I do realize that you only specifically mentioned "energy level", but Mikla mixed that in with libido and mood.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mitchden Based on my repeat biopsy, I have 1 or 2 cores that are Gleason 6 (3+3) less than 5% of the tissue. I hope to have Dr. Epstein's "second opinion" report by the end of the week. Assuming that Dr. Epstein confirms the Gleason (3+3), I will try active surveillance. The reason I say try is because, I need to override the psychological stress of knowing that I have low-grade cancer that is not going away. I will try meditation and thanks to "Tall Allen" Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction. Lets see what Dr. Epstein says. If he comes back with 1 or 2 cores at Gleason 6...less than 5%, then its time to put this on the back burner. At age 66, with your PSA, you would be fairly normal. Just that they happened to hit something. If, and its a big if, Epstein confirms that, then I'd place about 10% of my concern on my prostate cancer and about 90% on living a optimal lifestyle for my coronary artery disease. I know it doesn't have the big "cancer" attached to it, but it is the chief issue, much as it is for most men diagnosed with Gleason 6 prostate cancers. Best of all, its also something that every man can take positive action on. Right now, things seem to be going your way. Keep us informed. We always like to hear Epstein's second opinions on slides. He's kind of like God on these issues... all knowing

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance Protocol

Posts.Content: Your boss may be as unfamiliar with prostate cancer as the average public. I would tailor the message to not make it sound like it is CANCER!!!.... For some all cancers fit into one box and precede death. Consider ways to introduce it via the many other well known men who have it and have fully resumed their activities in high profile busy jobs.. There are dozens and dozens of good examples. Who is busier than Sec. of State John Kerry? I'll tell you who, John Kerry when he was running for president in 2004. Right in the middle of running for president, he has prostate cancer surgery. Then after a period of time he is back on a grueling campaign schedule that would kill most men. General and Sec. of State, Colin Powel., Robert De Niro at age 59 had surgery. Arnold Palmer, Warren Buffett, the list goes on and on. There are hundreds of well known men you can use as example to make it clear it is not much more disabling than many other operations or accidents. My point being that for much of the uneducated public you need to introduce the "cancer" as not typically being something like they think of most cancers. I don't know your job, but I can't imagine if you were in a car crash that they would fire you for taking some time off. I think the bigger issue is for them to not think of you dying down the road, or being unable to do your job in the future.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Robert De Niro at age 59 had surgery <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: What was your strategy about telling your employer, and how did it work out for you?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wifey It was the same urologist who did the biopsy. He's had an MRI and then an Atermis biopsy. I'm getting a copy of the MRI sent to me. Whilst we're not discounting HIFU or indeed any other treatment, the doc we saw who is apparently well known didn't exactly had a good bedside manner. I was probably a bit overboard in suggesting he might be a quack, but anytime I hear suggestions of going to Mexico you have to question the practice. If you send the core samples elsewhere you have to send the actual samples. I don't know what good the MRI will do. At the very least you need to deal with a doctor with whom you get along and can communicate.
Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: If that same urologist did the biopsy and is the one giving you the results, I'd question the entire process and analysis. Take your slides, if the doctor will even give them to you, and have them read by another quality person, such as at John Hopkins. Others on this board do that on a regular basis, even when they are seeing good doctors who aren't like the crazy doctor you seem to have found. I don't know the whole process to send them to John Hopkins, but it isn't that complicated. I wouldn't trust anything your current doctor says. Someone here may post and tell you how to send those slides for that second opinion of what type of cancer you actually have. The guy you are seeing sounds like he may be a quack out for fast buck.

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Flkjr Howdy. You seem to have a history of yo-yoing PSA. Your 7.3 in 2006 was followed by a 5.0 in the same year and a 4.5 the following. Why not wait 6 months (or even 3) and see if it indeed comes down again. If not then get that biopsy. Good luck and stay positive. I'd second this opinion. Even if it does drop back to around 5.0, then depending on how "enormous" your prostate is, you may or may not go ahead with a biopsy. At least you will have confirmed the PSA at 5.0 or perhaps 8.0, which might make a difference in how you approach treatment if you decide to do anything. Of course, the fact that you had a negative biopsy back in 2006 doesn't mean there wasn't some cancer back then. So if you are comfortable, give it 6 months or 3 months, just in case some "itis" or inflammation is driving the PSA up to 8.0. My psa jumps around more than yours. Have had 7.5 and 5.4 followed by going back under 4.0 and now down under 3.5 I no longer jump to biopsies after a jump up... but if I had the 7.3, followed by your 8.0... and that 8.0 was confirmed, then I'd do another biopsy just to see what is going on. BTW, at age 67, getting up once a night seems more normal than abnormal.

Posts.Title: Time for another biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla My wife is awesome and very understanding, but having low energy and libido is taxing on her and me. So I am a bit stuck... I am currently thinking that this would be the best plan: 1. Stop smoking 2. Lose some weight and improve diet 3. Exercise more (I certainly have the time) 4. AS for six months and re-access Age 55, DOB 11/1957, 6'2", 240# 08/29/2013 Biopsy: 2/12 positive (RLM,RLA), <5%/core, Gleason 3+3 ! I wouldn't even consider being treated now if I had your numbers. I'd wait and keep tracking your PSA, which according to you was probably about 3.8 in earlier tests and now in the mid 4 range. If it keeps advancing then do another biopsy in a year. I don't think I'd bother fishing around with a additional biopsy. I mean, the sampling is such a small portion of one's prostate that to have any certainty you'd have to do about 100 cores. Simply getting another 10 or 12 is fractional confirmation at best. You could randomly grab 55 year old guys walking down the street and come up with a portion who have Gleason 6 in one or two cores at 5% or greater. Take a look at this excellent measured discussion of the subject by two well known urologists. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 Delay is not always bad, even if you later seek treatment. Now, in the mean time, regarding your potential danger from PCa as well as your libido and your overall health. (btw, you didn't include your cholesterol panel, blood pressure and the other stuff such as your blood sugar readings which can be very important in pre-diabetes, Impaired Glucose Tolerance or Impaired Fasting Glucose etc). In your current state, you are probably 10 times more likely to die of heart disease than from prostate cancer, even if you never treat your prostate cancer. Lucky for you the changes in lifestyle needed are similar for all your problems, prostate cancer, heart disease, and even libido improvement without the injections. When is the last time you were fit? Smoking, obesity (over 30 BMI), and lack of exercise all affect your libido. Seriously, smoking is the most dangerous thing in your current health profile. You do know how bad it is for heart disease, right? You do know that all those blood vessels in your heart are not dissimilar to the blood vessels that bring blood to your penis, right? Unless you have fantastic genes you probably have a fair degree of typical heart disease in process. Greatly compounded by your long time smoking. All the damage your diet, lack of exercise, and smoking do to your heart are being done everywhere else your blood flows. The more radical dietary changes many prostate cancer subjects make are identical to those which studies have shown are best for your heart. BTW, they also bring about considerable weight loss in most subjects. A Trifecta of benefits. Dr. Dean Ornish has done published studies on this diet and how it affects PSA progression in those with diagnosed prostate cancer. How it slows the advance of your psa. UCSF (University of California, San Francisco) has a good overall nutrition guideline (64 pages) here... http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf Good for your prostate cancer advancement, excellent for your probable heart disease, and a near guarantee on weight reduction. A fairly good chance that following such a diet, along with a real exercise program, will do wonders for your libido even if you never take any more TRT injections.. You are 55, this may be a blessing in disguise for your overall health regardless of whether you treat or don't treat your prostate cancer. I'll tell you this, if you and your wife are concerned as you indicate about your libido, then you may face problems soon anyway, with all your other factors. Age, obesity, smoking, lack of exercise, etc. That combo leads to a good percentage of men losing it by age 55 or 60. OK, more than you asked for, but from your original post, you seem to have already come to many of the same conclusions. Time for action now, regarding all those lifestyle changes that will absolutely be beneficial to your future health. Your wife will be supportive and no doubt she could use some of the same lifestyle changes. If you like, I could suggest a few books to look into.

Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Some new interesting journal articles/studies on the variable criteria used for deciding who should and shouldn't use AS (active surveillance) as their initial choice. http://www.medpagetoday.com/Hematolo...eun=g879549d0r Some major PCa doctors mentioned in the article. Ian M. Thompson III, MD, of the University of Texas Health Science Center Jonathan I. Epstein, MD, of Johns Hopkins Hospital Peter Carroll, MD, MPH, of the University of California San Francisco. Primary Source Journal of Urology Source Reference: Overholser S, et al "Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for a proportion of men diagnosed with prostate cancer by prostate specific antigen testing" J Urol 2015;194:680-684. Secondary Source Journal of Urology Source Reference: Matoso A, et al "Radical prostatectomy findings in men on active surveillance: variable findings dependent on reason for surgery and entry criteria" J Urol 2015; 194: 685-689. Additional Source Journal of Urology Source Reference: Dall'Era M, Carroll P "What is the optimal way to select candidates for active surveillance of prostate cancer?" J Urol 2015; 194: 615-616.
Posts.Title: Updated new articles regarding the use of AS as a option

Posts.Content: Yes, read that particular section of the book I linked you to. Also, you said you and your wife were trying to have kids. This from Medscape on asymptomatic prostatitis "Asymptomatic inflammatory prostatitis is characterized by the incidental discovery of prostatic inflammation without genitourinary complaints.[3] This condition is diagnosed during a workup for infertility or elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level. This disease entity can produce elevated white blood cells in the ejaculate (leukocytospermia) and can cause male infertility but is usually otherwise left untreated. See the following for more information: " Also, look at this study http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20414405 RESULTS: The median age of the 75 men was 33 years (range, 26-40 years) and the mean PSA level was 6.57 ng/ml (range, 4.32-13.45 ng/ml). The results of the primary biopsy was 1 (1.3%) case of prostate cancer, 70 cases (93%) with benign tissue, 2 cases (2.6%) with inflammation, and 1 case each (1.3%) with high grade intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN) and atypical small acinar proliferation (ASAP).

Posts.Title: Scared and Confused 32 Year Old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by NYC GMAN Over almost two years, I had two, 50 core biopsies that showed small Gleason 6 cancer in just three cores. Post-op it turned out to be Gleason 7 (3+4). I’ll never know what a 12 core biopsy would have revealed, but I am glad I did the saturation biopsies and fortunate to have done the surgery when I did. My cancer was present in the nerves of the prostate. It is thought that traveling along the nerves is one of the ways it can spread. If your first ever biopsy was the indicated 49 core one, that is most unusual and I doubt 1 urologist in 50 would do that. Unless there were other indications that set you apart. Or that your 6.96 PSA was a very large jump from your prior history which you may not have included. BTW, whether or not the original poster has a infection is most often not the reason a PSA can be spiked by inflammation. The majority of PSA spikes caused by inflammation are not due to a bacterial infection. Prostititis has many causes, most of which are not infections. The original poster shouldn't leap at a saturation biopsy. Certainly not without first waiting to see if the PSA falls back down. I'm guessing your PSA going up and staying at 10+ was the driving force to finally do surgery. I don't think anyone would second guess that. However our original poster is far away from that. Look at what he says "Biopsy (9.10.2013)-12 core -negative , left lobe acute and chronic inflammation" Goodness, acute and chronic inflammation. That alone would could easily drive a PSA up to 5+, EASILY. He should calm down, follow up the psa in 6 months and put saturation biopsies out of his mind. As we all know, we don't want to discover every darn Gleason 6 that is residing in men's prostates. Other wise 3 out of 4 men would never reach age 85 without having their prostate removed or radiated. Hopefully a new test is around the corner that will separate indolent PCa from dangerous PCa.

Posts.Title: Negative Biopsy results this is what my Urologist Recommended

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Guys what do you think I should do about that other doctor that my father went to about 4.5 psa. He didn't recommend any test. Should I seek legal advice ? I am angry that he didn't tell him to repeat psa sooner nor he did any other test to figure out why psa is above normal. . You need to slow down. Prostate cancer is very slow in almost all cases. You are way off base in your assessment of the original doctor. You have not included your father's entire PSA history, but for the doctor to not act on a initial 4.5 psa test is rather normal. In fact under some criteria 4.5 is still considered normal at age 64. http://www.medicinenet.com/prostate_...igen/page3.htm Not doing a biopsy after ONE 4.5 reading is good medicine. Doing a biopsy at the drop of the hat, the first time someone gets a 4.5 would be unwise. There is ZERO reason to contact legal help. His doctor acted well within the standard of care. In fact he probably did a good job by NOT rushing to a biopsy based on one 4.5 psa test. As others have indicated, we have no idea what his real data is. the "7" could be 7 positive cores, or it could be 3+4= 7 Either way there is no rush for immediate appointments or decisions. Calm down, this is all going to take a very long time. There is every reason to believe your father has overwhelming odds to live well into his 80's, and die of something unrelated to prostate cancer. My father, diagnosed "late" at age 63, lived until age 88, dying of other causes.

Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH The random element here is HOW much time it took to double. If X represents several years, it may not be any cause for alarm. But if it is over just a year, that would probably warrant a visit to a urologist. I disagree. I think it would warrant a second PSA test, after a minimum of 3 months wait. At 2.6 psa there is little risk in simply waiting 3 to 6 months to retest. I mean, what is the urologist supposed to do? I am assuming the individual already had a DRE. If so, then the urologist can do the following 1. do another DRE 2. give the patient some antibiotics and take another PSA test in a few weeks...knowing that less than half of prostatitis cases are bacterial, thus subject to being helped by antibiotics. 3. go ahead with a biopsy at a PSA of 2.6, knowing that many people have short spikes in PSA, equal or greater than a 1.3 jump. 4. Or simply tell the patient to wait 6 months and re-test, knowing that in 98% of cases there is no danger in waiting for that next result. So, in most cases such as this, why even see the urologist after just one minor jump in PSA? Perhaps the only sound reason is to alleviate fear and worry, but realizing that neither of those two items will be solved by seeing the urologist, unless perhaps he goes ahead with a premature and unwarranted biopsy without waiting for a second PSA test after a reasonable amount of time.

Posts.Content: Interesting study released and in the news https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm From the news release -------------------------------------------------------------- "The high cure rate is striking when compared to the reported five-year cure rates from other approaches like surgery or conventional radiation, which range between 80 to 90 percent, while the side effects of this treatment are comparable to other types of treatment," said Dr. Raquibul Hannan, Assistant Professor of Radiation Oncology and lead author for the study. Posts.Title: SBRT 5 year study released. Claimed "98% cure rate"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ron_G This is all starting to suck, and mostly mentally. And I can't help but feel at times that if I could do AS for a year or two, that another solution might appear. What did Dr. Carter advise? Was he full-on suggesting you needed treatment now? You have a mixed bag of age, moderate psa, and very minimal positive cores. Actually only 2 out of 26 cores from the two biopsies. LESS THAN 5% each. Not even a close call in my book. You can't get much lower than that. I'd wait, keep my prostate, and do AS for a good year or so, while keeping a eye on the psa. Very unlikely that doing a treatment down the road would be inferior to doing it now. In the mean time, you get the use of your prostate which is not insignificant. Listen to this video if you hadn't already seen it in a prior link... only 11 minutes long. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 BTW, your most important family history is your father. A uncle and grandfather can be completely different.

There is every reason to believe your father has overwhelming odds to live well into his 80's, and die of something unrelated to prostate cancer. My father, diagnosed "late" at age 63, lived until age 88, dying of other causes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Guys what do you think I should do about that other doctor that my father went to about 4.5 psa. He didn't recommend any test. Should I seek legal advice ? I am angry that he didn't tell him to repeat psa sooner nor he did any other test to figure out why psa is above normal. . You need to slow down. Prostate cancer is very slow in almost all cases. You are way off base in your assessment of the original doctor. You have not included your father's entire PSA history, but for the doctor to not act on a initial 4.5 psa test is rather normal. In fact under some criteria 4.5 is still considered normal at age 64. http://www.medicinenet.com/prostate_...igen/page3.htm Not doing a biopsy after ONE 4.5 reading is good medicine. Doing a biopsy at the drop of the hat, the first time someone gets a 4.5 would be unwise. There is ZERO reason to contact legal help. His doctor acted well within the standard of care. In fact he probably did a good job by NOT rushing to a biopsy based on one 4.5 psa test. As others have indicated, we have no idea what his real data is. the "7" could be 7 positive cores, or it could be 3+4= 7 Either way there is no rush for immediate appointments or decisions. Calm down, this is all going to take a very long time. There is every reason to believe your father has overwhelming odds to live well into his 80's, and die of something unrelated to prostate cancer. My father, diagnosed "late" at age 63, lived until age 88, dying of other causes.

Posts.Content: Article from John Hopkins results after surgery. Keep in mind that John Hopkins is perhaps the top center in the country with some of the most skilled surgeons. I would not expect equal results from every center and every surgeon performing surgery. http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/prostate_cancer53.php Also note the definition used by the famous Dr. Walsh. "significant long-term problems with urinary control" (defined as needing to change a pad more than once a day)." I'm not arguing for one treatment or another, only that the patients need to understand the definitions of the terms. A few years ago, a NYTimes article was about how the leading cause of dissatisfaction was due to inaccurate expectations that men had going into surgery. Expectations based largely on differing definitions.
Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo I'm not sure I understand the logic of the Saturation Biopsy.... For example, wouldn't 24 cores double the chance of finding something? No, there is way too much emphasis placed on saturation biopsies. Unless the doctor has a specific reason to use one. http://www.hindawi.com/journals/pc/2011/386207/ --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In 2006, Eichler and colleagues published a systematic review and meta-analysis of published studies with a total of 20,698 patients. Data was pooled from 68 studies comparing a total of 94 extended schemes with the sextant standard, demonstrating once more that laterally directed cores significantly increase the diagnostic yield. In particular, 12-core with additional laterally directed cores detected 31% more cancers than the sextant scheme, with a comparable complication rate. Interestingly, no further benefit was seen in extended schemes with 18 to 24 cores, whereas the adverse event profile was poor with these templates. The authors concluded that more than 12 cores added no significant benefit [29]. In agreement with Eichler’s meta-analysis, two recently published studies critically reviewing the optimal biopsy strategies have further supported the use of extended 10- to 14-core biopsy schemes as the new “gold standard” for first-time prostate biopsy [30, 31]. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I'd leave it up to the urologist to suggest it, rather than thinking it would certainly improve the chances of discovering cancer.
Posts.Title: Negative Biopsy results this is what my Urologist Recommended

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate So, the two therapies sort of equal out. Many of the posters on this forum are glad that they did surgery, as the removed prostate can be fully assessed and that gives them peace of mind. . Regarding incontinence, a important issue to Jigger, I don't think the two therapies "equal out"... I'd say there is a much greater incontinence risk for many months with surgery and that there is also a much greater long term risk with surgery for incontinence. For about 1 out of 6-7 or so it remains to some degree very long term. Of course we don't yet know his actual numbers. (number of positive cores, percentage of each involved, 4+3 or 3+4...how many at 3+3 etc. During his appointments he should also ask about brachytherapy as that Allentown center indicates they also do that. It does not say if they do both low-dose brachy and high-dose brachy. Often with brachy they also include some external beam radiation for extra assurance. Trigger needs to ask those who do the radiation or brachy, how many of these procedures they have done and how many times each week they do them. Take notes on yellow pad... many many notes.. Exactly who is doing the treatment and how many times. If they say we have such and such results regarding incontinence, ask for definitions of what they mean. Some definitions consider 1 pad a day to be a acceptable definition of not having continence. I don't consider that a success and I'm guessing Trigger doesn't either. Don't rule out going farther than Allentown (depending on your insurance coverage). Here is a little discussion of the types of brachytherapy from a center at Temple University's Fox ... not that far down the road from Allentown http://www.fccc.edu/cancer/types/pro.../implants.html Lots of choices depending on those issues each man considers most important. The skill and experience of the doctors is critical. I'd surely drive a hour or two for someone I thought was best.

Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ron_G This is all starting to suck, and mostly mentally. And I can't help but feel at times that if I could do AS for a year or two, that another solution might appear. What did Dr. Carter advise? Was he full-on suggesting you needed treatment now? You have a mixed bag of age, moderate psa, and very minimal positive cores. Actually only 2 out of 26 cores from the two biopsies. LESS THAN 5% each. Not even a close call in my book. You can't get much lower than that. I'd wait, keep my prostate, and do AS for a good year or so, while keeping a eye on the psa. Very unlikely that doing a treatment down the road would be inferior to doing it now. In the mean time, you get the use of your prostate which is not insignificant. Listen to this video if you hadn't already seen it in a prior link... only 11 minutes long. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 BTW, your most important family history is your father. A uncle and grandfather can be completely different.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by regress I'm putting together questions for my local Uro. [*]% of your patients who have regained continence? [*]% of your patients who have overcome ED? If you ask these two questions you must have him/her be clear on their definition of "continence" and "ED". I can assure you those definitions vary widely. Some will say "usable erection" but that may miles away from what you now consider normal. Some say only one pad a day is continence. You may think otherwise. So get some fairly precise clarification on those terms in your questions.

Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe Dec 6, 2011 PSA 2.3 Dec, 11, 2012 PSA 5.9 Jan 2013. saw the uroligist who did a DRE and found nothing except enlarged prostate, set up time for biopsy Jan. 22, 2013 had biopsy, results 11 cores negative and one core a few atypical cells. Only one lab saw the slides. April 25, 2013 PSA 3.1 Oct. 29, 2013 3.3 Dec 11, 2013 had a physical from different doctor and PSA was 3.9 . You should never have had your first biopsy. Had they waited a bit, your PSA would have gone down, as evidenced by your subsequent results of 3.1 and 3.3... Which BTW fit nicely with a enlarged prostate. No matter what your April 2nd PSA score reveals, you should not jump. Look at that prior 5.9 that fell to a 3.1 a few months later. At age 69 you are way too cranked up about your fear of prostate cancer. Your odds of dying of prostate cancer are very low. OH and aches and pains at age 69..... join the crowd. The unusual 69 year old would be the guy without such. I hope you pay as much attention to your cholesterol and blood pressure as you pay to your PSA scores. That is where most men's real risk is.

Posts.Title: very nervous

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate But, at age 51, getting it out and over with probably makes the most sense. Being twenty years older than you, I am comfortable with AS, or doing Focal Laser Ablation or cryotherapy if things got worse. But, for you, a lot can happen in twenty years, and you probably want the assurance that the cancer has been dealt with in as final a manner as possible We've got 2 cores out of the last 26... "less than 5% each"... What is your cutoff for taking a chance, one core at 2% ? Seems you are saying that no one, age 51, should ever do AS for any period of time, regardless of how little Gleason 6 is found. Yet we know that most of those men will not go onto have life threatening prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Trump's Reported PSA by his Dr.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ryguy3000 Thanks everyone. I appreciate it. His PSA reading as recent as September was only just over 4. (Now it's around 11.) . The fact that it went from 4 to 11 in only 4 months makes it MUCH more probable that the hiked PSA is NOT caused by prostate cancer. It would be rare that a PSA would take off like that if the cause was cancer. Far more likely to be some sort of inflammation that can have many causes. The lower back and leg pain could be related or just coincidence. If I were betting, I'd put my money on it not being cancer. Given the facts at hand, that would be a easy call. However, still needs to see the urologist to get to the actual cause. One note of caution. If they do decide to give him a biopsy, it would be as likely as not that you'd find prostate cancer of some sort. Just as you might in any man age 85. Most men who die in their 80's, die with prostate cancer, but most of it is undiagnosed and never caused them any harm.

Posts.Title: Grandfather potentially has prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by NYC GMAN Over almost two years, I had two, 50 core biopsies that showed small Gleason 6 cancer in just three cores. Post-op it turned out to be Gleason 7 (3+4). I’ll never know what a 12 core biopsy would have revealed, but I am glad I did the saturation biopsies and fortunate to have done the surgery when I did. My cancer was present in the nerves of the prostate. It is thought that traveling along the nerves is one of the ways it can spread. If your first ever biopsy was the indicated 49 core one, that is most unusual and I doubt 1 urologist in 50 would do that. Unless there were other indications that set you apart. Or that your 6.96 PSA was a very large jump from your prior history which you may not have included. BTW, whether or not the original poster has a infection is most often not the reason a PSA can be spiked by inflammation. The majority of PSA spikes caused by inflammation are not due to a bacterial infection. Prostititis has many causes, most of which are not infections. The original poster shouldn't leap at a saturation biopsy. Certainly not without first waiting to see if the PSA falls back down. I'm guessing your PSA going up and staying at 10+ was the driving force to finally do surgery. I don't think anyone would second guess that. However our original poster is far away from that. Look at what he says "Biopsy (9.10.2013)-12 core -negative , left lobe acute and chronic inflammation" Goodness, acute and chronic inflammation. That alone would could easily drive a PSA up to 5+, EASILY. He should calm down, follow up the psa in 6 months and put saturation biopsies out of his mind. As we all know, we don't want to discover every darn Gleason 6 that is residing in men's prostates. Other wise 3 out of 4 men would never reach age 85 without having their prostate removed or radiated. Hopefully a new test is around the corner that will separate indolent PCa from dangerous PCa.

AgeInfo.Phrase: ever biopsy was the indicated 49 core one  that is most
men would never reach age 85 without having their prostate removed

Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate But, at age 51, getting it out and over with probably makes the most sense. Being twenty years older than you, I am comfortable with AS, or doing Focal Laser Ablation or cryotherapy if things got worse. But, for you, a lot can happen in twenty years, and you probably want the assurance that the cancer has been dealt with in as final a manner as possible We've got 2 cores out of the last 26... "less than 5% each"... What is your cutoff for taking a chance, one core at 2% ? Seems you are saying that no one, age 51, should ever do AS for any period of time, regardless of how little Gleason 6 is found. Yet we know that most of those men will not go onto have life threatening prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ron_G This is all starting to suck, and mostly mentally. And I can't help but feel at times that if I could do AS for a year or two, that another solution might appear. What did Dr. Carter advise? Was he full-on suggesting you needed treatment now? You have a mixed bag of age, moderate psa, and very minimal positive cores. Actually only 2 out of 26 cores from the two biopsies. LESS THAN 5% each. Not even a close call in my book. You can't get much lower than that. I'd wait, keep my prostate, and do AS for a good year or so, while keeping a eye on the psa. Very unlikely that doing a treatment down the road would be inferior to doing it now. In the mean time, you get the use of your prostate which is not insignificant. Listen to this video if you hadn't already seen it in a prior link... only 11 minutes long. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/804988 BTW, your most important family history is your father. A uncle and grandfather can be completely different.
Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by kennyk My twin brother psa doubled 2.6. Would you go to urologist No.... though we don't know your age or complete past history, a jump over X amount of time, from 1.3 to 2.6, would not be cause for alarm. More appropriately a reason to retest your psa in 6 months. PSA tests can and do jump up that much without cause or concern. They can just as easily drop right back down. BTW, are YOU worried about yourself, or about your brother? Are you fraternal or identical twins? Did your brother also have a DRE done recently? (thats the finger exam)
Posts.Title: Psa doubled 2.6. Twin bro has pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH The random element here is HOW much time it took to double. If X represents several years, it may not be any cause for alarm. But if it is over just a year, that would probably warrant a visit to a urologist. I disagree. I think it would warrant a second PSA test, after a minimum of 3 months wait. At 2.6 psa there is little risk in simply waiting 3 to 6 months to retest. I mean, what is the urologist supposed to do? I am assuming the individual already had a DRE. If so, then the urologist can do the following 1. do another DRE 2. give the patient some antibiotics and take another PSA test in a few weeks...knowing that less than half of prostatitis cases are bacterial, thus subject to being helped by antibiotics. 3. go ahead with a biopsy at a PSA of 2.6, knowing that many people have short spikes in PSA, equal or greater than a 1.3 jump. 4. Or simply tell the patient to wait 6 months and re-test, knowing that in 98% of cases there is no danger in waiting for that next result. So, in most cases such as this, why even see the urologist after just one minor jump in PSA? Perhaps the only sound reason is to alleviate fear and worry, but realizing that neither of those two items will be solved by seeing the urologist, unless perhaps he goes ahead with a premature and unwarranted biopsy without waiting for a second PSA test after a reasonable amount of time.

Posts.Title: 41 years old PSA of 0.9 and Urologist said wants to have another PSA done in 4 months

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe So my PSA was 4.36 and 34.4% free. The main doctor said I do not need to see him for another year. For me that means never. These PSA test for me generate more harm in anxiety then good. You're about 71... Your PSA is a steady "bit high"... with slightly higher than normal gyrations (like mine). Free PSA is great. The biggest problem you seem to be having is TOO MANY PSA tests. Waiting a year seems just fine. It would seem you risk very little should you ever get diagnosed as having PCa six months later than otherwise. As you have posted in the past, responding to one of my posts, if you keep letting them look via a biopsy, they'll eventually find something you don't want them to find. Instantly you become a person with "cancer" and are on a much more frequent protocol even if you choose AS. Right now, in your 70's chances are very high that if you never took another psa test ever, that prostate cancer would not shorten your life. However, like me, you'll probably keep doing it yearly. My last two times were 2.8 and 3.4, but in the many preceding years I was as high as 5.5 and 7.5 and one freepsa just under 20%... BTW, are you, or have you ever been on a statin..such as Liptor (atorvastatin)... That can affect your psa somewhat. If you are a normal 70+ year old man, your risk from heart disease is many times higher than any risk from PCa. I am also comforted by the fact that my father was diagnosed at age 63, "too late" for surgery, but lived 25 more years, dying of something else. There is such a range for this disease.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jronne 56 years old, recently diagnosed last week with prostate cancer. Looking for any feedback regarding robotic radical prostatectomy at the Kaiser Santa Clara location. Anyone with recent prostate cancer experience with other Kaiser locations, Stanford or UCSF would be appreciated also. First of all, you don't need to rush. Seems the program at Kaiser, Santa Clara is run by someone with a fair amount of experience https://mydoctor.kaiserpermanente.or...=About+Me&to=1 However being in Kaiser, Northern California, you have the right to go to any Kaiser doctor you choose, from San Jose, to San Francisco, to Walnut Creek, to Sacramento. Take some considerable time finding out who is best before you make a choice. You could also do brachytherapy, which I believe is all done in Roseville for Northern California. Kaiser Nor Cal began doing robotic surgery about in 2005 or 2006. Must be a few doctors who have hundreds of such surgeries under their belt. You must ask not only how many they have done, but also how many they do each week vs someone only doing 1 or 2 each month.

Posts.Content: Jona, I wonder... "I have plugged my numbers into the Partin tables and also the calculators at Sloan-Kettering and UroPredict Bostwick Laboratories Staging System. Sloan-Kettering numbers show a better 5 to 10 year history for surgery versus IMRT, but about the same for brachytherapy." Did any of those calculators have a input allowing for " involving from 10% to 90% of 8 of 9 cores", or did they just ask for the PSA and gleason score, etc,? They ask for "unifocal" yes or no, but I'm guessing that even 2 cores of 12, at 10% and 20% each, would qualify as NOT being "unifocal"... Whereas, and I don't know, it would seem there may be a significant difference between 8 of 9 ranging from 10% to 90% vs 2 of 12 going from 10% to 20%.. in terms of the potential for extraprostatic extension. Yet both would be entered into the calculator as the same value. PS... ( I see the Sloan-Kettering" asks for number of positive cores, but I don't see them asking about the percentage of each core) (also... did you fill in the "Enter Advanced Details (for Medical Professionals)" section? I realize you may not have all those details but it seems to make quite a difference on the data, perhaps dropping the "organ confined" from 66% to about 50%.. Yet oddly leaving the "Progression Free Probability after Radical Prostatectomy" numbers up at about the same place??? As I said, I really don't know, but you ought to explore that dimension and speak to your doctors about the different probabilities. Otago

Posts.Title: Surgery vs. Radiation

Posts.Content: Gleason Grade 3+3=6 discontinuously involving from 10% to 90% of 8 of 9 cores, T2C Given his stature as the top surgeon for prostate cancer, I'm sure he wouldn't be recommending you consider radiation unless he had some real concerns about doing surgery on you. I'm guessing its not only because of the incontinence issue, but also with 8 of 9 positive cores, up to 90%, he may well be more concerned about the likelihood of the PCa not being confined to the prostate which would then require radiation anyway. (meaning positive margins) Go to the Brady Urological page and run the Partin tables. Discuss it with your radiation guy. http://urology.jhu.edu/prostate/cancer.php Ask Walsh or others about the data, your cores, and all the probabilities. If there is little to be gained from surgery and there is a fair chance of the PCa not being confined, then it might make sense to go with radiation first and avoid all the surgical complications. Take your time in making the decision. Otago

Posts.Title: Interesting article on infections after biopsy and prevention with normal antibiotics

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JimT Age 57 Routine Checkup. 3/6 PSA 4.95 Recheck 3/11 PSA 3.69 Referred to Urologist. Recommend Biopsy. Due to reading and family history. (father he was 94 at time, pasted 3/31 unrelated to his prostate cancer.) Instructions: 4/8 Ciprofloxacin take two, day prior, two day of and two day after. Enema night before and 2 hours morning before procedure. 4/9 Biopsy This consisted of shot in hip (antibiotic). Then laying on table while doctor inserted ultrasound in rectum. Two numbing shots were administrated, one left and one right. Then 18 samples were taken, 9 on left and 9 on right. 4/16 Test result were negative. Was told it possible that it could be there. Its possible your high PSA might just be a high PSA.. Jim, your example is classic for the abuse of the system... Taking a PSA blood draw, getting a slightly high number, 4.95, then the doctor foolishly ordering retesting only 5 days later.. Wait it gets worse. In just those 5 days it drops from 4.95 to 3.69, yet the doctor refers you to the urologist. The urologist, also being overly aggressive, goes ahead and schedules a EIGHTEEN core biopsy. You have been mishandled and mistreated. Any reasonable primary care doctor would have waited a minimum of 3 months to take a second PSA reading. Then any sensible urologist would have told you to calm down.. possibly take a course of antibiotics... more likely just wait 3 to 6 months... and ONLY then take a second PSA test... BEFORE going ahead with a biopsy. And why 18 cores? who knows. Stay away from these doctors. They are excessively fast on the draw. Next thing you know, they'll go out of their way to find a single 5% core of Gleason 3+3=6 and have you in the operating room removing your prostate.. Unless you have left something out of your story, you just went through a unnecessary procedure.... not to mention the needless concern. Now, I don't know your family history, but given that your dad died at 94, just like mine at 88, of other causes, that in no way excuses a ultra aggressive move to do such a fast biopsy based on such flimsy PSA results. You'd do well to keep track of your next PSA.. Very possibly it will end up being right back where your prior PSA tests were before this latest pair were taken. Watch out. Don't simply follow the doctors without questioning what they are requesting. Best line in your post "Was told it possible that it could be there." Sure, just like it could be there in most men your age... EXCEPT, we don't want to find it in everybody. The majority of men with prostate cancer, die with it, never having been diagnosed or having it affect their life. You may have prostate cancer right now. I may have it right now. Nevertheless, they jumped the gun on your biopsy. (you might give us the rest of your PSA history prior to these last two tests. If you didn't already know it, PSA results can jump around wildly, and can jump up and back down in only a few months. Such swings are very very very common. They are not reason to suddenly biopsy unless other factors are involved, such as a unusual DRE)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Jim! With a PSA that went down in 26% in 5 days I would suspect that one of the 2 assays was incorrect. Question: On 3/6 at your "routine check-up," did your MD do a DRE? If yes, did he do the DRE before having your blood drawn? If "No" & "No" did you engage in sexual activity within 48 hours prior to having your blood drawn? (No need to post your answer, these questions are attempting to identify a cause for your initial elevated PSA) I think your MD was justified in ordering a 2nd PSA five days later. His rationale was likely to either validate the 1st finding or negate it. ! It has to be said that there are PSA results that leap up and down even if 1. No prior DRE was performed in the hour(s) before the blood draw. 2. No sexual activity in the prior 24 hours. 3. No bacterial infection is present. There is something called asymptomatic non-bacterial prostatitis that, as the name implies, isn't felt, and isn't curable with a antibiotic, yet it can raise your PSA from 3.5 to 5.5 or 7.5, just like that. And if allowed time to settle down, can leave you back at 3.0 or 3.5 a few weeks or perhaps a few months later. Asymptomatic prostatitis is more common than bacterial prostatitis. In short, "seemingly nothing" can often make a PSA jump several points. I do not think there was any good reason to retest in only 5 days. And after testing, seeing a drop of 1.26 in only 5 days, should have been a clear indication to allow some more time for a 3rd test. Like another 3 months. No need to even refer the patient to a urologist and certainly no reason to do a 18 core biopsy. As I mentioned before, it would be nice to know Jim's prior PSA history.
Posts.Title: New Member Sharing Story

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I made an appt with surgeon at MSKCC, they told me no agenda, if surgery is not my best option, then he will tell me. But he can't see me until Mid Dec. EVERY DAY THAT GOES BY I AM AFRAID I AM AT MORE RISK OF ESCAPING THE CAPSULE. Trying to see a RO at MSKCC, wont even give me an appt until they get the reports (easy) scans (easy), slides (still at Hopkins) and a TE Parametric MRI which they say i ccant have until end December because it needs to be 7-8 weeks after biopsy. More time lost. And how is it that i get to see two rock star surgeons who have done over 5000 robotic surgeries each, within days, but i cant see anyone at MSKCC for over a month? How does that work? I'm so confused, scared and depressed. Logically i know, i have time. But still. Its understandable how confuse and depressed you are. You've been through quite a scary episode. However you have one of the foremost experts in the nation telling you to relax a bit "I actually got to speak to Dr Epstein, and he was very emphatic that it was a G6 and that I had months to decide on how to proceed. " You've got to trust someone... I'd trust him. As such, getting that December appointment at MSKCC seems quite reasonable and not at all risky to wait. The news about your downgrade is really amazing.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wjw What I'm suggesting is we shouldn't be offering false hope for high PSA results to readers of this blog without scientific evidence. Correct me if I'm wrong or off task here, or at least let this be a thread for discussion. I agree that we shouldn't be suggesting that a man who gets a 5.6 psa, might really only be a 3.4 psa, but for sex, or a 20 mile bike ride in the 24 hours leading up to the test. The DRE factor is a bit more probable to increase a psa, but still not in the magnitude that some imagine. I've read the possible differences before, but can't recall them now. First of all, the bike riding info is scant. Sex and especially DRE impact have some better background information. However I don't think sex + dre would normally raise a psa by a full point. However not all DRE's are created (done) equally ...ouch!. I throw biking in, not for the single recent rides, but more for a individual who may be a regular rider doing 100 miles a week...possibly setting up a over all greater inflammation. Even then its iffy, but I don't ride in the days leading up to a test. (I'm talking about men not yet diagnosed) However there is one category that can have huge impact on PSA scores. That is prostate inflammation, which in some cases may be called prostatitis. It can make large impact on PSA scores far in excess of the sex, dre, or bike riding. I always emphasize that potential impact as being the one to watch for. Having said that, you can very often have such a condition and not even be aware of it. Also, a simple round of antibiotics will have little to no impact on it much of the time. Only a minority of the time is it caused by a bacterial infection. Rapid retesting is often a failure because such inflammation can take considerable time to resolve. And the, men should be told that PSAs can simply jump around significantly. I've had two spikes of significant size. I can't remember the precise number without looking it up, but I had one a few years ago that after jumping up to 7.4, dropped back to about 3.8 when I retested in about 3 or 6 months later. In the interim I had taken no antibiotics.

Posts.Content: Well, ideally you would have been better served by having him tell you to wait a few days or a week for the PSA blood draw. If that was easy for you. Either way, your PSA would probably have been 4.0 or more. Do you know your PSA history? The doctor was not wrong to do some extensive "digging around" in the exam. That is exactly the right thing for him to do before making you get biopsy. Right now you may want to get another urologist, but then he will have to re-examine your prostate again and you'll still have to get another PSA.. This time do it prior to the exam, and if possible long enough ahead of time for the new urologist to have the results when you see him for the exam. Then, he'll probably tell you to get a biopsy. Still in the long run, better to deal with someone you feel comfortable with. Whether your PSA is 2.8 or 4.8, with the nodule, they'll tell you to get a biopsy. Or, you can just forget all this and take your chances. Odds are good you'll die from something else before prostate cancer, if you have any, gets to you. That is not a totally unreasonable approach, though some may object to such ideas.
Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wjw What I'm suggesting is we shouldn't be offering false hope for high PSA results to readers of this blog without scientific evidence. Correct me if I'm wrong or off task here, or at least let this be a thread for discussion. I agree that we shouldn't be suggesting that a man who gets a 5.6 psa, might really only be a 3.4 psa, but for sex, or a 20 mile bike ride in the 24 hours leading up to the test. The DRE factor is a bit more probable to increase a psa, but still not in the magnitude that some imagine. I've read the possible differences before, but can't recall them now. First of all, the bike riding info is scant. Sex and especially DRE impact have some better background information. However I don't think sex + dre would normally raise a psa by a full point. However not all DRE's are created (done) equally ...ouch!. I throw biking in, not for the single recent rides, but more for a individual who may be a regular rider doing 100 miles a week...possibly setting up a over all greater inflammation. Even then its iffy, but I don't ride in the days leading up to a test. (I'm talking about men not yet diagnosed) However there is one category that can have huge impact on PSA scores. That is prostate inflammation, which in some cases may be called prostatitis. It can make large impact on PSA scores far in excess of the sex, dre, or bike riding. I always emphasize that potential impact as being the one to watch for. Having said that, you can very often have such a condition and not even be aware of it. Also, a simple round of antibiotics will have little to no impact on it much of the time. Only a minority of the time is it caused by a bacterial infection. Rapid retesting is often a failure because such inflammation can take considerable time to resolve. And the, men should be told that PSAs can simply jump around significantly. I've had two spikes of significant size. I can't remember the precise number without looking it up, but I had one a few years ago that after jumping up to 7.4, dropped back to about 3.8 when I retested in about 3 or 6 months later. In the interim I had taken no antibiotics.
Posts.Title: Bike riding, DRE, & sexual activity effects on PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dshinnick 3. The biggie: I'm still not clear on the value of Active Surveillance. From what I can tell: 4. It mostly just procrastinates and delays the inevitable. Am I missing anything? If I'm "ok" with the possible side effects, and if I gotta do treatment eventually, I'd rather do it now, get it over with, and not risk #2 above. Thoughts? First of all, each case is different. Having said that, you may be unfamiliar with how common prostate cancer is in the average 59 year old guy walking down the street. Those hundred and thousands and hundreds of thousands of 59 and 60 year old men who have prostate cancer but have not had a biopsy "proving" they have it. It is very very common, yet very few of them will die from it or even need treatment. I'm guessing you aren't aware of the data. Here is some data from recent studies http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23847245 In a easier to digest format http://www.mensjournal.com/health-fi...tment-20130730 http://research.lunenfeld.ca/rss/?page=2017 Again, every case is different. If you are treated now, you will almost certainly have side effects. For most men that includes some degree of difficulty with achieving erections that are equal to their pre-treatment status. Many men have no usable erections. Others have difficulty with urinary incontinence. Do not underestimate the number of men who have side effects from the various treatments. That is why some men choose to delay treatment for 5 or 10 or 30 years...forever. Every case is different. MOST men in the world die WITH prostate cancer untreated. They do not die from the prostate cancer. Most men with prostate cancer are never even diagnosed. You have been diagnosed with prostate cancer. It is unknown if treating your prostate cancer would be of any value in extending your life even one day. What is known is that treating your prostate cancer will have a impact on your life. In most cases there will be side effects. As always, every single case is different. You easily have months, probably even years, to take the time to learn about all of this. Do not rush. You don't yet have a good picture of what you are dealing with. You need months of reading to get familiar with the subject.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe In your experiences can you recommend any type of vitamins or supplements that will help the prostate in staying healthy. I know eating right and exercise helps but is there any thing else I can do. thanks Depends on what you mean when you say "eating right"... The definition of what that means from one person to the next is HUGE... How do you define it. Example, what percent of your total calories comes from fats?
Posts.Title: What type of vitamins to use

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon I consume approx. 2200 calories per day. Of that I restrict fat to around 100g, of which 50% comes from olive oil, avocados. I never eat junk food, other than a 6" veggie sandwich from Subway on rare occasions. I eat red meat about twice a month. My meals mostly consist of fish, vegetables, whole grain bread, green tea, fruit and red wine. Other than this PC I am in great health for 67. I also power walk for 8km, 6 days a week weather permitting. Do you realize that your diet is 40.9% fat? A little olive oil as a substitute for other more dangerous fats is OK, but recently people have been given the idea that olive oil is a health food. That to use olive oil on this and that is "adding" health to ones diet, vs using it simply replacing other more dangerous fats. Meaning using olive oil instead of bacon may be better for one's health, but actually trying to add in olive oil is not like adding in a health food. I may be misinterpreting your understanding and use of "healthy fats" as it regards prostate cancer. Usually, the men getting better results from eating more "healthy" fats, are deriving it from the substitution effect... taking away the meats, cheese, dairy, etc... For such men, they are better off getting their fats from olive oil etc... Just saying that "adding" olive oil for prostate cancer and even more so for heart disease, is a idea that has become oversold and has folks almost taking extra olive oil as it were a supplement. I think getting natural fats in their own package... like avocados and walnuts... is great, but using amounts of oils never seen in nature, may more than intended. Like eating a orange or a apple, is quite different than drinking a 12 ounce glass of juice. Off hand, I don't think any diet with over 40% of the calories coming from any fats is beneficial. Seems most of those thought to be beneficial for prostate health aim for half that amount regardless of the source. However I'm always open to new proof or indication of such.

AgeInfo.Phrase: realize that your diet is 40 9% fat <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: What type of vitamins to use

Posts.Content: Well, ideally you would have been better served by having him tell you to wait a few days or a week for the PSA blood draw. If that was easy for you. Either way, your PSA would probably have been 4.0 or more. Do you know your PSA history? The doctor was not wrong to do some extensive "digging around" in the exam. That is exactly the right thing for him to do before making you get biopsy. Right now you may want to get another urologist, but then he will have to re-examine your prostate again and you'll still have to get another PSA.. This time do it prior to the exam, and if possible long enough ahead of time for the new urologist to have the results when you see him for the exam. Then, he'll probably tell you to get a biopsy. Still in the long run, better to deal with someone you feel comfortable with. Whether your PSA is 2.8 or 4.8, with the nodule, they'll tell you to get a biopsy. Or, you can just forget all this and take your chances. Odds are good you'll die from something else before prostate cancer, if you have any, gets to you. That is not a totally unreasonable approach, though some may object to such ideas.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dshinnick Jeez, I wish. Didn't put this in my signature, but I've been close to impotent for years. I can masturbate with lotion and ejaculate, but sex? No way. Bought a pump, tried it once, didn't work. Haven't given up on that. Doc said to put the impotence issue on the back burner for now. I guess the treatment is testosterone, but that can spur cancer growth. So, ah well...... I was wondering about the rest of your health, aside from the prostate cancer. Are you overweight, or have high blood pressure, with or without medication, or high cholesterol or any other heart related conditions. (especially any that you take medication for) Or do you have any blood sugar issues, like pre-diabetes or even Type 2 diabetes? All of those issues can contribute greatly to other conditions from age 50 onward. And by the way, some of those issues can have some impact on prostate cancer outcomes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon I included the olive oil into my total fats, as I stated earlier it along with avocado represents 50% of my daily fats total. I had my annual physical 3 months ago. I am 67 and my cholesterol is 1.1, my BP is 123/74, my heart rate is 67. All in all my diet is serving me well. By the way I do not take any meds with the occasional exception of Ibuprofen after 18 holes of golf B Look, your cholesterol reading is not directly connected to anything that deals with Prostate Cancer. You are citing blood pressure and heart rate. Those numbers are fine, normal, but don't give any protection from prostate cancer. As to your cholesterol being 1.1, which equals 42.5 under the American system (1.1 mmol/l = 42.53674 mg/dl) If you are speaking about the normally stated "total cholesterol", then you are one of the most unusual men on the planet. I have never heard of a man having a total cholesterol of 1.1 mmol/l You must be referring to some other "portion" of your cholesterol. HDL, or LDL http://www.onlineconversion.com/cholesterol.htm Look, your total fat intake is still 40.9% It may or may not hurt or help your outcome with prostate cancer, but I don't think anyone I've read has advocated running your fat intake up that high by adding in extra olive oil. Olive oil is not a health food. Its not horrible food, just not something you'd want to consume more and more of for the sake of health.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman What does your Urologist mean when he says Dr Kaul is a superstar? How many surgeries has he done? Does he do open or robotic? What is his record of positive margins? These are all questions you should ask. You have a right to know. Trust your doctors, but verify. Dont take anyones word for anything. Prostate Cancer is big business. The vast majority of Drs have their clients best interest at heart, but they all have their natural biases. Be your own advocate I agree, though it does appear that Dr. Kaul has been at it for some time.... doing robotic surgery http://link.springer.com/article/10....-0071-4#page-1 Including doing other surgeries with the same machine http://www.theoaklandpress.com/gener...ticular-cancer Would be interesting do know how many prostate removal surgeries he does each week with the machine.
Posts.Title: Just learned my biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Foilingfool2 Hi, I am new here and hope to get some opinions. I started getting my PSA checked 3 years ago when I turned 50. My first check was 0.3 and my DRE was normal. A year later my PSA was 0.6 and my DRE was normal. I am now 52, and just had my most recent check. My PSA is now 3.4. I did have a colonoscopy on Jan 12 and my PSA test was on Jan 28. I see my GP next week. I will likely head to the urologist as well. Very worried, as expected. I don't agree that you should be ready to get a biopsy. The most likely explanation for your significant rise in one year, is a inflammation or "itis" of some sort. Could be from a bacterial infection or it could be from nothing in particular. Unless the doctor does a DRE and feels something unusual, then I think the best advice is to wait at least 2 months and retest. You don't even need to take a antibiotic unless some test shows something. Watch out that someone doesn't give you a antibiotic and then retest in a couple weeks. Even if there was some infection, testing too soon after the antibiotic doesn't allow time for the situation to calm back down. Lots and lots... most inflammation is not caused by bacteria and will not respond to the antibiotic. Prostatitis has many causes. I've had my PSA jump up and down many times.. AS high as 7.5. My last test was back to 3.3. I would definitely retest before doing a biopsy. When you see the doctor(s)... ask them if it would be prudent to wait and retest. If they insist on a biopsy now, ask them why. BTW a infection or simple inflammation can be happening without you feeling anything. Asymptomatic, yet causing a 2.8 rise in your psa test. A recent colonoscopy could have set in motion the factors that could lead to a inflammation. That is different than the method wherein a DRE actually releases more psa from direct pressure or agitation. Let the doctors give you their best estimate of the odds of how likely the psa rise is caused by prostate cancer. Ask them what are the odds that waiting a couple months to retest would endanger you.

Posts.Content: Well, ideally you would have been better served by having him tell you to wait a few days or a week for the PSA blood draw. If that was easy for you. Either way, your PSA would probably have been 4.0 or more. Do you know your PSA history? The doctor was not wrong to do some extensive "digging around" in the exam. That is exactly the right thing for him to do before making you get biopsy. Right now you may want to get another urologist, but then he will have to re-examine your prostate again and you'll still have to get another PSA.. This time do it prior to the exam, and if possible long enough ahead of time for the new urologist to have the results when you see him for the exam. Then, he'll probably tell you to get a biopsy. Still in the long run, better to deal with someone you feel comfortable with. Whether your PSA is 2.8 or 4.8, with the nodule, they'll tell you to get a biopsy. Or, you can just forget all this and take your chances. Odds are good you'll die from something else before prostate cancer, if you have any, gets to you. That is not a totally unreasonable approach, though some may object to such ideas.

Posts.Content: Lots of issues going on. Missing from your two recent PSA tests is the time frame. How far apart were the two PSA tests? How many days was the weekend sex before the 2nd PSA test. Also, very important, what is your past history of PSA tests. Prior years, dates and PSA values in those prior years. I would think extensive sex without ejaculation might very well have a impact. So we really need a more precise timeline and your PSA history over the past years. PSA values can bounce all over the place. More in some people than others. BTW, there is lots of types of "sex". Which could also make a difference. I can think of some acts between consenting adults that could exacerbate the impact. Your enlarged prostate would also add to the values. Then you have the Androgel. How long have you been taking that? That can lead to a enlarged prostate, can't it? Regarding that 40% chance. Seems high from some sites I see. One place I see 29% chance. http://www.lef.org/protocols/cancer/..._cancer_07.htm There may be many other probability tables. Anyway, give us your PSA history.

HDL, or LDL http://www.onlineconversion.com/cholesterol.htm Look, your total fat intake is still 40.9% It may or may not hurt or help your outcome with prostate cancer, but I don't think anyone I've read has advocated running your fat intake up that high by adding in extra olive oil. Olive oil is not a health food. Its not horrible food, just not something you'd want to consume more and more of for the sake of health.

Posts.Title: What type of vitamins to use

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Is this Forum at all informative? There only appears to be a handful of new initial posts in the last 12 months?!?! Any suggestions for for other Forums that have better engagement? TY Michael, it appears you are looking at only the first 8 or so "stickies".... Those stay the same and have few new posts as mostly they are only read. If that is not the problem, then I'm not sure what you are talking about. If you're still not satisfied, by all means, simply Google--- prostate cancer forums discussion --- start with the first ten or so.
Posts.Title: Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter Thanks for the article. I learned something new today: I never thought anyone diagnosed with cancer would not be diligently tracking their disease to make sure they stayed low risks. Anyway, 72% is an impressive number for a 13 years follow-up. However, looked like the 27% who "disappeared" were included in the no treatments required group so we really don't know what the real number was. . We have to wait until the study is formally published in a journal. The we can see how the 27% were counted , or possibly left out of the percentages we see that did not need treatment. I'm sure it will be in the news again when it is published formally. As to those who don't diligently track their disease, I find 27% to be about as expected. I doubt I would follow the frequency protocol that most AS programs prescribe. Here is UCSF's Active Surveillance Protocol at UCSF PSA Every 3 to 4 months Prostate ultrasound Every 6 to 9 months Prostate biopsy After 1 year * *If a patient's initial biopsy was performed outside of UCSF, an additional biopsy performed at UCSF may be recommended within a few months. Biopsies then may be performed every one to two years depending on other clinical findings. I'd be more inclined to the 2 year standard... whereas many programs have 1 year as their standard. Heck, before the diagnosis, look how long guys are going without biopsies... even though we know a huge percentage of them have existing, but undiscovered, Gleason 6 Only difference in those on AS and those undiagnosed is a lucky needle strike vs 12 misses.

Posts.Title: Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I made an appt with surgeon at MSKCC, they told me no agenda, if surgery is not my best option, then he will tell me. But he can't see me until Mid Dec. EVERY DAY THAT GOES BY I AM AFRAID I AM AT MORE RISK OF ESCAPING THE CAPSULE. Trying to see a RO at MSKCC, wont even give me an appt until they get the reports (easy) scans (easy), slides (still at Hopkins) and a TE Parametric MRI which they say i ccant have until end December because it needs to be 7-8 weeks after biopsy. More time lost. And how is it that i get to see two rock star surgeons who have done over 5000 robotic surgeries each, within days, but i cant see anyone at MSKCC for over a month? How does that work? I'm so confused, scared and depressed. Logically i know, i have time. But still. Its understandable how confuse and depressed you are. You've been through quite a scary episode. However you have one of the foremost experts in the nation telling you to relax a bit "I actually got to speak to Dr Epstein, and he was very emphatic that it was a G6 and that I had months to decide on how to proceed. " You've got to trust someone... I'd trust him. As such, getting that December appointment at MSKCC seems quite reasonable and not at all risky to wait. The news about your downgrade is really amazing.
Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Foilingfool2 Hi, I am new here and hope to get some opinions. I started getting my PSA checked 3 years ago when I turned 50. My first check was 0.3 and my DRE was normal. A year later my PSA was 0.6 and my DRE was normal. I am now 52, and just had my most recent check. My PSA is now 3.4. I did have a colonoscopy on Jan 12 and my PSA test was on Jan 28. I see my GP next week. I will likely head to the urologist as well. Very worried, as expected. I don't agree that you should be ready to get a biopsy. The most likely explanation for your significant rise in one year, is a inflammation or "itis" of some sort. Could be from a bacterial infection or it could be from nothing in particular. Unless the doctor does a DRE and feels something unusual, then I think the best advice is to wait at least 2 months and retest. You don't even need to take a antibiotic unless some test shows something. Watch out that someone doesn't give you a antibiotic and then retest in a couple weeks. Even if there was some infection, testing too soon after the antibiotic doesn't allow time for the situation to calm back down. Lots and lots... most inflammation is not caused by bacteria and will not respond to the antibiotic. Prostatitis has many causes. I've had my PSA jump up and down many times.. AS high as 7.5. My last test was back to 3.3. I would definitely retest before doing a biopsy. When you see the doctor(s)... ask them if it would be prudent to wait and retest. If they insist on a biopsy now, ask them why. BTW a infection or simple inflammation can be happening without you feeling anything. Asymptomatic, yet causing a 2.8 rise in your psa test. A recent colonoscopy could have set in motion the factors that could lead to a inflammation. That is different than the method wherein a DRE actually releases more psa from direct pressure or agitation. Let the doctors give you their best estimate of the odds of how likely the psa rise is caused by prostate cancer. Ask them what are the odds that waiting a couple months to retest would endanger you.
