<Z> <Z> I am now 52  and just had my most

Posts.Title: Jump in PSA from 0.6 to 3.4 have questions

Posts.Content: Here is a interesting study on longer term AS patients. http://www.webmd.com/prostate-cancer...iting-approach Interesting which title the article chooses to run so as to emphasize one part of the outcome. Both positive and negative news. Overall, for those who stick with it "Researchers found that after 13 years, about 28 percent of all patients required treatment because their prostate cancer flared up. Nearly all the men were cured of their prostate cancer, with an overall group survival rate of 94 percent." Which means that about 72% didn't require treatment (unsure if that includes the 27% who didn't follow up) I'll have to wait until I find the actual full study.
Posts.Title: Interesting follow-up study on AS patients

Posts.Content: Lots of issues going on. Missing from your two recent PSA tests is the time frame. How far apart were the two PSA tests? How many days was the weekend sex before the 2nd PSA test. Also, very important, what is your past history of PSA tests. Prior years, dates and PSA values in those prior years. I would think extensive sex without ejaculation might very well have a impact. So we really need a more precise timeline and your PSA history over the past years. PSA values can bounce all over the place. More in some people than others. BTW, there is lots of types of "sex". Which could also make a difference. I can think of some acts between consenting adults that could exacerbate the impact. Your enlarged prostate would also add to the values. Then you have the Androgel. How long have you been taking that? That can lead to a enlarged prostate, can't it? Regarding that 40% chance. Seems high from some sites I see. One place I see 29% chance. http://www.lef.org/protocols/cancer/..._cancer_07.htm There may be many other probability tables. Anyway, give us your PSA history.
Posts.Title: Elevated PSA and biopsy recommended - Q on Causes of elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Well, again, lots of stuff going on in your situation. Just the Androgel alone would seem to be enough to kick you up over 4.0. Seems you were on it for 90 or more days when the test was taken. I don't know the dose except that isn't the 1.63% the new higher concentration. I see studies and I also see anecdotal accounts of raised PSA values. Again, they are reporting the "average" rise, but that can be made up of individuals where the effect is much greater. Some studies indicate a added 0.26 to your values, but that is average. Some posts suggest much larger jumps can take place Look down in the following thread for some stories http://forums.webmd.com/3/mens-healt...ty/forum/673/9 However some of those are from using pellets instead of creams and such Also, your most recent sex weekend wasn't just a single episode, but seems to have extended for 2 or 3 days. All that without a ejaculation would seem to... well, might do anything, perhaps even more than a single ejaculation after short sex. I'd probably be inclined to allow the Androgel to leave the system and for everything else to get back to a normal baseline, then retest. You'll have to do more investigation into how long the effects of Androgel take to #1, leave the system, and #2, result in a lowered PSA value. It could be that after stopping it still takes some time for everything to get back to a true state. Then avoid all the other bike riding and sex for several days, 3 to 5 and then retest. Might be two or more months from now, I don't know. You may well end up only back at 4.0 or 3.80 like in 2012, or you could stick at 4.2 or even higher. PSA readings jump around all the time. I've had 8 tests since 2008 and the readings have gone from 2.6 to 7.3 The test following the 7.3 was 4.1, then a year later 3.6, a year later 5.5, then 3 months later 3.8. At one point during that bouncing around I had a biopsy that showed nothing wrong (in the samples taken, which doesn't mean there isn't something going on in the other 98% of the prostate. I just assume there are small groups of Gleason 6 cells, if one actually sampled every cell in the prostate, but that is true of most men age 60 if you sliced and diced up their entire prostates, such as at autopsy) So I'm now more relaxed when my PSA jumps up. BTW, my jumping around followed no obvious causation. You can have asymptomatic inflammations, non-bacterial in nature, that can boost PSA values a significant amount. As indicated, a course of antibiotics will not affect these in most cases. My true base value is probably about 3.5 to 3.8 and has been there for about 4 years. My age range during those tests was 59-63 Anyway, given my history and if I was you, I'd probably test again before doing the biopsy, if for no other reason to get a true picture of your PSA progression, even if you end up doing a biopsy in 3 or 4 months. Personally I'd avoid taking Androgel, but I do know there is much controversy on that subject (which I have not followed). Oh, also, this all assumes there was nothing unusual in your DRE. Of course, I'm not a professional and your urologist may have other information you have not mentioned. PS, of minor interest, a calculator http://www.prostate-cancer-risk-calculator.com/ Your numbers with a free-psa at 19% would give a 31.9% My numbers in 2009 gave a 34.4% and my current numbers give a 30.1% I wouldn't place too much in that calculator, but its fun to play with it.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA and biopsy recommended - Q on Causes of elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman What does your Urologist mean when he says Dr Kaul is a superstar? How many surgeries has he done? Does he do open or robotic? What is his record of positive margins? These are all questions you should ask. You have a right to know. Trust your doctors, but verify. Dont take anyones word for anything. Prostate Cancer is big business. The vast majority of Drs have their clients best interest at heart, but they all have their natural biases. Be your own advocate I agree, though it does appear that Dr. Kaul has been at it for some time.... doing robotic surgery http://link.springer.com/article/10....-0071-4#page-1 Including doing other surgeries with the same machine http://www.theoaklandpress.com/gener...ticular-cancer Would be interesting do know how many prostate removal surgeries he does each week with the machine.
Posts.Title: Just learned my biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by habhammer Most of you know my situation and since I have been diagnosed with low grade PC I have decided to seek a second opinion. I have an appointment 7-1-15 with a urologist ! From a earlier post of yours "I was finally found to have PCA and was told 2 days ago 06-18-15." You were diagnosed only 12 days ago, and are getting a 2nd opinion less than 2 weeks later. By all means----you should make NO decisions on any possible "treatment" for 3 to 6 months. Allow time for your thinking and awareness to develop on the subject. Any doctor who is telling you that you need to decide sooner is improperly advising you. No reason you can't do AS for a while. See what happens. Very little risk in doing so, even if you eventually decide you need to be treated later. Don't let them stampede you into a decision, when even they don't know what is really going on in your prostate. --Oh, just realized I don't know the percentage involvement in that one positive core. Might make a difference if it was 25% or 90%.. etc
Posts.Title: second opinion visit - what can i expect?

Posts.Content: I don't know about your pains, but your psa is fine regarding prostate cancer. On that issue, simply re-test your psa in one year. If you do test after test of the other types, if you're not careful, some doctor is going to find something you don't want to find. I doubt much would have shown up on your father prior to age 60... Who knows, by the time you reach that age, treatments will be far better should you need one.

AgeInfo.Phrase: your father prior to age 60    Who knows  by the time

Posts.Title: Strange Psa and prostate problems

Posts.Content: I'm a big supporter of "watchful waiting"... and perhaps there are details about the genetic tests you were given.... and the background of your current urologist. But short of there being something you've not told us, I'd be finding and seeing another well respected urologist who specializes in prostate cancer. Make sure he will have all your prior tests, biopsy, and psa data. I'm also very skeptical of the "herbs" angle. Could you tell us the name and "dose" of the herb(s) you are taking... as well as any study or details suggesting they work. I'd seek that second opinion sooner rather than later.
Posts.Title: Chinese herbs

Posts.Content: I think your position is reasonable. However, prior to your next psa draw, you need to refrain from anything and everything that might bump it up... including sex of any type. By the way, you didn't tell the doctor you ejaculate "every day" did you? Oh yes, and get a new urologist. I would seem you two don't get along and that is not likely to improve. Personally I wouldn't want any doctor who thinks I'm weird, giving me a DRE.
Posts.Title: I refused the biopsy. Urologist not happy and arrogant...

Posts.Content: Well, your doubling time seems to be about 5 years. Which would put you up to a PSA of 17 by age 65 and 34 by age 70 if it continues climbing. Nice to see you aren't in a instant panic. You really should get a second opinion from a second doctor regarding your treatment options. I assume you "Dr" is a urologist? Certainly isn't the case where your doctors jumped the gun on the needle biopsy procedure. You didn't mention what percent of each sample was involved, such as 10% or 30% or 60%, especially on the 3+4 sample. I don't think you'll get too many folks suggesting active surveillance unless your 3+4 turns out to be a 3+3 if you get a second opinion, AND your percentage on all samples is very low. Take your time, investigate all options and understand the true outcomes, not just the "good story" that some doctors give regarding their data on side effects. Of course you could do nothing and have excellent odds you'd still be alive at age 70 or 75, but these days most guys your age will live a fair bit longer than that unless you have some other serious medical problems. You seem to be fairly well read on the basics. Learn a whole lot more in the coming months and then make your choice. Just about every choice has its recommendations.

65 and 34 by age 70 if it continues climbing <Z>

Posts.Title: Do I really need treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Firemedic54 . I have scheduled my surgery for Sept. 27. Am I jumping the gun by doing it so fast? I am scared to death and want this done and over with, per my Dr. he has done 1000's of surgeries and he says not to worry, he is confident that I will be fine. Any advice is appreciated. That is a bit of a rush.. barely time for for the biopsy procedure to have healed. Take a bit of a breath. Get a second opinion. Perhaps have a second reading of the slides. That could influence your options. Doesn't sound like a extra month or two is gonna make any difference. You have only one chance to get it right. Most of all be sure you know what the doctor means when he says he has done 1,000's of surgeries. There are all types of surgeries...even within the urology profession. I'm assuming he is planning on a robotic surgery specifically to remove the prostate. You would want to know how many of those he has done and how many he does each month. Frequency keeps one's skill sharp. Sometimes doctors are counting all the other types of prostate removal they have done before switching over to the use of the robot. Sounds like he has done a adequate amount, but I'd want a few more details. Which version of the Da Vinci are they using. I believe there have been improvements and upgrades. Someone here may know what to look for.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed today, What do the number mean?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon There are few discussions about Hormone shots. Just wondering at what point people get them and how successful they are. Just a positive note about hormone therapy after radiation. My father at age 63 back in 1973,1974 was diagnosed with prostate cancer. There was no Gleason scoring system in place back then. Nor was there a PSA test at that time. Anyway, he was told it was no longer operable and that his only choice was external beam radiation. So he underwent 25 or more days of radiation. Either right after, or within a year or two he was placed on a drug called Diethylstilbestrol (DES) at a low dosage, 1 mg daily. He continued to take that hormone drug for about the next 20 years until I took him off it because of his legs swelling in his later 80s. Now, I don't know if the initial radiation killed all the cancer because there was no psa test until years later. But by that time he started getting 0.1 type results and they never changed. He died at age 88 of unrelated medical problems (mostly Alzheimers). So, did the DES keep the prostate cancer from returning or was it all killed by radiation. I don't know, but it is a positive story about the use of radiation and hormonal therapy. He outlived his prostate cancer for 25 years. DES is very cheap. It is no longer used much because in earlier larger doses it was thought to possibly cause some blood clots or such. My father took it for over 20 years with some side effects but no blood clots. He lived on the beach in Hawaii into his 80's So, stay positive about your future even though you have had some disappointments thus far.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed today, What do the number mean?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PaulG Thought I'd introduce myself. I'm 53 and was diagnosed with prostate cancer just five days ago, so I'm just starting to learn about all this. (I'm reading the Dr. Walsh book now.) I will meet with my urologist again in two weeks to discuss treatment options in more detail, and I am seeing a different urologist for a second opinion soon after that. (Also, awaiting lab results on whether PTEN is absent.) My initial reaction is that prostatectomy seems best, given my age and life expectancy (dad lived to 87). But I'm keeping an open mind, and I'd welcome any suggestions. You are only five days into this. It is hard to emphasize enough the need for you to slow down as you slowly learn about this.. There is absolutely no reason to even think about coming to a decision in less than 3 months. Your level of comfort with the information you learn will impact your initial thoughts. What sounds fearful in the beginning will give way to far less urgency or need to act by undergoing early treatment. In a case with the details your's seems to have, the odds are that a decision made 12 months from now would have the same outcome as a decision made in 1 month. See your doctor, but be wary if he seems to be indicating treatment any time soon. Ask him about having a second reading of your biopsy samples by a independent expert. (see the thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...ologist-Report I see no reason why you won't live longer than your father. If you speak to your urologist about issues relating to outcomes... incontinence and especially erectile dysfunction, be absolutely certain you understand what his definition is. More often than not, the doctor's definition of usable erection is far different than that held by the patient. The majority of men who undergo surgery do not return to prior sexual function as they understand it. Lastly, there is value in hanging onto your prostate as long as possible. Don't let fear rush you into a hasty decision.

life expectancy  dad lived to 87 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: New guy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Now What? Why would we need a new urologist? His recommendation was surgery but supported us in watchful waiting upon our initiative. Other answers: my hubby is 57 years old, his dad is 90 and his PC is gone due to radiation last year. He has lived with it for many years and is healthy now. The (Chinese) herbs my husband is taking: HM Protect from Numedica, DIM Enhanced from Douglas laboratories, Rabdosia Prostate Formula, Arctic Ruby Oil (500 mg Calanus Oil). His biopsy showed a minimal amount of cancer on one core. He has a new appointment scheduled with the urologist next month and then we will go from there. I think we will be going the Western medicine route. This urologist works with robotic surgery but we need to get more info from him regarding his numbers of surgeries etc. He is veyry passionate about his work and the visits are good experiences. Everyone's initial response was based on the very limited information you initially gave us. We still have limited information about the current status and biopsy... as well as the precise psa history. It is possible the 16 and 22 psa readings are a spike due to a inflammation.. but we don't know what the result was the prior year. I looked at those herbs. Did the doctor actually tell you to get all of those? Or is that just part of your attempt to lower the psa the "natural" way? Lots of questions which I'm sure you can answer such that we may modify our "get a new doctor" recommendation. You might also see a urologist who is more pro-radiation. Given that it worked so well with his father. You might look into brachythreapy (seeds), except I think they have a psa 10 cut off. If your actual psa is steady up at 15+, then you might not qualify.

This urologist works with robotic surgery but we need to get more info from him regarding his numbers of surgeries etc. He is veyry passionate about his work and the visits are good experiences. Everyone's initial response was based on the very limited information you initially gave us. We still have limited information about the current status and biopsy... as well as the precise psa history. It is possible the 16 and 22 psa readings are a spike due to a inflammation.. but we don't know what the result was the prior year. I looked at those herbs. Did the doctor actually tell you to get all of those? Or is that just part of your attempt to lower the psa the "natural" way? Lots of questions which I'm sure you can answer such that we may modify our "get a new doctor" recommendation. You might also see a urologist who is more pro-radiation. Given that it worked so well with his father. You might look into brachythreapy (seeds), except I think they have a psa 10 cut off. If your actual psa is steady up at 15+, then you might not qualify.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman and I came up with a result that of all the tissue taken, 6.6% of the total tissue was cancerous. So my question is, aside from the fact that I am being OCD and crazy, is this calculation meaningful? No Originally Posted by Pratoman I have been so vigilant, with regular testing over the last 5 years, a biopsy two years ago that was negative except for one core of high grade PIN, and PSA tests every six months for the last two years, and I am fearful that despite the care I took, I got it late, not early enough for full cure. But for that one core at 80%, you'd be looking at two Gleason 6 insignificant cores, from which many would opt for AS. Thus, you are just over the edge from possibly doing no treatment...to doing treatment. You are fairly early as these things go. Right now you are looking good. You discovered this early and everything appears to be in slow motion. Heck, you could probably wait a year or two and still not be too late. (I'm not advising that) Steady there.
Posts.Title: Tumor Load

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman He told me to stop the Cialis immediately, and he put me on a beta blocker, wants me back a week from Monday (i'm going away on vacation next week). He said, depending on what happens between now and then, he will possibly send me for a CT Angiogram to look for blockages. Just remember, if they find a blockage on a CT Angiogram and want you to come in shortly thereafter for a regular Angiogram, that you be very clear on not just automatically giving them permission to place a stent into a suspect artery "just because they're already in there". Huge numbers of unnecessary stents are placed in patients when there is no proof that they prevent heart attacks or deaths. The main reason for preventive stents is to alleviate angina symptoms, which you don't appear to have. Let us know the results should you do the CT Angiogram.

Posts.Content: I'm a big supporter of "watchful waiting"... and perhaps there are details about the genetic tests you were given.... and the background of your current urologist. But short of there being something you've not told us, I'd be finding and seeing another well respected urologist who specializes in prostate cancer. Make sure he will have all your prior tests, biopsy, and psa data. I'm also very skeptical of the "herbs" angle. Could you tell us the name and "dose" of the herb(s) you are taking... as well as any study or details suggesting they work. I'd seek that second opinion sooner rather than later.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tomseeley I'm totally new here. No clue at all what to expect or what to do. My PCP told me my PSA has risen suddenly, from 4-something to 7-something in 3 months. Why was your psa retested only 3 months after the 4-something? What was your psa history prior to the last two tests. Dates, psa result, .... the list including the last two. You want to make sure your jump up isn't just a blip unrelated to anything other than perhaps a mild inflammation of the prostate. Oh, in addition to your entire psa history, you might include your age. If your psa went from 4 to 7 in just three months, that sudden jump isn't likely to be caused by prostate cancer which is slow growing.

Posts.Content: Sam, Good that the 3+4 is now 3+3. However, its a little hard to see from your Sept 3rd, 16 core biopsy, but it appears that 8 of the 16 samples were positive. Spread all over the place and ranging from 5% to 40% but with most of them being 20% or below. I don't think there is any need to rush, but I don't think you fall under any of the normal criteria for AS. Usually they limit AS criteria to 2 or 3 positive cores. I'm a big fan of AS, but with 8 positive cores and your age at 52, that may be taking more than a normal chance. You'd do well for 10 years, but with 35+ years to live I don't know that I would wait too long. Brachy seems like good choice if you get a experienced doctor and team at a well respected center where they do "lots" of these procedures every week. You don't need a center or doctor who only does 1 or 2 a month. PS, what was your prior PSA history before the 2.29 and 3.26, and the prior dates? If any tests were done before those two recent ones.

Posts.Title: Gleason downgraded - AS now a good option?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter The interesting finding to me was that the Japanese men had more advanced and aggressive prostate cancers compared to the Russians. Yet current world prostate cancer statistics did not support that. Well, I hope I can see the actual study instead of only the abstract. The abstract said " When adjusted for age and prostate weight, ASI men still had a greater probability of having GS 7 or greater PCa " But the world prostate cancer statistics you refer to only include diagnosed cases and/or death rates from PCa, potentially leaving out a large number of the men in this study who, but for death from other causes, might never be diagnosed or have died from prostate cancer. I don't know the details, but screening for PCa in Japan is far lower. Thus naturally you'll have much lower incidence of PCa being reported. It may be that Russian and Japanese rates of screening are roughly comparable. Rates of new diagnosed cases per 100,000 (back in 2002) were similar in both Russia and Japan. http://www.gapminder.org/world/#$majorMode=chart$is;shi=t;ly=2003;lb=f;il=t;fs=11 ;al=30;stl=t;st=t;nsl=t;se=t$wst;tts=C$ts;sp=6;ti= 2002$zpv;v=0$inc_x;mmid=XCOORDS;iid=phAwcNAVuyj1ji MAkmq1iMg;by=ind$inc_y;mmid=YCOORDS;iid=phAwcNAVuy j3qX39HWaQjEg;by=ind$inc_s;uniValue=8.21;iid=phAwc NAVuyj2vXUZJKI0XHA;by=ind$inc_c;uniValue=255;gid=C ATID0;by=grp$map_x;scale=log;dataMin=377;dataMax=7 5860$map_y;scale=lin;dataMin=-2.3805;dataMax=135$map_s;sma=49;smi=2.65$cd;bd=0$i nds=i110_t002002,,,,;i184_t002002,,,, And in this chart, you can also compare. http://cebp.aacrjournals.org/content...3/F3.large.jpg Interesting. Lots of factors involved. I'd like to see the entire study with the details. It may be that genetics or especially the lifestyle of Japanese men forestalls their PCa from advancing to the point of obvious symptoms (diagnosis) or death. Gleason 6's and 7's may not advance so rapidly in those who have lived and eaten differently for their entire life. Of question is whether Western men, changing their diets after age 50, or after diagnosis will make a significant change in progression. I've completely altered my diet for over 7 years now but have no great faith it will do much more than perhaps delay my genetics. Thus far, no positive biopsy, but PSA still poking along at 3.5 to 3.8 (with some worrying leaps up here and there). That is why I watch and wonder about these types of reports. How come Japanese men can have considerable rates of PCa ongoing, yet have a mortality rate half of ours.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PaulG Thought I'd introduce myself. I'm 53 and was diagnosed with prostate cancer just five days ago, so I'm just starting to learn about all this. (I'm reading the Dr. Walsh book now.) I will meet with my urologist again in two weeks to discuss treatment options in more detail, and I am seeing a different urologist for a second opinion soon after that. (Also, awaiting lab results on whether PTEN is absent.) My initial reaction is that prostatectomy seems best, given my age and life expectancy (dad lived to 87). But I'm keeping an open mind, and I'd welcome any suggestions. You are only five days into this. It is hard to emphasize enough the need for you to slow down as you slowly learn about this.. There is absolutely no reason to even think about coming to a decision in less than 3 months. Your level of comfort with the information you learn will impact your initial thoughts. What sounds fearful in the beginning will give way to far less urgency or need to act by undergoing early treatment. In a case with the details your's seems to have, the odds are that a decision made 12 months from now would have the same outcome as a decision made in 1 month. See your doctor, but be wary if he seems to be indicating treatment any time soon. Ask him about having a second reading of your biopsy samples by a independent expert. (see the thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...ologist-Report I see no reason why you won't live longer than your father. If you speak to your urologist about issues relating to outcomes... incontinence and especially erectile dysfunction, be absolutely certain you understand what his definition is. More often than not, the doctor's definition of usable erection is far different than that held by the patient. The majority of men who undergo surgery do not return to prior sexual function as they understand it. Lastly, there is value in hanging onto your prostate as long as possible. Don't let fear rush you into a hasty decision.

Posts.Title: New guy

Posts.Content: The study, published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute, involved posthumous examinations of 320 men in from Russia and Japan between 2008 and 2011. None of the men had been diagnosed with prostate cancer before their deaths. http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/conte...f-edbdd83b1ae6 Only a abstract for free.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mitchden Is there a defined protocol for repeating a biopsy? The original pathologist said 1 core was cancerous with a Gleason 7 (3+4). My urologist says the protocol is to wait 6 weeks to 3 months after the original biopsy. I was hoping to wait a year. Six weeks.... yikes! Hmmm.... I don' know what the protocol is... but even for a simple repeat of the PSA test, 6 weeks would seem to be very rapid. You might ask him or the office where you can read up on that "protocol"... Or perhaps that is HIS protocol. I can't give you a answer, but anyone suggesting a brief 6 weeks sounds very unusual unless he has a study to show the value of such a rapid re-biopsy. I really don't know the answer as to what is appropriate. But I can't imagine any study showing 6 weeks or 3 months to be superior to 6 months or 1 year+. Keep us informed if you find a site giving the current protocol.
Posts.Title: Repeat Biopsy Protocol

DoctorRecommended.Sample: Perhaps another doctor would suggest doing only the radiation without surgery. I don't know....My urologist recommended prostatectomy or radiation. I want it out....As is often the case, surgeons recommend surgery and may not suggest a second reading of your biopsy samples. Strange things have happened and been reported here from those who obtain a second reading of samples....John Hopkins etc. Have you seen anyone who specializes in radiation? It would seem almost 100% certain that a doctor who has done over 2,000 surgeries will suggest you do surgery....The doctor doing the surgery also advised my father to do radiation after he has healed from surgery because of the aggressiveness. . Oh this fact about being 1 year on hormone therapy makes this case different....It would seem almost 100% certain that a doctor who has done over 2,000 surgeries will suggest you do surgery. BTW, how many of the 2,000 surgeries were robotic?...I was making appointments for surgery and fortunately my wife told her oncologist about my diagnosis and he insisted I get a 2nd opinion from a prostate oncologist that he recommended before making any treatment decisions. It was the best move I ever made....My uro has done hundreds of open prostatectomies and recommended surgery, although he took a couple of hours to explain all of my options to me and did not push anything. He said that I had some time and that I should carefully weigh my options....The 13th biopsy at UCI showed 2 cores out of 25 positive, Gleason 6 less than 5%. The urologist recommended surgery and was certain that the cancer was contained....I'll bet out there, 90% of men would have just taken the first reading as fact.. and their urologist would not have recommended a second opinion. Then most would have been scheduled for treatment...surgery....Again, I hope he is getting the opinion of more than one doctor. Perhaps another doctor would suggest doing only the radiation without surgery....The urologist recommended surgery and was certain that the cancer was contained. I was making appointments for surgery and fortunately my wife told her oncologist about my diagnosis and he insisted I get a 2nd opinion from a prostate oncologist that he recommended before making any treatment decisions....I took the news like a champ, but slowly unraveled over the next few days. My uro has done hundreds of open prostatectomies and recommended surgery, although he took a couple of hours to explain all of my options to me and did not push anything....24 cores done, only one confirmed PC, the others showed atypical cells. My urologist recommended prostatectomy or radiation....I live in the EastBay and if I were not a Kaiser member, I'd probably head to UCSF. Keep asking around and I'm sure there are some top surgeons that some will suggest.. (if surgery is your choice)...The vast majority of Drs have their clients best interest at heart, but they all have their natural biases. Be your own advocate I agree, though it does appear that Dr. Kaul has been at it for some time.... doing robotic surgery http://link.springer.com/article/10....-0071-4#page-1 Including doing other surgeries with the same machine http://www.theoaklandpress.com/gener...ticular-cancer Would be interesting do know how many prostate removal surgeries he does each week with the machine....Given that you have 5% + 5% + 10% in your three samples....OUT OF 16, not 12, you'd seem to fit their criteria if the 3+4 became a 3+3 Give yourself considerable time to get a second opinion and at the same time start reading as much as you can about AS I assume you've only been dwelling on this for the past 6 weeks. As is often the case, surgeons recommend surgery and may not suggest a second reading of your biopsy samples....Originally Posted by dmm1987 My father has been on hormone therapy for about 1 year and his PSA is now a 0. I think at one point he mentioned his PSA was an 8 when he started the hormone therapy. The doctor doing the surgery also advised my father to do radiation after he has healed from surgery because of the aggressiveness. ....
